# PLM proudly announces its newly-elected University President

Written by Calvin Agustin • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 30 October 23

The Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) declared Atty. Domingo Reyes, Jr.
as the new University President through a post on the PLM Facebook Page, Oct.
27.

Among his achievements were having earned his Doctor of Philosophy in Higher
Education Management with the Highest Academic Distinction from Centro Escolar
University; his Master of Laws from PLM, and having served as De La Salle -
College of St. Benilde’s special assistant to the Chancellor and special
assistant to the Vice Chancellor for Academics.

“Atty. Reyes is poised to lead PLM to new heights in the years to come with
his impressive background and a commitment to excellence in higher education,”
PLM stated in its post.

Along with Atty. Reyes’ appointed as the President of the PLM, Atty. Edward
Serapio was appointed as the new Chairperson of the PLM Board of Regents.

Previously, the City Council of Manila appointed Atty. Reyes together with
Atty. Serapio, Dr. Joseph Berlin P. Juanzon, and Dr. Neri S. Pescadera as
members of PLM’s Board of Regents. The said appointment was confirmed by the
City Council through Manila Vice Mayor Yul Servo-Nieto during its regular
session on Oct. 24.

Together with incumbent board members Wilma Galvante and Rita Riddle, the
University is looking forward to fostering “a diverse and inclusive campus
environment that embraces the full spectrum of human potential.”

Atty. Reyes is set to assume his post as the PLM President on Oct. 31, and the
University extends its warmest welcome to the new members of the PLM
community.

# MGA LARAWAN | PUV Modernization Program Protest - Manila

Written and Photos by Dean Joseph Palapar | 30 December 23

Sa iginanap na tigil-pasada kahapon, Disyembre 29, pinangunahan ng PISTON at
Manibela ang kilos-protesta upang itambol ang panawagan sa pagtutol sa Public
Utility Vehicle Modernization Program (PUVMP) at sa napipintong deadline ng
franchise consolidation bukas, ika-31 ng Disyembre.

Mula University Avenue ay nagsagawa ng malawakang jeepney caravan ang mga
tsuper at operator. Kasabay ng pagpuno ng kalsada ng daan-daang jeepney units
ay ang pagsigaw at pagbusina ng iba't ibang miyembro ng sektor ng lipunan at
organisasyon, mga komyuter, at kapwa manggagawa habang sila'y nagmamartsa sa
kahabaan ng España patungong Mendiola kung saan pormal na iginanap ang
programa.

Giit ng mga tsuper at operator, hindi makatarungan ang ipinapatupad na PUVMP
ng pamahalaan. Bunsod ng pagpapatupad ng panukala ang nagbabadyang krisis sa
transportasyon at ekonomiya na maaaring kaharapin ng bansa sa susunod na taon.
Ang kanilang nagkakaisang panawagan ay ang pagkakaroon ng mas nakabubuhay at
maka-masang transisyon sa 'modernization' ng mga jeepney units.

# SONA 2023 HIGHLIGHTS | Bagong Pilipinas: Marcos highlights accomplishments after a year as Chief of State

Written by Calvin Agustin, Rinoa Angeline Dela Torre, & Zarena Hermogeno • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 30 July 23

The President of the Republic of the Philippines Ferdinand “Bongbong” Marcos
Jr. delivered his second State of the Nation Address (SONA) in the Batasang
Pambansa, July 24.

Marcos’ speech focused on the accomplishments he attained during the first
year of his presidency, as well as his future plans for the country and the
people in terms of economic recovery, agriculture and livelihood,
infrastructures, education, healthcare, employment digitalization, climate
change, and law enforcement.

**_Economic Recovery_**

Inflation, being the biggest problem faced by the country so far, has affected
not only the Philippines but the world as well. Marcos said that the increase
in the price of most goods and services has been significantly felt by
everyone in the past few months. With the help of local economists, Marcos was
able to draft policies that shall serve as the foundation of the Philippine
economy for the years to come.

The Philippine economy also recorded a 7.6 percent growth in 2022 – the
highest growth rate in 46 years. With this, the Philippines is still
considered as one of the fastest-growing economies in the Asian region and in
the world.

The country’s financial system was said to remain strong and stable, as the
inflation rate continues to make progress. From an 8.7 percent inflation rate
back in January, the numbers plummeted to 5.4 percent in June, which shows the
government’s efforts in transforming the Philippine economy through
stabilizing prices of all necessary commodities.

For this year, 70 percent of the national budget is allocated to economic and
social services while investments in infrastructures and in the capacity of
the people through food, education, health, jobs, and social security remain
as the government’s top priority.

Overall, the administration is giving its full efforts to boost local
production through expanding various industries, putting up vital
infrastructures to increase the flow of products and services. Moreover, they
are focused on the people’s skill-building to improve their quality of life,
which is stipulated in the Philippine Development Plan.

**_Agriculture and Livelihood_**

In the first three months of the year, the agricultural sector increased to
2.2 percent. While in the past few months, people have seen a decrease in the
price of products and services from different sectors which proved that the
government can lower the price of basic goods.

The Kadiwa Store, which ought to directly connect farmers and consumers, has
been vital in stabilizing the agricultural sector. With more than 7,000 Kadiwa
Stores nationwide, it was able to generate 700,000 pesos in sales, provide
food to 1.8 million families, and jobs to more than 3,000 members of different
cooperatives and organizations. Because of such results, the administration
aims to build more Kadiwa Stores nationwide, with help from local government
units (LGUs) and the agricultural sector.

**_Agriculture and Livelihood_**

In the first three months of the year, the agricultural sector increased to
2.2 percent. While in the past few months, people have seen a decrease in the
price of products and services from different sectors which proved that the
government can lower the price of basic goods.

The Kadiwa Store, which ought to directly connect farmers and consumers, has
been vital in stabilizing the agricultural sector. With more than 7,000 Kadiwa
Stores nationwide, it was able to generate 700,000 pesos in sales, provide
food to 1.8 million families, and jobs to more than 3,000 members of different
cooperatives and organizations. Because of such results, the administration
aims to build more Kadiwa Stores nationwide, with help from local government
units (LGUs) and the agricultural sector.

Marcos mentioned that the Fisheries Code must be reviewed again to incorporate
and strengthen the science-based analysis and determination of fishing areas
to protect the interests of local fisherfolk and the aquatic resources. He
then sought further support from the Congress to amend the code in order to
guarantee sustainable development for the fisheries sector.

To help the local farmers, the Department of Agriculture introduced new
technology and practices such as bio-fertilizers to improve harvest at less
cost. In addition to this, more than 28,000 agricultural machineries and 5.1
million seeds are to be sown on almost 10,000 hectares of land across the
country. The national government has also built agricultural infrastructures
such as farm-to-market roads, 4,000 fabrication laboratories, productions,
cold storage facilities, and multi-species hatcheries.

As Marcos promised, he has been putting the talks on agrarian reform forward
as he believes that this foundation of agriculture should be fixed. With this,
more than 70,000 land titles were given to agrarian reform beneficiaries.
Through the Agrarian Emancipation Act, the 57 million debt of more than
600,000 beneficiaries were ceased.

Marcos said that the government is in full preparation to mitigate the impacts
of El Nino on the people through water security. The administration worked
with the Congress to put into law the establishment of the Department of Water
Resources Management. This year, 14.6 billion pesos was allocated for water
supply projects to help communities and 6,000 rainwater collection systems
were installed all over the country.

**_Infrastructures_**

The “Build Better More” Program, with 194 projects under it worth 8.3 trillion
pesos, is still in progress. Projects in this program encompass physical
connectivity, water resources, agriculture, health, digital connectivity, and
energy.

Building links between the three islands of the Philippines, as well as links
between potential economic sites, are prioritized in the administration’s road
network plans. As of June, more than 4,000 kilometers of roads, 1,000
kilometers of railway projects, and 500 bridges were constructed and upgraded.
This interconnected road network will give access to economic markets across
the country such as agricultural and tourism sites, as well as business
districts.

A portion of underutilized funds under the newly established Maharlika
Investment Fund will be used for various projects to make highly profitable
investments without added debt. Economic managers will be hired to oversee the
management of the fund to ensure that investment decisions will be based on
financial considerations alone. Meanwhile, funds allocated for social welfare
and public health shall remain separated and intact.

The administration was also constant in pursuing total electrification
throughout the country. The national government was able to build eight new
power plants which make up the 17 power generation facilities in the country,
increasing energy production to 1,174 megawatts. With this, 500,000 homes have
been supplied with electricity while Marcos’ goal is to achieve 100 percent
electrification by the end of his term.

**_Education_**

Taking to heart the lessons of the pandemic, learning recovery will be at the
forefront of the government’s education agenda.

The MATATAG Agenda for Basic Education has been introduced, concentrating on
the welfare of both students and teachers as well as the relevance of the
curriculum and its prompt and effective implementation. The K–10 curriculum
will be reevaluated as part of the education reforms to make sure that it is
current, responsive, and up to line with international standards, giving
priority to literacy and numeracy skills.

For eligible students, higher education institutions (HEIs), as well as state
universities and colleges, will continue to be free.

With this, 500,000 homes have
been supplied with electricity while Marcos’ goal is to achieve 100 percent
electrification by the end of his term.

**_Education_**

Taking to heart the lessons of the pandemic, learning recovery will be at the
forefront of the government’s education agenda.

The MATATAG Agenda for Basic Education has been introduced, concentrating on
the welfare of both students and teachers as well as the relevance of the
curriculum and its prompt and effective implementation. The K–10 curriculum
will be reevaluated as part of the education reforms to make sure that it is
current, responsive, and up to line with international standards, giving
priority to literacy and numeracy skills.

For eligible students, higher education institutions (HEIs), as well as state
universities and colleges, will continue to be free. Nearly half of the 4.1
million college students who were enrolled in classes last year were
recipients of the nation's free higher education through the Universal Access
to Quality Tertiary Education program.

Private sector partners continue to provide support for school renovation and
improvement through the DepEd Partnership Assistance Portal as they work to
solve the shortage of classrooms and infrastructure.

Compared to just 15 HEIs last year, the Philippines have reached 52 HEIs
included in the World Universities Rankings.

**_Health_**

Following three years of fighting the global pandemic, the Philippine
government is now focusing on the nation's health goals, applying the lessons
learned from the pandemic into practice, and addressing the shortcomings it
has shown.

The government has introduced the Food Stamp Program and developed convergent
programs to address concerns with nutrition and hunger that affect Filipinos,
particularly children. It would support ongoing programs that guarantee
nutrition and routine immunizations for newborn children up to the sixth
grade.

Additionally, public health facilities are increasing with over 3,400 projects
completed last year. To increase capacity for specialized medical treatment,
specialty centers in various sectors are being constructed and integrated into
government hospitals, adding 60 specialty centers being open to the public.

Marcos also mentioned that the government is actively striving for a more
direct and efficient delivery of services. This will be achieved through
integrating primary care providers and networks, together with the LGUs and
private sectors, all of which will be enforced by “better and more efficient”
PhilHealth.

As the percentage of PhilHealth subscribers rises to 93 percent, the number of
Konsulta Centers nationwide has increased by 35 percent since last year.
Additionally, the number of free dialysis sessions for patients has increased
from 90 to 126.

Along with the implementation of the maximum retail price restriction, 59
critical pharmaceuticals for conditions like cancer, diabetes, hypertension,
kidney disease, and mental illnesses had their costs reduced according to the
targeted value-added tax exemption. The cost of essential medications has also
dropped from 40 percent to 90.

As the administration advocates for more healthy communities and lifestyles,
Marcos said that the lack of healthcare experts is a problem that they are
still working to address through educational reforms, more training, and
welfare assurance. The government is going to distribute its COVID health
emergency allowance and other benefits to local healthcare workers from
private to public hospitals.

**_Employment_**

Employment rate surged from 82.4 percent in April 2020 to 95.7 percent in May
2023 with a 13.3 percent increase, securing jobs for over 48.26 million
Filipinos.

Generating jobs was also among the priorities of the administration’s economic
missions. In matters of foreign affairs, Marcos stated that the national
government has formed strategic alliances with traditional and newfound
partners in the international community.

During his to- and from- trips abroad, despite the lack of clear context on
its agenda, the President’s foreign economic missions have garnered an
estimated total investment value of 71 billion US dollars, or 3.9 trillion
pesos, with a potential 175,000 jobs to generate.

Looking beyond the numbers, Marcos urged that there is more to be done for the
workforce to yield better employment opportunities. He vows to provide
additional jobs for the remaining 4.3 percent of the workforce, as well as for
the 11.7 percent of underemployed Filipinos.

**_Digitalization_**

** __**

**__**

To provide better public service, Marcos believes that the government must
fully embrace digitalization, as it would support their data-driven and
science-based planning and decision-making.

The Philippine Identification System (PhilSys) will be the center of the
administration’s digital transformation goal.

**_Digitalization_**

** __**

**__**

To provide better public service, Marcos believes that the government must
fully embrace digitalization, as it would support their data-driven and
science-based planning and decision-making.

The Philippine Identification System (PhilSys) will be the center of the
administration’s digital transformation goal. As of July 2023, 80 million
people had already registered for the National ID system, 12 million short of
the President’s target of 92 million IDs to be issued by mid-2023. Data from
the Philippine Statistic Authority also shows that around 34.32 million cards
have been given, while 38.35 million ePhil IDs have been printed.

Despite these backlogs in the issuance and delivery of national IDs, Marcos
was hopeful that the government is now closer "to establishing a complete,
accurate, and reliable digital database of our own for the entire population,"
which is now already integrated in the eGov PH app.

Last month, Marcos led the launch of the e-Gov PH Super App, an application
that integrates and centralizes key government services on one platform. The
chief of state added that these efforts to digitize government services are
the most powerful tool to combat graft and corruption.

Marcos also stated that internet speed in the country has improved, both for
fixed broadband and mobile internet. According to him, the Philippines ranked
47th amongst 180 countries for fixed broadband speed, 11 places higher than
last year, and 83rd amongst 142 nations for mobile internet speed, showing an
eighth-place improvement over last year. The President also mentioned the
entry of Elon Musk’s Starlink into the country early this year.

"Digitalization is the call of today; not the call of the future—but of the
present. It is here. It is needed, and it is needed today," Marcos said.

**_Climate Change_**

Standing as one of the imminent issues affecting nations globally, President
Marcos fixates on improving climate change mitigation strategies to achieve
liveable and sustainable communities.

“The building blocks of progressive, livable, and sustainable communities will
never be complete without appropriate and responsible action to mitigate and
to adapt to the effects of climate change,” he said.

According to him, the Philippines remains committed to global decarbonization
goals and carbon footprint reduction as well as the need to conserve green and
blue economies. He also grazed the cultivation of a “circular economy”—or
maximizing resource efficiency while minimizing environmental impacts and
greenhouse gas emissions.

Even if certain climate action strategies were envisioned, Marcos failed to
mention any policy or program to achieve these.

Marcos notes that his administration considers climate change as an “important
criterion” in crafting and implementing government programs.

“Just like our climate change action, this new system requires the
participation of all sectors of society, up to each individual citizen, for it
to succeed,” the President said.

**_Law Enforcement_**

Through years of attempts in lessening corruption, the President decides to
take a shot at marking the end of its long-standing crusade.

Marcos urges an anti-corruption stunt to challenge normative auditing systems
in the country. He urged lawmakers to pass two measures that will improve
government procurement and auditing.

He believes that enacting a new government procurement law and government
auditing code would strengthen the whole-of-government and whole-of-society
approach, which is deemed as a "transformative" solution amid the changing
times.

"Once again, on this same principle, I urge Congress to enact a new Government
Procurement Law and a new Government Auditing Code, to make government
procurement and auditing more attuned to these changing times," he said.

Marcos also mentioned that collaboration between the government and across
various sectors remains the "key" in making this transformation successful.

The administration is confident with the country’s future, rooted from world-
class quality workforce and highly competent workers serving in the
government. He commended everyone who stood behind him, who courageously took
the challenge of being part of the nation’s future– all for the love of the
Philippines.

He urged lawmakers to pass two measures that will improve
government procurement and auditing.

He believes that enacting a new government procurement law and government
auditing code would strengthen the whole-of-government and whole-of-society
approach, which is deemed as a "transformative" solution amid the changing
times.

"Once again, on this same principle, I urge Congress to enact a new Government
Procurement Law and a new Government Auditing Code, to make government
procurement and auditing more attuned to these changing times," he said.

Marcos also mentioned that collaboration between the government and across

The administration is confident with the country’s future, rooted from world-

government. He commended everyone who stood behind him, who courageously took
the challenge of being part of the nation’s future– all for the love of the
Philippines.

“With this in my heart, I know that the state of the nation is sound, and is
improving. Dumating na po ang Bagong Pilipinas,” Marcos said.

Marcos also took the chance to address the Congress to support and help him
enact important legislations which will be vital in the country’s continuous
recovery such as measures under the Medium Term Fiscal Framework, amendments
on various codes, and newly crafted laws of the administration.

# Candle Lighting 2024

Caption and Photos by Dean Joseph Palapar | 18 June 24

To end the first day of the university's week-long 59th founding celebration,
fellow Haribons and PLM admin officials, joined together in lighting the PLM
Eternal Torch and Flame of Excellence, at the university facade, yesterday,
June 18.

The torch lighting traditionally symbolizes the mark of a new prosperous
chapter for the Pamantasan in the next academic years to come.

# Transition and Turnover Conference 2024

Caption by Dean Joseph Palapar • Photos by Charlotte Mei Quintana | 20 July 24

The new key editors took their oath of office during Ang Pamantasan's
Transition and Turnover Conference (TTC) held at the Justo Albert Auditorium,
yesterday, July 21.

The TTC serves as the formal program to officially conclude the term of the
current Editorial Board and to present its new Key Editors for the next
academic year.

For this year's conference, a series of workshops on News Gathering by Sir
David Ramos Jr., Editorial Writing by outgoing Associate Editor Kenjo De
Paula, and Feature Writing by outgoing Editor-in-Chief Alessandra Frianela,
were conducted for the publication staff.

# PLM ComSci students bag Best Paper Award with algorithm for local crime
rates

Written by Mark Anthony Montalban • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 23 April 24

“It turns out, it’s an entirely new algorithm; what we needed to deliver the
desired results.”

Select 4th year BS Computer Science students of Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng
Maynila (PLM) were honored with the Best Paper Award - Computer Science Track
at the International Research Conference on Information Technology Education
(IRCITE) 2024 in Wesleyan University Philippines, March 8.

Patricia Nicole C. Trajano, Ayra Shane C. Villacarlos, Mark Christopher R.
Blanco, Jamillah S. Gualil, Gabriel R. Hill, Leisyl M. Mahusay and Jonathan C.
Morano proudly introduced their work entitled "An Enhanced Hartigan-Wong
Algorithm Applied for Determining the Crime Rates Per Area in the Philippines"
to the information technology (IT) community.

Trajano and Villacarlos talked about the technicalities of their thesis, as
well as their journey towards their victory in an exclusive interview with Ang
Pamantasan.

With the Hartigan-Wong algorithm as their basis in creating their thesis, the
problems they encountered with this were continuously enhanced and improved
through the application of other existing algorithms, in order to deliver
their desired results.

Their algorithm was applied to see the crime rates per area in the Philippines
in crime-specific clusters derived from the Philippine National Police
database. They utilized an enhanced K-means clustering algorithm which is
currently trending and popular in the field.

This innovation is for everyone, especially travelers, to be prepared and
alarmed to the place where they are going in accordance to the crime rates it
has. Moreover, their work is not solely intended for civilians but also for
police task forces and the IT world, since this is a new and innovative type
of algorithm that could help future researchers.

"We also wanted to target our police task forces… These results from the
enhanced algorithm can be used as monitoring to employ more task forces in
areas with high crime rates… We aim to contribute to a more advanced
technology and to raise awareness to the general public and for them to have
easy access to this kind of information," the students explained.

Moreover, Trajano and Villacarlos added that their creation is not limited to
local crime rates, but it can be also applied in various fields such as in
hospitals, to track diseases and other pertinent data that needs to be
treated. They emphasized that the algorithm they have produced has its wide
range of purposes.

The students shared that they faced little bumps in the process of crafting
this project but the big challenge for them was the time constraint. They said
that they only had one week to polish everything in their work and two days to
finalize everything before their deadline. Their preparation required them to
go back and forth to PLM everyday to work on their paper and continuously
coordinate with their thesis adviser, Mr. Mark Christopher Blanco, and
research coordinators.

Despite the challenges they faced, their paper emerged victoriously and
dominated the conference.

On the day of the conference, Trajano and Villacarlos were happy as they had
finished presenting their project in front of IT enthusiasts.

They emphasized that the algorithm they have produced has its wide
range of purposes.

The students shared that they faced little bumps in the process of crafting
this project but the big challenge for them was the time constraint. They said
that they only had one week to polish everything in their work and two days to
finalize everything before their deadline. Their preparation required them to
go back and forth to PLM everyday to work on their paper and continuously
coordinate with their thesis adviser, Mr. Mark Christopher Blanco, and
research coordinators.

Despite the challenges they faced, their paper emerged victoriously and
dominated the conference.

On the day of the conference, Trajano and Villacarlos were happy as they had
finished presenting their project in front of IT enthusiasts. Villacarlos’
goal was to showcase their work and leave an impression of how technology can
be integrated to crime annotation. Meanwhile, the researchers were happy and
surprised as they received the award.

"Actually, hindi namin ineexpect na mananalo.. kasi marami ring magagaling na
presenters," Trajano said.

They extended their utmost gratitude to their thesis adviser, as well as the
research coordinators for their unwavering support and belief in their
capabilities. They also appreciated each other's support from their
preparation up to its presentation.

"Huwag susuko. Mahirap.. Mahirap talaga siya, lalo sa umpisa, hindi mo alam
[ang] gagawin mo… Minsan mapapaisip ka kung kaya mo ba ito pero syempre,
kakayanin," Villacarlos stressed on her personal message for future
researchers.

Trajano also advised students to think among themselves about what they want
to contribute to society.

"Mahirap talagang mag-innovate pero we need to continue search ways para
makapag-contribute.," she added.

Trajano also wants their work to be known outside and to represent the
University as they contributed to the technology.

The international conference was attended by IT students, professors, and
educators from around 14 schools to participate in various events, but mostly
were from Central Luzon.

# PLM opens the AY; asserts its autonomy

Written by John Coby Cabuhat • Photos by Dean Joseph Palapar • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 29 August 23

Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) commenced the Academic Year 2023 -
2024, welcoming its returning students and around 2000 freshmen, Aug. 29.

![First Day IL
\(1\)](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2FjcmPvNMLnRdGbxC9dVghw%2F9db2f5d59ba2594ed52450b602df7c45%2FFirst_Day_IL__1_.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

Students were greeted by the performances of the newly established College of
Music headed by its Dean, Prof. Harold Galang.

PLM Board of Regents Chairperson Atty. Jose Ngaw welcomed the students for
their first day of class and the start of the academic year.

University President Emmanuel Leyco concluded the morning ceremonies by
welcoming the PLMayers and thanking employees who prepared the program,
classroom, and facilities in the PLM for the opening of the classes.

![First Day IL
\(2\)](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F5dSpnsq0DpvXMpHNruzCgj%2F07cafd2b78d4150900d98e84794e7bda%2FFirst_Day_IL__2_.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

In line with the celebration of National Heroes Day last Aug. 28, Leyco stated
to not forget the Filipino heroes who fought for the freedom and sovereignty
of the country. He added that the heroes of the education sector should also
be remembered.

“Huwag din po natin kakalimutan ang bayani ng sektor ng edukasyon,
pinangungunahan po ng ating mga guro, pinangungunahan ng ating mga estudyante,
pinangungunahan kasama ang ating mga kawani ng pamantasan upang ipagpatuloy
ang ating pong magandang ginagawa, magandang record ng Pamantasan ng Lungsod
ng Maynila,” Leyco said.

In addition, Leyco also emphasized facing the issues threatening the
independence of the University with everyone and called all stakeholders to
assert together its autonomy and direction established for more than fifty
years.

Last Aug. 15, the Commission on Higher Education (CHED) sent a letter revoking
the exception of PLM in complying with the policies on institutional
recognition of Local Universities and Colleges (LUCs). PLM’s failure to comply
would result in the commission recommending to the Governing Board on Free
Tertiary Education the delisting of the university as its beneficiary.

The administration has already sent a reply to the letter. The University
President refuted the claims that students will now pay tuition fees in an
online briefing last Sunday and reiterated it in his remarks.

“At ito rin po.

independence of the University with everyone and called all stakeholders to

Last Aug. 15, the Commission on Higher Education (CHED) sent a letter revoking
the exception of PLM in complying with the policies on institutional
recognition of Local Universities and Colleges (LUCs). PLM’s failure to comply
would result in the commission recommending to the Governing Board on Free
Tertiary Education the delisting of the university as its beneficiary.

The administration has already sent a reply to the letter. The University
President refuted the claims that students will now pay tuition fees in an
online briefing last Sunday and reiterated it in his remarks.

“At ito rin po. Mayroon man pong issue ang mga tao na sasabihin [nilang ay]
magbabayad na raw po ang mga estudyante ng tuition [fees]. Hindi po yan
totoo,” Leyco explained.

READ ALSO: [_‘Hindi po tayo maniningil ng tuition mula sa mga estudyante’ -
Pres. Leyco_](https://www.angpamantasan.org/news/hindi-po-tayo-maniningil-ng-
tuition-mula-sa-mga-estudyante-pres-leyco)

![First Day IL
\(5\)](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F3nh7efEaub6d9NF3lbBD9D%2Fd0c906ffc120388ca59cb9d8b6b0dcd6%2FFirst_Day_IL__5_.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

The administration also asserted that PLM is a chartered university created by
a national law and not by a local ordinance and should not be recognized only
as an LUC. Therefore, the university should not be delisted as a beneficiary
and students could still enjoy free higher education.

"Kaya po kung mayroon mang pong mga issue, kung mayroon man pong maaring
makapaglihis sa direksyon na tinatahak ng ating pamantasan, sama-sama rin po
natin linawin ito at wala rin pong makakasagabal sa patuloy na pagpapatupad ng
patakaran ng PLM," the University President added.

Leyco said that students will not be asked to pay tuition fees as there are
laws affirming their right to free education.

![First Day IL
\(4\)](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F2wOdYRSfhpN3KOtGYTYMXe%2F8a4b54541398b27bd3163e85576cb895%2FFirst_Day_IL__4_.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

“Mayroon nga [r]in po na ang sinsabi ay hindi raw po makakasweldo ang mga
mangagawa, wala pong katotohanan ang mga alingasngas na iyan,” the president
also clarified the issues on the salaries of the employees.

In the same online briefing, Leyco reassures university stakeholders that they
are exhausting all available measures to remedy the concern.

In an interview, the Supreme Student Council (SSC) President Vince De Guzman
welcomes new faces in the university, “Una sa lahat, ako’y nalulugod na
syempre sa ating pagbabalik klase dito sa ating pinakamamahal na pamantasan ay
marami kaagad tayong nakitang mga bagong mukha. Lalo na yung ating mga
freshman na alam natin na napaka-excited din nila dahil sa kanilang first day
of classes [din].”

De Guzman also emphasized that student concerns and issues must also be
addressed in the opening of classes.

“Pero kailangan pa natin tingnan lahat ng mga problema na kinahaharap ng bawat
estudyante dito sa pamantasan lalo na ngayon ang mga concern sa enrollment,”
De Guzman said.

The SSC President also shared the concerns of ‘floating students’ who have
issues with the enrollment procedures.

The SSC President also shared the concerns of ‘floating students’ who have
issues with the enrollment procedures.

![First Day IL
\(5\)](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F3nh7efEaub6d9NF3lbBD9D%2Fd0c906ffc120388ca59cb9d8b6b0dcd6%2FFirst_Day_IL__5_.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

“Pati na rin sa pagkakaroon ng mga issues o ng [ating mga] PLM demands din na
panawagan din ng ating mga mass organizations,” the SSC President added.

De Guzman said that the opening of classes is also an opportunity to discuss
the needs of every stakeholder in the Pamantasan, “At syempre nakikiisa tayo
rito, lalo na sa pagbubukas ng klase, dahil isang panuruang taon na naman ang
kailangan nating pagdaanan at syempre dito, matatalakay talaga natin lahat ng
pangangailangan ng bawat isa.”

The students also held a protest, the First Day Fight, together with the SSC,
mass organizations, and accredited student organizations.

# KathNiel: Huling Pahina ng Isang Dekada

Written by Jamilla Marie Matias • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 6 December 23

Isa ang “love team” sa mga kalinangang tanyag na walang dudang sinusuportahan
at kinaaaliwan sa Pilipinas. Kaya naman nang umugong ang balitang hiwalayang
“KathNiel” o tambalang Kathryn Bernardo at Daniel Padilla, hindi maiwasan ang
kirot sa puso ng karamihan, bahagi man ng _fandom_ o hindi. Sa tinagal-tagal
ba naman ng kanilang pagsasama — mula _reel to real_ , ang labing-isang taon
ay tila ba naging kahapon na lamang.

Tinapos ng Instagram post ni Kathryn ang espekulasyon at agam-agam ng
paghihiwalay nila ng kanyang _long-time boyfriend_ na si Daniel. Walang
isinaad na dahilan kung bakit, ngunit tagos-puso ang bawat salitang kaniyang
sinambit. Tanda ng tunay na pagmamahal na kanilang pinagsaluhan.

Bagama’t nagsara na ang kabanatang ito ng kanilang buhay, hindi naman
matatawaran ang markang iniwan nila sa bawat Pilipino sa pamamagitan ng
kanilang mga pelikulang minsang pumuno ng takilya, mga teleseryeng inabangan
at pinag-usapan, at ang mga aral na itinuro nito sa madla. Bitbit ang mga
tagpong nagpaluha, nagpangiti, at nagpakilig sa milyong indibidwal na saksi ng
kanilang tambalang naging pamantayan ng pag-ibig at tagumpay.

**Mata ang unang nagmamahal**

Sa mata marahil ng kanilang mga taga-hanga nagsimula ang pagmamahal at
suportang kanilang nakamit. Sila ang unang nakapansin ng solidong _chemistry_
ng dalawang aktor na tinangkilik at sinubaybayan ng maraming Pinoy.

Isa si Elaisa Jasmine Moreno ng College of Education (CED) sa libu-libong
sumusuporta sa KathNiel. Para sa kaniya, ang nasabing tambalan ang naging isa
sa rason kung bakit siya patuloy na naniniwala sa pagmamahal at sa sakit na
dulot nito.

**Mata ang unang nagmamahal**

Sa mata marahil ng kanilang mga taga-hanga nagsimula ang pagmamahal at
suportang kanilang nakamit. Sila ang unang nakapansin ng solidong _chemistry_
ng dalawang aktor na tinangkilik at sinubaybayan ng maraming Pinoy.

Isa si Elaisa Jasmine Moreno ng College of Education (CED) sa libu-libong
sumusuporta sa KathNiel. Para sa kaniya, ang nasabing tambalan ang naging isa
sa rason kung bakit siya patuloy na naniniwala sa pagmamahal at sa sakit na
dulot nito. At sa loob ng labing-dalawang taon ng pagiging _die hard fan,_
ikinuwento niya ang mga bagay na nagawa niya para tangkilikin ang KathNiel
gaya ng pagbili ng mga magazine at libro, pagtitiyaga dumalo sa mga pagtitipon
sa kabila ng kumakalam na tiyan, at pag-aalay ng kanyang mga medalya at
sertipiko sa mga ito upang ipabatid na isa ang nasabing tambalan sa dahilan
kung bakit siya nag pupursigi sa pag-aaral.

Hindi man nagulat sa rebelasyon si Elaisa ay hindi pa rin naiwasan ang pighati
para sa _love team_ na sinubaybayan niya ng mahigit isang dekada. “Nung nabasa
ko yung open letter ni Kath kay DJ, nasaktan ako, for 11 years kasi I was
there, I witnessed how strong their love is. I cried, and until now masakit,”
aniya.

Paglalahad pa niya, ang pinaka natutunan niyang aral bilang taga-hanga ay ang
pagkatutong tumigil at magpahinga kapag hindi na kaya dahil ang pagmamahal ay
di nauubusan ng oras. Humantong man sa dulo ang relasyong matagal niyang
hinangaan, patuloy pa rin naman niyang susuportahan ang dalawa sapagka’t batid
niya at naniniwala pa rin siya sa talentong taglay ng kanyang mga idolo.

**Sa Susunod na Habang Buhay**

Mahigit isang dekada ang pinagsamahan ng KathNiel —- sa likod man o sa harap
ng mga lente ng _camera_. Nasaksihan ng mga tagasubaybay ang kanilang karera
mula sa seryeng _Growing-Up_ hanggang sa _growing apart_ na pahinang ito ng
kanilang buhay. Hindi man sumapat at umayon ang kanilang pagmamahalan sa
ngayon ngunit magpapatuloy pa rin hanggang sa susunod na habang buhay ang mga
alaalang inukit nila sa kultura, paniniwala, at prinsipyong kanilang itinuro.

At sa pagdating ng huling pahinang ito, higit pa sa two months, two-weeks,
three-days, ten-hours at 57 minutes ng kanilang pagmamahalan ang babaunin ng
mga taong sumuporta at patuloy na sumusuporta kay Kathryn at Daniel. Sinamahan
nilang sumayaw ng _sexy love_ ang kanilang mga taga-hanga sa rurok ng ligaya
at kinantahan naman sa pighating nadarama.

Isa ang KathNiel sa may pinakamalaking _fanbase_ sa bansa. Patunay ito ng
matagumpay na karerang kanilang tinamasa. Kaakibat nito ang mata ng publiko na
laging nagmamatyag at nag-aabang sa hakbang na kanilang tinatahak. At kagaya
ng kanilang hiling, respeto’t pang-unawa ang kanilang nais. Dahil gaya ng mga
pinagbidahan nilang serye’t pelikula, darating at darating talaga ang huling
kabanata. Gaano man kaganda ang ikot nito, laging may hangganan sa bawat
kwento.

matagumpay na karerang kanilang tinamasa. Kaakibat nito ang mata ng publiko na
laging nagmamatyag at nag-aabang sa hakbang na kanilang tinatahak. At kagaya
ng kanilang hiling, respeto’t pang-unawa ang kanilang nais. Dahil gaya ng mga
pinagbidahan nilang serye’t pelikula, darating at darating talaga ang huling
kabanata. Gaano man kaganda ang ikot nito, laging may hangganan sa bawat
kwento.

# ICYMI | “Carry On and Carry Off”: PLM ChESS students win intercollegiate chemical plant design competition 

Written by Zarena Hermogeno • Board by Elyse Abadilla | 4 November 23

Students from Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) Chemical Engineering
Students' Society stood first place at the 2023 Asian Pacific Confederation of
Chemical Engineering (APCChE) held at the SMX Convention Center, Sept. 5.

Chemical Engineering fresh graduates: Aaron Calvin Reyes, Stephanie Mae Luna,
Joyce Ann Orata, and Maria Katrina Barrozo proudly presented their thesis
titled: "Enzymatic Depolymerization of Waste Poly (Ethylene Terephthalate) for
Terephthalic Acid, Sodium Sulfate, and Ethylene Glycol Recovery" to the Asian
Pacific community of highly-esteemed chemical engineers and industrial
chemists, and well-respected persons in the field.

In an exclusive interview with Ang Pamantasan, Reyes shared the technicalities
of their thesis.

The plant design was all about decomposing macromolecules into smaller
compounds or “monomers” through a process called “depolymerizing”.
Polyethylene Terephthalate (PET), a common material used in plastic bottles is
depolymerized to recover its monomers which are Terephthalic Acid and Ethylene
Glycol. Both of these monomers are also used to re-create PET bottles again,
or if necessary, to produce other polymeric materials such as polymeric
polymers.

Reyes emphasized that there are multiple processes that can be done to easily
degrade PET but chose to use different enzymes to swiftly recover Terephthalic
Acid and Ethylene Glycol.

They also added that Sodium Sulfate appeared as a by-product of recovering
Terephthalic Acid from the acidification of solution from the depolymerization
of PET.

"We aim to contribute to a more sustainable way to produce plastics while at
the same time reducing the waste of our plastics," Barrozo said.

During the interview, Reyes, Luna, Orata, and Barrozo also shared the highs
and lows they endured during the project.

Among those is having to redo the entire thesis in a span of a week after
failing their first defense and having to submit at 10:54 PM, an hour and 5
minutes before the competition requirement deadline due to necessary changes.
They also admitted that the feeling of immense pressure was not foreign but
they still continued.

Despite the adversities they faced, the APCChE plant design victors emerged
triumphant, unfazed by the dominating projects of other universities--taking
into heart the trust given to them by their advisers, family, and friends.

The group also extended their utmost gratitude to their thesis advisers, Engr.
Vince Harvey O. Alano and Engr. Peniel Jean A. Gildo for their unwavering
support and belief in their capabilities.

When asked about a piece of advice that they could give to their
lowerclassmen, each of them had different takes.

Among those is having to redo the entire thesis in a span of a week after
failing their first defense and having to submit at 10:54 PM, an hour and 5
minutes before the competition requirement deadline due to necessary changes.
They also admitted that the feeling of immense pressure was not foreign but
they still continued.

Despite the adversities they faced, the APCChE plant design victors emerged
triumphant, unfazed by the dominating projects of other universities--taking
into heart the trust given to them by their advisers, family, and friends.

The group also extended their utmost gratitude to their thesis advisers, Engr.
Vince Harvey O. Alano and Engr. Peniel Jean A. Gildo for their unwavering
support and belief in their capabilities.

When asked about a piece of advice that they could give to their
lowerclassmen, each of them had different takes.

Reyes did not sugarcoat but stressed how difficult the Chemical Engineering
program of the university is, yet it should not be a reason for the students
to hinder their progress and strive harder as they can learn a thing or two
along the way.

"Don't give up even if it's hard," he said.

Orata also advised students to be on the lookout for opportunities and grab
them while they can--not forgetting to also be responsible with every choice
they make.

"Grab every opportunity with great responsibility," she said.

In her own words, Barrozo reminded students to be confident in every output:
"no one knows your work more than you."

Most importantly, APCChE's "Best Oral Presentation" title holder Stephanie Mae
Luna concluded the interview by saying "Be honest if you don't know anything
but don't be dependent in not knowing anything", reminding students to stay
inquisitive yet diligent in seeking answers.

The team was also selected for an oral presentation for another thesis
entitled "Synthesis of Copper-Carbon Dots from Waste Expanded Polystyrene via
One-Pot Solvothermal Method for Carbon Monoxide Detection" under the advisings
of Dr. Rugi Vicente Rubi and Engr. Jarlie R. Clemena.

# PLM COMELEC logs 30.26 percent mock elections voter turnout, tackles voting
system issues ahead of Election Day

Written by Rylan Gabriel Bernardo • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 7 May 24

The PLM Student Commission on Elections (COMELEC) reported a 30.26 percent
voter turnout for the 2024 mock elections, with 4,274 students out of 14,123
eligible voters casting their votes through the new electronic voting
procedure, May 2.

The Commission created 67 clusters to cater all 14 colleges of the University,
kicking off its electoral run-through for the upcoming Supreme Student Council
(SSC) and College Student Council (CSC) elections through utilizing the
Assignments tab in Microsoft Teams to notify students that they may access the
election ballot.

“This year’s mock elections has allowed the commission to obtain 30.26% or
4,274 students to try out the system to be used on Election Day. The
percentage is almost double of last year’s mock elections,” PLM COMELEC report
stated.

Eight out of the 14 colleges in the University declared a successful election
in accordance with Article I, Section 10 of the PLM Omnibus Election Code of
2019, logging in a voter turnout of more than 25% of their respective voting
population.

However, the College of Architecture and Sustainable Built Environments
(CASBE), College of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences (CHASS), College of
Law (CL), College of Medicine (CM), College of Nursing (CN), and College of
Physical Therapy (CPT) were remarked with “failure of election,” recording an
overall electoral turnout of less than 25% their respective voting population.

PLM COMELEC further noted that out of the nine colleges which had candidates
for the upcoming elections, CN, CASBE, CHASS, CL, and CPT have “failed to
reach the threshold for the college council election to be considered
successful.”

Meanwhile, PLM COMELEC has highlighted “mostly technical and isolated” issues
during the mock elections, which included some students receiving the mock
election ballots ten minutes after its scheduled start and some students
having difficulties accessing the Assignments tab in Microsoft Teams.

In addition, some students also failed to be added to their respective cluster
precincts due to either their names not being listed on the Office of the
University Registrar (OUR) Masterlist or malfunctioning PLM email addresses.
However, the commission assured that the students concerned will be added to
their respective cluster precincts a week before the election day.

“The Commission believes that the voting system is cleared and can be used for
the upcoming elections along with the adjustments necessary to settle any
isolated technical problems,” PLM COMELEC added, ensuring that the issues
mentioned will be resolved before Election Day.

In order to deem the polls successful, the Commission expects at least 25% of
the 14,123 eligible voters to participate in the official elections to be held
on May 21, with the campaign period of the candidates beginning May 7 until
May 16. Dates for HARAPAN 2024 will be on May 16 (Thursday) for the CSC and
May 20 (Monday) for the SSC.

However, the commission assured that the students concerned will be added to
their respective cluster precincts a week before the election day.

“The Commission believes that the voting system is cleared and can be used for
the upcoming elections along with the adjustments necessary to settle any
isolated technical problems,” PLM COMELEC added, ensuring that the issues
mentioned will be resolved before Election Day.

In order to deem the polls successful, the Commission expects at least 25% of
the 14,123 eligible voters to participate in the official elections to be held
on May 21, with the campaign period of the candidates beginning May 7 until
May 16. Dates for HARAPAN 2024 will be on May 16 (Thursday) for the CSC and
May 20 (Monday) for the SSC.

PLM COMELEC also assures consistent dissemination of information regarding the
events during the campaign and election period through their social media
platforms.

# “An indelible part of SSC History”: PRO resigns, demands accountability

Written by Zarena Hermogeno • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 16 November 23

The Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila Supreme Student Council (PLM SSC) Public
Relations Officer (PRO), Joseph Andrei Torres steps down from his post, Nov.
15.

Earlier this day, PLM SSC released Resolution No. 17, S. 2023 signifying
Torres's departure from the highest student-governing body in the Pamantasan.

In his resignation letter, the former council spokesperson highlighted that
his "terrible experience," ranging from “unreasonable behavior”, “power
tripping” within the council members, and an issue with a “freedom wall”
significantly impacted his well-being.

Moreso, Torres attested that he is among the victims of the alleged bullying
issue involving the SSC executive officers.

READ ALSO:

[ _https://www.angpamantasan.org/news/anonymous-post-exposes-alleged-bullying-
within-plm-ssc_](https://www.angpamantasan.org/news/anonymous-post-exposes-
alleged-bullying-within-plm-ssc)

According to him, this incident affected his mental health and work ethics to
the point that he had to leave the PLM SSC.

"Working alongside some council members has made me question my own worth and
the efficacy of my role." he said.

As Torres ends his 6-month term as PRO, he demanded accountability from his
former colleagues in the council involved in the bullying controversy:

"I would like to demand for accountability from those responsible for the
challenges faced within the PLM SSC. Your actions have not only inflicted harm
upon the victims but have also had repercussions for the broader student body
and the future Haribons. The impact of all your actions will become an
indelible part of PLM's history." he said.

# CHASS-SC receives adverse opinion from PLM SCOA; council’s prior financial
statement disregarded

Written by Calvin Agustin • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 24 July 23

The PLM Student Commission on Audit (SCOA) gave the College of Humanities,
Arts, and Social Sciences - Student Council (CHASS-SC)’s financial statement
an adverse opinion due to its lack of fair presentation, June 15.

The report stated that the adverse opinion was rendered to the council’s
financial statement because of its lack of sufficient and appropriate evidence
to support the financial statement; incorrect entries on transactions; misuse
of cash disbursement form and unused miscellaneous disbursement receipt; joint
bank account of the council and personal funds; material misstatements in the
council’s previous financial statement, limiting SCOA’s further auditing
procedures.

Moreover, CHASS-SC failed to meet the deadline set by SCOA which affected the
commission’s time frame in conducting the auditing procedures. This instance
acted on SCOA’s ability to obtain evidence on the council’s financial
statement in forming its opinion. This also raised concerns from the
commission’s end on the effectiveness of CHASS-SC’s internal financial control
and the credibility of the financial information presented to the
stakeholders.

As recommended by the commission’s independent auditor, CHASS-SC should
appoint a qualified individual to handle the council’s financial
responsibilities and implement standardized procedures in recording and
safekeeping its financial documents. In addition, the council should conduct a
thorough review of its accounting procedures to reduce errors and fraud in its
financial statement and observe the scheduled submission of the commission to
identify discrepancies early.

Furthermore, CHASS-SC members should be trained in utilizing the necessary
documents while monitoring the usage of such forms to avoid any
irregularities. The council’s treasurer should create a separate bank account
for the council funds to track all transactions made. The council should also
utilize all resources provided by SCOA as guides for its financial statement.
Lastly, CHASS-SC should structurize its turnover process, especially for all
financial matters to ensure the continuity of financial management within the
council.

Dated June 15, SCOA officials also signed a resolution disregarding the
financial statements of CHASS-SC for AY 2021-2022 because certain auditing
procedures were limited due to the pandemic, thus restricting the proper
settlement of the misstated amounts identified in their submission. This
incident has ensued the council’s unreliable presentation of its financial
position and performance for the academic year.

With this, SCOA decided that the council’s net assets shall be reset to zero
at the beginning of the current year and its financial report shall encompass
all records from the current year only.

Additionally, the commission recommends that the incoming council take actions
to ensure that the succeeding financial statements will accurately reflect
CHASS-SC's financial position and performance. Financial controls and
procedures shall also be enhanced to reduce the risk of significant
misstatements, in compliance with SCOA’s auditing standards.

Dated June 15, SCOA officials also signed a resolution disregarding the
financial statements of CHASS-SC for AY 2021-2022 because certain auditing
procedures were limited due to the pandemic, thus restricting the proper
settlement of the misstated amounts identified in their submission. This
incident has ensued the council’s unreliable presentation of its financial
position and performance for the academic year.

With this, SCOA decided that the council’s net assets shall be reset to zero
at the beginning of the current year and its financial report shall encompass
all records from the current year only.

Additionally, the commission recommends that the incoming council take actions
to ensure that the succeeding financial statements will accurately reflect
CHASS-SC's financial position and performance. Financial controls and
procedures shall also be enhanced to reduce the risk of significant
misstatements, in compliance with SCOA’s auditing standards.

The PLM Student Commission on Audit functions as a University commission whose
duty is to examine, audit, and settle all accounts recording the revenue,
receipts, expenditures, and use of funds and properties of student councils
and student organizations in the Pamantasan.

# Ang Lumilisang Tinig ng Bayan

Written by Jan Rennie Abat • Art by Elyse Abadilla | 30 August 23

Sa mala obra maestrang pagkakakilanlan ng bansa na binubuo ng iba’t-ibang
wika, tinig ng iilan ay unti-unting nawawala.

Tagalog. Bisaya. Ilocano. Iilan lamang sila sa mga wikang Pilipino na
karamihan sa’tin ay nakaririnig at nakaiintindi. Ngunit sa kabila ng mga buhay
na wikang nakasanayan sa pang araw-araw ay ang katotohanang may parte nito ang
tuluyan nang humuhumpay – ang tinig ng labing-isang wikang katutubo.

**(LABI)ng-isang wika**

Ayon sa Summer Institute of Linguistics (SIL)’ Ethnologue 2022, ang Pilipinas
ay tahanan ng 184 na wika kung saan 35 dito ang nanganganib mawala. Kinikilala
naman ang Arta, Bontok ng Hilaga, Bontok ng Timog-kanluran, Dumagat-Remontado,
Inagta Alabat, Katubung Agta, Ata, Ayta ng Sorsogon, Ratagnon, Tagbanwa
Central, at Eskayan bilang ang 11 wika na buhay ay tuluyan nang matutuldukan.

Base sa kanilang pagsusuri, ang labing-isang wikang nabanggit ay mga “dying
language” na siyang mga matatanda na lamang ang mga gumagamit at hindi na kaya
pang buhayin muli sa pamamagitan ng intergenerational transmission.
Samantalang ang 35 wika naman na nanganganib mawala ay dahil sa hindi na ito
naituturo pa sa susunod na henerasyon ng kanilang komunidad.

“The loss of one language would be a loss to the overall body of knowledge,”
saad ni Jesus Federico Hernandez, isang propesor ng Department of Linguistics
sa University of the Philippines (UP).

Hindi nayayari sa isang iglap ang kamatayan ng wika – mabagal na kinikitil,
bawat parte ay isa-isang nawawala. Kalimita'y mga kaalaman sa relihiyon ang
unang biktima na siyang susundan ng mga salitang nagbibigay buhay at kahulugan
sa sining at kultura ng mga mamamayan. At ang pinakahuling yugto ng pagkawala
nito ay ang pagkalimot sa mga simpleng salita na siyang ginagamit upang
makisalamuha sa iba. Ito ang sabi ng isang cultural anthropologist at propesor
ng UP Department of Anthropology na si Nestor Castro.

Hindi rin madali ang pagligtas sa mga wikang nabanggit.

Hindi nayayari sa isang iglap ang kamatayan ng wika – mabagal na kinikitil,
bawat parte ay isa-isang nawawala. Kalimita'y mga kaalaman sa relihiyon ang
unang biktima na siyang susundan ng mga salitang nagbibigay buhay at kahulugan
sa sining at kultura ng mga mamamayan. At ang pinakahuling yugto ng pagkawala
nito ay ang pagkalimot sa mga simpleng salita na siyang ginagamit upang
makisalamuha sa iba. Ito ang sabi ng isang cultural anthropologist at propesor
ng UP Department of Anthropology na si Nestor Castro.

Hindi rin madali ang pagligtas sa mga wikang nabanggit. Ayon kay SIL
Philippines Language Assessment Specialist Rynj Gonzales, ang urbanisasyon na
nagpapaalis sa mga indigenous groups sa kanilang mga lupain ang isa sa mga
pinaka dahilan ng pagkawala ng wika. Kaya naman ay kailangan ng malawakang
“interangency and intergenerational push.”

**Tinig ng pag-asa**

Sa kabila ng lumilisang tinig ng wikang katutubo, mayroong mga umaksyon upang
matulungan isalba ang mga ito. Isa na rito ang Marayum na isang proyektong
pinopondohan ng Department of Science and Technology (DOST).

Community-built online dictionary ang Marayum na pinangungunahan ni Mario
Carreon na assistant professor ng Department of Computer Science sa UP
Diliman, kasama ang iba pang dalubwika at computer scientists.

"Working with Marayum, I came to realize that we are a country of many
tongues, but these tongues are slowly dying, and if we do not take an active
stance to preserve it, future Filipinos will never be able to hear it," saad
ng Chief Volunteer Contributor ng Marayum na si Adellsbi Lao. Dagdag pa rito
ay ang paghikayat ni Lao sa mga kabataan na makilahok sa kanilang proyekto.

Ilan din sa mga aksyong isinasagawa upang maisalba ang wika ay ang Buhid
Mangyan Dictionary ng komunidad ng Buhid Mangyan kasama ang UP Department of
Linguistics, at ang Bahay-Wika project at Master-Apprentice Language Learning
Program (MALLP) ng Komisyon sa Wikang Filipino (KWF) sa Ayta Magbukun
community noong 2017.

Sumasalamin ang bawat wikang bumubuo sa mala obra maestrang pagkakakilanlan ng
mga Pilipino – isang bansang puno ng makukulay na mga kultura at buhay na
wika. Ngunit sa paglipas ng panahon at sa pag-usbong ng panibagong henerasyon,
nanganganib maglaho ang iilang wika na bumubuo rito. Gayunpaman, tulad na
lamang ng iba’t-ibang proyektong naging tugon, buhay ang tinig ng pag-asang
may wikang katutubong maisasalba.

# IN PHOTOS | Day 1 of APEx 2023

Caption by Roland Justin Molato • Photos by Dean Palapar, Roland Justin Molato, & Estelle Theresa Gulay | 22 November 23

IN PHOTOS: Ang Pamantasan, the official student publication of PLM, conducts
the Ang Pamantasan Examination 2023 in the Bukod Tanging Bulwagan.

# GALING NG FILIPINA: Ramirez, Ochoa strike gold, banner Filipina’s strength
in Asian Games Jiu-Jitsu

Written by Cedrick Paynor • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 12 October 23

Margarita 'Meggie' Ochoa and Annie Ramirez not only triumphed in Jiu Jitsu but
also demonstrated the extraordinary capabilities of Filipina athletes through
their stellar performance, clinching two gold medals for the Philippines in
the 19th Asian Games, Oct. 5 and 6.

Ochoa secured the Philippines' second gold at the Hangzhou Asian Games after
winning over the United Arab Emirates' Balqees Abdulla with a 1-0 victory in
the women's -48kg division finals.

Advancing to the final, Ochoa secured victories in the preliminaries by
overcoming Odgerel Batbayar of Mongolia and Nazkul Rakhayeva of Kazakhstan,
followed by a strategic triumph over Pechrada Kacie Tan of Thailand via a 4-2
points decision in the semifinals.

The victory gave Meggie her first-ever gold medal in the Asian Games, marking
a profoundly significant achievement in her career and emphasizing the
paramount importance of this victory for the accomplished jiu-jitsu standout.

Meanwhile, Ramirez achieved another milestone for the Philippines by securing
the nation's third gold in the 19th edition of the continental showcase and
second gold in Jiu Jitsu as she dominated the women's -57kg division.

Ramirez sealed her unbeaten run by clinching a 2-0 victory over Kazakhstan's
Galina Duvanova in the finals, following the impressive success in her earlier
bouts against Le Thi Thuong of Vietnam, Fiona Toh of Singapore, and Shamsa
Alameri of the UAE.

Her triumph unfolded just a day after fellow jiu-jitsu standout Ochoa secured
the second Filipino gold medal in Hangzhou, and in the aftermath of pole
vaulter EJ Obiena's groundbreaking gold.

The resounding success of Ochoa and Ramirez stood as a powerful testament to
the undeniable potential of Filipina athletes to showcase their ability to
raise our flag with pride and excellence on any international sporting stage.

Caption by Roland Justin Molato, Dean Joseph Palapar • Photos by Roland Justin Molato, Dean Joseph Palapar, Estelle Theresa Gulay, and Theresa Mareez Garcia | 24 November 23

The second day of the Ang Pamantasan Examination (APEx) 2023 officially
concluded yesterday, November 24.

A total of 23 examinees were interviewed at the Ang Pamantasan Office.

Stay tuned on the Ang Pamantasan page for the results.

Good luck, Future Staffers!

# Run Youth Run

From the Archives • Written and Board by John Coby Cabuhat | 15 May 23

Various interest groups, youth, and election-related organizations have
started the countdown as it will be less than a year until the 2022 Philippine
National and Local Elections. On May 9, 2022, a stronghold of 40 million youth
voters will be having a chance once again to participate in and revolutionize
the politics in the country. This should also be an opportunity to activate,
empower, and engage with youth institutions through voting in the second
Sangguniang Kabataan (SK) Elections under the Republic Act (RA) 10742 also
known as the SK Reform Act of 2015.

Aside from the noise of “premature campaigning” of politicians both in local
and national positions, plastering faces of individuals all over the city,
interest groups rallying up to encourage personalities to run for office,
people traveling around the country even with the pandemic just to collect
signatures, to the coalition-building forwarding fair and safe elections,
youth will also have great participation in these upcoming elections.

However, not everyone is privy to that “great participation.” This upcoming SK
election is a right chance for the youth to be reminded and informed on its
critical role in the existence of SK and the future of the governance of young
politicians. According to Section 4 of SK Reform Law, a Filipino citizen
residing in the barangay for at least six months and who is 15 to 30 years old
is a member of Katipunan ng Kabataan (KK). A youth assembly not requiring an
individual to run for office to be part of the governance of SK.

This is an avenue for the ordinary youth, whether you are a student, out-of-
school youth, young professional, or from any background to participate and
contribute and not just only to elect your SK officials. In fact, Section 5
(a) of the same law, mentioned that the KK is the highest policy-making body
to decide on the affairs of the youth in barangay. The youth have now the
ability to directly raise issues and concerns affecting them and other youth
in the barangay, and visions that they might want to see for their community.

It is just sad to point out that this is not really what can be seen in some
barangays. The pandemic also adds up to the issues on how youth can
participate in governance. This boils down to the question relating to the SK
asking for the concurrence of KK for its projects and if they involved the
youth of their community in formulating their plans at all. On the other side,
it is not only the burden of SK to sustain and enforce this provision of the
law, but also the shared responsibility together with the youth in their
community if they have what it takes to actively participate in this process.

The youth hold enormous potential to bring change to the Philippine
government. It is in this age bracket where youth are still within the walls
of educational institutions as learners, gaining experiences as young
professionals in various fields, and have the energy to forward ideologies and
principles. However, it is the same group of people who are vulnerable to the
wrongdoings of the society might it be working in bad faith, being
untrustworthy, to acts of corruption.

This boils down to the question relating to the SK
asking for the concurrence of KK for its projects and if they involved the
youth of their community in formulating their plans at all. On the other side,
it is not only the burden of SK to sustain and enforce this provision of the
law, but also the shared responsibility together with the youth in their
community if they have what it takes to actively participate in this process.

The youth hold enormous potential to bring change to the Philippine
government. It is in this age bracket where youth are still within the walls
of educational institutions as learners, gaining experiences as young
professionals in various fields, and have the energy to forward ideologies and
principles. However, it is the same group of people who are vulnerable to the
wrongdoings of the society might it be working in bad faith, being
untrustworthy, to acts of corruption.

The vulnerability of the youth, specifically of the youth institutions such as
SK to the traditional politics and some who exist in corrupted environments
hinder the full extent of what youth can bring to the country’s governance.
Where in some instances, the figure who they should expect to follow is the
same figure who can introduce, influence, and inflict harmful activities not
just for their constituency but for the future of the young leaders.

However, the SK Reform Law provided provisions to lessen or even solve the
possibility of these influences over the youth. This is a time to call for
stronger enforcement and support to Section 20 (b) of RA 10742. This pertains
to the financial independence of the SK from their Barangay Council whose
budget will be given separately to their own account having full and direct
control on the appropriations of SK Funds. This is crucial to the governance
of SK as corruption starts whenever there is money involved. This will be a
chance for the youth to decide on their own, bound with their duties, on what
kind of leader they want to be.

In campaigning for the elections, the youth know the ‘tricks’ or strategies of
candidates in winning seats in the offices that they are running for. There
are the decent ones - holding town hall meetings, conversation with their
constituents, campaign paraphernalia for them to be remembered, presentation
of platforms, among others. Youth are not innocent of the dance craze, song
number, and an event with an entertainment package during elections that might
beat your favorite Sunday noon show.

This election is an opportunity for the young politicians to say that “we know
better” and to raise the bar or standard of election campaign culture in their
localities, and if done collectively, in the whole country. Where there is
appreciation in hearing the voices of their fellow youth determining issues
and concerns affecting them, presenting not only themselves but their youth-
centered plans, engaging with their constituents bringing the affairs of SK
closer to them, and providing visions on how for everyone to move forward. To
appeal to the interest of constituents might be challenging but the real
reasons of these young candidates should not be given up and turn to the
‘other tricks.’

Youth leaders can also consider encouraging one another to run for their
respective barangay. It is not easy to survive in an environment that might be
against your principles while you are a young leader either in schools or non-
government organizations, but the difficulty will surely be lessened if you
have other young leaders fighting for the same cause with the same passion to
service. As the campaign started, it would be helpful to forward a greater
cause if you build a genuine relationship with fellow SK candidates from other
barangays. This way, youth can prepare for a bigger avenue, the SK Pederasyon.

Where empowered SK Chairpersons knowing who they will be voting as SK
Pederasyon President. A coalition of SK across their localities who are for
the interest of their constituents and even for all the youth in general,
preparing to extend their service to their city, municipality, or province as
a federation. A federation is created or elected not just through bonding in
an outing, swimming, or gathering but because of the plans that they want to
do for their localities. This is crucial for the youth to know and understand
because according to Section 22 of SK Reform Law, as the head of the
federation, the SK Pederayon President, is an ex-officio member of the city
council, chairperson of relevant committees, have the same function as a city
councilor and power to bring the concerns of the youth citywide it might be
through proposing resolutions or even to author ordinances.

There is progress in the attainment of youth having a platform and space to
engage and participate in Philippine governance.

A coalition of SK across their localities who are for
the interest of their constituents and even for all the youth in general,
preparing to extend their service to their city, municipality, or province as
a federation. A federation is created or elected not just through bonding in
an outing, swimming, or gathering but because of the plans that they want to
do for their localities. This is crucial for the youth to know and understand
because according to Section 22 of SK Reform Law, as the head of the
federation, the SK Pederayon President, is an ex-officio member of the city
council, chairperson of relevant committees, have the same function as a city
councilor and power to bring the concerns of the youth citywide it might be
through proposing resolutions or even to author ordinances.

There is progress in the attainment of youth having a platform and space to
engage and participate in Philippine governance. In these upcoming elections,
Filipinos are not only voting for the Presidency but also the future of the
Presidency. They might disregard the role of youth, especially of the SK all
they want, but one thing is certain, that the youth is the only one who can
create its path, a path to the future of the Republic of the Philippines.

# Turning Dreams into Crowning Glory: Estephanie Ladignon’s Journey to Miss
University Belt 2024

Written by Viance Redoblado • Board by Joseph Andrei Torres | 9 February 24

One constant truth remains in the ever-changing adventure called life: the
world is a place for dreamers. Be it within the familiar space of home, in the
school environment, or outside one’s comfort zone, a dream always has a place
to grow and blossom. For this woman, the beauty pageant stage became the
birthplace of her greatest aspiration and an avenue to express her commitment
to advocacies close to her heart.

On January 27, Estephanie Gaebrielle Ladignon stepped into the stage of Miss
University Belt (U-Belt) 2024 and secured the crown as the representative of
the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM). Not only did she make the
Pamantasan proud that night, but her story also serves as one of the many
affirmations that dreaming loudly with a kind spirit takes anyone a step
closer to their destination.

It was in 2020 that Estephanie embarked on a new chapter in her life as she
began her journey as a first-year student at PLM, pursuing a degree in BSBA
Financial Management. The very same year, she started watering the roots of a
newfound dream to someday take home the crown at the annual intercollegiate
beauty contest, Miss U-Belt. This 2024, in her senior year, she graced the
pageant stage to claim the coveted crown she prayed for and rightfully earned
at the perfect time when she felt the most ready.

She approached the Miss U-Belt stage well-prepared, undergoing a series of
training sessions and a rigorous diet before the contest. Simultaneously, she
navigated the challenges of balancing work, her small clothing and accessories
business, and training–all while ensuring to not fall behind on her
responsibilities as a graduating student.

Sad as it is, despite being strong-willed, the world for women leaves, if not
enough, too much space for doubts and insecurities to linger. At one point,
she almost gave up, if not for the encouragement of her handler and her
strongest support system, her mother who gave her the push she needed.
Afterall, though she dreamt of bringing pride to the Pamantasan, undeterred by
adversities, her biggest inspiration is fulfilling a childhood dream she
envisioned with her mother.

Estephanie took her first step into the world of pageantry at the age of
eight. Faced with limited resources at this early stage in life, she learned
and cultivated resilience, resourcefulness, and an unwavering determination to
persevere. Today, she stands as an advocate for children, particularly young
girls, emphasizing the importance of receiving the proper support they need
and serving to inspire them to dream fearlessly for themselves. Firm in her
belief that children, regardless of their circumstances, deserve to achieve
their dreams without hindrance, she launched the Happy Feet Foundation by E,
an initiative where she allocates a portion of her pageant winnings for gift
giving projects, feeding programs, donation drives, and other charity events.

Estephanie took her first step into the world of pageantry at the age of
eight. Faced with limited resources at this early stage in life, she learned
and cultivated resilience, resourcefulness, and an unwavering determination to
persevere. Today, she stands as an advocate for children, particularly young
girls, emphasizing the importance of receiving the proper support they need
and serving to inspire them to dream fearlessly for themselves. Firm in her
belief that children, regardless of their circumstances, deserve to achieve
their dreams without hindrance, she launched the Happy Feet Foundation by E,
an initiative where she allocates a portion of her pageant winnings for gift
giving projects, feeding programs, donation drives, and other charity events.
Notably, though her primary advocacy focuses on children, she expressed in an
interview her openness to catering to diverse people and contributing to a
wide range of causes. In her commitment to her advocacies, she added her
desire to give back to various communities, including her home province, Nueva
Ecija.

Beyond her advocacy efforts, she braved beauty pageants with another goal: to
challenge conventional beauty standards. At 5’4”, she confidently stood,
radiating her morena beauty and showcasing her warm personality at each
pageant she participated in. Society’s predefined beauty norms, which once
contributed to her lack of confidence, now serve as a catalyst for her mission
to break stereotypes associated with societal expectations of beauty.

Throughout the journey, while getting crowned by Miss Universe Philippines
2023 Michelle Dee left a notable impact, the highlight of the entire
experience for Estephanie is the bond she forged with the other contestants.
According to her, the competition created a sisterhood of women who,
regardless of their different upbringings and personalities, collectively
aspire to bring great change with their advocacies. Beyond being just a
pageant, the event transformed into a safe space for the contestants to
express their individuality and voice out their stories.

In an interview with Ang Pamantasan, Estephanie shared that along with the
Miss U-Belt crown, she also took home a cash prize of Php 50,000 in which a
portion of it will be intended for her charity work. Furthermore, the Miss
U-Belt 2024 also received a grocery package and endorsement deals from Isetann
Malls as their ambassadress.

Estephanie expressed her sincerest gratitude to the PLM community for their
never-ending support throughout her journey towards the crown.

“Thank you so much sa pag-support. Alam kong ginawa natin yung best natin sa
pag-vovote. Sobrang maraming salamat. Also, sa mga nanood. May mga alumni na
nanood during the Miss University Belt, nakita ko sila doon. Mga schoolmates
ko, nakita ko [rin]. Sobrang-sobrang thank you sa mga support na binigay niyo,
hindi lang online, sa physical din. Sobrang dami [kong] support na natanggap
na doon pa lang, panalong-panalo na ako kasi alam ko na may mga tao na
naniniwala sa’kin,” Estephanie said.

_(Thank you so much for the support. I know we did our best on the online
voting. Thank you so much. Also, to those who watched. There were alumni who
watched the Miss University Belt, I saw them. To my schoolmates, who were also
there. Thank you so much for the support both online and physically. I have
received a lot of support and I felt like a winner from that alone, knowing
that there are people who believed in me.)_

Following her momentous win, she eagerly anticipates engaging in more charity
projects and evolving into a transformative leader. She aspires to have a
bigger platform and gracing more prominent pageant stages in the future–And
though she cannot promise anything to her mother whom she expressed great
admiration for, she vows to always stay humble.

Whether within the world of beauty pageants and beyond, Estephanie Ladignon’s
journey hopefully inspires students and children to enjoy the journey, never
give up and persevere in the face of challenges, and if dreaming is the only
thing they can afford for now then nothing should stop them.
