# PLM ChESS’ lack of fair report receives adverse opinion from PLM SCOA

Written by Raniel Paquingan • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 24 July 23

The PLM Student Commission on Audit (SCOA) regarded that the financial
statements submitted by the PLM Chemical Engineering Students’ Society (ChESS)
did not fairly present their financial position for AY 2022-2023, obtaining an
"adverse opinion", June 10.

Based on their report, the auditing commission cited the following as to why
they gave PLM ChESS such an audit opinion: usage of multiple GCash accounts in
their transactions, inconsistency in proper documentation of GCash
transactions, lack of signatures in the acknowledgement receipts and cash
disbursement forms issued, and failure to report and properly reflect all
transactions in the journals and in the financial report.

In order to address these issues, PLM ChESS must create a separate bank
account and an e-wallet bearing the organization’s name and establish a policy
that will ensure the efficient handling of funds in a virtual manner, as per
SCOA’s recommendation.

The commission also advised the involved party to observe proper recording and
documentation of transactions, wherein all forms must have signatures from
necessary officers for security and verification purposes.

Aside from these shortcomings, PLM ChESS also failed to present all the
information needed during the onsite audit. For this reason, SCOA reiterated
that it is the responsibility of the organization to provide the audit team
access to all information relevant to the auditing process.

Being the third highest out of the four audit opinions, an "adverse opinion"
means that the organization’s financial statements are not fairly presented in
accordance with the applicable financial reporting framework.

PLM ChESS is one of the two accredited academic organizations among 38, along
with Medical Alliance Rendering Service to Fellowmen, that received an
"adverse opinion" from the commission. The other 36 academic organizations
earned either the highest "unqualified opinion" or the following "qualified
opinion”.

# ISKUWENTO | ; Padayon

Written by Estelle Gulay • Board by John Ivan Pasion | 28 October 23

Napamulat ang mata sa paghaplos ng init ng liwanag sa aking mukha.

Pilit na bumabangon ngunit tila buhat ko yata ang isang kabang bigas sa bigat
ng aking katawan. Marahil tuluyan na ngang nagiba ng paulit-ulit na tampal ng
gawaing pang-akademiko at hampas ng alon ng mga pagsusulit ang inakala kong
matibay kong katawan, damdamin, at isipan. Ilang linggo nang walang gana’t
madalas na nakatingin sa kawalan – iniisip kung kailan matatapos ang kahirapan
na aking pasan hanggang sa labas ng paaralan.

Ito na yata ang epekto ng hindi pagpapahinga; ang pagkaligta sa kahalagahan ng
kagalingan buhat ng mga katagang muli't muling sinasambit hanggang sa tainga't
isip ay siya nang naka-ukit – “Padayon, iha, pag-asa ng pamilya; pag-asa ng
bayan.” Ngunit paano nga naman magpapatuloy kung ang kalagayan ng katawan at
isipan ay siya nang napabayaan? Kung sarili’y hindi na maibangon ng mga
katagang “laban lang; _okay_ ka pa; kung kaya nila, tiyak kaya mo pa.”

Kaya’t siguro nama’y ayos lang na sa araw na ito, ako muna’y hihiga – ako
muna’y hihinga; ipapahinga ang isip kong pagod na pagod na.

At marahil bukas sa muling paghaplos ng init ng liwanag sa aking mukha ay
manumbalik ang lakas na idaos ang lahat ng pagsubok na kinahaharap. Taas noong
magpapatuloy, dala ang mga katagang “Padayon, sarili, para sa 'yong bayan.”

# ESPORTS | Atomos Haribons dominates Golden Gears in OT thriller; finishes 4th after bowing to Teletigers Esports Club

Written by Alessandra C. Frianela • Pubmat by Elyse Abadilla | 12 December 22

The fight for greatness is not yet over for Haribons Esports’ Valorant team,
Atomos Haribons. They’ve slain the Bulacan State University's Golden Gears,
defeating them 2-1, in an overtime thriller in both, the second and third maps
of the Alliance Games Split 2 - Valorant playoffs. The match was broadcasted
live on AcadArena’s official Facebook page last Saturday, December 3. The
start of the match didn’t favor the Atomos Haribons. Golden Gears appeared to
claim the upper hand with remarkable strategic gameplay, making them secure
the first map. During the second map, both sides’ defensive and attacking
struggles were evident. The Golden Gears exhibited superiority in the first
half, but due to Atomos Haribons’ best effort, they managed to cut the lead of
the opposing team, bringing the score to 14-12 in their favor. Against all
odds, Haribon Esports’ team managed to push a do-or-die heading into the third
and final map of the match. The team seemed to gain back their confidence
which paved the way for their victory, ending the score 13-11, still in favor
of Atomos Haribons. The day didn’t end there, they were set to fight against
the winner of the second game. Atomos Haribons and UST Teletigers Esports
Club, the two winners from the first and second game of the day, fought their
way up to the semi-finals in the third match. The hopeful Atomos Haribons
continued to showcase their strategic moves with the goal of winning in mind.
Despite exhibiting prowess in the game, the team failed in claiming victory
against the opposing team. In the end, the UST Teletigers Esports Club was
able to snatch the chance for a podium finish with a score of 13-8, 13-4 in
both maps, officially ending the journey of the Atomos Haribons in the current
season.

# The PAWfect Companion from BS ARFchitecture

Written by Eunice Anny Morales • Board by Elysse Abadilla | 18 September 23

Imagine a day when nothing seems to be going your way, and you're overwhelmed
by exhaustion due to the never-ending list of tasks. The weight of
responsibilities presses you down, leaving you drained and stressed. But as
you get home, a tiny furball zooms its way to you with a very excited
expression on its face, as if exclaiming, _“I’m glad you are back!”_ In that
moment, all your weariness and fatigue melt as your pet licks away the traces
of sadness from your face.

A best friend, companion, family, and protector—that is how Mary Elaine A.
Esteller describeds her dog, Shihpooh. As Elaine recently graduated from
Bachelor of Science in Architecture, Shihpooh also wore a cap and earned her
degree in _Arf-chitecture._ The adorable graduation photo of Shihpooh quickly
captured the hearts and attention of many.

As Elaine stared at their wall and found an extra frame, she wanted to put her
pet’s graduation picture beside hers since Shihpooh is the youngest family
member after all. As they went to the studio, the seven-year-old dog proved
herself to be a _model student_ displaying a calm behavior, who does not bark
at strangers even during the photo session.

**Indeed, she deserves her own toga.**

Being a night owl was an inherent part of Elaine's student life as an
architecture major. Yet, this posed no issue for her pet, who rooted for
Elaine and even pulled all-nighters alongside her. Acting as Elaine's
protector, Shihpooh is also concerned about her owner’s well-being. Whenever
Elaine’s family attempts to wake her up, Shihpooh was there to fulfill her ten
more minutes of sleep, warding off any disturbances. Even when Elaine's own
mother once reprimanded her, Shihpooh stood guard, ensuring that the scolding
never felt too severe.

Naturally, there were moments when Elaine found herself at her lowest point.
Being part of the pioneer batch of Senior High School under the K-12
Curriculum, adding two extra years to her academic journey, making the already
demanding architecture program, which typically spans five years, even more
challenging. Then, the pandemic struck, further bringing a multitude of
unforeseen adjustments. There were instances when Elaine felt overwhelmed by
the weight of school work and life's general challenges. Fortunately, Shihpooh
was always there as her unwavering emotional support especially during these
trying times. Even though she looks confused while Elaine is crying, she never
fails to sleep beside her, not leaving her side as if silently assuring her
that she is not alone and everything will be okay after this day.

Elaine knew that the road ahead may still hold its share of challenges, but
Shihpooh’s presence became her constant reminder that in the face of
adversity, there was always a four-legged friend who believed in her and stood
by her side.

Becoming a fur-parent is no small responsibility.

Then, the pandemic struck, further bringing a multitude of
unforeseen adjustments. There were instances when Elaine felt overwhelmed by
the weight of school work and life's general challenges. Fortunately, Shihpooh
was always there as her unwavering emotional support especially during these
trying times. Even though she looks confused while Elaine is crying, she never
fails to sleep beside her, not leaving her side as if silently assuring her
that she is not alone and everything will be okay after this day.

Elaine knew that the road ahead may still hold its share of challenges, but
Shihpooh’s presence became her constant reminder that in the face of
adversity, there was always a four-legged friend who believed in her and stood
by her side.

Becoming a fur-parent is no small responsibility. It's a commitment that may
start as a simple decision, but evolves into a profound connection that
enriches your life in ways you could never have imagined. In their eyes, you
become their universe, so it would only be fitting to cherish your pets as you
would your own child, for they deserve every ounce of love and care you can
offer in return.

After all, despite occupying just a fragment of your daily life, their
devotion knows no bounds. As Elaine aptly puts it, **_" Kung graduate na ako,
graduate na rin siya" _**– underscoring the enduring bond between a devoted
fur-parent and their eternal companion.

# First Day Fight: Students call for free quality education to all; admin
holds dialogue

Written by Calvin Agustin & John Coby Cabuhat • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz & Stefanie Santilla • Photo by Dean Joseph Palapar | 1 September 23

“Libreng edukasyon para sa lahat” was the cry of the student councils,
National Democratic Mass Organizations (NDMOs), and students of Pamantasan ng
Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) during the ‘First Day Fight’ mobilization on the
opening of classes, Aug. 29.

Panday Sining-National, PLM Propaganda, Gabriela Youth PLM, Anakbayan PLM,
STAND PLM, and the PLM Supreme Student Council (SSC) spearheaded the said
mobilization in line with PLM’s possible delistment from the Commission on
Higher Education (CHED) Unified Financial Assistance System (UniFAST)
reimbursement program.

The students also pushed forward other PLM demands identified by the
aforementioned NDMOs.

PLM Propaganda called for the inclusion of uniform policies in the Student
Manual, mandatory gender and development (GAD) training, mandatory ROTC, and
SOGIE Bill.

In addition, Gabriela Youth PLM raised awareness on the unresolved cases of
harassment while STAND PLM called for higher subsidy, quality education, and
SAP distribution.

They also expressed their stance on Irregulars, Shiftees and Transferees,
sexual harassment cases, mandatory ROTC, and the right to free tertiary
education.

PLM-SSC President Vince Edrick De Guzman expressed his gratitude to the
student activists who consistently help the council to amplify and raise
concerns to the PLM administration.

“Ako ay lubos na nagpapasalamat na kahit papaano ay may katulad nilang mga
estudyante na, ating mga student activists na buong puso talagang kanilang
binibigay ang kanilang makakaya para mapakinggan din ang mga PLM demands ng
bawat estudyante, lalo [na’t] tayo ang biggest stakeholders ng pamantasan,” De
Guzman said.

The said protest was set to be done outside the university premises. Later on,
members from the Philippine National Police arrived at the vicinity and
started asking for names according to one of its participants.

Meanwhile, University President Emmanuel Leyco allowed the students to conduct
the protest inside the PLM premises.

"Ang pamantasan ay isang malayang pamantasan na malayang mamahayag ang ating
mga estudyante. At kung mayroong bisita, okay lang yun na sila ay pumunta
dito. Ngayon, walang mga CSW (completed staff work) pa eh pero pinayagan na
natin pero sa susunod, mayroon tayong mga steps, kailangan mayroong mga CSW
para malinaw [at] maayos ang ating mga program," Leyco said.

After the mobilization, the PLM president held a dialogue with the SSC and
student organizations to address their concerns all at once.

Meanwhile, University President Emmanuel Leyco allowed the students to conduct
the protest inside the PLM premises.

"Ang pamantasan ay isang malayang pamantasan na malayang mamahayag ang ating
mga estudyante. At kung mayroong bisita, okay lang yun na sila ay pumunta
dito. Ngayon, walang mga CSW (completed staff work) pa eh pero pinayagan na
natin pero sa susunod, mayroon tayong mga steps, kailangan mayroong mga CSW
para malinaw [at] maayos ang ating mga program," Leyco said.

After the mobilization, the PLM president held a dialogue with the SSC and
student organizations to address their concerns all at once.

With the ongoing education crisis, Leyco noted that the university will not be
capable of covering the tuition fee of 18,000 students, which doubled from
previously 9,000. Moreover, he added that the university opened its gates to
non-Manilan students all over the country.

SSC Treasurer Sophia Rhyzel Pitero asked the president if there were updates
regarding the UniFAST issue. PLM has already responded to CHED emphasizing
that it is a chartered university, therefore, PLM shall not be required to
comply with the requirements set for local universities and colleges.

The university president further explained that this is not an issue of the
president’s lack of a doctorate degree because the PLM Charter does not
require such, similar with the case of Unibersidad ng Pilipinas.

SSC Vice President Jam Iris Paglicawan and PLM Business School College
Representative Rey Lagoc asked Leyco on the abolishment of the retention
policy.

“Malaking usapin ang retention policy dahil ito ang pundasyon ng kalidad.
Hindi rin kaya natin na ibaba nang ibaba. Pag recon nga, nagre-recon tayo eh.
Pero pagdating sa retention, unang reason, mag-aral tayo talaga,” Leyco
replied.

On the matter of the dress code and uniform policy, Leyco said that it is the
students who decided on these through a survey. Regardless, it is ensured that
students can freely wear clothes of preference, befitting their gender
identity.

Leyco emphasized that PLM recognizes the students’ rights to freedom of speech
and expression, and that the university is with them in pushing free tertiary
education forward.

“Hindi natin susupulin ang inyong karapatan mamahayag. Liwanagin din natin ang
isyung pambansa, isyung pang-edukasyon, [at] isyung pang-pamantasan,” Leyco
said.

As the program and dialogue concluded, Leyco assured the students that PLM is
with them in ensuring that their right to free quality education shall be
asserted once again.

In an interview with Ang Pamantasan, SSC Treasurer Pitero assured that the
council and other student and mass organizations are one in advancing PLM
student demands.

“Tinutulungan namin ang administration na ilatag din yung demand na ibigay
yung para sa mga estudyante and yung ini-ensure - binibigyan naman tayo ng
assurance ng Presidente natin na hindi tayo magbabayad ng tuition fee at wala
tayong babayaran na tutiton fee, at hindi tayo iiwanan dun sa laban natin na
libreng edukasyon para sa lahat,” Pitero added.

# We Are Called To Bring Out The Heroism in Others

Written by President Domingo Reyes Jr. • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 30 December 23

 _“Let the New Year—and the years to come—always bring out the silent heroism
in us: to be somebody’s hero and to bring out the heroism in others.”_

As we commemorate the martyrdom of our National Hero, Dr. Jose Rizal, allow me
to share my reflections when a student once asked me about my thoughts
regarding him.

In high school, I was not given the opportunity to read Rizal’s masterpieces
_—_ the “Noli Me Tangere” and the “El Filibusterismo.” In college, I had the
“Works of Rizal” as a subject and was tasked to memorize “Mi Ultimo Adios”
whose first stanza I remember until today. In spite of these close chances to
delve more into this hero’s life, when I was asked for my thoughts regarding
him, I could not think of anything that I could say about the great man. Aside
from Ambeth Ocampo’s articles in the Philippine Daily Inquirer, my knowledge
and understanding of Rizal’s life and works remain much to be desired.

One day, I chanced upon a scene in the movie “Rizal” when he was being shot at
Luneta (formerly “Bagumbayan”). While it was a moving picture of his
martyrdom, it was not really Rizal that caught my attention. It was the
soldiers that aimed their firearms and fired at Rizal on that fateful morning
of December 30, 1898 which forever sealed his fate as a hero and changed the
course of Philippine History. Numerous questions filled my mind _—_ Who were
they? What was going on in the minds of these soldiers when they were chosen
to be part of the execution? What were they thinking when they aimed their
rifles and shot Rizal? Was there remorse? Were they even aware of what was
going on, its impact?_—_ questions I know I would never know the answers to. I
could only speculate.

With this, I believe that heroism is a destiny that heroes were unprepared
for. To some extent, it is probably unwanted _—_ but it is never planned and
never ambitioned. Rizal, like the other heroes, just allowed the circumstances
to happen and unfold as they should and did what ought to have been done on
those present and precise moments of their martyrdom. I also want to believe
that they did what they believed was the right thing to do. It was the choices
heroes made that made the difference. However, in the process, either good or
bad, I want to believe that there is a need for other people, like the
soldiers, for a hero to reach his or her destiny. In a manner, I think that we
need others to bring about heroism in us and in others as well.

As we are always called to heroism, we should not aim to be heroes only by
mere verbal declarations. To be such would be self-serving that will defeat
the very essence of heroism that is the selfless service of oneself for the
greater good of others without expecting anything or any recognition in
return.

I also want to believe
that they did what they believed was the right thing to do. It was the choices
heroes made that made the difference. However, in the process, either good or
bad, I want to believe that there is a need for other people, like the
soldiers, for a hero to reach his or her destiny. In a manner, I think that we
need others to bring about heroism in us and in others as well.

As we are always called to heroism, we should not aim to be heroes only by
mere verbal declarations. To be such would be self-serving that will defeat
the very essence of heroism that is the selfless service of oneself for the
greater good of others without expecting anything or any recognition in
return. To be heroes is not to merely think, feel, and act courageously like
heroes _—_ it is to be plainly sincere, and be so selfless to offer oneself as
sacrifice for the sake of others in the altar of righteousness.

After contemplating the heroism exhibited by mortals, it becomes compelling to
shift our focus to the ultimate exemplar: Jesus. In all His divinity, Jesus
Christ is the existential hero of all time. He is the ultimate hero that
descended from heaven for the redemption of the world as His life of service
and suffering is the perfect template of what heroism is all about. Amidst His
heart’s desire to take away the cup [of divine wrath] from Him, He set aside
His divinity and allowed Himself to be sacrificed for our redemption and the
salvation of the world.

We are not after the magnitude of the heroism that our heroes and that of
Jesus have done for all of us. We may not be destined to be the popular heroes
that we want to. Nonetheless, we are called upon to be silent heroes, or to be
another person’s hero, as simple acts of kindness, charity, and service are
more than enough to be considered heroic acts. Who knows, our destiny may not
be to become the kind of heroes we want to be but to bring out the heroism in
others _—_ that is heroism in itself.

Let the New Year _—_ and the years to come _—_ always bring out the silent
heroism in us: to be somebody’s hero, and to bring out the heroism in others.

May the blessings and graces of the New Year be with us all!

# Binibini at Ginoong Pamantasan 2024 officially commences

Written by Calvin Agustin • Photo by Dean Joseph Palapar | 18 June 24

Candidates and students from various colleges gathered as the Binibini at
Ginoong Pamantasan 2024 Preliminary Competition began at the Justo Albert
Auditorium, June 18.

This part of the pageant showcased the sports, casual attire, and talents of
each candidate from the College of Business Administration; College of
Nursing; College of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences; and College of
Business Administration.

Present in the event are the esteemed panel of judges, Office of Student
Development and Services Acting Director, Dr. Lynnette Cleto; Vice President
for Academic Research and Extension Services, Dr. Dan Michael Cortez; Vice
President for Administration, Dr. Ronaldo Tan; and University President, Atty.
Domingo "Sir Sonny" Reyes, Jr.

Candidates also presented their personal advocacies and passion projects
through their advocacy videos.

The preliminary competition will conclude with the Coronation Night of
Binibini at Ginoong Pamantasan 2024 at JAA on June 20, Friday.

# IN PHOTOS | PLM Intramurals Awarding 2023

Caption and Photos by Charyll Joan Pascua and Roland Justin Molato | 4 March 24

The PLM Intramurals, which commenced in July 2023, have finally concluded with
the closing ceremony that took place today at the PLM Gymnasium. The event was
attended by PLM student-athletes and faculty members from various colleges as
well as the PLM President, who emphasized the importance of integrating sports
into students’ academic life. The president also mentioned being in talks with
various universities for an intercollegiate sports event.

# SSC Auditor follows resignation of PRO from the council

Written by Mark Anthony Montalban • Board by Arjay Samson | 30 November 23

The PLM Supreme Student Council (SSC) gave its formal consent for the
resignation of Jannel F. Letrero, the Acting Auditor of the council, Nov. 20.

Through Resolution No. 18, S. 2023, the PLM SSC ratified Letrero's stepping
down from the highest student-governing body in the University.

She expressed that the unbefitting behavior of some "student leaders"
negatively impacted her mental and physical well-being. She is among the
victims of the alleged bullying in the council.

In her resignation letter, the former Auditor emphasized her inability to
function well in a toxic and unproductive working environment.

"This has had a negative impact on my mental and physical well-being, which is
why I'll be leaving my position and choosing to safeguard my mental health,"
Letrero remarked.

Although grateful for being given the opportunity to hold her post, she
laments her experience with her co-officers and demands accountability for the
injustice and lack of action.

"You have caused damage not only to your victims but also to the entire
student body. Individuals like you have no place or right in the council and
within the Pamantasan," Letrero declared.

# Araw ng mga Guro: Lipas na Pagpupugay sa Ilaw ng Karunungan

Written by Jan Rennie Abat • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 4 October 23

Mabuhay sa ating mga dalubguro, ang mga ilaw ng karunungan na isinasapuso ang
pagtuturo! Mula sa bukang-liwayway na dama ang init ng araw hanggang sa
pagdating ng takipsilim na dama ang lamig ng hangin, patuloy na nagpapa-usbong
ng edukasyon.

Idineklara ng United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
ang ikalima ng Oktubre bilang Araw ng mga Guro noong 1994. Gayunpaman, sa
kabila ng mga papuri, pagpupugay, at pagdiriwang ng mga lumipas na Araw ng mga
Guro, tila ang kanilang pagod at paghihikahos ay hindi kayang tumbasan ng
kanilang sweldo buwan-buwan.

Sa paglipas ng apat na taon mula nang isinabatas ang Republic Act 11466 o
Salary Standardization Law na nagdadagdag ng sahod sa mga empleyado ng
gobyerno. Kumikita lamang ng P29,165 (Salary Grade 12) ang Instructor 1 sa mga
akreditadong state universities and colleges (SUC) ng Commission on Higher
Education (CHED), hindi pa kasama ang bawas sa buwis. Kaya’t hindi
maipagkakaila na marami pa ring mga propesyunal sa larangan ng edukasyon ang
nahalina’t piniling tugisin ang mataas na suweldong alok ng dayuhang lupain.

Bunga nito ay ang labis na naiwang mga bakanteng posisyon sa pagtuturo.
Naitala ng Department of Budget and Management (DBM) na mayroong 140 na
bakanteng posisyon sa CHED, samantalang 938 naman ang bilang ng mga tauhang
kailangan ng Technical Education and Skills Development Authority . Sa dami ng
mga mag-aaral ngayong taon, ang mga naulat na kakulangan sa plantilya ay isang
katibayan ng kakapusan sa bilang ng ating mga ilaw ng karunungan.

Maliban sa mababang sweldo para sa mga guro, babagsak ng mahigit ₱11.45 bilyon
ang pondo para sa edukasyon na siyang sumasalamin sa pagkakaltas ng isang
makabuluhang bahagdan – 27 porsyento – ng laang-salapi para sa sektor ng
pakatuto.

Sa dami ng
mga mag-aaral ngayong taon, ang mga naulat na kakulangan sa plantilya ay isang
katibayan ng kakapusan sa bilang ng ating mga ilaw ng karunungan.

Maliban sa mababang sweldo para sa mga guro, babagsak ng mahigit ₱11.45 bilyon
ang pondo para sa edukasyon na siyang sumasalamin sa pagkakaltas ng isang
makabuluhang bahagdan – 27 porsyento – ng laang-salapi para sa sektor ng
pakatuto. Partikular, mula sa halagang ₱107.037 bilyon noong nakaraang taon ay
magiging ₱100.88 bilyon na lang ang pondong ilalaan ng DBM para sa 2024
National Expenditure Program.

“Additional budget is needed for our learning institutions to regain their
public character and provide ample support for student services and faculty
development. If our state universities and colleges are to be expected to do
their duties, they must be funded accordingly,” tugon ng 36 na presidente ng
SUCs sa kanilang pahayag ng pagkakaisa laban sa pagkaltas ng pondo ng
kongreso.

Dagdag pa rito, isang panawagan at panghihikayat ang iniwan ng Kabataan Party-
list Rep. Raoul Manuel para sa mga magulang, mag-aaral, at mga guro – patuloy
lamang ipaglaban ang nararapat na edukasyon para sa pag-asa ng bayan.

Mataas na bilang ng mga mag-aaral, labis-labis na mga bakanteng posisyon,
mababang sweldo at pondo- iyan lamang ang iilan sa mga suliraning hinaharap at
kahaharapin ng mga tagapagsulong ng edukasyon. Sa mga papugay na ibinibigay
dala ng lumipas na Araw ng mga Guro, mataas na sweldo at sapat na pondo ang
kanilang nais dinggin. Datapwa’t sa kabila ng mga ito, patuloy pa rin ang
pagpasok sa apat na sulok ng silid-aralan – tuloy ang pagsindi ng ilaw ng
karunungan.

# SineHaribon: Ang Pagtanggap sa Pagsibol ng Bagong Tradisyon

Written by Jamilla Marie Matias • Board by Arjay Samson | 7 June 24

Umikot na ang mga lente ng _camera_. Sumunod ang malakas na sambit ng “
_action!”_ Kasabay nito’y binigyang hustisya ng mga aktor ang mga hinabing
diyalogo ng mga manunulat – damang-dama, walang puknit ang galing, walang
mapagsidlan ng damdamin. Hanggang umabot sa “ _cut_!” — tagumpay ang pagkuha
sa eksena kaya naman baklas na; hudyat ng pagpalaya ng hiningang kaakibat ay
ginhawa.

Sa ganitong mga senaryo umiikot ang mundo ng pelikula. May pag timpla ng
anggulo, may pagkalkal sa bawat yugto, at may mithiing iparating ang mga
kwentong sumisimbolo sa maraming anyo at istilo ng pamumuhay ng mga tao sa
mundo. Kaya naman hindi maitatatwa ang kahalagahan ng pelikula sa sining at
kultura dahil patuloy nitong minumulat ang mga manonood sa iba’t ibang talamak
na pangyayari sa lipunan.

Buhat nito, isinakatuparan ng PLM Independent Film and Arts (PIFA) ang
SineHaribon. Layunin nitong tipunin ang mga mag-aaral na nagnanais maghayag ng
mga istorya gamit ang mga malilikhaing pelikula. Daan din ito upang mas lalo
pang pagyabungin ang sining sa loob ng Pamantasan.

**Mga Haligi ng Produksiyon**

Pagkukwento ni Anna Sophia Valdez, Promotions & Coordination Head ng
SineHaribon, ang naturang proyekto ng PIFA ay hinango sa kolektibong pangarap
ng mga kasapi ng organisasyon na makabuo ng kultura na nakatuon sa paglikha ng
pelikula hindi lamang sa loob ng kanilang samahan bagkus para sa buong mag-
aaral sa loob ng Pamantasan.

“Alam namin na maraming mahuhusay na estudyanteng manlilikha sa Pamantasan.
Sadyang hindi lang sila nabibigyan ng plataporma para ipamalas ang kanilang
talento sa larangan ng sining at pelikula. Kaya bilang mga alagad ng sining,
kaming mga miyembro ng PIFA na mismo ang gumawa ng inisyatibo para pagyabungin
pa ang diwa ng pagpepelikula”, saad niya.

“Alam namin na maraming mahuhusay na estudyanteng manlilikha sa Pamantasan.
Sadyang hindi lang sila nabibigyan ng plataporma para ipamalas ang kanilang
talento sa larangan ng sining at pelikula. Kaya bilang mga alagad ng sining,
kaming mga miyembro ng PIFA na mismo ang gumawa ng inisyatibo para pagyabungin
pa ang diwa ng pagpepelikula”, saad niya.

Naibahagi rin niya ang ilan sa mga pagsubok na kanilang kinaharap sa
pagtataguyod ng nasabing okasyon. Ilan dito ay ang kakulangan sa tao, hindi
tukoy na pagpaplano, at kawalan ng sapat na pananalapi. Ngunit sa kabila ng
mga ito, tagumpay pa rin nilang naisakatuparan at nalampasan ang mga hamong
nagdaan bunga ng sama-samang pagsisikap, dedikasyon, at kooperasyon ng mga
haligi ng produksiyon na siyang lubos na pinagpapasalamat ni Anna.

Dagdag pa niya, bagamat walang karampatang salaping gantimpala para sa mga
nanalo at lumahok, batid niyang napaglingkuran nila ang mga batang manggagawa
ng pelikula nang buong puso sa abot ng kanilang makakaya. Hiling niya rin na
sana’y naging daan ang SineHaribon upang mas higit pang yumabong ang
kagustuhan ng mga ito sa paggawa ng pelikula.

**Sa Lente ng mga Manonood**

Sa lente ng mga manonood tulad ni Jan Ella Almerol mula sa Bachelor of Arts in
Communication, ang mga ganitong patimpalak ay napakahalaga sapagkat nagbibigay
ito ng plataporma sa mga estudyante upang mas lalo pang palawigin ang
kakayahang lumikha ng mga kwentong sumasalamin sa estado at gawi ng buhay ng
mga Pilipino. Kung kaya’t labis ang kanyang tuwa at paghanga sa mga kapwa mag-
aaral na lumahok sapagkat nailahad at naipikita ng walong tampok na pelikula
ang reyalidad ng buhay — may saya, lungkot, pagkabigo, pagtanggap, at
tagumpay.

Paglalahad pa niya, naisipan diumano niyang sumali sa naturang proyekto ng
PIFA ngunit dahil sa kakapusan sa oras ay hindi niya ito nagawa. “May story na
ako on mind and like possible production team, unfortunately hindi lang kinaya
ng oras since busy masyado with academic responsibilities. But hopefully, on
the next year, makapagpasa ako, kami ng mga friends ko and I’m very looking
forward to that”, aniya.

Ayon naman kay Aisac James De Leon mula sa College of Business Administration,
isang matagal na pag-aantay ang pagsibol ng SineHaribon lalo pa’t bukas ito
hindi lamang sa mga mag-aaral ng komunikasyon sa paaralan ngunit pati na rin
sa ibang kurso. “Honestly natuwa at na-excite ako nung mabalitaan kong
magkakaroon ng ganitong film fest sa Pamantasan. Dahil karamihan sa mga film
fest na nagdaan ay open lamang sa mga communication students, sa tulong ng
SineHaribon mas nabigyan ng lawak ang mga estudyante na nais maglahad ng
kanilang kwento. Nakakatuwa na mas nagkakaroon ng malaking entablado para sa
mga filmmakers sa loob ng ating Pamantasan”, saad niya.

Gaya ni Ella, ninais din ni Aisac na ibahagi ang kanyang nabuong istorya
subalit dulot ng mga personal na kadahilanan at responsibilidad na mas dapat
unahin ay bigo rin siyang makasama rito.

“Honestly natuwa at na-excite ako nung mabalitaan kong
magkakaroon ng ganitong film fest sa Pamantasan. Dahil karamihan sa mga film
fest na nagdaan ay open lamang sa mga communication students, sa tulong ng
SineHaribon mas nabigyan ng lawak ang mga estudyante na nais maglahad ng
kanilang kwento. Nakakatuwa na mas nagkakaroon ng malaking entablado para sa
mga filmmakers sa loob ng ating Pamantasan”, saad niya.

Gaya ni Ella, ninais din ni Aisac na ibahagi ang kanyang nabuong istorya
subalit dulot ng mga personal na kadahilanan at responsibilidad na mas dapat
unahin ay bigo rin siyang makasama rito. Sa kabilang dako, hiling niya namang
mas makilala pa ang _film festival_ na ito at makapagtampok ng _full-length_
na pelikula at maisama ang dokumentaryo bilang kategorya.

**Ang Pagdaloy ng Tradisyon**

Malaki ang naging papel ng Cinematheque sa tagumpay na tinamasa ng SineHaribon
sa pagsibol nito. Dulot ng mga pook tampukan na ibinihagi ng Cinematheque,
naipaabot sa iba’t ibang tagapanood hindi lamang sa loob ng eskwelahan ang
walong pelikulang bumida sa unang taon ng SineHaribon.

Para kay Mx. Jen Lopez, Project Development Officer ng Cinematheque, marahil
isang aral ang pakikipag-ugnayan sa PIFA sapagkat nabatid nilang marami pang
mga kabataan ang may kakayahang lumikha at magpahayag ng kanilang kwento gamit
ang pelikula. “Learning ito para sa amin. Dahil nalaman namin na may iba pang
students na aspiring, ginaganahan kami na lalong tumulong sa mga estudyante,
hindi lang sa mga current na mga filmmakers but also sa mga aspiring
filmmakers pa na darating”, aniya.

Ayon pa sa kanya, handa nilang tulungan ang SineHaribon sa mga susunod pang
taon upang magkaroon pa ng mas maraming manonood para bigyang halaga ang mga
pelikula. Nailahad niya rin na labis siyang natuwa sa _talkback session_ dahil
naipapakita rito ang layuning nais iparating ng mga manlilikha ng pelikula.
“Nagustuhan ko rin yung not just the film but also ‘yung nangyaring talkback
kung saan na-engage ‘yung audience para magtanong, kung ano yung mga ideas ng
filmmakers which is actually kapag ‘yung mga student-filmmakers natin ngayon,
if gusto nilang i-pursue pa [ang] pagiging filmmaker, malaking help ‘yon kasi
nakaka boost ‘yon ng confidence as aspiring filmmakers”, saad niya.

Dagdag pa rito ang isang mensaheng nais niyang iparating sa mga nagmimithing
gumawa ng pelikula sa hinaharap. “Kapag may naririnig kayong negative
criticism take that as positive kasi dapat ginagamit nyo siya as learning. Sa
mga aspiring filmmakers huwag kayong madadown kapag may sinasabi sa inyong
comments na hindi maganda about sa film nyo but gamitin nyo siyang motivation
para mas mag-improve pa”, wika niya.

Sa pagdaloy ng tradisyong ito sa Pamantasan, mas lalo pa sanang sumibol ang
kagustuhan ng mga mag-aaral na maipakita at maipahatid ang kanilang likhang
kwento sa madla. Nawa’y ang pag-agos ng bagong tradisyong ito ay magdulot pa
ng mas progresibo at maunlad na sining sa Pamantasan.

# Peanut Butter

Written by Ella Mae De Asis • Board by John Ivan Pasion | 28 April 24

Gimme one!

So sweet yet so vicious

Not knowing what it is

So volatile yet dripping like liquid gold

It was never bland nor cold

Yet every beat makes us liable

But why must it be so—unidentifiable?

What is it? What are we?

Must it always be a mystery?

In its surface, no mark, no spot, not a clue

“Why not with a name that’ll compliment you?”

“Why even settle for this?”

“Is it worth it for a little bliss?”

Our tastes may not coincide

Though it’s hard to hide

No traces, no tracks, no right

—I dream of it every night

The soothing words, the sugar rush

The sliding of our spoons, every blush

Irreplaceable, no one can condone

I solely want this, and this alone.

I couldn't focus, I was enthralled, enchanted

Never did one graze put me in a trance

I'd keep this privilege for any price

I'd pull every existing heist for this spice

A diamond in the rough—the ultimate rarity

Even if given all the pearls in the sea...

I wouldn't trade this feeling, not for an eternity.

The risk, the thrill, the uncertainty

A plot against the ordinary, fascinated in ambiguity.

Stubborn hearts know what they want

Laugh of the present above the pryers’ taunt

Savored every minute, heart and mind

The chase is fun but a faster one draws near

A harsh slap of reality, a lingering fear

Not by hook nor crook, but merely tangling the line

Even if I turned the world supine...

It stands, I never got to call you mine.

The jar's still blank

and I guess… _that 's fine._

# smooch pit

Written by Rommel Lacambra • Board by Angelle Valbuena | 28 February 24

hold me so tender

— an audible kiss

one turns to many

— the luck of the draw

was there a time you are here

where i am

or is it all in the waiting that tells

we co-existed

deserted in the heat

of lips as it sits

on the very heavy part, on the interim much of time

more likely to be one's thirst

had you do it over and over again

straddled, brushing against the run

a round for few laps, less of a sound

pit-landing per millisecond

mesothermal on its arrival

— romance demands

gentle as the dream

warm akin to a fever

passing from right here

to there, then mine

to you— an audible kiss

# APEx DAY 1 CONCLUDED

Caption by Dean Palapar • Photos by Roland Justin Molato and Estelle Theresa Gulay | 22 November 23

Ang Pamantasan officially concludes the first day of the Ang Pamantasan
Examination (APEx) 2023, this day, November 23, at the Bukod Tanging Bulwagan.

This year's APEx had a total of 24 examinees. They will proceed on the second
day of APEx tomorrow for their interview examination

# PLM SSC President comments on SSC issue on International Students’ Day

Written by Calvin Agustin • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 20 November 23

Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) Supreme Student Council (SSC) President
Vince Edrick De Guzman addressed the students, as well as the still on-going
issue of bullying during the International Students’ Day celebration, Nov. 17.

In a flash interview with Ang Pamantasan, De Guzman gave his message to the
student community in line with the said celebration. He said that with this
commemoration, they are also recognizing not only the big achievements of the
students, but also the small ones, even from those in the various sectors that
the students contribute to.

Given the number of concerns from students regarding the SSC bullying issue,
the council president was asked for updates in addressing such.

“Actually, nasa process pa rin tayo ng pagtetake din ng action, especially
nandun pa rin naman yung mga college representatives natin na tinitignan din
yung case natin. Though, nandoon din yung side na mayroon din tayong guidance
from the SSC advisers, and of course, yung OSDS na nagmemediate and nag-
gaguide din sa mga concerns na nireraise ng students, lalo na yung concerns sa
SSC issue,” De Guzman said.

The SSC President was also asked for his comments regarding the recent
resignation of former Public Relations Officer Joseph Andrei Torres.

“Napag-usapan naman namin ito before. We understand din na ayun yung reason
niya but of course, moving forward, kailangan din namin tignan kung ano yung
naging pagkukulang. Syempre, napakalaking bahagi rin ng pagkawala ng posisyon
ni Mr. Torres sa SSC. Kailangan din namin agad magmove forward para maghanap
ng bagong PRO or kahit yung OIC lang mismo,” he said.

accountability](https://www.facebook.com/story.php?story_fbid=742148774609766&id=100064439512133&mibextid=WC7FNe)

# Ika-38 na taong anibersaryo ng People Power Revolution

Caption and Photos by Janelle Ugot | 25 February 24

Iba't ibang miyembro ng sektor ng lipunan ang nagsama-sama sa ikinasang kilos
protesta upang gunitain ang ika-38 na taong anibersaryo ng People Power
Revolution, kahapon, Pebrero 25, sa harap ng EDSA Shrine. Kasabay ng pag-alala
ang kolektibong panawagang tutulan ang isinusulong na Cha-Cha sa Kamara.

Matatandaang inulan ng batikos ang Palasyo dahil sa pag-alis nito ng EDSA
People Power Anniversary sa opisyal na listahan ng special non-working days
ngayong taon.

# In-SAP-ficient

Written by Zarena C. Hermogeno • Board by Joseph Andrei Torres | 13 December 23

Students of Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) are now overjoyed after the
recent release of the supposed monthly Social Amelioration Program (SAP)
allowance, they’ve waited months to arrive. As the bountiful Christmas season
inches closer to these SAP recipients, for other students in the Pamantasan,
it's just another holiday to pass.

PLM, along with the Universidad de Manila, is among the two recognized public
higher institutions for residents in the City of Manila. Since its approval 5
years ago, both undergraduates of PLM and UDM receive 1,000 Php monthly cash
allowance (better known as SAP) under [City Ordinance No.
8568](https://citycouncilofmanila.com.ph/city_ordinances/ordinance-
no-8568-2/#:~:text=AN%20ORDINANCE%20PROVIDING%20ONE%20THOUSAND,THEREOF%20AND%20FOR%20OTHER%20PURPOSES)
to ease their financial constraints.

Aside from being known as a production factory of licensure exam topnotchers
and a highly-esteemed medical school, the SAP allowance is another hook for
aspiring haribons.

Besides, what more could you ask for? Pursuing your tertiary education for
free and being paid subsequently in doing so is every financially-challenged
student’s dream.

And just like any other dreams one may have, not all of it do come true.

As stated in Sec. 5 of the ordinance, only those students who are bonafide
residents and registered voters of Manila are qualified for the cash
allowance.

At plainsight, this seems to be reasonable, the university’s name is
“Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila” (University of the City of Manila) after
all, of course it targets Manila residents.

**However, viewing this angle also places students who are non-Manila
residents on its periphery.**

In retrospect, PLM owns up to its moniker being the “People’s University”.
Throughout the years of admissions, Manila’s premiere university also takes in
students who reside or come from schools outside the city. Based on recent
(available) statistics from the 2021 PLM Admissions Test (PLMAT) results, 35%
of the total passers are non-Manilans. A year prior to that, 1,700 students
comprised the 5,000 first-year students to be admitted for the academic year
2020-2021.

**Though such a miniscule number compared to the university’s population, they
should not be treated as a minority. Every student should at least reap the
same equitable benefits.**

It is because of the reason that each student has their own life to bear with
and academic burdens to tread. One should not assume that a non-Manila
resident who chose to study in the Pamantasan, despite the free tuition, can
actually afford to study.

Personally, I know friends and colleagues who shell out hundreds of pesos each
day just to attend an hour of lecture or a minutes-worth of group
meeting.There are also those who are in the middle of their 3-hour trip, only
for their professor to cancel that single class for the day.

A year prior to that, 1,700 students
comprised the 5,000 first-year students to be admitted for the academic year
2020-2021.

**Though such a miniscule number compared to the university’s population, they
should not be treated as a minority. Every student should at least reap the
same equitable benefits.**

It is because of the reason that each student has their own life to bear with
and academic burdens to tread. One should not assume that a non-Manila
resident who chose to study in the Pamantasan, despite the free tuition, can
actually afford to study.

Personally, I know friends and colleagues who shell out hundreds of pesos each
day just to attend an hour of lecture or a minutes-worth of group
meeting.There are also those who are in the middle of their 3-hour trip, only
for their professor to cancel that single class for the day. And let’s not
forget about the students in those courses who allot more than they could
budget for transportation to routinely purchase supplies for academic
purposes.

These concerns are just the tip of the iceberg but are enough to prove how
committed students are in their studies, but with financial struggles, they
are burdened further.

The Preamble of City Ordinance No. 8568 mentioned that “there is a need to
support the youth of the City of Manila intellectually by providing allowances
to its public school students to allow them to continue their education
despite the hardships and struggles of the family;” But what happens to
students who are not targeted by this ordinance?

**The non-inclusion of students of PLM who are non-Manila residents to the SAP
cash allowance is equivalent to alienating these students who come from far
and wide just to attain the quality education and support they know that the
City of Manila could only provide.** These students could opt to study in
their own residential cities but chose to study and, for some, bring pride to
the Pamantasan and the city it renders its service for.

Including the students of PLM who are non-Manila residents to the SAP
allowance would not mean less compared to those bonafide Manila residents,
rather it could foster a more breathable environment for financially-stricken
students outside the city that could help them learn comfortably. And through
this initiative the Pamantasan could optimize its vision in being the
university for the people regardless from which city its students come from.

# Preno muna!

Sulat ni Elecyl Cabalquinto • Dibuho ni Elyse Abadilla • Layout ni Jhon Bert G. Payos | 28 May 23

Kung pagiging kumportable, malinis, at maganda lang din naman ang pag-uusapan,
sino bang hindi gugustuhin ang ganitong pagbabago? Ngunit, kung ang pagbabago
ay isang balatkayo lamang upang masabi na ang bansa’y umuusad at hindi
sumasagot sa totoong pangangailangan ng mga mamamayan nito, bagkus ay lalo
pang humahatak pababa sa mga Pilipinong dati nang nasa laylayan, tingin ko’y
hindi na dapat suportahan ito.

Nagsimulang umarangkada ang hangarin ng gobyerno na gawing moderno ang mga
pampublikong transportasyon noong taong 2017 sa ilalim ng Departamento ng
Transportasyon (DOTr) na Public Utility Vehicle Modernization Program (PUVMP).
Bukod sa aniya’y mas maayos na regulasyon at industry consolidation, isa ring
hangarin ng programa ang pag-phaseout ng mga jeepney, bus, at iba pang public
utility vehicles na may 15 taon na ang tagal at palitan ang mga ito ng
transportasyong sinasabing mas ligtas, mas komportable, at mas makatutulong sa
kalikasan.

Gayunpaman, ang transisyon sa modernisasyon, imbis na makatulong sa
nakararami, ay nagharap ng limpak-limpak na hamon sa mga operator, mga tsuper,
mga komyuter, at maaaring maging dahilan ng pagkabura ng isang simbolong
pangkultura ng bansa – ang tradisyunal jeepneys.

Kitang-kita ang tila palyadong paraaan ng gobyerno sa pagpapatupad ng
programa, lalo pa’t ang mataas na halaga ng bawat unit ng modernong jeepney ay
maaaring magresulta sa pagtaas ng pamasahe upang matumbasan ang kanilang
ginastos sa pagbili nito. Ang modernong jeepney ay nagkakahalaga ng P1.6M
hanggang P2.6M, masyado itong mahal kumpara sa tradisyunal na jeepney na
mabibili ang isang unit sa halagang P200,000 hanggang P600,000 lamang.

Bagama’t ibinibida ng gobyerno ang pinansyal na tulong na ibinibigay bilang
suporta, na nagkakahalagang P160,000 hanggang P260,000, nasa P1.4M hanggang
P2.4M pa rin ang kailangang bunuin ng mga operator at driver para sa isang
unit ng modernong jeepney.

Ang modernong jeepney ay nagkakahalaga ng P1.6M
hanggang P2.6M, masyado itong mahal kumpara sa tradisyunal na jeepney na
mabibili ang isang unit sa halagang P200,000 hanggang P600,000 lamang.

Bagama’t ibinibida ng gobyerno ang pinansyal na tulong na ibinibigay bilang
suporta, na nagkakahalagang P160,000 hanggang P260,000, nasa P1.4M hanggang
P2.4M pa rin ang kailangang bunuin ng mga operator at driver para sa isang
unit ng modernong jeepney. Imposible para sa mga driver at maliliit na
operator ang makakuha ng ganitong halaga lalo pa’t naglalaro lamang sa P500
ang nauuwi kada araw ng isang jeepney driver at P2,500 hanggang P3,000 naman
ang sa operator. Kaya naman, isinisigaw nilang imbis na bumili ng modernong
jeepney ay isailalim na lamang sa rehabilitasyon ang mga tradisyunal jeepneys
upang pumasa sa guidelines ng DOTr, na magkakahalaga lamang ng P900,000 kada
unit, mas mura at mas kakayaning pagkagastusan ng mga maliliit na operator.

Bukod sa mataas na presyo ng unit ng modernong jeepney, isa pang dahilan kung
bakit maraming kontra sa PUVMP ay ang kaakibat nitong “Industry
Consolidation,” kung saan pagsasama-samahin ang mga jeepney operator at tsuper
upang maging isang korporasyon o kooperatiba. Ito ay kaugnay ng Omnibus
Franchising Guidelines ng DOTr na tanging ang mga korporasyon o kooperatiba na
may hindi bababa sa 15 unit ang papayagang mag-apply para sa mga bagong
prangkisa. Problema ito sa mga maliliit na operator na walang sapat na
mapagkukunan ng kinakailangang 15 na unit ng sasakyan. Bagama’t
pinahihintulutan ng gobyerno ang mga kooperatiba o korporasyon na makakuha ng
loans sa mga bangkong pagmamay-ari ng estado, tiyak na magreresulta lamang ito
sa pagkabaon sa utang ng maliliit na operator. Ngayon nga’y iginagapang na
nila ang araw-araw sa kakaunting salaping nakukuha sa pang-araw-araw na
operasyon, paano pa nila maitatawid ang interes kung sila’y kukuha ng loans?

Maituturing ang ganitong istilo bilang mali, sapilitan, at panlalamang
sapagkat tila inaalis nito sa mga operator ang kanilang mga karapatan at
pribilehiyo bilang indibidwal na may hawak ng prangkisa. Dahil sa oras na
hindi na nila kayanin pa ang magastos na modernisasyon, wala na silang
babalikan pa sapagkat naisuko na nila ang kanilang karapatan sa kanilang
prangkisa kapag sumali sila sa kooperatiba o korporasyon. At kahit pa
pinalawig ng gobyerno ang deadline ng pagsapi ng mga indibidwal na may hawak
ng prangkisa sa kooperatiba o korporasyon, hindi pa rin nito nabubura ang
malaking gastos at ang katotohanang kakailanganin din nilang i-upgrade ang
kanilang 15 unit sa modernong jeepney kapag naglaon.

Bilang isang estudyante na may kalayuan ang tirahan sa Pamantasan, naging
bahagi na ng araw-araw kong buhay ang pagsakay sa jeep. Mula sa amin, walang
ibang pwedeng masakyan kung ‘di tradisyunal jeepney at iilang modernong jeep
na may kalakihan ang pamasahe.

At kahit pa
pinalawig ng gobyerno ang deadline ng pagsapi ng mga indibidwal na may hawak
ng prangkisa sa kooperatiba o korporasyon, hindi pa rin nito nabubura ang
malaking gastos at ang katotohanang kakailanganin din nilang i-upgrade ang
kanilang 15 unit sa modernong jeepney kapag naglaon.

Bilang isang estudyante na may kalayuan ang tirahan sa Pamantasan, naging
bahagi na ng araw-araw kong buhay ang pagsakay sa jeep. Mula sa amin, walang
ibang pwedeng masakyan kung ‘di tradisyunal jeepney at iilang modernong jeep
na may kalakihan ang pamasahe. Kung tradisyunal jeepney ang sasakyan, nasa P74
ang pamasahe papunta-balikan, samantalang kung modernong jeep naman ay nasa
P102. Talagang malaki ang natitipid kung tradisyunal na jeepney ang sasakyan.

Ngunit dahil masyadong nagtatagal ang biyahe sa mga ruta na ito, napipilitan
akong sumakay sa bus at tren na ang kakailanganing pamasahe ay nasa P118
papunta-balikan. Kung may P150 o P200, na sa palagay kong mabigat na sa bulsa
lalo pa’t hindi lamang ako ang nag-aaral sa pamilya, nasa 32-82 pesos na
lamang ang pwedeng magamit pambili ng pagkain.

Dagdag pa, madalas na mahaba ang pila sa mga terminal ng bus at jeep. Tuwing
rush hour naman, halos wala na ring masakyan. At kung mawawala ang tradisyunal
jeepneys, malamang kakailanganin ko na ng 3 hanggang 4 na oras na palugit bago
pumasok. Ngayon nga ay pasakit na ang 1 hanggang 2 oras na byahe papunta pa
lamang, ano pa ang mangyayari kung mawawala ang daan-daang tradisyunal
jeepneys?

Ngayon pa lamang ay kinailangan nang magkansela ng pasok ang mga paaralan
dahil sa isang linggong tigil-pasada, para na rin itong pagsang-ayon sa
malaking kawalan ng jeepneys sa buhay ng mga komyuter. Nakasisiguro akong
marami pang estudyante, guro, at manggagawang Pilipino ang may ganitong
suliranin.

Hindi ang magastos, kontra sa mahihirap, at ‘di napag-aralang modernisasyon,
bagkus pagsasaayos ng sistema ng transportasyon, lalo na sa mga ruta at
mahabang pila sa mga terminal ang mas kailangang bigyang pansin. Tiyak akong
mas komportableng bumiyahe kung hindi kakailanganin ng 2 hanggang 3 oras upang
marating ang Pamantasan.

Ang imposible, mahal, at mapanlinlang na hangaring modernisasyon ay hindi
lamang nakaapekto sa mga operator, tsuper at komyuter, kung ‘di maging sa mga
jeepney artists kung saan iniaasa ang ikinabubuhay sa pagpinta sa metal na
katawan ng mga tradisyunal jeepneys. Sa personal kong pakikipag-usap sa ilang
jeepney artists, napag-alaman kong isa ang jeepney phaseout sa mga dahilan ng
pagbaba ng kanilang customer at pagbaba ng kanilang bilang. Naniniwala silang
rehabilitasyon ng jeepney ang susi upang mapangalagaan ang kanilang
industriya, “Ipapa-modification lang nila ang mga jeep, parang papagandahin
lang ulit para dumami ulit yung jeep”, “Tangkilikin talaga yung ating mga
jeep”, “Sana ay mag-import tayo ng makina ng jeep kaysa i-phaseout.

Sa personal kong pakikipag-usap sa ilang
jeepney artists, napag-alaman kong isa ang jeepney phaseout sa mga dahilan ng
pagbaba ng kanilang customer at pagbaba ng kanilang bilang. Naniniwala silang
rehabilitasyon ng jeepney ang susi upang mapangalagaan ang kanilang
industriya, “Ipapa-modification lang nila ang mga jeep, parang papagandahin
lang ulit para dumami ulit yung jeep”, “Tangkilikin talaga yung ating mga
jeep”, “Sana ay mag-import tayo ng makina ng jeep kaysa i-phaseout. Makina
lang naman ang problema ng jeep eh.”

Maituturing na “moving street art” at “cultural icon” ang jeepneys dahil sa
mga makukulay, magaganda, at nakakaaliw na imaheng nakaguhit sa mga katawan
nito, na ngayo’y tila malapit nang mabura bilang anyo ng pambansang
representasyon. Ang mga pintor nito ay napipinto ring mawalan ng hanapbuhay
kung matutuloy ang jeepney phaseout. Sa bansang hindi nakikita ang sining
bilang mahalaga, ano pang bukas ang naghihintay sa kanilang mga galing at
talento.

Ang lahat ng mga ito ay patunay lamang na hindi pa handa ang Pilipinas sa
ganitong pagbabago. Hindi ngayon ang oras upang magpanggap na umuusad ang
bansa, lalo pa’t kung bubusisiin ay mas lamang pa ang mga pahirap kumpara sa
“kumportable” at “maganda” na sinasabi. Hindi tsuper at komyuter ang
magkakalaban.

Maaaring hindi ang hangaring pag-unlad sa pamamagitan ng modernisasyon ang
problema, kung ‘di ang palpak na pagpapatupad ng programa. Hindi pagpapalawig
sa deadline ng industry consolidation ang nais ng mga operator at tsuper, sa
halip ay totoong suportang pinansyal mula sa gobyerno—hindi mapanlilang na
taktikang magbabaon lamang sa kanila sa limpak-limpak na utang. Isa pa, dapat
ding pag-isipan ang “import-dependent nature” ng programa na tiyak na
malalaking negosyo at banyaga lamang ang makikinabang.

Matatandaang nagresulta ang palyadong modernisasyon na ito sa isang transport
strike o tigil-pasada mula March 6, na dinaluhan ng mga transport group, mga
tsuper, at operator. Nakatakda sanang matapos ang strike ng March 12 ngunit
itinigil matapos ang dalawang araw kasunod ng dayalogo sa pagitan ng gobyerno
at lider ng mga transport group. Masasabing matagumpay kahit papaano ang
naging strike dahil naging paraan ito upang pakinggan ng gobyerno ang mga
panawagan. Sa ngayon, pinanghahawakan ng ating mga tsuper at operator ang
pahayag ng gobyerno na bukas sila sa pag-aaral at pagrebisa ng programa. Sana
lang ay hindi ito maisama sa mahabang listahan ng mga pangakong isinambit lang
dala ng sitwasyon, bagkus tunay na pakinggan nawa ang kanilang hinaing.

Ang jeepney ay kilalang bahagi ng ating pagka-Pilipino, kung mawawala ito,
iwinaksi na rin natin ang isang parte ng ating pagkatao. Naniniwala akong
rehabilitasyon ng jeepney, pagtangkilik sa lokal na materyales, at pagsasaayos
ng sistema ng transportasyon—hindi pagbili ng mamahaling unit ng sasakyan at
importasyon—ang paraan upang umunlad ang bansa at upang hindi mawalan ng
hanapbuhay ang ating operator, tsuper, at jeepney artists.

Ang jeepney ay kilalang bahagi ng ating pagka-Pilipino, kung mawawala ito,
iwinaksi na rin natin ang isang parte ng ating pagkatao. Naniniwala akong
rehabilitasyon ng jeepney, pagtangkilik sa lokal na materyales, at pagsasaayos
ng sistema ng transportasyon—hindi pagbili ng mamahaling unit ng sasakyan at
importasyon—ang paraan upang umunlad ang bansa at upang hindi mawalan ng
hanapbuhay ang ating operator, tsuper, at jeepney artists. Ating suportahan
ang panawagan ng ating kapwa Pilipino. Kung tunay na pambansang “pagkakaisa”
ang isasaalang-alang, ating isigaw “NO TO JEEPNEY PHASEOUT!”

# moribound

Written by Jhea Buela • Board by John Ivan Pasion | 29 February 24

hold my fingers

like loose threads

that ache to be pulled.

unravel me

until i am delicate

enough to be torn.

clench me

into your hands

when you ache

until i am darkened

with creases.

wipe me the tears

from your lost plans

and the laundry dew

on your hands

\- you are a rainforest,

my scent

that lulls you to sleep.

allow me to be

the mosaic of you,

a patchwork of

your childhood quilts

and the dreams

you’ve once built.

for you,

i will exist

and shrivel

in frays.

only i pray,

you won’t take me off

because of

someone else’s warmth.

# PLM students and faculty lined up for Passport on Wheels

Caption and Photo by Janelle Ugot | 20 June 24

PLM students and faculty lined up for Passport on Wheels (POWS), Katipunan
Lounge, GEE, June 21.

POWS is a passport service inside the university, in partnership with
Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) and the Department of Foreign Affairs
(DFA), brought in line with the celebration of Pamantasan's 59th founding
anniversary.

# Haribon ESports secures accreditation as non-academic organization of PLM

Written by Cedrick Paynor • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 12 March 24

The best is yet to come for Haribon Esports as they have successfully secured
accreditation as a non-academic organization of Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng
Maynila after enduring a prolonged period of anticipation.

On February 14, Haribon Esports announced on their Facebook page that the
group has achieved the long-awaited accreditation they have been working
towards for more than a year.

The newly acquired accreditation is poised to unlock doors of opportunity,
allowing the Esports industry to flourish within the walls of Pamantasan.

In an interview, Peter Simoun Carlos, Haribon Esports Vice President for
External Affairs, emphasized the significance of recognizing esports in
Pamantasan as a substantial progression, highlighting that the accredited
group will work hand in hand to foster the thriving of esports within the
student body.

“We want every student to acknowledge that there is a career beyond esports,
and let them do what they love without being afraid of getting lost as we are
here to guide and establish esports in Pamantasan”, he said.

However, despite the forthcoming triumph of securing accreditation, the
journey leading up to this milestone presented Haribon Esports with notable
challenges, as they grappled with various limitations within the industry.

Among the challenges faced was the inability to use the PLM name in
competitions due to the lack of accreditation, limiting Haribon Esports'
visibility and recognition on the competitive stage.

Now that they have achieved formal recognition, navigating a competitive
landscape becomes a less daunting task for Haribon Esports.

“It opens doors for players like me to actively engage, compete, and
contribute to the vibrant Esports community at PLM”, Mark Dave Limpin, an
active player of Haribon Esports stated.

“I look forward to the exciting developments this accreditation will bring to
our gaming experience and the broader campus culture,” he added.

The accreditation of Haribon Esports in PLM not only opens doors for the
organization but also paves the way for a broader understanding of esports as
a legitimate and valuable aspect of university life.

As the esports community continues to grow, this recognition highlights the
university's commitment to embracing emerging industries and providing diverse
opportunities for its student body.

# Miss Manila 2024 goes to PLM in search for beauty and brains

Written by Zarena Hermogeno • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 17 April 24

Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) pageant aspirants may attend the on-
site screening for the Miss Manila 2024 on April 19, 8:00 AM.

Aside from the pageant screening, a masterclass on Personality Development
with Bb. Pilipinas Universe 2002 Karen Agustin Ostrea will be held along with
an empowering talk from Miss Manila Tourism 2023 Angela Okol. Moreover, a
Cream Silk Hair Institute Booth will be stationed inside the campus.

PLM marks the third stop of the Campus Search for the said pageant. Students
of the City of Manila are encouraged to join for a chance to be crowned as
Miss Manila 2024 and take home the coveted prize of 1 million pesos.

Among the PLM alumnas who have graced the pageant stage were April Love
Jordan, 3rd Princess of the Miss World Philippines 2012; Maria Sovietskaya
Bacud, Binibining Pilipinas 1996 1st Runner Up and Miss Intercontinental 1993
2nd Runner Up; and Julian Aurine “Ja” Flores, a candidate from the Binibining
Pilipinas 2014 and among the contestants from the Season 4 of Asia’s Next Top
Model.

Interested applicants may register through:
[_http://missmanila.ph_](http://missmanila.ph)

# STAND PLM, Gabriela Youth, Ang Partidong Tugon condemn, call out select SSC
Execs on alleged bullying

Written by Zarena Hermogeno • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 26 September 23

In press releases, the Student Alliance for the Advancement of Democratic
Rights (STAND) PLM, Gabriela Youth PLM, and Ang Partidong Tugon (APT)
condemned the Supreme Student Council and disaffiliated its executives
allegedly involved in cases of bullying, Sept. 26.

STAND PLM officially revoked the affiliation of incumbent Supreme Student
Council (SSC) Vice President Jam Iris Paglicawan after she filed for her
disaffiliation to the organization and called out its other affiliate College
of Education Representative Jomarie Soriano. Ang Partidong Tugon also
condemned and stated its disaffiliation with College of Education
Representative Jhon Christian Rebortera. Meanwhile, Gabriela Youth condemned
Treasurer Sophia Pitero.

__

_“_ Kaya naman, bilang isang alyansa na lagi't laging sasandig sa hustisya,
karapatan, at interes ng masang estudyante, tahasang kinukundena ng STAND PLM
ang paninirang-puri nina Jam Iris Paglicawan, Jomarie Soriano, at ng kanilang
mga kasama! Ang krimeng ito ay nakapanakit ‘di lamang sa mga biktima, kundi sa
kabuuan ng masang estudyante,_”_ STAND PLM stated.

The organizations condemned the participation of Paglicawan, Soriano, Pitero,
and Rebortera, respectively in the alleged bullying incident claimed by the
organizations.

_“_ Tahasang kinukundena ng Gabriela Youth PLM si Sophia Pitero dahil sa
kanyang atrasadong kilos na ipinikita bilang isang estudyante-lider! Hindi
karapatdapat suportahan ng malawak na hanay ng kababaihan ang mga mapanupil at
mapang-abuso,_”_ Gabriela Youth said referring to their support on Pitero
during the elections.

Gabriela Youth perceived Pitero's participation in the incident as
‘oppressive’, ‘divisive’, and ‘betraying’ to her fellow student leader.
Meanwhile, STAND viewed Paglicawan's remarks as an act of bullying through
verbal abuse or "berbal na pamamahiya.”

As a countermeasure, STAND imposed disciplinary actions on Paglicawan and
Soriano, during their meeting last Sept. 24.

Paglicawan and Soriano were instructed to "condemn" the group chat and other
included members along with issuing an apology and corresponding assistance to
the victims. They are also subject to "Specialized Educational Discussions"
while simultaneously rendering community service.

“Tanghali ng Setyembre 24, 2023 nang matuloy ang pagpupulong.

Gabriela Youth perceived Pitero's participation in the incident as
‘oppressive’, ‘divisive’, and ‘betraying’ to her fellow student leader.
Meanwhile, STAND viewed Paglicawan's remarks as an act of bullying through
verbal abuse or "berbal na pamamahiya.”

As a countermeasure, STAND imposed disciplinary actions on Paglicawan and
Soriano, during their meeting last Sept. 24.

Paglicawan and Soriano were instructed to "condemn" the group chat and other
included members along with issuing an apology and corresponding assistance to
the victims. They are also subject to "Specialized Educational Discussions"
while simultaneously rendering community service.

“Tanghali ng Setyembre 24, 2023 nang matuloy ang pagpupulong. [...] Sa usapan,
pinatawan ng mahigpit na pagpupuna at Disciplinary Action si Paglicawan at
Soriano. Inatasan silang kundenahin ang “Mga Backstabbers” Group Chat at ang
mga sangkot dito. Kasapakat nito ang paghingi ng tawad at pag-abot ng tulong
sa kanilang biktima,” __ STAND PLM narrated in their press release
statement.__

“Dagdag pa riyan, sila ay ipapailalim sa Specialized Educational Discussions
kasabay ng paghahanap ng lokal na komunidad na pagsisilbihan (community
service) upang mas mapagtibay ang mga aral na matututunan bunsod ng paglubog
sa masa. Kung sakaling sila ay mananatili sa pwesto, inatasan din silang
magkaroon ng mahigpit na pagtatasa sa mga kinikilos sa loob ng konseho,” __
STAND PLM added.

However, last Sept. 26, Paglicawan filed her disaffiliation to STAND PLM that
prompted the latter to renounce the membership of the SSC Vice President from
their organization.

“Bilang respeto sa desisyon ni Paglicawan, pormal nang ibinababa ng STAND PLM
ang disaffiliation kay Jam Iris Paglicawan, ang dating miyembro ng partido at
kasalukuyang Bise Presidente ng Kataas-taasang Konseho ng Pamantasan. Magmula
ngayon, hindi na kinikilala ng STAND PLM si Paglicawan bilang miyembro” STAND
PLM stated.

As per APT, Rebortera’s actions “clearly neglected to uphold the values and
principles that the party ingrained.” In their statement, they also
acknowledge their own lapses as an organization in guiding (their affiliates)
and preventing such situations to happen.

APT added that they shall impose stricter guidelines in the selection of
candidates by considering their moral conduct and work ethics alongside
leadership and academic credentials.

Some students also demanded accountability from the involved SSC officers
while others called for their impeachment.

Ang Pamantasan has reached out to the individuals involved and as of this
writing, they are not yet ready to comment on the issue.

This is a developing story.

# ‘JuanFlix and Chill!’: PLM student short films currently streaming on the
national film agency’s official channel

Written by Zarena Hermogeno • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 16 June 24

Nine (9) student short films from the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM)
are currently streaming for free under the Special Features category of the
Film Development Council of the Philippines’s (FDCP) official streaming
channel, JuanFlix until June 30, 2024.

Among the featured short films are Jennica Reyes’s “E4” and “Gomang Pudpod”;
Jerome Flores’s “Genesis” and “Quiapo Blues”; Raquel May Bendo’s “It Will Rain
Tomorrow” and “Panaad”; Ren Verzosa’s “Kolateral”; Mark Neil Corong’s “Liban”
and Jaed Ababao’s “Misterio de Familia”

These short films present varying stories on unrequited romances;
serendipitous encounters; burying family secrets; a look back on the love that
bloomed; mending relationships; a strategic game plan of life; a chance to
turn things around; and friendships that stood societal prejudices.

To stream, simply Sign Up/Log-In to the official JuanFlix website at
[_www.juanflix.com.ph_](http://www.juanflix.com.ph) and click the
“SineHaribon” category under the “Special Features” tab.

These nine short films were initially official selections featured during the
university-wide SineHaribon Film Festival organized by the PLM Independent
Film and Arts (PIFA) last May 10-11. These films were also showcased at a
public film screening at the Cinematheque Centre Manila last May 18.

# Lotto sa Kolehiyo

Written by Estelle Theresa Gulay • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 12 February 24

Uno, dos.. nanlumo na lamang matapos masulyapan ang tres sa _CRS_. Bagama’t
ninakawan ng ilang gabi’t idlip; ng oras ng pagkain; mga araw na dapat ay para
sa pamilya; sa pahinga, ay hindi pa rin pinalad sa gradong inasam na makamit.

At ang isip na puno ng katanungan ay pumewersang lumapit sa maestrong nagkait
ng karapatang makita ang marka bago opisyal na italaga. Nanlambot sa yamot,
pagtataka’t lungkot nang makatanggap ng kasagutang sa aki’y nagdamot ng
kalinawan ng isipan. Sapagka’t sambit ang paninindigan na wala nang magagawa;
payong tanggapin ang gradong binansagang nakalkula ngunit walang ebidensya; at
pampalubag-loob na katagang hindi nasusukat ng numerong itinalaga ang tagumpay
sa hinaharap na paglalakbay.

Subalit ‘di maalis ang bigat sa damdamin datapwa’t ang gradong natamasa na
hindi naman sumasalamin sa pagsisikap na ginawa– na hindi ko alam saan
hinulma– ang siyang pumawi ng pangarap na matawag na unang _cum laude_ ng
pamilya. Batid ko na higit pa ang sa aki’y nararapat na kahihitnatnan
sapagka’t ako’y nagpunyagi– nagbuhos ng luha at pawis! Ngunit ang
pinakamasakit? Ang realidad na naubos ang sarili sa kurso na tinanggihan ng
karampatang pagtuturo; ng aral na nararapat na ibahagi ng propesor na
pinagkatiwalaan ng Pamantasan.

Muli na naman yata akong hinampas ng sinasabi nilang realidad na kolehiyo ay
minsa’y laro ng lotto. Kung gayo’y hiling ko sa pagpasok sa panghuling
semestro ay nawa’y tumama ang numero ng aking tadhana. Makatamasa ng _jackpot_
– hindi, uno sa _CRS_ ngunit isang maestrong magbibigay ng sa akin ay karapat-
dapat. Propesor na maghahandog ng panghabambuhay na kaalaman; na sa akin ay
huhulma bilang mabuti’t maasahang mamamayan.

# Cultivating Dreams: Ino Pamaran’s Account of Seed and Harvest

Written by Charyll Joan Pascua • Board by Angelle Valbuena | 10 October 23

To dream, my friends, is a universal language. It’s a birthright not exclusive
to the privileged, and it’s not a privilege limited to the realm of adults.
But let me make one thing clear—while dreams are free, transforming them into
reality demands something more profound.

From a young age, grown-ups around me encouraged me to dream big and reach for
the sky. “ _Mangarap ka nang matayog_ ,” they would say. However, I hold the
belief that to dream deep, or “mangarap nang malalim,” is equally essential,
as if planting a seed deep in the soil, allowing it to grow, bear fruit, and
eventually reap a bountiful harvest. To be more precise, I see a dream as a
seed, and before I reap its rewards, I must first and foremost plant it in the
perfect soil. So, picture this: a young man named Ino, raised by a single
mother, driven by the ambition to support his family, embarked on a quest to
find the most fertile ground.

After hearing the words of tongue and immersing myself in various news
articles, I resolved to plant my dreams in what I then perceived as the
richest of soils—the University of the Philippines (UP). To gain admission to
this esteemed institution, I wholeheartedly dedicated myself to rigorous
preparation throughout my high school years. When the fateful UPCAT
(University of the Philippines College Admission Test) arrived, I poured every
ounce of my effort into securing a place in my dream university. So, when the
disheartening news arrived that I hadn’t made the cut, I was left in a state
of profound dismay, as if the realization of my dream had been stunted before
it even began.

“Is this it? Is this all the Earth’s solid ground has in store for me?” I
asked myself. I couldn’t simply accept that my dream of attending UP had come
to an abrupt end. “One last attempt,” I declared. Before contemplating
surrender, I was determined to exhaust every effort and explore all
possibilities. With unwavering resolve, I gathered wood, crafted a sign, and
marched towards UP with a bold message: “RECONSIDER ME?” There were no hints
of shame, no room for doubts. For the sake of my dream university, I was
prepared to go all in.

However, like a seed planted in the wrong soil, despite my patience, my dreams
failed to take root. With the realization that my pursuit of UP had reached
its conclusion, I decided it was time to replant my aspirations somewhere
else. This was then that my focus shifted to a place I believed to be equally
suitable—PLM (Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila)—where I eventually secured
admission.

Planting and waiting for dreams to bloom can be daunting, but knowing I wasn’t
alone in pursuing a great personal ambition at PLM brought reassurance.

With unwavering resolve, I gathered wood, crafted a sign, and
marched towards UP with a bold message: “RECONSIDER ME?” There were no hints
of shame, no room for doubts. For the sake of my dream university, I was
prepared to go all in.

However, like a seed planted in the wrong soil, despite my patience, my dreams
failed to take root. With the realization that my pursuit of UP had reached
its conclusion, I decided it was time to replant my aspirations somewhere
else. This was then that my focus shifted to a place I believed to be equally
suitable—PLM (Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila)—where I eventually secured
admission.

Planting and waiting for dreams to bloom can be daunting, but knowing I wasn’t
alone in pursuing a great personal ambition at PLM brought reassurance. Within
our university’s halls, I found myself surrounded by fellow dreamers, hailing
from diverse backgrounds and inspired by different visions. Nevertheless, we
all shared a common trait—the audacity to dream on a grand scale. Initially,
PLM appeared as an imposing institution, nearly overwhelming for a mere
dreamer like myself. But as the years progressed, I unearthed that it’s more
than just an institution—PLM is a tight-knit community, an ecosystem of
support. Our school instilled in us the belief that we are capable of
achieving our dreams. And as we grasped the full extent of our potential, we
witnessed those very aspirations burst forth after taking root in the
nurturing soil of our _pamantasan_.

Our dreams, initially no more than seeds, were never destined to achieve their
full potential merely by taking root; that was but the beginning. From that
point forward, our mission was clear: We needed to invest every ounce of
effort in nurturing our dreams, fortifying them against the unpredictable
winds, and ensuring they could withstand even the harshest weathers. When the
pandemic struck, leaving me utterly bewildered, it felt as though an
unrelenting storm was obstructing the fulfillment of my grand goal. I found
myself adrift, uncertain of how to proceed, as I had never encountered such
circumstances before. Nevertheless, our instructors, together with our
classroom leaders Jamela and Miggle, had diligently taught us to remain
focused on our ultimate objectives and to confront challenges like what we
experienced head-on.

After three years at the university, a profound transformation started to
unfold. My dreams and I, as a dreamer, were now closer to fulfillment. During
those three years, I gained sincere appreciation for the path I was on,
journeying alongside my fellow _Haribons_ Caezar, Jet, Edrian, Andre, and
Leoj—a transformative experience I had never seen coming. Even surpassing my
initial expectations, I received the news that I was a contender for honors in
my Bachelor of Science in Business Administration, Major in Economics. This
revelation ignited a strong conviction within me. I dedicated countless hours,
day and night, to safeguarding that dream. I pushed myself relentlessly,
determined to attain the grades that would catapult me to the pinnacle.
Finally, after enduring countless trials and tribulations, I harvested my
first triumph—graduating Magna Cum Laude.

As I reflect on this achievement, I recognize that this is merely the initial
step, the first yield of my unwavering efforts. A bountiful harvest awaits,
patiently biding its time. In this understanding, I find profound solace,
assured that during my college years, I was precisely where I was meant to be.

So, remember this: Within each of us resides potential for greatness, awaiting
its bloom. These potentials manifest as dreams in our minds, and to see them
flourish, all they require are unwavering perseverance, all-season hope, and a
radiant attitude that welcomes life’s spontaneity. Understand, my friends,
that dreams remain mere fantasies unless we act upon them. However, if you
acknowledge your potential and actively harness it, the heavens will shine
their light upon you, fulfilling the deepest desires of your heart.
