# PLMayer represents PH, finishes fourth in eFIBA World Finals in Sweden

Written by Raniel Paquingan • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 10 December 23

Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) student Isaiah Vincent Alindada and the
eGilas squad have proven the country's gaming brilliance as they snagged
fourth place in the Westerner-dominated eFIBA Season 2 World Finals at
Jönköping, Sweden, Nov. 25–26.

eGilas Pilipinas, the Philippines’ official basketball eSports team composed
of Alindada or "PHI_Ice2fast," Clark “PHI_ZavaLCB” Banzon, Kenneth “PHI_Clue”
Gutierrez, Prich “PHI_DonPriich-” Diez, and Julian “PHI_Social” Mallillin,
fell short of a podium finish as Turkey spoiled the squad's tournament dreams,
62-46.

Before entering the bronze medal match, the Filipinos faced the eventual
champions, the United States of America (USA), but our representatives failed
to get hold of the lead until the final buzzer, kneeling down to the kings of
the tournament in two games, 43-33 and 67-33.

Despite this "almost but not quite" ending, eGilas still brought home 4,000
euros, or over P240,000.

The national squad also dominated the regional qualifiers of the tourney with
a flawless record against other Southeast Asian countries, which punched them
their ticket to the world finals.

Amidst the continuous rise of eSports in the country, this type of sport that
is played on PlayStation consoles, where teams work together like a true
basketball team in the 5v5 ProAm mode of NBA2K24, is still foreign to the
public.

In an online interview, Alindada even shared how small the 2K community is in
the Philippines compared to western countries like the USA, which already have
established competitions.

"Sa Philippines, sobrang liit lang ng community ng NBA2K. Ilang eSports team
lang, parang tatatlo lang ata. Sa atin maliit lang yung competition, maliit
lang yung teams na pwedeng makalaban, mas konti lang yung experiences natin,"
he said.

But despite this little exposure, Alindada still found success and a career in
the sport, which started with just a curiosity to try different online games
during the pandemic.

According to the PLM information technology student, he still plans to compete
in various upcoming 2K tournaments while balancing gaming with his studies.

"School lagi yung priority ko, kapag may pasok, hindi ako pwedeng maglaro,"
Alindada added.

In a doubters-filled eSports industry, Alindada left some words of motivation
for those who also dream to represent the country in this type of sport and
follow in his footsteps.

"Always do what you want. Sundan mo lagi yung passion mo.…try to be the best
and never give up lang," he stated.

# IN PHOTOS | Strengthening Campus Press Freedom

Caption by Roland Justin Molato • Photos by Ibanica Dionisio & Bill Ariega | 2 July 23

Ang Pamantasan, the official student publication of Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng
Maynila concluded its term with the Transition and Turnover Conference (TTC),
presenting its New Key Editors for A.Y 2023-2024 includes Alessandra Frianela
for the position of Editor-In-Chief, Ken Joshua De Paula for the position of
Associate Editor, and Stefanie Ann Santilla for the position of Managing
Editor at Justo Albert Auditorium, June 30.

# BAC students showcase own short films at FILMayer film festival

Written by Calvin Agustin • Board by Calvin Agustin | 7 June 24

Senior Communication students presented ten short films on the screening day
of the most coveted FILMayer: A PLM Festival of Movies at the Justo Albert
Auditorium, June 7.

As part of the 4th year students’ Film and Writing Production course, the
following short films were submitted as official entries to the film festival:

  * “Sa Pintuan ni Alison” by Dorothy Productions

  * “Para Po!” by Sangandaan Productions

  * “Overnight Stay” by Four Walls Motion Pictures

  * “D’Served” by Kusine Films

  * “Alamat ng Isdang Kulay Bahaghari” by Dalayday Productions

  * “Absolusyon” by AbanTake Productions

  * “Tara, G!” by ROUTE 5 Productions

  * “Balong, Balong… Balong?” by Inari Productions

  * “Evangeline” by Serafilm Productions

  * “Ang Nanay Kong Sapatero” by Pawid Productions

These short films were made possible with the help and guidance of their
respective lecturers Mr. David Ramos Jr. and Ms. Ayen Bayani, who are both
experienced in the field of writing and producing shows in a local television
network, testified by their decade-long work.

Today, June 8, these films are set to be recognized with the FILMayer Awards
Ceremony at the Justo Albert Auditorium. The FILMayer Committee revealed the
set of judges, all known in the industry namely directors Mr. Adolfo Alix Jr.
and Mr. Zig Dulay; cinematographer Mr. Carlo Mendoza; and veteran actress Ms.
Amy Austria. The panel of judges will determine the most deserving films to be
recognized with the 22 production and performance awards in this year’s
FILMayer.

Mass Communication Students’ League President and FILMayer Chairperson Ms.
Kamila Ysabel Cotoner expressed her gratitude to the distinguished guests and
audience who took their time and supported the screening day of the film
festival.

Afterwards, University President Atty. Domingo Reyes Jr. graced the auditorium
with his presence and addressed the students with a message.

“I’m truly amazed and you never fail to amuse me with the shared talents that
PLM have… I’ve never seen so much talent being manifested in a single film
festival [which] are all student productions,” Pres. Reyes stated.

Moreover, the President also shared that with the upcoming 60th founding
anniversary of PLM, he hopes to have a university-wide film festival as one of
the activities.

The FILMayer: A PLM Festival of Movies 2024 Screening was exclusive for the
faculty, students, and staff of PLM, as well as for the invited guests by the
production houses.

# Binibini at Ginoong Pamantasan 2024 officially concludes

Caption and Photos by Roland Justin Molato | 20 June 24

Binibini at Ginoong Pamantasan 2024 officially concludes. Six young and
beautiful students strongly gave their best to bring home the crown, June 20.

College of Humanities, Arts, and Social Science won the first ever Binibini at
Ginoong Pamantasan followed by the College of Nursing and College of Business
Administration as the 1st Runner up and College of Public Administration as
the 2nd Runner up.

# ALAB Pamantasan, APT, STAND-PLM appeal to PLM COMELEC on election concerns

Written by Calvin Agustin • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 30 April 24

University political parties ALAB Pamantasan, STAND-PLM, and Ang Partidong
Tugon (APT) collectively submitted an appeal to the PLM Student Commission on
Elections (COMELEC) to address some election-related issues, April 26.

The aforementioned political parties raised concerns on the prohibition of
non-members to run under their preferred political party, and on the
adjustment of the electoral calendar to the Commission.

With regards to the said prohibition, the political parties requested PLM
COMELEC to allow all re-accredited political parties in the university to
update and resubmit their member databases until May 1. This is due to the
five-month gap between the re-accreditation of political parties and the
publication of the electoral calendar, whilst some student leaders have yet to
decide whether to run for office or not.

“As a result, the member databases submitted by political parties are
tentative and incomplete, reflecting the prevailing indecision among students
regarding their participation in the elections,” the parties stated.

Having mentioned the official calendar of election activities, the parties
also raised concern on the adjustments on the dates in the said calendar,
stating that these changes affected their planning which resulted in
challenges such as lack of adequate time to prepare as a party. They added
that the consecutive suspension of on-site classes may compromise their time
to process pertinent documents required for the electoral process. With this,
they have requested to extend the filing of Certificate of Candidacy (COC)
until May 6.

In response to these, the Executive Officers of PLM COMELEC discussed the
details of the submitted appeal by the said parties, and it was made public
through PLM COMELEC Resolution 6-2024, April 29.

The Commission stated that the scheduled date for the re-accreditation of
political parties was made in compliance with Article 3, Section 35 of the PLM
Omnibus Election Code. Moreover, the scheduled date for the filing of COC was
decided upon by PLM COMELEC and was not decided dependent on the date for the
re-accreditation process.

“Moreover, the scheduled date of the re-accreditation process in relation to
the issuance of the electoral calendar does not necessarily impact the
deadline for the filing of candidacy,” the Commission stated.

Since PLM COMELEC have made previous adjustments in the dates of electoral
events due to unforeseen incidents, they further emphasized the importance of
compliance with the set regulations and deadlines which the political parties
are expected to do so given that the Commission has been putting up
publications to make the student body well-informed.

To address the restrictions imposed by the class suspension, PLM COMELEC made
the filing of COC possible through online modality on April 27, extending the
submission of documents until April 30 to give candidates ample time to do so.

Moreover, the scheduled date for the filing of COC was
decided upon by PLM COMELEC and was not decided dependent on the date for the
re-accreditation process.

“Moreover, the scheduled date of the re-accreditation process in relation to
the issuance of the electoral calendar does not necessarily impact the
deadline for the filing of candidacy,” the Commission stated.

Since PLM COMELEC have made previous adjustments in the dates of electoral
events due to unforeseen incidents, they further emphasized the importance of
compliance with the set regulations and deadlines which the political parties
are expected to do so given that the Commission has been putting up
publications to make the student body well-informed.

To address the restrictions imposed by the class suspension, PLM COMELEC made
the filing of COC possible through online modality on April 27, extending the
submission of documents until April 30 to give candidates ample time to do so.

As decided by the PLM COMELEC En Banc, together with their adviser, they have
respectfully rejected the requests made by the political parties in their
joint appeal letter to the Commission. However, the deadline for the filing of
COC may still be adjusted depending on unforeseen circumstances that may take
place, affecting the execution of the activity.

# Several flooding hit areas of Manila; LGU provides free transportation

Written by Rinoa Angeline Dela Torre • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 4 September 23

To aid stranded commuters, the Manila Disaster Risk Reduction and Management
Office (DRRMO) is providing free transportation services to several areas in
Manila due to heavy rains caused by the southwest monsoon enhanced by Super
Typhoon Saola, Sept. 3.

The Manila NDRRMO is providing free transportation services on two routes:
España to Buendia (loop) and Quiapo to España (loop) since Aug. 31. Mayor
Honey Lacuna has also deployed additional "libreng sakay'' vehicles to help
passengers navigate areas covered in gutter-deep flood water, including Kalaw,
Taft Ave., Vito Cruz, P. Ocampo, Tayuman, Abad Santos, Yuseco, Lacson,
Dapitan, and Maceda in Sampaloc.

The Meisic Police Station also utilized mobile cars deployed to provide free
transportation to stranded areas and monitoring areas affected by the typhoon
for immediate response.

Several districts, including Pedro Gil, Taft Ave., Espana Blvd., Lacson Ave.,
Loyola, Penafrancia, Padre Faura, Kalaw, and Roxas Blvd., have seen flooding,
with water levels ranging from gutter- to half-tire deep.

The national government has suspended work in government offices in the
National Capital Region following the recommendation of the National Disaster
Risk Reduction and Management Council. Classes at all levels and government
offices in Metro Manila were also suspended for two days due to heavy rains.

The Manila DRRMO is actively monitoring flooded areas in the city, and
residents are advised to remain vigilant and take necessary safety precautions
as scattered rain showers and thunderstorms are expected to persist in Manila
over the next few days.

As of a report at 5:00 AM yesterday, Metro Manila continues to face a notable
chance of encountering light to moderate rainfall due to thunderstorms,
indicating potential hazards such as flooding in flood-prone areas.

According to the Philippine state weather bureau PAGASA, Typhoon Hanna, which
primarily impacted Northern Luzon, is expected to exit the Philippine Area of
Responsibility by Sunday night or Monday morning. However, there is still a
possibility of continued rainfall until early this week. As of this writing,
there are still no announcements on the duration of Manila NDRRMO’s free
transportation services.

# ISKOMPOSISYON | Vol. III Issue 3 flowerbed

Written by Gabriel Ciego • Illustration by Ashley May Hernandez | 22 February 23

there used to be flowers growing here

and every now and then they'd fall and i'd pick them up

to pretend that they are your favorite flowers and i am giving it to you

i'd put them between pages of spare books and hide them among my shelves

crossing my fingers that it'll stay that way

come sunday i open your book

and there you are dead petals in powders of meaningless words dried leaves

in dried leaves

there used to be flowers growing here

and every now and then i’d remember how tending nurtures us both

and i look above to blur my eyes with the daily sun

was there a day we did not share the same sky? was there

any moment of peace? of tranquility? the flowers you did not plant

take solace in the candor of temporal fruitlessness

there used to be flowers

growing here

and they still do only every now

and then

# Yulo marks historic back-to-back Olympic triumph, lands second gold for PH
in men’s vault

Written by Raniel Paquingan and Kyla Camilla Martinez • Board by Jared Luis Ysmael Sicat | 4 August 24

There is no stopping for Carlos Yulo, as he snagged the Philippines' second
gold medal in the 2024 Paris Olympics after reigning in the men’s artistic
gymnastics vault, Aug. 4.

Yulo’s almost perfect handspring double front half out pike on his first vault
earned 15.433 points establishing an early gap between the other competitors.
Meanwhile, a safe and steady Kasamatsu double twist in Vault 2 ended him a
decent score of 14.800, catapulting him to the gold podium finish with 15.116.

Filipinos were ready to celebrate, but nail-biter impressive vaults from the
last competitor, Artur Davtyan of Armenia, turned the excitement into anxiety.

Luckily, the Armenian gymnast finished with only 14.966, fifteen hundredths
shy of stealing the gold from the Paris 2024 floor exercise champion paving
Yulo to stand as the first-ever Filipino athlete to win consecutive olympic
gold medals.

A day prior, Yulo secured the Philippines’ first Olympic gold in the men’s
artistic gymnastics category.

# SINEHARIBON 2024

Caption and Photos by Janelle Ugot | 9 May 24

PLMayers gathered at the Justo Alberto Auditorium (JAA) for the first ever
SineHaribon film screening and filmmaker talkback session on May 10, 2024.

Eight films by PLM's young and promising directors are competing for this
year's SineHaribon. The said event is a university-wide film festival
organized by the PLM Independent Film and Arts (PIFA) that aims to showcase
the talents of PLMayers in the field of filmmaking.

# ISKOMPOSISYON | Vol. III Issue 4 patintero

Sulat ni Jhea Buela • Guhit ni Bianca Valenzuela | 16 June 23

Sa simula ng larong ito,

umaapaw ang determinasyon na makaabot sa dulo habang nasa presensya ng
pamilya.

Ngunit sa pagbukod mula sa aking pugad,

saka ko napagtanto

ang takot sa unang yapak

unang halimuyak

na hindi nakasanayan.

Baguhan ako sa isang sayaw;

kung saan ang mga tao’t sasakyan

ay saligwayan

at ang mga klase’y magkabilaan.

Bawat pagtawid nito ay parehas

na pinagkakaingatan.

Sa aking pag-iisa,

naramdaman ko

ang kahinaan ng aking mga pakpak.

Bawat maling pagaspas,

at bawat pagbagsak ng katawang

sarili mo lamang ang sumasalo

— hindi na akap ng isang ina

o akbay ng kuya.

Ngunit sa tinagal ng panahon,

nasanay na rin tayong

humugot ng lakas;

mula sa mga de-latang telepono

kung saan, ang dating pananabik

na marinig ang kanilang boses

sa malayuan

ay kasalukuyang napalitan

ng pangungulila

para sa init ng kanilang

mga salita.

Ang pag-iisa ang siyang

nagpatibay sa atin na magpatuloy

upang makabalik muli

sa bisig ng pamilya’t

maibalik ang kanilang sakripisyo

sa pagkamit ng sariling mga pangarap.

At pagkatapos na lagpasan

ang mga nananayang pagsubok,

mula sa pakikipagpatintero

sa daang mapanghamon,

kumakaripas akong pabalik

sabik na maihiga sa duyan

ang katawang nahapo.

# There’s this waterfall

Written by Charyll Joan Pascua • Board by Angelle Valbuena | 29 September 23

 _Trigger Warning: Mentions of self-harm_

That I have visited at several points in my life

It takes a lot in me to reach it

But I take the path anyway

because lately I find

Myself often going to the waterfall

Sitting on it’s cliff and staring down

Because there are just days when I want to

Let my body and the falling waters collide

If I muster up all the little courage the world has spared me

Will the waterfall’s noise

Finally overpower the voices

In my head cursing my worthless life

Midair, will the waterfall finally grant me

The freedom from the nights

That my demons had haunted me

And give the deepest sleep I long desired

When I hit the surface

Will the water finally numb and cleanse

The pain and resentment

that had been drowning me in the inside

And when I sink will I finally

Be of service to this wicked earth

As I offer myself to its creatures

To tear and swallow me alive

But just before I allowed my fears,

sorrow and rage get the best of me

A voyager out of nowhere

pulled me and said I shouldn’t dive

There he stands beside me, sweating and panting

“Don’t jump,” he repeatedly begs

He brings me to his arms and whimpers

And by the waterfall we cried

He goes on and tells a story

Of how darkness once won over his resolve

But like what he unhesitatingly did to me

Someone saved him from his own will to fall

So trust me when I say today

It will get better; this life

And you may just not know right now

But someone is thankful you’re around

* * *

# Another Haribon competes in TNT: Mendoza proceeds to weekly finals

Written by Mark Anthony Montalban • Board by John Ivan Pasion | 11 July 24

Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) was once again represented in It’s
Showtime’s Tawag ng Tanghalan (TNT): The School Showdown as another haribon
made it to weekly finals, Jul 11.

Julia Faith Mendoza, a graduating student of Bachelor of Music in Music
Performance Major in Voice, got the highest combined scores from the judges
with 93.7 percent as she took on Wicked Broadway’s song, “Defying Gravity.”

Mendoza impressed the hurados, as well the madlang-people, beating the
representative of Lobong National High School.

"Kitang-kita yung knowledge mo, yung taas ng musicality... Gustong-gusto ko
kung paano mo ginamit lahat ng placements mo at ang ganda pakinggan. Actually,
nabitin nga ako doon sa mga head voice mo kanina, sa falsetto mo... I think
that's your strength.", Klarisse de Guzman stated as she believed that her
song was a hard choice, needing much preparation to give justice to her
performance.

She also received praise from the TNT Punong Hurado Ms. Zsazsa Padilla on her
techniques, brilliant voice, and her connection to the audience after she won
the hearts of everyone in her performance.

Mendoza will face this week's daily winner on Saturday for their Prelims
Competition to advance in the 3rd Midterm Round slot (Semi-finals).

# PLM announces management restructuring; some Colleges split up, renamed,
combined

Written by Rylan Gabriel Bernardo • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 29 January 24

Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) is set to introduce new colleges as
part of the reorganization of the University’s management and organizational
structure, Dec. 28, 2023.

Pursuant to Pamantasan Administrative Order No. 26-AD, s. 2023, “Management
Reorganization of the PLM,” the University will undergo amendments in its
Academic Affairs cluster, which will introduce five new colleges.

College of Engineering and Technology (CET) will be split into two separate
colleges: College of Engineering (CE) and College of Information Systems and
Technology Management (CISTM). CET will retain its existing undergraduate
programs except for BS Computer Science (BSCS) and BS Information Technology
(BSIT), which will be under CISTM.

PLM Business School (PLMBS) will also be reorganized into three colleges:
College of Accountancy (CA), College of Business Administration (CBA), and
College of Tourism and Hospitality Management (CTHM).

Meanwhile, College of Architecture and Urban Planning (CAUP) and School of
Government (SOG) will be renamed into College of Architecture and Sustainable
Built Environments (CASBE) and College of Public Administration (CPA),
respectively.

Programs such as Bachelor of Science in Social Work (BSSW) from the School of
Social Work (SSW) and Bachelor of Music in Music Performance from the School
of Music were once again under the College of Humanities, Arts, and Social
Sciences (CHASS).

The colleges will be responsible for directing the entrance requirements and
course of study for its programs, along with initiating and implementing
educational activities of their respective colleges, as subject to review and
approval by the University Council and Board of Regents (BOR), respectively.

This management restructuring by the University intends to streamline PLM’s
operations and further enhance responsiveness to the needs of the learners and
other stakeholders.

Other related programs may be added to the University’s colleges, as subject
to the approval of the BOR.

These changes are set to take effect upon the end of the first semester of
Academic Year 2023-2024.

# Gintong Aral sa kwento ng mga Atletang Pinoy

Written by Jan Rennie Abat • Boards by John Ivan Pasion | 11 August 24

Magbigay-pugay sa mga atletang Pilipino!

Iba-iba man ang mga kwento at karanasan ng ating mga atletang Pilipino sa
Paris Olympics 2024, sila ay mananatiling wagi at mga kampeon ng ating bayan.
At sa kanilang muling pagbabalik sa bansa, hindi lang gintong medalya ang
naiuwing tagumpay– kasama nito ang mga gintong aral na ating babaunin nang
walang humpay.

!

Iba-iba man ang mga kwento at karanasan ng ating mga atletang Pilipino sa
Paris Olympics 2024, sila ay mananatiling wagi at mga kampeon ng ating bayan.
At sa kanilang muling pagbabalik sa bansa, hindi lang gintong medalya ang
naiuwing tagumpay– kasama nito ang mga gintong aral na ating babaunin nang
walang humpay.

# Leyco retracts statement on his retirement as PLM President

Written by Calvin Agustin • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 19 September 23

“Muli ko pong inuulit sa inyo, tutuparin ko ang tungkulin na aking sinumpaan
hanggang sa [aking] makakaya at makakasama sa pagsulong ng PLM,” said
University President Emmanuel Leyco as he addressed the current status of the
PLM in the UniFAST delistment, Sept. 18.

Leyco previously stated that despite having announced his plan to retire, he
added that “...nais ko pong bigyan ng kapanatagan ng loob ang mga kasamahan
natin na nangangarap na patuloy na isulong ang kapakanan ng PLM.”

READ MORE: [Leyco will step down on Sept.
29](https://www.facebook.com/100064439512133/posts/pfbid0iT3gAHU3Akh49xeZdvmECwUvnnXDsdbEcBCp3eFYs11GAvCfE6EjeBgjys1Nv2YMl/?mibextid=cr9u03 )
\- source

During the morning ceremonies, Leyco gave updates to the PLM community
regarding the ongoing fight for free quality tertiary education in line with
the Commission on Higher Education’s (CHED) possible recommendation to delist
the university from its subsidy reimbursement program.

The University President used the University of the Philippines (UP) as an
example, having Atty. Angelo Jimenez as its President. Jimenez finished his
Master’s in Public Management at the National University of Singapore’s Lee
Kuan Yew School of Public Policy and did not pursue a doctoral degree. Leyco
then explained that the very law that established UP is no different from the
law that created PLM, and wondered why this is now an issue to the commission.

Leyco expressed his disappointment on how hearsays and indifferences of the
interpretation of the law impact the university and its stakeholders. He also
reiterated that no personal interest shall come first before the interest and
goals of PLM.

With this, the University President made clear to the whole PLM community that
he will not be stepping down from the presidency.

“Kung kaya’t nais ko pong iparating sa inyo; ako po ay nanumpa na itataguyod
ang interes ng PLM. Ako po ay nanumpa at sa loob ng apat na taon, mayroon ba
tayong nakita? Mayroon ba tayong mga pangyayari na sa pamumuno ng kasalukuyang
administrasyon ay inilugmok [nito] ang PLM? Tayo ba ay pumalya na magpasweldo?
Tayo ba ay pumalya na magbigay-daan ang pagsulong ng ating mga kawani? Bagamat
tayo ay dumaan sa gitna ng napakahirap na pandemya, itinawid natin ang PLM,”
Leyco said.

Furthermore, other university officials were also called on stage to give
updates on the ongoing issue. Vice President for Finance Ms.

Ako po ay nanumpa at sa loob ng apat na taon, mayroon ba
tayong nakita? Mayroon ba tayong mga pangyayari na sa pamumuno ng kasalukuyang
administrasyon ay inilugmok [nito] ang PLM? Tayo ba ay pumalya na magpasweldo?
Tayo ba ay pumalya na magbigay-daan ang pagsulong ng ating mga kawani? Bagamat
tayo ay dumaan sa gitna ng napakahirap na pandemya, itinawid natin ang PLM,”
Leyco said.

Furthermore, other university officials were also called on stage to give
updates on the ongoing issue. Vice President for Finance Ms. Andrea Solomon-
Malunes announced that PLM has received a sum amount of Php 127 million last
Monday from CHED’s UniFAST for the second semester of Academic Year 2022-2023.

Meanwhile, University and Board of Regents Secretary Atty. Carlo Florendo
Castro stated that the university administration will be submitting a position
paper to CHED, signed by the President of the Republic of the Philippines, the
Senate, and the House of Representatives. The said paper will encapsulate
their objection to the treatment of PLM as a local university and college.

Leyco gave his assurance to the university officials, stakeholders, and the
studentry that he will put his best foot forward in advancing the welfare of
Manila’s premier university.

# Tao Ang Nasa Traffic

Written by Gabriel Ciego • Board by Joseph Andrei Torres | 22 January 24

the lines before home are too long.

my watch stays unbroken, peels

each metal inch

into mindless stretches.

the horizons have their silence

the way I would

have: lazily kept

in shoeboxes hiding

under dusty narra.

later my hands will wave off the beeps

of a nearing jeepney, later grab what loose

change remains in my pocket, later

reach for help, later see

a struggling movement

of clenched fists; only

common coins as fuel.

intramuros, hours ago

was a coastline of marooning

daydreams—ashore

the moment I let it go.

_“Humawak ka sa bakal”_

the words start to line my stomach

like barbed wire. and in there

I have yet to believe,

the thought escaping, out there,

always, but never not soon.

# HEROIC MILESTONE: EJ Obiena clinches Philippines' inaugural gold, shatters
Asian Games record in pole vault

Written by Cedrick Paynor • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 12 October 23

EJ Obiena lived up to the high expectations of Filipinos as the Philippines'
top gold prospect by clinching the nation's groundbreaking gold and
establishing a new record at the 19th Asian Games on September 30.

The 27-year-old Filipino pole vault sensation soared to a height of 5.90
meters in the finals, surpassing the previous record of 5.70 meters set by
Japan's Seito Yamamoto during the 2018 Asian Games.

Obiena, who is currently World No. 2 in men's pole vault, rapidly gained
traction in the tournament by clearing 5.55 meters on his first attempt and
later navigating two successful leaps over 5.75 meters.

Obiena stood alone in supremacy in the pole vault finals, being the sole
athlete to clear the 5.75-meter mark and cemented his gold medal victory with
a seamless clearance of 5.90 meters in a single attempt.

Truly a history-maker!

Aside from the current success, in the past five months, Obiena shattered the
six-meter barrier twice, successfully defended his title in the Asian
Athletics Championships, and secured a momentous silver in the World Athletics
Championships last August.

He is also the first Pinoy athlete to qualify in Paris Olympics as he ascended
to a career-high second in the world rankings and garnered a silver in the
Diamond League Final merely two weeks before the Asian Games.

Moreover, Obiena’s Asian Games triumph signified a historic juncture in
Philippine athletics, putting an end to a 29-year gold medal drought since
Elma Muros Posadas secured bronze in women's long jump at the 1994 Hiroshima
Games.

"There is an opportunity and a possibility to achieve greatness, and everybody
would want to be remembered and contribute to the rich legacy of Philippine
sports," Obiena expressed on his Facebook post after his triumphant campaign
at the Asian Games.

This is also the first gold medal achievement by a Filipino track and field
athlete in the Asian Games since the legendary Lydia De Vega's victory in the
century dash during the 1986 Seoul Games in South Korea.

Obiena received a P10-million cash incentive for his outstanding performance
in the Asian Games.

# SSC PRESIDENT | Harapan 2023 Day 2

The Editorial Board | 25 May 23

Here are the answers of the Presidential candidates of the Supreme Student
Council as they stand before the students at the Justo Alberto Auditorium for

# New Board of Regents Chair meets with student councils and campus
publication, recognizes recent licensure examinations topnotchers

Written by Alessandra Frianela • Photos by Roland Justin Molato | 6 December 23

The newly elected Chairman of the PLM Board of Regents (BOR) Atty. Edward S.
Serapio invited the heads and representatives of the Supreme Student Council
(SSC), College Student Councils (CSCs), and Ang Pamantasan (AP) for a lunch
meeting at the Ilustrado Restaurant, Dec. 5.

Atty. Serapio initiated a dialogue with student representatives to discuss the
important matters in the university.

“We meet with all the different groups in our PLM community to learn from them
the challenges and issues. But I am also excited in hearing from you, the
students,” the new Chairman of BOR stated.

The chairman started the meeting by extending his message to the students,
faculty, and staff of PLM. He assured that together with Mayor Lacuna-Pangan,
the City Council, PLM President Sonny Reyes, other esteemed members of the
Board, the dedicated faculty, and the passionate staff, PLM will continue to
be a breeding ground for excellence.

“I am confident that we can further elevate the Pamantasan’s status as one of
the leading institutions of higher learning in the Philippines,” Atty. Serapio
said.

The governing body of the Pamantasan, the BOR, will be following fundamental
principles that will further guide the Board in their governance; Academic
Excellence, Academic Freedom, Affirmative action to Protect the Rights of
Students to Free and Quality Education, and Commitment to the promotion of the
professional and economic rights of academic and non-academic personnel.

In order to pursue academic excellence in the University, the BOR will strive
to create an environment that fosters intellectual growth, encourages
innovation, and provides the necessary tools and resources to excel in the
student’s chosen fields.

Atty. Serapio stated that he is open with dialogue, exchange of ideas, and
respectful debate among the studentry to push the boundaries of knowledge and
the exercise academic freedom.

“We pledge to protect and uphold the academic freedom of our students,
faculty, and staff, allowing for the exploration of diverse perspectives and
the pursuit of truth without fear of censorship or reprisal,” he emphasized.

The chairman also mentioned that the BOR will actively work towards creating
equal opportunities for all talented individuals, regardless of socio-economic
background.

Affirmative actions are being planned to protect the rights of students to
free and quality education. Alternative and equitable admission process will
be provided to enhance the access of poor but deserving students from Manila.
Financial grants and allowances will also be given to students from indigent
families. “We will include these allowances and grants in our budget, and we
will zealously solicit donations from benefactors to make this possible.”

The BOR Chair believes the dedicated staff and faculty from PLM are the
backbone of the institution, and their well-being and growth are crucial for
its collective success. A fair compensation, professional development
opportunities, and conducive work environment that fosters growth and
recognizes invaluable contributions will be advocated.

At the end of his speech, Atty. Serapio mentioned that he looks forward to
working closely with the students to achieve the shared vision for the
Pamantasan.

Affirmative actions are being planned to protect the rights of students to
free and quality education. Alternative and equitable admission process will
be provided to enhance the access of poor but deserving students from Manila.
Financial grants and allowances will also be given to students from indigent
families. “We will include these allowances and grants in our budget, and we
will zealously solicit donations from benefactors to make this possible.”

The BOR Chair believes the dedicated staff and faculty from PLM are the
backbone of the institution, and their well-being and growth are crucial for
its collective success. A fair compensation, professional development
opportunities, and conducive work environment that fosters growth and
recognizes invaluable contributions will be advocated.

At the end of his speech, Atty. Serapio mentioned that he looks forward to
working closely with the students to achieve the shared vision for the
Pamantasan.

“If you have any ideas, suggestions, or concerns regarding the University’s
development, please do not hesitate to share them with us. Your input will be
invaluable as we navigate the path towards excellence,” the Chairman
highlighted.

City Administrator Bernie Ang joined the meeting to address his insights on
the possible improvements that they envision for the university. “We have the
best plan for PLM,” he stated.

Atty. Serapio also mentioned that the City Administrator will help the Board
address all the challenges faced in the University. They will be joined hand
in hand with the rest of the appointed members namely Dr. Joseph Berlin P.
Juanzon, Atty. Domingo Y. Reyes, Jr., and Dr. Neri S. Pescadera.

Atty. Serapio congratulated different colleges for their excellence including
the College of Nursing, Physical Therapy, and Law for their stellar
performances in the recently released Licensure and Bar Exams.

The topnotchers from the recently concluded November 2023 Philippines Nurses
Licensure Examination; Aristotle Castronuevo, Ian Rocky Aguirre, Aiyanah Jhen
Flores, and Nia Angeli Reyes were recognized during the said meeting and
received a congratulatory gift from the Chairman.

In a letter to the PLM College of Law, the Chairman extended his heartfelt
congratulations to the twenty-seven PLM graduates who have successfully passed
the 2023 Bar Exams. “We will collectively and continuously work for the
betterment of our academic programs and support systems to ensure that all of
our aspiring lawyers are equipped with the knowledge and skills necessary to
pass the Bar Exams and excel in their professional endeavors.”

# ICYMI | PLM Law reduces units for admission; Math, Social Sciences units no longer required

Written by Zarena Hermogeno • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 24 August 23

The Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila’s (PLM) College of Law now requires 12
English units for admission to the PLM Juris Doctor Program.

Previously, the College of Law required 15 units of English for incoming
freshmen last March 2023.

In 2022, pursuant to the Legal Education Board (LEB) released Memorandum
Circular No. 122, Series of 20221, the College of Law removed 6 units of
Mathematics and 18 units of Social Science as a prerequisite to admission in
the Juris Doctor program but retained the 18 units of English as a
requirement.

The PLM College of Law Student Council (CLSC) petitioned for the reduction of
required units last May 2023.

As a result, PLM CLSC released Memorandum No. 2023-0627-02 indicating that the
PLM Juris Doctor Program requires 12 English units and that Social Science and
Math units were no longer required for admission.

This memo also takes effect immediately and retroactively. A copy of the
above-cited memorandum can be accessed through:

https://bit.ly/CLSCMO-2023-0627-02

Also stated in its memo, the resolution hopes to aid the students in
“defraying additional costs while maintaining the quality of legal education
in the College by ensuring that students are in good command of the English
language.”

Last year, PLM out betted 58 schools with 11-50 candidates in the 2022 Bar
Examinations and was hailed as the third top-performing law school in the
country with a performance rating of 81.82% passers.

# PIFA conducts first-ever university-wide film festival; submission of
entries extends

Written by Jeanette Tropa • Board by Angelle Valbuena | 16 April 24

Organized by the PLM Independent Film and Arts (PIFA), SineHaribon will take
center stage as the pioneering university-wide film festival poised to
illuminate the campus with a celebration of cinematic brilliance. Scheduled
for May 10-11 and 18, 2024, this event is part of the organization's
dedication to fostering creativity and providing a platform for emerging
filmmakers to flourish.

True to their vision, PIFA focuses on practical learning and artistic
development with the aim of cultivating a vibrant film culture within the PLM
community. As they usher in a new era of cinematic storytelling, they proudly
announced the inaugural year of SineHaribon on March 6th.

From PELIKUWIKA and HARIHUNI, PIFA has laid the groundwork for SineHaribon to
foster collaboration and showcase the talents of PLM students. Now, with the
theme “Bagong Simula,” PIFA, through SineHaribon, invites students from all
year levels and courses to submit their short films, supposedly until April 15
but was extended until April 21.

As the name signifies, SineHaribon represents the convergence of two powerful
forces: the magic of cinema and the untamed spirit of the eagle. Hence, it is
more than just a film festival; it's a celebration of creativity, innovation,
and the boundless possibilities of cinematic expression, soaring with the
spirit of storytelling and the pursuit of artistic excellence.

In an interview with Kendrick Clement Reyes, the Festival Director for
SineHaribon I, they revealed that the motivations behind SineHaribon stem from
the absence of a film culture within PLM. Among the goals of the event are to
provide enjoyment for PLM students, lay the foundation for a film culture, and
establish PLM's presence in the filmmaking community.

“We also want to stand out din and makilala rin yung PLM na meron din kami
nun, na meron din tayong film culture and we have, [tawag dito], mga aspiring
or not aspiring actually kasi filmmakers na rin talaga sila as of the moment.”

PIFA expresses neutral expectations for the first SineHaribon, emphasizing the
importance of support from PLM students. As a growing tradition, they envision
SineHaribon evolving into a cornerstone event, expanding its audience and
maintaining its purpose of fostering a film culture within PLM.

“Sana ito magtuloy-tuloy. Ayun naman yung purpose namin na itong SineHaribon
year one ay magsisimula ng punla at sa mga susunod ay uusbong ito katulad ng
isang puno o isang halaman. So sana mas maging maayos, mas makilala and mas
mag-expand yung mga audience and all.”

In addition to the excitement surrounding the festival, PIFA has proudly
unveiled its esteemed panel of judges for SineHaribon 2024 last April 11.

As a growing tradition, they envision
SineHaribon evolving into a cornerstone event, expanding its audience and
maintaining its purpose of fostering a film culture within PLM.

“Sana ito magtuloy-tuloy. Ayun naman yung purpose namin na itong SineHaribon

In addition to the excitement surrounding the festival, PIFA has proudly
unveiled its esteemed panel of judges for SineHaribon 2024 last April 11.
Evaluating the entries with their wisdom and expertise in the field are judges
Zig Dulay, Gabriela Serrano, Gleen Barit, and Ma-an Asuncion Dagnalan.

As the countdown to SineHaribon continues, PLM students are encouraged to
submit their films and join in the celebration of cinematic brilliance.

# Student Governance is Student Trust

Written by John Coby Cabuhat • Board by John Ivan Pasion | 3 October 23

Public office is public trust, as a principle, has been an effective guide for
public service and also applies to student governance.

Amidst the concerns raised by student political parties, a democratic
alliance, student organizations, and college student councils on bullying
incidents allegedly perpetuated by ‘student servants’ from the University’s
highest-governing student body, restoring trust among the studentry is
paramount.

Integrity is about doing what is right even if no one is looking. The claims
may be divulged or not, student servants must uphold integrity and be a model
to the studentry. Student leaders being good in public is no use if there are
moments when they are not true to their principles when students cannot see
them. This is demanding integrity by a constituent from their elected
officials and leaders.

It can be agreed that no one is perfect and may be susceptible to mistakes. At
the same time, integrity and offices of student governance are no ordinary
principles and positions to take lightly. The mistakes have been allegedly
made and trust has been put into question but, what will be the resolution?
Remorse from mistakes and proactively taking accountability may have been the
way.

One may argue that self-imposition of corrective and disciplinary measures is
not hard for those who genuinely would like to show remorse. Community service
for the University and issuance of public apology, it may be for the victims
or for the student body in general, may be reasonable instead of seeing the
involved “student servants” walking around campus as if nothing has happened.

If it is true that an “internal” investigation was being conducted, preventive
suspension of involved officials is a standard move to keep them from
exercising the powers vested to them. The concern about the continuity of the
operations of the council is valid. If it is really their position to not
hinder the operations, suspensions could be done alternatively per involved
officials while the investigation is ongoing. This is because the issue
involves a large part of the bureaucracy of the council.

Article XV of the 2014 Supreme Student Council (SSC) Constitution and By-Laws
provides who will impeach officials and why should they be impeached. It is
upon the SSC officers to impeach an officer with their majority vote based on
several grounds in accordance with Section 2 of the article.

One of the grounds is If an SSC officer is found to deliberately violate the
constitution (Section 2a, Article XV). But, what could be a violation of the
SSC Constitution?

This may be the failure of an officer to put priority in defending and
electing the rights and general welfare of the studentry in the University
stipulated in Section 2b, Article II of the same constitution.

It may also be a violation of the constitution if an officer fails to serve
the highest sense of responsibility, integrity, dignity, and efficiency… to
the studentry and the university (Section 1, Article XV).

The other grounds for impeachment is if an officer acted or conducted inimical
to the interest of the PLM SSC (Section 2d, Article XV).

It does not say anything about filing a case with the Office of Student
Development and Services, though the filed case may further help in the
decision-making of the council.

But, what could be a violation of the
SSC Constitution?

This may be the failure of an officer to put priority in defending and
electing the rights and general welfare of the studentry in the University
stipulated in Section 2b, Article II of the same constitution.

It may also be a violation of the constitution if an officer fails to serve
the highest sense of responsibility, integrity, dignity, and efficiency… to
the studentry and the university (Section 1, Article XV).

The other grounds for impeachment is if an officer acted or conducted inimical
to the interest of the PLM SSC (Section 2d, Article XV).

It does not say anything about filing a case with the Office of Student
Development and Services, though the filed case may further help in the
decision-making of the council. The article does not provide procedures.
Hence, the matter could be handled the way how council decides on its matters.
One way is by voting on the matter may be through an adoption or approval of a
resolution.

In the application of basic parliamentary procedures with the absence of
internal rules and procedures, it is just reasonable that a meeting could be
called upon with a quorum, and if the presiding officer is involved the next
in line could preside over the meeting.

In line with due process, the involved parties may be called upon to present
their cases and open the proceeding to the interested members of the student
body.

If the body determined that due diligence has been made in the conduct of the
meeting, a resolution could be drafted relevant to the impeachment and let the
SSC officers vote based on the merits of the cases and arguments presented.

Out of _delecadeza_ and common sense _,_ it is just for the involved parties
to be recused from the decision-making of the council. There is also a
question on the characterization of the majority vote. Basic parliamentary
procedures with the absence of internal rules and procedures, suggest that it
is more than half of the officers present in the meeting and not by more than
half of the total number of voting members.

For the members of the student body, you may call on your respective College
Representatives and uninvolved Executive Officers to do what is necessary and
just. Proceedings related to Article XV must be transparent.

In the matter of the continuity of governance, suspending or even the removal
of a large number of the officials may lead the studentry to appoint
additional student officials or even hold special elections if the
constitution permits.

Given the track record of previous elections, there are lone candidates for
the Secretary, no candidate for the Auditor, no candidates in some college
representative posts, and lone slates for the majority of the College Student
Councils. If this path will be pursued, to what extent can the student
participate in governance? Are there students who will step up after this
fiasco? These are the questions for the whole student body.

However, the alleged bullying, whether a victim has resolved it with the
involved parties (though, other victims must also be considered) must not be
tolerated. **The student body has already let a former administration off the
hook for their own political mistakes. This time, accountability must prevail.
If trust cannot be restored, how can students approach whom they voted for and
supposedly the representatives of their interests?**

The stakes are too high and there is a need for a functional and formidable
student council. There are vacancies in the Board of Regents posts, the
highest governing body of the University.

It is unclear if the Pamantasan has a President or an officer-in-charge or if
the budget of the council has been approved. Also, the implementation of the
council’s programs and activities, and attending to day-to-day concerns from
the student body.

Student governance is student trust. Without trust, how will the student body
move forward with these issues and agenda of the student council?

# One day left: Graduates raise concerns; SSC urges student representation to
Graduation Committee

Written by John Coby Cabuhat • Board by Stefanie Santilla | 5 September 23

One day before the 55th Commencement Exercises, graduating students of Class
2023 raised concerns over the preparation and conduct of ceremonies, Sept. 6.

Students who are set to graduate on Sept. 7 and 8 shared their frustrations
online about the lapses of the University particularly on the release of the
list of graduates and Latin honors, distribution of tickets, concerns raised
during the orientation, and other graduation policies.

“The fact that this institution has been established since 1965 and yet the
administration can’t even plan the commencement exercises well,” an anonymous
member of the University's online community said.

A member also called out the Supreme Student Council (SSC) on the updates in
communicating the concerns to the University administration.

“Anyway, for transparency, sana magrelease na kayo statement ng naging bunga
ng meeting nyo with the admins…” a member posted anonymously.

On the other hand, SSC shared the updates related to graduating students with
Ang Pamantasan.

As of this writing, the University Graduation Committee said that the approved
list of graduates are with the Office of University Registrar already and to
be supposedly released yesterday, Sept. 5.

Another anonymous member also shared, “Hanggang ngayon wala pa ring list of
graduates, sobrang lugi na kaming graduating na pinaghandaan namin ang
graduation…”

In addition, graduands also reacted that their photos and names will not be
projected at the venue once their names are called.

The issues mentioned on anonymous posts were confirmed upon reaching out of
Ang Pamantasan to graduating students.

****

**SSC: No student rep in the committee**

SSC President Vince De Guzman said that all concerns regarding the graduation
have only been forwarded since there was no student representative on the
committee.

“As of now, lahat ng concerns ay nilalapit ko sa kanila since wala ngang
student representative sa University Graduation Committee which is we think
[ay] vital talaga to direct concerns na rin sa kanila and [makatulong] fully
sa programs and events,” De Guzman said with Ang Pamantasan.

The SSC President added that the Ad-Hoc Committee was only composed of faculty
members and administrators.

Last night, the council sent a letter to the Office of the Vice President for
Academic Affairs through the Office of Student Development and Services
regarding student concerns on graduation ceremonies.

“…we humbly request that the University heighten its urgency about the said
matters,” SSC urged.

De Guzman mentioned that they initially recommended addressing the issue of
flashing graduands’ photos and names at the Philippine International
Convention Center, the venue of the ceremonies last July 31.

SSC had a discussion with the administration again last Aug. 24 and said that
management did not allow the request.

The council divulged that they started addressing the concerns for graduation
rites with the administration as early as Aug. 15, particularly the
recognition for transferees and shifters who are underload.

The undergraduates are set to attend the commencement exercises on Sept. 7 and
8.

This is a developing story.

# Carlos Yulo secures Philippines’ first Olympic gold of the year, bags first
medal for southeast Asia

Written by Kyla Camilla Martinez • Board by John Ivan Pasion | 3 August 24

Carlos Yulo delivered this year’s first Olympic gold medal for the Philippines
as he finished with 15.000 points, achieving the highest score in the men's
gymnastics floor finals at the Paris Olympic Games 2024.

Yulo’s flawless' three-and-a-half twist dismount rules the men’s artistic
gymnastic floor, which gained Artem Dolgopyat (Tokyo 2020 champion) from
Israel (14.966), his silver placement followed by Great Britain’s Jake Jarman
to earn bronze (14.933).

Achieving this, the six-time world champion also clinched the first gold medal
for the Southeast Asia teams in the same event.

Placing his hand on his heart, Caloy’s triumph became his redemption after
finishing last in the all around qualifications in the 2023 World
Championships–receiving a 0.000 score on the vault.

Yulo is the second Filipino who won a gold medal for the Philippines following
Hidilyn Diaz’s same feat in the women’s 55-kg weightlifting event in the 2020
Summer Olympics.

# Ang Pamantasan, COMELEC sign MOU for fair, clean, and transparent PLM
Elections

Written by Jeanette Tropa • Photos by Stefanie Santilla | 13 May 24

The PLM Student Commission on Election (COMELEC) and Ang Pamantasan (AP)
signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) in line with their partnership for
the conduct of the PLM Supreme Student Council (SSC) and College Student
Council (CSC) Elections 2024 and its related electoral activities, May 13.

Aiming to strengthen voter education and empowerment, the MOU formalized the
partnership between the two independent and non-partisan organizations.

“The COMELEC and AP recognizes the importance of fair, clean, transparent
student elections in the university, and recognize the role of the media in
informing the public and promoting good governance,” the two organizations
stated in MOU.

Present at the signing were Stefanie Ann M. Santilla, Managing Editor; and
Jeanette B. Tropa, Board Secretary of Ang Pamantasan. COMELEC was represented
by Zion C. Malibunas, Chairperson; and Rafael George F. Fornoles, Operations
Officer.

As part of this partnership, AP will provide special coverage and publish
articles related to the election, provide a platform for COMELEC's conferences
and announcements, and contribute questions for the Harapan 2024: Elections
Debate.

Bantay Halalan 2024 is the Special Coverage of AP for the PLM SSC & CSC
Elections 2024.

# Fitted: PLMayer’s film competes as a finalist for best short film in Asia

Written by John Coby Cabuhat • Poster by Jaed Ababao | 11 November 23

“To tell the stories of little queer boys and girls that being different
doesn’t mean you have to embrace yourself in the dark but rather shine the
most in the light.”

This has been the inspiration for the short film, “Fitted”, directed by a
PLMayer that was selected as a finalist in the Best Short Film - Vertical
Category of Viddsee Juree Awards Asia 2023 last Nov. 2.

The director of the film is Jaerick Dionuel Ababao or Jaed, which most people
call him, is a senior communication student from the College of Humanities,
Arts, and Social Sciences.

Ababao described the vertical short film as a teaser, which is about the story
of a boy finding a new world.

“In a magical closet, a young boy finds a new world of joy. His mother must
choose whether to encourage his pursuit of happiness in the outside world,”
the Viddsee finalist teased in a written reply through an exclusive request.

Together with his fellow senior communication student, Amor Merjudo who served
as the Director of Photography, did the film as part of their internship
within their program.

As part of their journey in the competition, Fitted is among other films to be
voted for Audience Choice Award on a website and Tiktok until Nov. 13, Monday.
The following are the steps for voting Fitted as your favorite film:

On Tiktok

Step 1. Go to Viddsee TikTok account.

Step 2. Find your favorite film post.

Step 3. Like, comment, or share your favorite film.

On Viddsee’s website (viddsee.com)

Step 1. Sign in to Viddsee with a free registered account.

Step 2. Check out the Audience Choice Awards lineup.

Step 3. Click the heart icon to vote for your favorite film.

Ababao thanked everyone who welcomed Fitted “with open arms” in support of
this special piece for the LGBTQ+ community.

“It is truly an honor to be part of this event, but the love and support that
comes from our fellow Haribons [is what] makes this remarkable,” the Fitter’s
director added.

Viddsee is an entertainment platform that drives distribution and marketing of
short premium content that targets global audience to showcase especially the
Asia.

# Isang Uyayi sa Maingay na Mundo

Written by Jan Rennie Abat • Board by Junnine Tupaz | 19 February 24

Sa mundo ng ligalig, ang mahalin ka ay isang uyayi.

Paulit-ulit akong sumusulyap sa iyong mga mata. Puno ng buhay. Puno ng saya.
Mistulang nawawala ang ingay ng mundo at nababawasan ang pangamba sa tuwing
ikaw ay nasa tabi. At wala mang kasiguraduhan ang hinaharap, sa atin ay ako’y
tiyak.

Ganito pala ang pakiramdam ng magmahal– gugustuhing ika’y makapiling sa bawat
paraan at pagkakataong makakaya. Ikaw ay haharanahin sa'yong paboritong
awitin. Ikaw ay susulatan ng liham kung saan ibubuhos sa bawat letra ang
damdamin.

"Hindi ba't naikwento mo noon?" ang bungad ko kapag ibibigay na ang inihandog
na regalo para sa'yo. Sa isang oras nating magkasama ay hindi halata ang pagod
sa tatlong oras na ibiniyahe mo patungong Intramuros.

Ikaw ay bibisita dala-dala ang kape at sorbetes sa mga araw na tila hindi ko
na kaya ang bigat ng mga gawain sa Pamantasan. Unti-unti ay mapapapikit.
Makararamdam ng antok dahil pahinga ang makasama ka.

Ganito pala ang pakiramdam ng mahalin– hawak-kamay na lalabas upang maghapunan
at sa paglakad sa kalsada ng napapaderang lungsod ay ako lagi ang nasa
tagiliran. Hindi ba’t kay sarap magmahal lalo na kapag nasusuklian?

At sa kabila ng hindi perpektong pag-ibig— ng mga araw na may hindi
pagkakaintindihan at pagtatampuhan; ng mga pagtatalo na nauuwi rin sa suyuan
ay mapagtatantong higit na nananaig ang kagustuhang unawain ang isa't-isa— ang
ating pagmamahalan.

Dahil sa dami ng nangyayari, ang ating pagmamahalan ay isang himig na
nagpapakalma sa akin. Tila isang uyayi sa bawat araw na dadaan. At sa mga
dadating na Bagong Taon, Araw ng mga Puso, at ano mang okasyon— ikaw at ikaw
ang pipiliin.

# PLM confers honorary degrees to its guests of honor

Written by Calvin Agustin • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 13 September 23

Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila’s (PLM) Board of Regents (BOR) bestowed
honorary degrees to profound public servants during its 55th Commencement
Exercises at the Philippine International Convention Center, Sept. 7-8.

The honorees were Hon. Aquilino Martin “Koko” De La Llana Pimentel III, Senate
Minority Leader; Hon. Judy Marigomen Taguiwalo, former Department of Social
Welfare and Development Secretary; Her Excellency Chantale Yok-Min Wong,
United States Ambassador of the Asian Development Bank; and Hon. Alexander
Gahon Gesmundo, Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the Philippines.

In the first session, Pimentel was conferred with Doctor of Laws, honoris
causa for his outstanding contributions in the field of law, public
governance, and administration. Afterward, Pimentel responded and delivered
his commencement address, commending the PLM community for their hard work in
achieving the students’ academic triumph. He then emphasized the university’s
role in nation-building as a provider of quality education.

“Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila, through its commitment to excellence and
social responsibility, exemplifies the transformative education that our
nation needs by fostering a learning environment that equips students with
competency, skills, and values. Institutions like PLM laid the foundation for
a future where public servants, leaders, and citizens are committed to the
betterment of society,” Pimentel said.

Doctor of Humanities, honoris causa was conferred upon Taguiwalo in the second
session for her lifelong advocacy for human rights, women empowerment, and
gender equality. In her commencement address, she tackled the university’s
history and contributions of individuals who made PLM what it is today.
Taguiwalo also shared the story of Liliosa Hilao, the first Filipina student-
activist killed during Martial Law.

“Malamang naiisip ninyo, panahon ng pagtatapos namin ngayon, panahon ng
selebrasyon, bakit isang pinatay limampung taon na ang nakakaraan ang aking
ibinabahagi? Ito ay sa simple at taos-pusong intensyon na kilalanin na may mga
dakila na hanay ng estudyante ang PLM noon at sa tingin ko, hanggang ngayon na
tumitindig para sa sa katotohanan at karunungan,” Taguiwalo said.

In the third session, Wong was recognized with the degree of Doctor of
Humanities, honoris causa for her exemplary community service not only in the
United States but also for developing Asia, including the Philippines. She has
also been known for her advocacy on fiscal transparency and development
finance. Afterward, Wong addressed the graduates and recognized the
extraordinary resilience it took for them to navigate their academic journey.
She also shared her story of service to Manila and the value of public
service.

Ito ay sa simple at taos-pusong intensyon na kilalanin na may mga
dakila na hanay ng estudyante ang PLM noon at sa tingin ko, hanggang ngayon na
tumitindig para sa sa katotohanan at karunungan,” Taguiwalo said.

In the third session, Wong was recognized with the degree of Doctor of
Humanities, honoris causa for her exemplary community service not only in the
United States but also for developing Asia, including the Philippines. She has
also been known for her advocacy on fiscal transparency and development
finance. Afterward, Wong addressed the graduates and recognized the
extraordinary resilience it took for them to navigate their academic journey.
She also shared her story of service to Manila and the value of public
service.

“As you embark on this new chapter, considering the profound privilege of your
education [that] your family, your city, your country has invested in you, I
implore you to give back, to consider a career in public service… In
hindsight, I can confidently declare, it is the most fulfilling endeavor.
There is no higher calling than working to solve the challenging problems
facing you and your fellow citizens,” Wong said.

Lastly, Supreme Court Chief Justice Gesmundo will be conferred with Doctor of
Laws, Honoris Causa in the last session of the commencement rites on Sept. 28.

BOR recognized the aforementioned individuals with honorary degrees for their
“exemplary record, achievements, and service to the Filipino people, as well
as their awards of distinction, whose virtues are worthy of emulation.”
Present in the conferment rites of the honorees were BOR Chairperson Atty.
Jose Ngaw, Vice Chairperson and University President Emmanuel Leyco, and
members of the Board.

This year’s theme for the 55th Commencement Exercises of Manila’s premier
university was “PLM Transformation: Quality Education for the Public
Interest.”

# TNT contender from PLM advances to 2nd Midterm Round

Written by Mark Anthony Montalban • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 9 June 24

Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) College of Nursing student Claire Maaba
belted her way to the semifinals round of the Tawag ng Tanghalan (TNT): The
School Showdown after getting the highest average score of 96.3, June 8.

Maaba amazed the judges, hosts and audiences at the Showtime studio while
singing “Ain't Nobody” by Chaka Khan.

"Claire, ito lang masasabi ko... I love it from the very beginning until the
end. You were fabulous," Louie Ocampo commented on her performance.

She was also praised by Darren Espanto on her Daily Performance last Wednesday
on how her dynamics and storytelling was so beautiful as she charmed everyone
with her performance of the song “Better Days” that received a 94.3 average
score.

Maaba will face the other four semi finalists to battle for the Golden
Medallion as a ticket for the Grand Finale of this show.

# PLMBS Jaguars prey on CED Titans, rule PLM intrams basketball

Written by Raniel Paquingan • Photo by Dean Joseph Palapar • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 23 August 23

Lions might be the kings of the jungle, but jaguars proved to be the kings and
queens of PLM basketball.

PLM Business School (PLMBS) survived tight back-to-back title faceoffs against
the College of Education (CED) to reign anew in men’s basketball and
flawlessly dominate its women’s division in the PLM Intramurals 2023 held at
the Raja Sulayman Gym, August 10.

The PLMBS men's squad relied on their almost perfect perimeter and inside
scoring to end the resistant CED’s championship hope, 77-71, and bring back
the trophy to their college for two consecutive tournaments.

Led by George Edward Craw, the Jaguars took early access to the driver's seat
against the Titans with their impressive performance on both ends of the
court, establishing an 8-point lead at the end of the first frame, 24-16.

Craw tallied 23 points, followed by Vince Joseph Esgana and Jeshrick Renz
Ocana, who contributed 18 and 10, respectively.

The Titans rallied during the second period to tame the Jaguars and cut the
lead by just a single point at the end of the first half, thanks to Walliant
Barren Burog’s hot hands. Christian Jacob Laher assisted Burog and sank back-
to-back treys to give CED the lead at the 7-minute mark of the third frame.

Burog finished with 22 points, including four triples, and found support from
John Miles Marcelino with 12 and Laher with 9, all of which came from behind
the arc.

CED’s grasp of the lead did not last long, and everything went from bad to
worse for the Titans after losing one of their offense providers, Marcelino,
in the payoff period and unstoppable close and midrange scoring from Craw and
Esgana.

The CED stalwart was called for a disqualifying foul after getting entangled
and heated up with Joemylex Brent Dela Cruz of PLMBS while jostling for a
rebound, effectively ejecting him out of the game.

Emotions were high during the hard-fought finals clash of men’s basketball
that saw at least five players from both teams get either a technical or
unsportsmanlike foul.

The Jaguars took great advantage of the situation and started to pull away
from the handicapped Titans in the final minutes, despite persistent attempts
from the latter to get close.

Craw’s crucial fastbreak steal in the dying seconds of the game that disrupted
CED’s run, aided by their lockdown defense and championship experience,
secured PLMBS their back-to-back men’s basketball titles at the intramurals.

"Ang lamang namin sa laro ay height advantage, tsaka may depensa kami tsaka
shooting sa perimeter at three points kaya kami lumamang," Craw said on their
advantage against the Titans.

that saw at least five players from both teams get either a technical or
unsportsmanlike foul.

The Jaguars took great advantage of the situation and started to pull away
from the handicapped Titans in the final minutes, despite persistent attempts
from the latter to get close.

Craw’s crucial fastbreak steal in the dying seconds of the game that disrupted
CED’s run, aided by their lockdown defense and championship experience,
secured PLMBS their back-to-back men’s basketball titles at the intramurals.

"Ang lamang namin sa laro ay height advantage, tsaka may depensa kami tsaka
shooting sa perimeter at three points kaya kami lumamang," Craw said on their
advantage against the Titans.

Before facing CED, PLMBS caged the College of Humanities, Arts, and Social
Sciences Blue Ravens to advance to the finals, 68-43.

On the other hand, the championship clash for women’s basketball followed a
similar storyline after PLMBS also found success and crushed their fated
rivals from CED, with the help of their jaguar-like strength and speed, 64-52.

The more skilled Jaguars shifted to high gear in the fourth quarter to further
distance themselves from the Titans, led by Kyla Ramirez, who supplied more
than half of PLMBS’ points with 36, while Maria Isavel Trisha Mendoza
contributed 15.

Nicole Jay Dayrit and Maycaylla Evardo powered CED’s offense with 16 and 14,
respectively, but the squad ran out of gas and was unable to keep up with the
Jaguars' fast-paced game.

Turnovers and missed charities also haunted the Titans, and a three-point
dagger in the closing minute from Ramirez hammered the last nail in CED’s
coffin, sealing the victory and the title for PLMBS.

"Dapat kapag naglalaro ka lagi kang nasa puso. Kapag nagte-training naman
kami, binibigay din namin lahat yung best namin," Ramirez stated.

Ramirez and the Jaguars swept all of their games in the intramurals with a 4-0
slate.

# Panday Sining PLM marks Bonifacio Day through mural art

Written by Rylan Gabriel Bernardo • Board by Arjay Samson | 4 December 23

Panday Sining PLM held a mural-making event on the campus Freedom Wall in
commemoration of Bonifacio Day, dated Nov. 29 - 30.

The national democratic mass organization conducted the mural painting in
celebration of the late hero's fight against imperialism. This initiative aims
to rally the youth's participation in resisting the current indirect
imperialism from the US and China.

"Ngayon naman ay patuloy pa rin tayong kinakalaban ng imperyalismo which is
may indirektang pananakop sa atin ng US at China. Ito 'yung pinapakita ng
ating mural art na ang mga kabataan [bilang] malawak na hanay ng masa ay
makisama na gapiin itong dalawang pwersa o 'yung malalaking pwersa ng
imperyalismo sa bansa," Panday Sining PLM Education and Research Officer
Arthur Jude Mendoza said.

The accessibility of the mural on the university's Freedom Wall amplified the
calls of Panday Sining PLM to overthrow imperialism and increase the awareness
of the broad masses on its manifestation in the country, Secretary General of
Panday Sining National Ariana P. Villamor said.

"Gusto namin bilang mga iskolar ng bayan sa Pamantasan na gamitin 'yung
talento namin sa art para magsulong ng mga panawagan ng mga manggagawa, mga
iskolar ng bayan, at ‘tsaka ng pinakamalawak na hanay ng masa,” Villamor
added.

The two-day creation of the mural underscored the youth’s role, specifically
students, in serving the broad masses to bring about social change.

"Bilang Panday Sining, ang layunin namin ay baguhin 'yung namumutawing kultura
sa Pilipinas which is colonial, feudal, and bourgeoisie [...] dapat sinusulong
natin 'yung kulturang national, scientific, at mass-oriented culture,”
Villamor further emphasized, adding that the mural was used politically to
emphasize the cultural involvement of arts in socio-political matters.

Earlier, the organization also took part in the multi-sectoral mob along with
Panday Sining National and other labor groups at Kalaw Avenue to commemorate
Bonifacio Day and to raise their calls on sociopolitical and labor issues.

# Ang Aking Kanlungan

Written by Estelle Theresa Gulay • Board by Elyse Abadilla | 13 May 24

Minsan nang sa atin ay nabanggit–“ang ina ang ilaw ng tahanan.” Mukhang hindi
naman nagkamali ang mga gurong nag-ani bagkus dinaig ni nanay ang liwanag at
init na hatid ng araw sa kaniyang kakayahang magpamulat sa akin. “Bumangon ka
na, tanghali na!” ang bungad sa aking umaga, kasunod ang paroo’t parineng
sermon na madalas ay labas pasok na lamang sa aking tainga.

Ilaw ka nga ng tahanan, ina. Tunay na nariyan para ako’y gabayan sa aking
bawat hakbang, mula sa pagkasilang hanggang sa pagtanda. Hanggang sa pagtanda
na ako’y mayroon nang sariling kaisipang ibig kong ihayag ngunit inanino ng
tingkad ng ‘yong liwanag; nagahis ng iyong mga salita–ng iyong mga pangaral na
tila ‘di dapat pabulaanan.

Subali’t sa kabila ng inis sa madalas mong pagwakas sa aking tinig; sa bawa’t
utos at bukambibig, ikaw, ina, ang ilaw na gumabay patungo sa kasalukuyan kong
katayuan. Bagama’t nakaririndi, ang tilaok mo sa umaga ang dahilan ng
pagtindig ko sa bawat hamon ng araw. Bagama’t pumpantig ang tainga, ang ‘yong
wika ang hinahanap sa mga oras na tila ako’y nawawala–sa mga panahong katawan
ko’y bumibigay, isip ko’y pagal, at dibdib ko’y kay bigat. At tulad ng ibang
mga ina sa mundo, ang tingkad ng ilaw mo’y hindi kayang maantala sa apat na
sulok ng bahay na ito. Sapagka’t ang ‘yong sirang plakang mga paalala’y nanuot
sa puso’t isipan. ‘Di namamalayang bitbit sa bawat pasilyong pinaroroonan–tila
bait na umakay sa akin sa tamang landas at sa aki’y nagtalaga ng kagandahang
asal, disiplina, at takot sa Maykapal.

Kung minsa’y napapaisip, hindi kaya napupundi ang ‘yong ilaw nanay?

At tulad ng ibang
mga ina sa mundo, ang tingkad ng ilaw mo’y hindi kayang maantala sa apat na
sulok ng bahay na ito. Sapagka’t ang ‘yong sirang plakang mga paalala’y nanuot
sa puso’t isipan. ‘Di namamalayang bitbit sa bawat pasilyong pinaroroonan–tila
bait na umakay sa akin sa tamang landas at sa aki’y nagtalaga ng kagandahang
asal, disiplina, at takot sa Maykapal.

Kung minsa’y napapaisip, hindi kaya napupundi ang ‘yong ilaw nanay? Sapagka’t
sa kabila ng hirap at bigat ng responsibilidad sa pagdadala ng isang buhay sa
loob ng siyam na buwan; ng walang patid na pagod at puyat mula sa pag-aruga ng
isang musmos kahit na ito’y natuto nang tumayo sa sariling mga paa; sa araw-
araw na pagsasakit na maghanapbuhay, matapos ay uuwi at gagampanan ang
marangal na tungkuling pambahay–nagsusumikap harapin ang tumpok ng labahin at
ligpitin, sinisiguradong ang pamilya’y aalis at uuwi nang may pagkaing
nakahain, at matamo ang kagustuhan ng mga supling kung mamarapatin–ay wala
paring palya ang iyong bibig. Walang palyang nagpapahiwatig ng paalala,
suporta, at ng mga katagang “mahal kita” kahit noo ko’y kunot na at ang wika
mo’y labas sa tainga.

Kaya’t hindi na ako magtataka kung kanila ngang sabihin na ikaw, ina, ang ilaw
ng tahanan natin. Ngunit para sa akin ay hindi lamang liwanag ang ‘yong
hatid–ikaw rin ay haligi tulad ng bawat ama; isang kumot na anumang oras ay
magpapainit sa malamig kong mga gabi; isang _superhuman_ na hindi nauupos at
tila sa bokabularyo’y hindi kilala ang salitang “pagsuko.” Hindi lang ikaw ang
ilaw ng tahanan, ina. Ikaw ang aking tahanan–ang aking kanlungan. At sa
bandang huli, sa kabila ng iyong paroo’t parineng pangaral na sumasalubong sa
bawat sikat ng araw, ang katahimikang dama sa yakap mo ang parating
pinaroroonan sa tuwing humihikbi–sa iyong piling pa rin uuwi.
