# Sa Mga Pasilyo ng Maunlad na Sining sa Pamantasan

Written by Jamilla Marie Matias • Board by Arjay Samson | 28 February 24

Sa bawat haplos ng krayola’t lapis sa papel, sa pag-indak ng katawan lulan ang
mga lirikong inaawit, sa mga tugma ng mga tulang binabanggit ng mga makatang
may hatid sa tenga’t kaluluwa ng rikit, at sa bawat pag-iyak at pagtawa ng
madla sa pinilakang-tabing buhat ng drama’t komedya, hindi maikakaila ang
taglay na karilagang handog ng sining.

Kalakip na marahil nang mabuhay ang sining— katuwang sa pagpapanday ng mga
natatanging kakayahan at talento ng isang indibidwal. May tunguhin itong
magpalaya, magpahayag, magbahagi, at makibahagi sa pagpapaunlad at
pagpapanatili ng mayabong na kasaysayan ng mga kultura’t tradisyon ng lipunan.

Bunsod nito, inilaan ang buwan ng Pebrero hindi lamang upang bigyang pansin
ang araw ng mga puso bagkus upang gunitain din ang pambansang sining at
bigyang pugay ang mga tagapagtaguyod nito.

**Alab ng Kolektibong Mithiin**

Sa Pamantasan, hitik sa kulay ang pagsasabuhay ng sining, sumibol man ang
pagdiriwang na ito o hindi. Patunay dito ang mga organisasyong nagtataguyod at
gumagabay sa mga artistikong kaisipan ng mga Haribon katulad na lamang ng
Magwayen Creative Scholars’ Guild (MCSG) na tanyag sa pagsulong ng isang
masining na pamantasan. Mula sa kolektibong pagsisikap na pagsamahin ang mga
malikhaing imahinasyon ng mga miyembro, sa harap man o sa likod ng telon,
binuhat nito sa hagway ng tagumpay ang bawat pagtatanghal na may mithiing
imulat ang mga manonood sa reyalidad ng kasalukuyan.

Kagaya ng pagnanais ni Janelle Chryslene Tieng, Presidente ng Magwayen,
naitatag ang naturang organisasyon sa hangaring pagbuklurin ang mga
estudyanteng may interes at pagnanais na pasukin ang mundo ng teatro sa loob
ng eskwelahan.

Aniya, buhat ng pakikisalamuha sa ibang tao gamit ang lenggwahe ng sining, mas
lalo umano siyang namulat sa kalagayan at estado ng lipunang kanyang
ginagalawan.

Kagaya ng pagnanais ni Janelle Chryslene Tieng, Presidente ng Magwayen,
naitatag ang naturang organisasyon sa hangaring pagbuklurin ang mga
estudyanteng may interes at pagnanais na pasukin ang mundo ng teatro sa loob
ng eskwelahan.

Aniya, buhat ng pakikisalamuha sa ibang tao gamit ang lenggwahe ng sining, mas
lalo umano siyang namulat sa kalagayan at estado ng lipunang kanyang
ginagalawan. Dagdag pa niya, ang sining rin ang naging dahilan kung bakit mas
higit pang umigting ang taglay niyang kumpiyansa at pagmamahal sa kanyang
sarili. “Sobrang laki ng impact ng sining sa buhay ko, in all its different
shapes or forms. Para bang in every step of my life, sining talaga ang
umaagapay sa akin. Medyo OA man pakinggan, pero hindi ako magiging ako kung
wala ang sining sa buhay ko,” saad pa ni Tieng.

Sa kabilang dako, ang pagiging sagisag ng nag-aalab na pag-ibig sa sining ng
mga iskolar ng bayan ang siyang isinasadiwa ng Santelmo Arts. Kaya naman
dito’y naitatampok ng mga estudyante ang kanilang mga katha’t obra sa istilo
man ng pagguhit, pagkanta, at pagsulat ng mga tula at nobela. Binubuo ng
tatlong kolektibo– biswal, musika, at pampanitikan, misyon nitong bigyang
tahanan ang mga mag-aaral na may adhikaing makibahagi sa pagpapanatili ng
matingkad na sining sa Pamantasan.

Pagbabahagi ni Anthony Acoba, _Collective Head_ ng Santelmo Arts, sumali siya
sa naturang organisasyon dahil alam niyang nakahanay ang kanyang hilig dito.
Ikinuwento niya rin na sa halos isang dekadang pagtugtog, ang mga himig ng
musika ang naging kasangga niya sa buhay at bukas palad na nagbigay ng mga
oportunidad na nakatulong sa kanya higit lalo sa pinansyal na aspeto.

Malugod din niyang inilahad na sa darating na Marso, bahagi siya sa
magbabandera ng Pilipinas sa isang kultural na pagtatanghal na gaganapin sa
Thailand. “Super excited ako since ito yung unang pagkakataon na makakapag-
perform ako sa labas ng bansa. Mayabong ang kultura ng Pilipinas at masaya ako
na maibabahagi ko ito sa ibang bansa, at makita ko rin ang kulturang meron
sila at matuto rin mula rito,” wika ni Acoba.

Sa pag-indayog naman nailalathala ng PLM Iskolars Dance Incorporated (PIDI)
ang kanilang masidhing damdaming itindig ang bandera ng mga mananayaw na
kamakailan lamang ay nagbigay pugay sa paaralan.

Ibinahagi ni Donald Ritaga, _in-house member_ ng PIDI, na marahil ang
pagsasayaw ang naging dahilan kung bakit mas naging madali sa kanyang ihayag
ang sarili na naging susi tungo sa pag-unlad hindi lamang ng kanyang talento
bagkus pati na rin ng kanyang pagkatao.

Inilahad niya rin ang kahalagahan ng patnubay ng kanilang mga tagapagturo na
siyang naging dahilan ng mga tagumpay na kanilang natamo. “Sobrang grateful
ako kanila coach Dhz and Ren dahil without them, isko wouldn’t be isko.
Gagawin nila best nila to help you improve and that gives us the push to
strive harder na sumayaw nang sumayaw,” saad ni Ritaga.

Inilahad niya rin ang kahalagahan ng patnubay ng kanilang mga tagapagturo na
siyang naging dahilan ng mga tagumpay na kanilang natamo. “Sobrang grateful
ako kanila coach Dhz and Ren dahil without them, isko wouldn’t be isko.
Gagawin nila best nila to help you improve and that gives us the push to
strive harder na sumayaw nang sumayaw,” saad ni Ritaga.

**Aral na Handog ng Sining**

Bagama’t hitik sa talento at kahusayan ang komunidad ng mga Haribon, hindi pa
rin maiwawaglit ang mga katahimikang minsa’y bumabalot sa mga pasilyong
patuloy na humuhubog sa angking galing ng mga kabataang nagpupunyagi. Bakas
nito ang pagod, hirap, at kaliwa’t kanang suliraning kinakaharap upang bigyang
hustisya ang bawat pag-akyat sa entablado para gumiling, bumirit, at iguhit
ang pagnanasang ipagmalaki ang sarili at ang sintang Pamantasan.

At sa kabila ng mga dagok na dumarating; sa pagkalkula man ng oras o sa
pananalapi, ang mga alagad ng sining kung ituring ay kailanman hindi magagapi.
Ito’y tanda ng ginintuang aral na handog ng sining sa pagtanggap, pag-unawa,
at pagkakaisa upang tupdin ang iisang layunin— magtanghal at itanghal.

Hindi maitatatwa ang karikitang ambag ng sining sa pagbuo ng isang
progresibong eskwelahan. Tulay ito upang sama-samang isadiwa ang mapagpalaya
at ingklusibong komunidad ng lipunan. Kaya naman, pagpupugay sa mga isko at
iska sa patuloy na pag-aalab ng pusong lumikha ng sining, lagi't lagi para sa
sining at sa Inang Bayan.

# One Life is Too Many

Written by Charyll Joan Pascua • Board by Elyse Abadilla | 3 October 23

Not only in the scenes of Cardo Dalisay in the former TV series “FPJ’s Ang
Probinsyano,” and not only on the screens of every action film, but also in
our educational institutions that it was instilled in us at a young age that
police officers preserve life and maintain peace. As actors on television and
teachers alike would always say, “the police take care of the bad guys.” But
as one grows older and develops a deeper consciousness of our society, reality
unveils a sobering truth: that there exist police officers who unjustly
apprehend individuals and, tragically, claim the lives of innocent
individuals.

On August 20th, a fatal incident transpired in which John Francis Ompad lost
his life after being struck in the abdomen by a bullet fired by Police
Corporal Arnulfo Sabillo. The 15-year-old’s passing took place in Barangay San
Isidro, Rodriguez, Rizal, when Sabillio and his civilian companion Jeffrey
Baguio attempted to stop John Ace, Ompad’s brother, who was riding his
motorcycle. The pursuit of John Ace led to their doorstep, where he resorted
to tossing his helmet at Sabillo and Baguio, who were pursuing him, in an
attempt to ward them off. In an apparent fit of anger, Sabillo drew his
firearm and fired at John Ace but missed, inadvertently hitting John Francis,
who had come out of their house upon hearing the commotion. Due to a cop’s
gunfire, John Francis’ aspiration to become a cop by attending the Philippine
National Police (PNP) Academy will now never come to fruition, as the teen
lost his life while under medical care at the hospital.

Weeks before the death of Ompad, 17-year-old Jerhode “Jemboy” Baltazar
suffered a fatal gunshot and was wrongfully killed by six operatives from the
Navotas City Police Station who mistakenly identified him as a crime suspect.
The tragedy took place last August 2 as Jemboy and his friend were cleaning
their fishing boat by the river near their home in Barangay NBBS Kaunlaran.
The police had arrived at the scene in pursuit of an alleged shooting suspect.
Without proper verification, the said officers opened fire on Baltazar. They
later realized that Baltazar was not the suspect they were hunting down.

Regrettably, incidents akin to these have not only transpired in recent months
but have persisted over the years.

In the most unimaginable display of ruthlessness, all it took was a
neighborhood dispute for Sonya and Frank Gregorio to also become victims of
police abuse as they were shot by off-duty cop Jonel Nuezca in Paniqui,
Tarlac, in December 2020. A video of the crime emerged online, allowing all
social media users to witness the appalling murder. In the mentioned clip,
Nuezca was filmed as he unhesitatingly pulled the trigger and ended the lives
of the unarmed individuals. A witness claims that after shooting the mother
and son at point-blank range, Nuezca took his daughter and walked away as if
it were nothing.

They
later realized that Baltazar was not the suspect they were hunting down.

Regrettably, incidents akin to these have not only transpired in recent months
but have persisted over the years.

In the most unimaginable display of ruthlessness, all it took was a
neighborhood dispute for Sonya and Frank Gregorio to also become victims of
police abuse as they were shot by off-duty cop Jonel Nuezca in Paniqui,
Tarlac, in December 2020. A video of the crime emerged online, allowing all
social media users to witness the appalling murder. In the mentioned clip,
Nuezca was filmed as he unhesitatingly pulled the trigger and ended the lives
of the unarmed individuals. A witness claims that after shooting the mother
and son at point-blank range, Nuezca took his daughter and walked away as if
it were nothing. Prior to this killing, records shared by the PNP showed that
Nuezca faced six cases over his last 10 years in service for grave misconduct,
serious neglect of duty, refusal to undergo a drug test, an administrative
case, and suspension.

[ _“Tama na po, may test pa ako bukas (Please stop, I have a test
tomorrow).”_](https://www.rappler.com/nation/217770-caloocan-policemen-
convicted-murder-kian-delos-santos-killing/) “[ _Sir, ‘wag po, sir (Sir,
please don’t, sir!).”_](https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1008657) These were
the last words of Kian delos Santos before becoming a casualty of unjust
killings by police officers after a "one-time, big-time" anti-illegal drugs
operation by the Caloocan City police on August 16, 2017. Witnesses tagged
police officers [_Arnel Oares and Jeremias Pereda as the killers while their
fellow Jerwin
Cruz_](https://www.philstar.com/headlines/2018/11/30/1872988/3-cops-guilty-
kian-delos-santos-murder) was reported to have observed the situation without
intervening. The Caloocan policemen alleged Kian was a drug runner, but the
schoolboy’s family vehemently denied the allegation. Police asserted that the
17-year-old fired at them while resisting arrest amidst the conduct of the
operation. However, a neighborhood video camera caught two of the policemen
dragging the unarmed Delos Santos moments before he was shot dead in a pig
pen.

This seemingly timeless shoot-now-think-later disposition that cops manifest
goes by many names. Civilians and politicians who are well aware of the
existence of such form of abuse among police officers call it “trigger-happy
culture.” Those belonging to the said organization who are in denial of such
abuse call it “a mistake.” Meanwhile, those in a position of higher authority,
who do not wish to take part in the extermination of this form of police
violence dub it an “isolated case”—which is how all the incidents cited were
described as so by PNP personnel. While different groups may not agree with a
universal name for such atrocities, it cannot be denied that these patterns of
unjust shooting are a violation—of the procedure of PNP, of the laws of the
nation, and of the most fundamental right that is the right to life. And
because of how evident these patterns are, the masses may soon totally lose
their confidence in how law enforcement officers uphold their sworn purpose to
the society that is to serve and protect.

If the PNP is earnest in maintaining the public’s trust in them, one earnest
and reasonable action would be their use of body cameras during operations.
Currently, there are only 2,700 body-worn cameras available for the entire
police force, despite the agency having received funding since 2018.
Furthermore, the PNP has only added 100 cameras out of the initially procured
2,600 cameras counted in its inventory when the equipment was first acquired
in 2021. Providing more exhaustive efforts to the procurement of such cameras
will contribute to the reliability of their reports during their duty,
especially in operations.

Procuring adequate body-worn cameras is one thing; actually utilizing them is
another necessary thing. During the killing of Jemboy, Navotas police chief
Allan Umipig says the body camera worn by policemen was turned off. This
eliminates yet another critical potential source of evidence that could have
helped determine whether standard operating procedures were adhered to during
the execution of their operations.

Currently, there are only 2,700 body-worn cameras available for the entire
police force, despite the agency having received funding since 2018.
Furthermore, the PNP has only added 100 cameras out of the initially procured
2,600 cameras counted in its inventory when the equipment was first acquired
in 2021. Providing more exhaustive efforts to the procurement of such cameras
will contribute to the reliability of their reports during their duty,
especially in operations.

Procuring adequate body-worn cameras is one thing; actually utilizing them is
another necessary thing. During the killing of Jemboy, Navotas police chief
Allan Umipig says the body camera worn by policemen was turned off. This
eliminates yet another critical potential source of evidence that could have
helped determine whether standard operating procedures were adhered to during
the execution of their operations. More concerningly, Umipig admits that this
is not the first time that body-worn cameras were turned off during police
operations.

The PNP must also prioritize the evaluation of the psychological well-being of
its personnel as part of a comprehensive reform effort. Their current system
for supporting the mental health of uniformed officers is in dire need of
repair. While neuropsychiatric exams are a necessary step, the evaluation of
the psychological resilience and capacities of these personnel should be an
ongoing process during their service tenure. Given the inherent risks and the
authority to carry arms associated with their roles, it is paramount to ensure
that they remain psychologically capable of fulfilling their duties
effectively and responsibly. Furthermore, the agency must go the extra mile to
ensure the integrity and validity of its neuropsychiatric exams. It has come
to light that some police applicants have managed to pass these tests through
bribery, casting doubt on the overall effectiveness of the evaluation process.

Significantly, the PNP should be reminded that despite their authority, they
are not above the law, and they must be held accountable for committing
violations such as abuse of power. Of course, this is only attainable if the
agency stops overlooking–shielding–each other’s violations, as evident in how
a recent ex-cop pulled out a pistol during a traffic confrontation with a
cyclist yet was able to hold a press conference with the chief of the Quezon
City Police District, or how Nuezca was able to keep his rights to bear arms
despite being involved in cases of grave misconduct involving homicide, or how
Navotas police chief Umipig "instructed the team leader of the operatives to
exclude from their reports 11 police officers who were also involved in the
fatal shooting of the 17-year-old Jerhode Jemboy Baltazar," according to the
PNP Internal Affairs Service. A police officer’s loyalty should always be
directed toward the people they serve, rather than solely to the organization
or any individual within it.

"This is an isolated incident that does not represent the vast majority of PNP
officers who go beyond their duties every day to make the public feel
comfortable and secure," [_Rizal PPO Provincial Director PCol. Dominic
Baccay_](https://mb.com.ph/2023/8/25/15-year-old-shot-dead-by-police-in-rizal)
claims in his statement regarding the death of Ompad. The assertion made by
the director may appear valid, but only if one’s social perspective is
confined to the events of the past few months. But when one dares to adopt a
more expansive viewpoint, it becomes evident that such isolated instances form
a recurring pattern. More importantly, even in a fictional Philippines where
the unjust death of Ompad is only an isolated case, one life is still too
many.

# 59th Founding Anniversary Wish Bus

Caption and Photos by Jonas Shane Duque | 20 June 24

PLM students jam with the OPM music of Wish Bus 107.5 in partnership with
Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila to celebrate the university's 59th
anniversary. The event features vibrant band performances by Mayonnaise and
FERODINA, June 19.

# 60% of graduates to receive Latin honors; OSDS releases baccalaureate,
recognition schedule

Written by Raniel Paquingan • Board by John Ivan Pasion | 6 August 24

More than 2,620, or 60%, of the estimated 4,330+ students of Pamantasan ng
Lungsod ng Maynila will graduate with Latin Honors, Aug. 6.

This is according to the PLM Board of Regents, who approved the final list of
graduating students in a meeting held on Aug. 2.

On the same day, the Office of Student Development and Services (OSDS)
released the schedule for the baccalaureate ceremonies on Aug. 27 at the
Metropolitan Theater.

In the morning, from 9:00 AM to 10:00 AM, the ceremonies will be for the
graduates of College of Business Administration (CBA), College of Public
Administration (CPA), and College of Accountancy (CA).

It will be followed by College of Tourism and Hospitality Management (CTHM),
College of Education (CED), College of Science (CS), and College of
Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences (CHASS) from 11:00 AM to 12:00 NN

Meanwhile, the first session for the afternoon, from 1:00 PM to 2:00 PM, will
be for the graduates of College of Engineering (CE), College of Information
Systems and Technology Management (CISTM), and College of Architecture and
Sustainable Built Environments (CASBE).

The last session will be for College of Nursing (CN), College of Physical
Therapy (CPT), College of Medicine (CM), and Graduate School at 3:00 PM to
4:00 PM.

To recognize students’ outstanding achievements, dedication, and excellence,
PLM will hold its recognition ceremonies in the evening, after the
baccalaureate ceremonies.

The university has yet to announce the official dates for the 56th
Commencement Exercises.

# Notes from Nurse Aris: 5Ws & 1H Tips to Survive College and Beyond

Written by Charyll Joan Pascua • Board by John Ivan Pasion | 31 July 24

Stepping into college is like entering an uncharted world of endless
possibilities and daunting challenges. As you embark on this transformative
journey, the anticipation of success and the fear of failure can feel
overwhelming. You might find yourself asking, “Will this experience make me or
break me?” As the new academic year begins and graduation approaches for
others, Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) alumnus Aristotle Calayan
Castronuevo—College of Nursing Batch 2023 Cum Laude and Philippine Nursing
Licensure Exam (PNLE) topnotcher—offers invaluable insights. His journey,
marked by resilience and determination, provides a guiding light for both
fresh and seasoned Haribons navigating the challenges of college life.

**When Plan A is no longer possible, make the most of Plan B.**

Aris’ path to college might appear to be a flawless success story—graduating
as the class valedictorian from elementary to senior high school. However, he
candidly reveals that his experience upon entering college was anything but
perfect.

Initially, Aris planned to study at the University of the Philippines (UP). “I
only applied to UP as that was my only plan. I took the PLM Admission Test
(PLMAT) only because my mom forced me,” Aris shares. A few days after
delivering his valedictory speech at his senior high school graduation, Aris
received the gut-wrenching news that he hadn’t been admitted to his dream
school. “ _Durog na durog ako noon. Para akong napahiya_ (I was crushed. I
felt humiliated),” he reminisces. Despite his disappointment, Aris knew that
success meant not dwelling on setbacks. Determined, he enrolled in PLM as the
next best step forward.

**Where your heart is, your actions will follow.**

As a Humanities and Social Sciences (HUMSS) graduate, Aris struggled in his
first semester as a nursing student. “ _Hirap ako mag-excel_ (I had a
difficult time excelling),” Aris, now a nurse, shares. He felt at a
disadvantage compared to his classmates who had graduated from the Science,
Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) strand and even considered
shifting to Tourism. However, he chose to stay when he learned that his
caregiver of 18 years had been diagnosed with a life-altering illness. Aris’
love for his yaya inspired him to continue in nursing so he could learn how to
take care of her like she had taken care of him. Realizing the importance of
his field, he soon came to appreciate his chosen course and adapted to the
demands of being an Iskonars.

**Whoever has your back and whoever stabs your back, never forget them when
you face success.**

College, like actual high school, isn’t always a musical. Aris faced his share
of challenges, including conflicts with classmates and doubts from others
about his place in the program.

He felt at a
disadvantage compared to his classmates who had graduated from the Science,
Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) strand and even considered
shifting to Tourism. However, he chose to stay when he learned that his
caregiver of 18 years had been diagnosed with a life-altering illness. Aris’
love for his yaya inspired him to continue in nursing so he could learn how to
take care of her like she had taken care of him. Realizing the importance of
his field, he soon came to appreciate his chosen course and adapted to the
demands of being an Iskonars.

**Whoever has your back and whoever stabs your back, never forget them when
you face success.**

College, like actual high school, isn’t always a musical. Aris faced his share
of challenges, including conflicts with classmates and doubts from others
about his place in the program. He vividly remembers a person he used to look
up to in the classroom asking him, “Deserving ka ba na nandito? (Are you
deserving to be here?).” Despite this, the inner voice urging him to persevere
for his loved ones was stronger. During his third year, Aris had caught up
with his peers. Although he aimed to graduate Magna Cum Laude, he fell short
by a mere 0.0091 in his Overall General Weighted Average (OGWA). Heartbroken
but resolute, Aris set his sights on becoming a PNLE topnotcher to honor both
his supporters and detractors.

**How you act towards your goal determines your future.**

Exactly how much are you willing to sacrifice for your dreams? Aris learned
early on that achieving greatness demands significant sacrifices. He devoted
months to rigorous study, missing family gatherings, chugging coffee, and
relying on chocolates for sugar rush and alertness. He even chose to skip his
own graduation rites to focus on his review. “Missing my graduation was not a
difficult choice,” Aris explains. His unyielding commitment to his goal fueled
his success, proving that dedication and sacrifice pave the way to triumph.

**Whatever You Do, Do It Well.**

Aris believes that one must work well and rest well. As he prepared for his
board exam, he followed a strict daily routine that balanced thorough coverage
of exam topics with time for other essential activities. He attributes his top
rank in the board exam to this discipline. Aris also credits his success not
only to his hard work but also to ensuring he got adequate rest. “ _Kapag
kompletong walong oras ang tulog mo, mas maaabsorb mo yung inaaral mo_ (If you
get complete eight hours of sleep, you’ll absorb what you’re studying
better),” he advises.

**“Why’s” to “That’s why”: Never forget that you can change the narrative**

Who would have thought that failing to get into your dream university would
lead to becoming a topnotcher in a course you never considered? Or that
missing Magna Cum Laude by 0.0091 would fuel the determination to achieve a
91% and top the board exams? Aris emphasizes that you can change your
downfalls by persevering through challenges.

Aris’ story, along with those of other Haribons who have excelled beyond the
walls of our _Pamantasan_ , illustrates that every challenge faced, every
sacrifice made, and every setback endured contributes to a story of triumph.
So, as you step into this new chapter, take inspiration from Aris and others
who have paved the way. Face each challenge head-on, draw strength from your
people, and never lose sight of your goals.

# Estrangherong Pamantasan

Written by Estelle Theresa Gulay • Board by Angelle Valbuena | 18 December 23

Mahigit isang libong araw na nang ako’y tumungtong sa Pamantasan. Parang
kailan lang ay dama ko ang kaba sa pagpasok sa lugar na kakatwa– puno ng mga
bagong mukha; gusaling ngala’y ‘di ko mawari; at kalakarang iba sa
nakalakihan.

Datapwa’t bago sa paningin, ang bigat sa mga yapak ko’y unti-unting guminhawa.
Kasabay ng nalinang na kadalubhasaan sa pasiko’t-siko’t sa paaralan; nabuong
pamilya kasama ang aking mga ka-eskwela; pag-usbong ng ginhawa sapagka’t alam
kong sa likod ng aking mga pangangamba ay may mga kawaning handang makinig—
handang ipaglaban ang kabutihan ng isang karaniwang estudyanteng tulad ko at
ng bawat kapwa ko kolehiyo.

Ngunit sa pagpatak ng ika-isang libong araw na pamamalagi ay muling gumapang
ang takot at pangangamba sa aking isipan. Naglaho ang kaginhawaang kay tagal
kong nakamtan sa pagbagsak ng isang larawang nagbunyag ng mapang-aping
kataastaasan. At sa isang iglap, ang itinuring kong pangalawang tahanan ay
muling naging estrangherong Pamantasan.

Sapagka’t tahanan pa nga bang maituturing ang isang lugar na pinamamalagian ng
mapanupil na kinakatawan? Kung ang pinuno naming mga mag-aaral ay uliran ng
panunukso’t walang pakialam? Kung bitbit ko’y bigat ng damdamin sa bawat
hakbang sa pasilyong noo’y aking kanlungan datapwa’t naglaho na ang tiwalang
ipinagkaloob sa kanilang nangakong magtataguyod ng inklusibo at progresibong
konseho; gumuho na ang pag-asang sila’y tatayo para sa kapakanan ng karamihan;
ako’y binalot na ng kaisipan na hindi malayong ang aking– aming mga hinaing ay
gawin ring katatawanan. Tugunan rin ng kibit-balikat at hayaang mabulok
hanggang sa mabaon sa isipan.

Subalit ‘di tulad ng nagdaang mahigit na isang libong araw na pamamalagi sa
paaralan ay hindi na ako tutunganga’t maghihintay ng kasagutang minsan nang
inabot ng pag-itim ng tagak.

Tugunan rin ng kibit-balikat at hayaang mabulok
hanggang sa mabaon sa isipan.

Subalit ‘di tulad ng nagdaang mahigit na isang libong araw na pamamalagi sa
paaralan ay hindi na ako tutunganga’t maghihintay ng kasagutang minsan nang
inabot ng pag-itim ng tagak. Sapagka’t ngayo’y tila wala nang iba pang
mapagkakatiwalaan para sa kabutihan naming masang mag-aaral kundi sarili at
silang mga kapwa ko iskolar ng bayan. Kaya’t harangan man ng sibat, masugid
kong isisigaw ang hangaring nawa’y muling tumindig ang dating pinagkatiwalaan;
gisingin ng multo ng mga nalimutang pangako.

Patuloy na hihingi ng katarungan– ng pananagutan. Para sa kaginhawaan sa
nalalabing mga oras sa itinuring na kanlungan nang mahigit isang libong araw
ng aking kamayhan. At muling naging estranghero man sa paningin, ako’y lalaban
dahil sa puso ko’y tahanan pa rin.

# Manila councilors express concerns; PLM admin explains its “special legal
stature” over CHED’s resolution

Written by Zarena Hermogeno & John Coby Cabuhat • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 31 August 23

On Tuesday, Manila City councilors expressed concerns over Pamantasan ng
Lungsod ng Maynila’s (PLM) possible delisting as a beneficiary of the Free
Tertiary Education through resolutions, based on a report from
[Philstar.com](https://www.philstar.com/nation/2023/08/31/2292648/plm-may-
lose-p350-million-government-subsidy-councilors-
warn?fbclid=IwAR2GB62EuH1QOOwHkGQ14nUNYlH5Jpzn0PBK2dOB_hOTE1H-9NhpoAKRe94)
published Aug. 31.

On the same day, the University released a
[statement](https://www.facebook.com/PLM.Haribon/posts/pfbid0JptLBB5Bp5TBs4Pz2yoYJu88Xeu6tcMmHWSasnyKpytivhB5V6JMEYFg98vx5YPTl)
assuring continued free tuition and salary payments.

In a report, District 6 Councilor Elmer "Joel" M. Par filed a resolution
noting that the Commission on Higher Education (CHED) previously warned PLM it
might be “delisted” as a beneficiary of the Universal Access to Quality
Tertiary Education (UAQTE) Act and the lack of a doctorate degree is an
alleged violation of requirements to be recognized as a subsidy recipient
under the law.

In a copy of the resolution that Ang Pamantasan obtained this morning, Coun.
Par called for an immediate response, “Now, therefore, be it resolved, by the
City Council of Manila, to call for an immediate response in relation to the
CHED Resolution No. 285-2023 that may delist Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila
as one of the beneficiary of the Universal Access to Quality Tertiary
Education Act if the current president remains.”

District 2 Councilor Darwin “Awi” Sia and District 5 Councilor Jaybee S. Hizon
maintained “someone must make a sacrifice” and “differences must be set
aside,” based on The Philippine Star’s website.

In contrast, the University administration said that it has explained the
“circumstances unique to PLM that puts its appointive officials outside the
standards set under the executive agency's memorandum orders,” in their
written response to CHED.

In the same statement, the administration argued that the pertinent CHED
policies that require the universities and colleges’ presidents to have a
doctorate degree apply to LUCs established by a local ordinance while PLM, in
contrast, was created by a national law.

PLM University President Emmanuel Leyco said “The University maintains
constant and open communication with CHED regarding this issue, and we are
hopeful that CHED will recognize the unique legal position surrounding our
University.”

The University draws its mandate from the Republic Act No.

In contrast, the University administration said that it has explained the
“circumstances unique to PLM that puts its appointive officials outside the
standards set under the executive agency's memorandum orders,” in their
written response to CHED.

In the same statement, the administration argued that the pertinent CHED
policies that require the universities and colleges’ presidents to have a
doctorate degree apply to LUCs established by a local ordinance while PLM, in
contrast, was created by a national law.

PLM University President Emmanuel Leyco said “The University maintains
constant and open communication with CHED regarding this issue, and we are
hopeful that CHED will recognize the unique legal position surrounding our
University.”

The University draws its mandate from the Republic Act No. 4196 or “An Act
Authorizing the City of Manila to Establish and Operate the University of the
City of Manila and for Other Purposes” signed into law by former President
Diosdado Macapagal on June 19, 1965.

Furthermore, the administration added that the law places the university “at a
special legal stature as it is not a local university – rather, it is a
locally-funded public higher education institution that was created through
the enactment of a law originating from the Philippine Congress.”

The statement also provided comparisons between PLM and the University of the
Philippines (UP) System. It stated that UP has the same legal standing, being
created by a law, which does not require a doctorate degree for its
presidents.

“UP receives funding from the national government under both the annual
General Appropriations Act and via subsidies under the Unified Financial
Assistance System (UniFAST). Meanwhile, PLM is funded by subsidies from
UniFAST and from the City Government of Manila,” the administration added in
the same statement.

“PLM also takes exception in CHED's attempt to classify PLM as an LUC, as its
unique legal stature clearly proves otherwise,” the statement said.

On the other hand, District 3 Councilor Pamela Fugoso-Pascual also filed
another resolution calling Mayor Maria Sheilah “Honey” Lacuna-Pangan together
with the city government to meet with the PLM’s Board of Regents to resolve
the issue. The resolution was seconded by 21 other councilors.

Last night, Coun. Fugoso-Pascual replied to an Ang Pamantasan News staffer
that her copy of the resolution is at City Hall and the publication is
requesting a copy.

Last Aug. 15, CHED released a letter to the University with a copy of CHED En
Banc Resolution No. 285-2023. The said resolution approved the revocation of
the exemption of PLM from the compliance with the minimum guidelines as to the
establishment of and operations of Local Universities and Colleges (LUCs).

CHED also directed PLM to comply with Institutional Recognition requirements
in 15 days after the receipt of the letter. Failure of the University to do so
will result in the commission’s recommendation to the concerned governing
board its delisting from the list of UAQTE Act beneficiaries.

The University has sent a written response to the commission. As of this
writing, the publication has yet to have a copy of the response.

"It is our fervent hope that the matter will be resolved swiftly and
amicably," Leyco added in the said statement.

This is a developing story.

# First day of FILMayer 2024: A PLM Festival of Movies

Written by Roland Justin Molato • Photos by Jonas Shane Duque | 7 June 24

Fourth-year Bachelor of Arts in Communication (BAC) students under the College
of Humanities, Arts and Social Sciences (CHASS) showcased their talent in the
field of filming through the screening of 10 short films inside the Justo
Albert Auditorium yesterday, June 7.

# ICYMI | PLM-COMELEC proclaims new SSC, CSC officials

Written by Rinoa Angeline Dela Torre • Board by John Coby Cabuhat | 4 June 23

PLM Commission on Elections (COMELEC) declared the newly elected officers of
the Supreme Student Council (SSC) and College Student Councils (CSC) at the
Justo Albert Auditorium, May 31.

The Office of Student Development and Services Dean Prof. Vilma A. Dela Cruz
started the program by congratulating and delivering her message to the newly
elected officers.

“As you embark upon your responsibilities as student leaders to 18,000
students, you represent the vision and mission of the university. As a student
leader, you represent the PLM Values, the academic excellence, integrity and
social responsibility,” Prof. Dela Cruz said.

COMELEC proclaimed the SSC for Academic Year 2023-2024 namely Vince Edrick A.
De Guzman, President; Jam Iris M. Paglicawan, Vice President; Janine Ysabelle
Nacuna, Secretary; Sophia Rhyzel Pitero, Treasurer; and Joseph Andrei Torres,
Public Relations Officer.

Newly elected college representatives are Krystle Mae Cabagay, CAUP; Jhon
Christian Rebortera, CED; Jomarie Soriano, CED; Mark Jose Marcelo, CHASS;
Ysabelle Tamani, CHASS; Ruth Ann Romero, CL; Edwin Joseph Espinas, CN; Denisse
Margarette Madrid, CN; Nathaniel Arizala, PLMBS; Jancel Louise Natividad,
PLMBS; Angel Lyka Palisoc, PLMBS; Krisha Clyde Reprado, SOG; and Mithi Redem
Laya Morales, SSW.

While the following student leaders are elected to their respective College
Student Councils:

Kristiana Lois Ocon, President; Joy Keshia Ocenar, Vice President; Precios
DIane Catchuela, Secretary; Rowena Villan, Treasurer; Dannielle Ann Abengana,
Auditor; and Cana Anrie Franco, Public Relations Officer (College of
Architecture and Urban Planning Student Council).

Evander John Buenaflor, President; Mary Grace Ann Laguitan, Vice President;
Aliah Mhae Begino, Secretary; and Joshua Marco, Public Relations Officer
(College of Education Student Council).

Elmer Joaqi Pangindian, President; Charles Daniel Dy, VIce President; Irish
Mae Metran, Secretary; Renzelle Anjelo Esguerra, Treasurer; Andrea Kate Gacad,
Auditor; and Jaymark Laurence Asis, Public Relations Officer (College of
Engineering Student Council).

Kim Kervyn Antonio, President; Jar-el Beatrice Garcia, Vice President; Aliyah
Dinglasan, Secretary; Kristelle Anne Fernandez, Treasurer; Adrian Jonson,
Auditor; and Mary Chanel Allyson Paraoan, Public Relations Officer (College of
Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences Student Council).

Evander John Buenaflor, President; Mary Grace Ann Laguitan, Vice President;
Aliah Mhae Begino, Secretary; and Joshua Marco, Public Relations Officer
(College of Education Student Council).

Elmer Joaqi Pangindian, President; Charles Daniel Dy, VIce President; Irish
Mae Metran, Secretary; Renzelle Anjelo Esguerra, Treasurer; Andrea Kate Gacad,
Auditor; and Jaymark Laurence Asis, Public Relations Officer (College of
Engineering Student Council).

Kim Kervyn Antonio, President; Jar-el Beatrice Garcia, Vice President; Aliyah
Dinglasan, Secretary; Kristelle Anne Fernandez, Treasurer; Adrian Jonson,
Auditor; and Mary Chanel Allyson Paraoan, Public Relations Officer (College of
Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences Student Council).

Claudine Chelsea Faylogna, President; Natalie Troncales, Vice President-
External; Jasper Jovellanos, Vice President-Internal; Cheelouvette Tiaga,
Secretary; John Yves Sibug, Assistant Secretary; and Jenneth Regalam, Auditor
(College of Law Student Council).

Mineli Joyce Cinco, President; Lara Seraspi, Vice President; Remijean Milan,
Secretary; Francine Nicole Tabuac, Treasurer; Rizcie Elaine Collantes,
Auditor; and Althea Earl Sachi Viernes, Public Relations Officer (College of
Nursing Student Council).

Margareth Grace Jorvina, President; and Lara Nicole De Paz, Secretary (College
of Science Student Council).

Lean Emeri Nerie, President; Ryanne Samantha Villalon, Vice President; Kaye
Shekinah Senadre, Treasurer; Joyce Angelbelle Tarrobal, Auditor; and Jeanella
Villegas, Public Relations Officer (PLM Business School Student Council).

Mark Ellies De Guzman, President; Lana Gabriel Micaela Salac, Vice President;
Gwyneth Arcilla, Secretary; Rene Reyes Jr., Treasurer; Jan Henrix Vallespin,
Auditor; and Christian Anthony Cullarin, Public Relations Officer (School of
Government Student Council).

Charles Dane Del Alcazar, President; Louise Marga Cejes, Vice President; Leif
Jethro Jimenez, Secretary; Julien Kate Recto, Treasurer; Camille Ambalada,
Public Relations Officer (School of Social Work Student Council).

PLM-COMELEC Chairperson Shairamagne Kade Kua also said that a leader should be
liable, exceptional, accountable, dedicated, energetic, responsible, and
sacrifice.

“Prove them that you deserve the position. Student leaders should first be
accountable, first to their acads, but then you should assure the student body
na ang desisyon nila ay tama,” Kua said.

She also reminded that the student officers must submit their notarized
Statement of Contributions and Expenses upon completion of their electoral
candidacy.

New elected officers are set to take the oath on June 27.

# Sikhay announces distribution of 2022 PLM Yearbook, framed pictures

Written by Angel Crismar Joy Udtohan • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 9 December 23

Sikhay Graduation Picture and Yearbook Committee announced the distribution of
Batch 2022’s Yearbook and unclaimed framed pictures starting on Dec. 9 onwards
at Photo x Media Studio, Santa Mesa, Manila.

The distribution schedule for College of Architecture and Urban Planning,
College of Education, and College of Engineering and Technology is on Dec. 9;
College of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences on Dec 12; College of
Physical Therapy and School of Government on Dec 15; College of Science on Dec
20; and PLM Business School on Dec.27.

Students are required to present at least one valid ID for verification, a
copy of their receipt, and settle any outstanding balance to claim their
yearbook and framed pictures. Authorization made online or written on a paper
with the student’s signature and valid ID shall be provided if another person
will claim the student’s yearbook.

The 2022 Sikhay Yearbooks and pictures can be claimed at the studio from
Monday to Saturday at 9:00 AM - 5:00 PM except on all Sundays and holidays.

# Mom, I’m Still Thomas

Written by Charyll Joan Pascua • Illustrated by Carl Justine Mogol | 29 June 23

 _I wish to tell her that rather than feeling as though living in sin, it
feels like actually living, and no longer foreign under my own skin._

Our mothers–they probably are the universal answer to the question of who
inspires us the most. After all, before we were even born, they already
rendered care for us. And after giving life to us, they tended and are tending
to us one milestone after another. As a person who was raised only by his
mother, I am a part of such majority. My mom is my rock and my hero, and I
love her with everything of me.

For as long as I could remember, Mom has never allowed me to forget how
valuable I am in her eyes. “Your name is Thomas. Your name came from the
Bible. You are a child of God,” she would always stress in my self-defeating
moments, such as when I link my worth for love to not having a father. Being
the religious person that she is, knowing how she related my name to something
close to her heart ceaselessly brings calm during overwhelming times.

Aside from being my first line of support, Mom was also my first teacher. She
taught me the important things I needed to do to grow up well, like how to
write my name on paper, and how to drink and eat properly. She also taught me
things that I shouldn’t do because they weren’t nice. From when I was young, I
could recall her saying:

“Thomas, it’s not right to take someone else’s toys.”

“Thomas, it’s not right to start a fight with your friends.”

“Thomas, it’s not right to lie.”

Since my beginning, it was only Mom that I had, and this is why she is so many
things to me. Besides everything I mentioned, she is my strength, my joy, and
my respite. But above all else, Mom is my refuge. It is only her that I deem
trustworthy and it is only her whom I share my secrets with. She knows
everything about me–except for this one big thing.

I was around 14 when I found fondness in wearing Mom’s clothes. When I look at
the mirror with her skirts or dresses on, I like how I look more than in my
polos and shirts. Being in those makes me feel more raw and real. At first, I
couldn’t explain why I take pleasure in wearing such clothes. All I know is
that it kept going for the whole year, and after a year, and after another
year.

I wore Mom’s wardrobe in secret. I wore them when she was out for work. I
would sleep in one of her nightgowns when she was out of town. First, it was
only her clothes, and then her accessories, and then I started borrowing her
lipstick as well as various make-up products.

One time, I came home early from school. Tired from my classes, I decided to
dress up to enjoy that brief moment of solitude. I wore her white satin blouse
and her cyan skirt. I wrapped my wrist with her bracelets and added some blush
on my cheeks.

Being in those makes me feel more raw and real. At first, I
couldn’t explain why I take pleasure in wearing such clothes. All I know is
that it kept going for the whole year, and after a year, and after another
year.

I wore Mom’s wardrobe in secret. I wore them when she was out for work. I
would sleep in one of her nightgowns when she was out of town. First, it was
only her clothes, and then her accessories, and then I started borrowing her
lipstick as well as various make-up products.

One time, I came home early from school. Tired from my classes, I decided to
dress up to enjoy that brief moment of solitude. I wore her white satin blouse
and her cyan skirt. I wrapped my wrist with her bracelets and added some blush
on my cheeks. Finally, after a very long day, I was finally having a good
time. I was dancing while stroking my cheeks with her brush. I was dueting the
song playing out loud. I was shouting the lyrics at the top of my lungs, that
I couldn’t hear our gate opening, or our car parking, or our door knob
turning, or mom entering my room.

I couldn’t paint Mom’s face when our eyes met. I couldn’t pacify my heart
which was beating too loud and fast. It felt like everything besides my
beating heart paused. Before a minute had gone by, Mom finally came to her
senses and took a deep breath. “Thomas, it is not right for a boy to wear girl
clothes,” she said in a firm and unemotive tone. Her words were simple and
easily comprehensible, but they weighed heavy on my ears and in my heart. As
her words lingered, my heart stopped beating fast, but it was as if it totally
stopped beating. Because at age 18, I already knew Mom meant more than just
clothes.

I knew what she really meant to say was that she deems it sinful to act or be
contrary to the sex God assigned you to. I knew what she really meant was that
between God and me, the only two things her life revolved around, she didn’t
want any hint of conflict to exist.

The last thing I would want to do to Mom was to hurt her, so I did all my best
to do her will. I stopped sneaking into her closet. I ceased trying her
belongings on. I stuck with putting on what society considers appropriate for
a man. In the name of my love for Mom, I chose her peace over mine.

They say that no matter how we hide our true selves with a facade created by
norms, our true selves will always find a way to surface. That was the case
for me. I may have stopped wearing Mom’s clothes, but my effeminate identity
still prevailed in other forms. I still frequently daydreamed of making my
hair long, so I could style it with clips or braid it. I still preferred the
company of my girls rather than boys as we share the same interests. Most
significantly, I still found men attractive rather than women.

I knew my mother’s heart would break if she knew all of these things that I
was hiding from her. Because of this, I did my utmost best to keep them from
her awareness. I became so extreme in repressing this side of me that although
it felt so off, I forced myself to date a girl.

Driven by the possible revelation that I may just be confused, I took a girl
out to the movies. At face value, the date seemed perfect. The lights were
dim, the seats were cold, and the movie was romantic. As we watched, I took
the big leap of reaching for her hand and holding it. For a second, it felt
like nothing; within two seconds, a tingling feeling set off inside me. It
wasn’t that kind of current that ensured a romantic connection–it was the kind
of current that gave the feeling of being electrocuted as punishment. So like
holding a live wire, I dropped her hands and bolted out the cinema.

Unlike how a protagonist in a movie reaches his or her resolve, realizing who
I really am was anticlimactic. It just occurred on my walk home from the
theaters on a mundane weekend, exhausted and embarrassed for ditching my date.
All the other details back then appears blurry, but when it came to my
identity from that moment on, it was clear as day.

It has been three years now since I embraced my true self, but my Mom still
doesn’t know.

As we watched, I took
the big leap of reaching for her hand and holding it. For a second, it felt
like nothing; within two seconds, a tingling feeling set off inside me. It
wasn’t that kind of current that ensured a romantic connection–it was the kind
of current that gave the feeling of being electrocuted as punishment. So like
holding a live wire, I dropped her hands and bolted out the cinema.

Unlike how a protagonist in a movie reaches his or her resolve, realizing who
I really am was anticlimactic. It just occurred on my walk home from the
theaters on a mundane weekend, exhausted and embarrassed for ditching my date.
All the other details back then appears blurry, but when it came to my
identity from that moment on, it was clear as day.

It has been three years now since I embraced my true self, but my Mom still
doesn’t know. I wake up every day in the hopes that such a day will gift the
right timing to tell her. And oftentimes, I would rehearse in the mirror how I
would tell her. Only the heavens know when the perfect timing will come.
Nonetheless, I am hopeful that one day, the heavens will shine upon me and
give me the courage to tell Mom how I actually identify myself. I wish to tell
her that rather than feeling as though living in sin, it feels like actually
living, and no longer foreign under my own skin. I'm dying to tell her, I’m
this Thomas, but I’m still the Thomas that is a child of God.

# The Pitfalls of ‘Pa-Reporting’

Written by Dean Joseph Palapar • Board by Junnine Tupaz | 12 October 23

 _‘Pa-reporting na naman?’_

It is that dreadful feeling, when all lessons in the syllabus of your course
are simultaneously presented in the first weeks only to have it entirely
assigned and discussed by small groups in your block throughout the whole
semester.

As waves of students enter once again the halls of PLM to welcome anew the
academic year, old habits die hard as some are still met with professors or
instructors who only have nothing but class reportings or ‘pa-reports’ to
include as their mode of instruction in most subjects.

This was echoed through sentiments of PLMayers, pertaining to the over
saturation of class reporting instances among subjects they are currently
taking this semester. It was, however, not a set of isolated cases, as older
posts dating back to when classes were still held online are reminiscent of
such. Even the same sentiments were aired then from the currently inactive
‘PLM Freedom Wall Facebook Page’, implying that frustrations regarding such
practice that has become a norm, though collectively recognized by the student
body, at present, has only reached virtual spaces.

To put into perspective, class reporting is a method of instruction mentioned
in the CHED Implementation Handbook for Outcome Based Education (OBE) and ISA,
from CHED Memorandum Order No. 46 series of 2012. It is in the list among
other approaches that faculties may opt to employ in their class. OBE tackles
a paradigm shift in which students become the ‘center of the learning process’
as opposed to teachers being the sole provider or the ‘instructor’ of
information to learners.

Class reportings and other methods of instruction that have been a product of
shifting from the implementation of OBE, root from the essence of honing the
students’ competencies to fulfill the learning outcomes as indicated in their
course syllabus. In class reportings, students discern relevant sources on the
topic to be discussed then ensure the veracity of gathered information in
their presentation. It also provides an avenue for creative expression,
participation and improving social relations among groups.

Perhaps, when paired with a student’s knack for information literacy, the
practice of intensive research counters the chances for possible
misinformation. Students become gradually accustomed with the practice of
fact-checking, and critical thinking is fostered through going beyond topics
on what was assigned. A useful set of skills to consider in the information
age we currently live in— and in a time when the spread of misinformation has
become a prevailing issue in Philippine society.

**An approach rooted from the idea of developing a learner’s self-esteem,
appreciation for collaboration, and upholding academic integrity through
required discussions of lessons are indeed beneficial in its fundamental
essence. But make it a pervasive routine, forge only a culture in which
opportunities for genuine empowerment and the further development of students’
social consciousness are instead replaced by the task of accomplishing a mere
plethora of compliances.**

‘Pa-reporting’ becomes counterproductive when it becomes extensive, and
faculties in-charge become overly reliant to their students on the overall
discussion of topics in their syllabus to a point of total nonparticipation
throughout the semester. This leads to perceived academic overload and burden.

A useful set of skills to consider in the information
age we currently live in— and in a time when the spread of misinformation has
become a prevailing issue in Philippine society.

**An approach rooted from the idea of developing a learner’s self-esteem,
appreciation for collaboration, and upholding academic integrity through
required discussions of lessons are indeed beneficial in its fundamental
essence. But make it a pervasive routine, forge only a culture in which
opportunities for genuine empowerment and the further development of students’
social consciousness are instead replaced by the task of accomplishing a mere
plethora of compliances.**

‘Pa-reporting’ becomes counterproductive when it becomes extensive, and
faculties in-charge become overly reliant to their students on the overall
discussion of topics in their syllabus to a point of total nonparticipation
throughout the semester. This leads to perceived academic overload and burden.
Coupled with little to no feedback from the instructor or professor, it
becomes detrimental to the morale of students. Extensive ‘pa-reportings’
became all the more ineffective during the online setup given the set of
compromises of the virtual environment, where students and faculties miss out
on the favorable conduciveness for learning.

In a 2018 study conducted by Mari Anjeli Crisanto, from the Faculty of
Information and Communication Studies of the University of the Philippines
Open University, the efficacy of group reportings in the online education set
up was explored. Diploma and master students in a class of database and
management systems were made to conduct group reports on certain modules of
their syllabus. A faculty-in-charge held an initial discussion of the
preceding modules prior. The conduct brought forth generally positive
receptions from students towards group reports, and their perceived benefits.
However, mixed responses were found to a question about whether students are
amenable to the conduct of all modules in the course in group report format,
with only 41% agreeing. To quote, _“Further studies can be done to determine
how much or how less of the course should be done in group reporting format.”_

Crisanto’s findings, despite being framed at the online education set up,
contribute to the notion that group reportings should be in moderation. In the
current state where F2F classes are slowly returning— with some at the
Pamantasan still sadly held online due to pending classroom assignments— the
outcomes of extensive ‘pa-reporting’ consist of just as many negatives as
there are positives. Extensive ‘pa-reports’ render the foundation of the
practice futile as it remains framed in a myopic perspective that it is the
end-all, be-all approach to delivering quality education among students.

It is not only in the matter of whether or not there is presence or absence of
quality education in ‘pa-reports’. Rather, it is in the fostered uncertainty
of the accessibility of quality education to students as extensive ‘pa-
reports’ become the dominant but faulty approach.

For one, there is a burden that befalls students to solely rely on their
blockmates for information on lessons reported. On part of the student
reporters, one can either be lauded for their skill in comprehensive
explanation and presentation, or be unsuccessful, despite their best efforts,
in engaging the class. What is further at stake is the state of uncertainty
among students when what was discussed are not even remarked or reviewed by
the instructor on matters of credibility of the report. What may occur is a
scenario reminiscent of the instructions-based approach as perhaps, possible
unengaged listeners merely receive information from talking presenters; vastly
different from the essence of CHED’s OBE. Further, extensive ‘pa-reporting’
makes student reporters also vulnerable to academic burnout or fatigue on the
nature of its repetitiveness across courses.

Without the faculty’s significant input in class, the chances for elaboration
to bridge contemporary issues and the implications of topics in society
dissipate into missed opportunities. The supposed wisdom and the depth of
knowledge from which students could have obtained from them are left unsaid.
And the likelihood of instances for further debate or a quenching of
curiosities through dialogues between the student and the instructor are
instead replaced by a mere reportage of information.

Students are able to grasp information through various methods of learning.
CHED’s handbook addressed this as it underscored the need to appropriate
approaches to develop students’ learning outcomes. And that extensive ‘pa-
reports’ having a monopoly on teaching instruction at worst, inhibits only the
intellectual development of those who are adapted, leaving those who may have
different perceptions on learning in shambles as they try to make up in their
class.

Without the faculty’s significant input in class, the chances for elaboration
to bridge contemporary issues and the implications of topics in society
dissipate into missed opportunities. The supposed wisdom and the depth of
knowledge from which students could have obtained from them are left unsaid.
And the likelihood of instances for further debate or a quenching of
curiosities through dialogues between the student and the instructor are
instead replaced by a mere reportage of information.

Students are able to grasp information through various methods of learning.
CHED’s handbook addressed this as it underscored the need to appropriate
approaches to develop students’ learning outcomes. And that extensive ‘pa-
reports’ having a monopoly on teaching instruction at worst, inhibits only the
intellectual development of those who are adapted, leaving those who may have
different perceptions on learning in shambles as they try to make up in their
class.

Class reportings root from the idea of connectivism through collaborative
learning, where the focus of imparting knowledge is prioritized to and by
students. This does not mean to exclude in totality, the role of the professor
or instructor as collaborative learning may transcend beyond from learner-
learner to learner-learner-facilitator. The term ‘facilitator’ as well does
not equate to nonparticipation.

Discussion entails an interchange of ideas from all factors present.
Therefore, ‘pa-reports’, although a method of instruction that has its pros,
should not be in any way, the only choice to consider in academic instruction.

It is important that instructors and professors recognize their responsibility
in classroom discussions as their takes on matters that concern their field
are essential facets to consider by the students. It is in this conduct of
such practice where quality education, higher learning, and academic
excellence is ensured while still upholding the idea of student-centered
learning.

The University prides itself for the academic excellence of its students.
Evident in this are the high passing rates of its alumni in the board exams,
with others even securing top ranks. These lists are one of many that continue
to engrave Pamantasan’s status as Manila’s premiere university. However, it is
important to consider that the recognition of academic excellence is not
finalized at the students’ success in passing their course nor their board
exams. Rather, academic excellence is a continuous progression towards being
able to apply and contribute what one has learned to the benefit of society
wherein the wisdom and expertise of instructors and professors have an
undoubted significant role in shaping students in their formative years in the
university before becoming a full-fledged serving citizen of the country.

# The PLM Intramurals 2024 finally concluded

Caption and Photos by Janelle Ugot | 5 August 24

The PLM Intramurals 2024 have finally concluded with an awarding ceremony
yesterday, at the Rajah Sulayman Gym. Aug 5.

The said intramurals commenced on June 21 as part of the university's 59th
founding anniversary celebration, which championed the talents of Haribons in
various sports events.

The cheerdance competition was also held on the same day as the awarding
ceremony, crowning the College of Education as the first placer, the College
of Nursing as the second runner-up, and the College of Humanities, Arts, and
Social Sciences as the third runner-up.

# Limampu’t isang taon makalipas ang Martial Law; Mensahe ng Paggunita kay
Liliosa Hilao at mga biktima ng Batas Militar

Written by Stefanie Santilla • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 20 September 23

Bagama't limampu't isang taon na ang nakalilipas, 'di maipagkakait ang malalim
na pinsalang naidulot sa Pilipinas ng madugo at mabagsik na panahon ng Martial
Law. Ang mga paghihirap na siyang naranasan ng ating mga kababayan noon,
bagama't limang dekada nang dokumentado sa kasaysayan, ay nananatiling hilaw
tuwing nakararanas tayo ng mga kaapihan at kawalang-katarungan na sumasalamin
sa rehimen ng diktator na Marcos noon.

Sa araw na ito, nararapat lamang na gunitain at parangalan nating muli ang mga
taong pilit na tinaasan ang kanilang boses sa kabila ng kamay na pilit namang
tinatanggal ang kalayaan ng taumbayan. Isa na rito si Liliosa Hilao, ang
pangalawang patnugot mula sa Ang Hasik, na siyang pahayagan ng ating
pamantasan noon. Bagama't hindi sa pisikal na aktibismo ang kaniyang naging
pamamaraan, kundi sa kaniyang mga salita na naipahayag gamit ng panulat at
papel, siya pa ang naging unang babaeng aktibista at mag-aaral na naitalang
biktima ng dahas at pisikal na kalupitan sa panahon ng Batas Militar. Dagdag
pa rito na sinubukang itago ang katotohanan ng kanyang paghihirap sa
pamamagitan ng paglista ng kaniyang kamatayan bilang isang suicide attempt.
Ngunit sa kabila ng kaapihan na kaniyang naranasan, siya ay nananatiling
simbolo ng hustisya at kalayaan na patuloy nating ipinaglalaban sa mga pwersa
na pilit naghahasik ng kasamaan at kawalang-katarungan sa bansa.

Sa araw na ito, bigyan natin si Lili, at marami pang mga biktima at kababayan
natin na matapang na tumayo sa panahon ng Martial Law, ng karangalan na
nararapat sa kanila ay naibigay, sa halip ng kalupitan at karahasan na
kanilang naranasan noon.

Ngunit sa kabila ng kaapihan na kaniyang naranasan, siya ay nananatiling
simbolo ng hustisya at kalayaan na patuloy nating ipinaglalaban sa mga pwersa
na pilit naghahasik ng kasamaan at kawalang-katarungan sa bansa.

Sa araw na ito, bigyan natin si Lili, at marami pang mga biktima at kababayan
natin na matapang na tumayo sa panahon ng Martial Law, ng karangalan na
nararapat sa kanila ay naibigay, sa halip ng kalupitan at karahasan na
kanilang naranasan noon. At sa ating paggunita, ay nawa'y mapukaw nating muli
ang ating pagmamahal sa bayan upang tumindig at makiisa laban sa mga
napapanahong isyu, tulad ng isang mungkahi na unti-unting bubura sa kasaysayan
sa pamamagitan ng pagtanggal ng apelyidong Marcos sa tabi ng salitang diktator
mula sa mga libro ng mga ikaanim na baitang; at laban sa kalupitan at kawalan
ng kasanayan ng kapulisan na patuloy na nagreresulta sa mga inosenteng
biktima, limampu't isang taon nang makalipas ang Martial Law.

# Of Super Typhoons and Tropical Storms: Roots of Manila Flooding

Written by Jan Rennie Abat & Estelle Theresa Gulay • Board by Elyse Abadilla | 10 September 23

Once relentless rain has unleashed a flooding crisis, traffic jams and
stranded commuters find themselves in the icy grip of one of the most flood-
prone areas in the Metropolitan– Manila City.

On Aug. 31, a southwest monsoon enhanced by Super Typhoon Saola (Goring),
Severe Tropical Storm Haikui (Hanna), and Tropical Storm Kirogi triggered the
gutter- to knee-deep flooded streets of Manila, mainly on Pedro Gil – Quirino
Avenue northbound, España-Lacson intersection, España corner dela Fuente,
Pureza and V. Mapa Ramon Magsaysay Boulevard (RMB) westbound, and Kalaw Roxas
Boulevard northbound.

The same perennial flooding was encountered a month before with Super Typhoon
Doksuri (Egay) and Severe Tropical Storm Khanun (Falcon) enhancing a southwest
monsoon that swamped the roads in Metro Manila. On July 27, tire to gutter-
deep floods in the areas of Recto, Taft Avenues, and Padre Faura were
reported.

With the continuous reports of flooded areas as the monsoon season continues,
the challenged resiliency of the drenched urban landscape reveals the deep-
rooted problems of Manila flooding.

The local government units (LGUs) in Manila have consistently joined forces
with the Metro Manila Development Authority (MMDA) in their attempts to
mitigate and uproot the problems of flood. After the perils brought by Falcon
and Egay, Metro Manila Council President and San Juan City Mayor Francis
Zamora emphasized the importance of coordination with MMDA for building flood
control initiatives.

MMDA Task Force Special Operations head Edison “Bong” Nebrija, on the other
hand, admitted that a ‘flood-free’ Metro Manila is not possible since some
areas are below sea level. He also stressed in a GMA interview last July 13
that trash continues to be a problem with solid wastes clogging drainage
systems, and hence, the need to improve “garbage monitoring” and waste
reduction programs.

On the other side, one of the roots of flooding in the Metro mentioned by
Venus Zoleta in a safety blog titled “Flood-Prone Areas in the Philippines:
Places to Avoid While Driving”, was inadequate drainage capacity. Areas such
as Pedro Gil and Quirino Ave. are flood-prone due to poorly built and
insufficient drainage systems.

In relation, Nebrija reported that the MMDA has focused on developing pumping
stations to shorten draining periods of flood water to mitigate the problem.

However, the unfinished pumping stations and pipelines headed by the
Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH), specifically three main
drainage outposts near Manila Bay Dolomite Beach: the Faura and Remedios
drainage systems, and the Estero de San Antonio Abad, were declared to have
caused a longer time for the Manila flood to subside after heavy downpours
last year, Aug. 22, as per MMDA acting General Manager and Flood Control
Director, Baltazar Melgar.

Areas such
as Pedro Gil and Quirino Ave. are flood-prone due to poorly built and
insufficient drainage systems.

In relation, Nebrija reported that the MMDA has focused on developing pumping
stations to shorten draining periods of flood water to mitigate the problem.

However, the unfinished pumping stations and pipelines headed by the
Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH), specifically three main
drainage outposts near Manila Bay Dolomite Beach: the Faura and Remedios
drainage systems, and the Estero de San Antonio Abad, were declared to have
caused a longer time for the Manila flood to subside after heavy downpours
last year, Aug. 22, as per MMDA acting General Manager and Flood Control
Director, Baltazar Melgar.

Melgar also denied the alleged relationship between the white-sanded shores of
Manila Bay and the flooding on the bustling streets of Manila.

In an interview over Teleradyo, DPWH Secretary Manuel Bonoan admitted that
they have yet to finish the construction because of the need to install longer
pipes that require a built-in sewage treatment plant that would filter the
flood water going into Manila Bay.

In contrast with the MMDA acting general manager, the Public Works Secretary
claimed that such was relative to the bay rehabilitation program, specifically
to maintain cleanliness of the Dolomite Beach at the Manila Baywalk.

Bonoan argued that the three pumping stations of concern needed an enhanced
pump capacity to accommodate the extension of pipes going to Manila Bay, as
requested by the DENR (Department of Environment and Natural Resources) in
consideration of keeping the Dolomite Beach clean. He also added that the
repair was a collaborative effort among the DPWH, the MMDA, and the DENR.

Lawyer Rose-Liza Eisma-Osorio, legal and policy director of Oceana—a nonprofit
international advocacy organization dedicated to protecting the world’s
oceans—remarked on the simultaneous closure of the three pumping stations and
pipeline as a reflection of a “lack of foresight” considering the rainy season
that occurs in the country from June to November.

In addition, Eisma-Osorio noted that reclamation and similar coastal
development activities in Manila Bay—such as that of Dolomite Beach, along
with 27 other proposed and ongoing reclamation projects—place the lives of
residents along the coastal area at risk due to its vulnerability to many
natural hazards such as flooding, storm surges, and land subsidence arising
from stronger typhoons.

Similarly, urban planning expert and landscape architect Paulo Alcazaren has
also mentioned rapid urban development along with the uncoordinated response
between Metro Manila’s local governments as another root of the persistent
city flooding.

“Ang problema, ang government planning ay not based on science but based on
politics,” Alcazaren claimed in an interview with One PH.

The expert observed that while Singapore addresses climate change in its green
infrastructure expansion with periodical land use reviews, Metro Manila city
local governments fail to consult one another with their own land use plans.
He also stated that the continuous development and construction of structures
reduced the green open spaces in Metro Manila that should be absorbing
rainfall.

With a glimmer of hope, LGUs in Metro Manila are considering a 50-year water
drainage system master plan in collaboration with MMDA. The proposal aims to
build drainage systems across the city to be similar in terms of size and
design, as reported by acting MMDA Chairman Romando Artes last Aug. 2.

An integrated master plan focused on flood control programs in flood-prone
regions was also proposed during a Senate hearing last Aug. 9. On Thursday,
Mayor Honey Lacuna appealed to the national government to resolve the issue of
flooding problems on Taft Avenue.

# SCOA, AP partners for transparency, accountability

Written by Rinoa Angeline Dela Torre • Photos by Jeanette Tropa | 29 May 24

The PLM Student Commission on Audit (SCOA) and Ang Pamantasan (AP) signed a
Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) for their partnership in the special
coverage of auditing of student councils and organizations in Pamantasan, May
15.

As stated in their MOU, both parties acknowledge the importance of
transparency and accountability in the university, and wish to establish a
partnership to raise awareness through disseminating accurate and relevant
information on financial concerns.

Present at the signing are Samantha Nicole R. Martinez, Chief Commissioner;
and Christian Andrei G. Narito, Treasurer from PLM SCOA. On the other hand,
Ken Joshua De Paula, Associate Editor; and Jeanette B. Tropa, Board Secretary,
represented AP.

The agreement shall be effective upon execution and therefore shall be
completed on June 30, 2024, with flexibility based on the auditing duration as
long as specific deliverables and outputs of the agreements are met by the
parties.

PLM SCOA is vested by the PLM Student Manual Title 5 Section 2.5 and 2.6b with
the power, authority, and duty to examine, audit and settle financial concerns
of student councils and accredited organizations.

# PLM Department of Psychology conducts its first Pinning Ceremony, celebrates
student success and resilience

Written by Jeanette Tropa • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 5 March 24

The Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) Psychology Department marked a
significant milestone for the community of the said department, particularly
the fourth-year Psychology students of Batch 2023-2024 as they conducted their
first-ever Pinning Ceremony last February 7. The event, which was attended by
distinguished professionals in the field, was meant to honor the achievements
and resilience of students who navigated their academic paths amid the
challenges they stumbled upon from their freshmen to senior years.

The ceremony marked the turning point in the academic careers of the
psychology students. Due to the pandemic, the batch that participated in PLM's
first-ever pinning ceremony had to adjust to the abrupt switch to online
learning. The bumpy roads they traveled on played a pivotal role in their
academic journey—all of which makes the ceremony both a life-changing event
and an unforgettable experience.

"It will definitely be a good transition for all the students' efforts to get
to this point." In a post-event interview, Shane Cuevas—President of the PLM
Psychological Society (PsySoc)—emphasized the symbolic nature of the ceremony,
highlighting how students will then apply what they have learned in real-world
settings despite starting their college virtually. "Parang ayun, parang
kahapon lang we're conducting all classes nung first year ng online," Cuevas
said.

Moreover, PsySoc Vice President for External Affairs, Chriztel Faye Reyes,
emphasized that the pinning ceremony represented the psychology students'
whole journey, showcasing their enthusiasm for the field of psychology and
serving as a withstanding feat that will endure with them as they begin their
internships.

The College of Science Dean, Prof. Aileen Atienza, gave a heartfelt welcome
and encouraged the students to take pride in the event and realize their
commitment to their chosen field.

Following that, PLM's Vice President for Academic Affairs, Dr. Ronald Romero,
read Atty. Domingo "Sir Sonny" Reyes, Jr.’s message to set the tone for a day
filled with reflection, enthusiasm, and inspiration. In his message, President
Sonny urged the psychology students to live up to the acronym EGO, which
stands for excellence, godliness, and optimism. "May each of us develop a
strong sense of self-worth and grow into better versions of ourselves, who
will soon lead your chosen field," Dr. Romero read.

Prominent professionals graced the event, including Rachel Faye Torio Nuñez,
an alumna of batch 2022 who gave an inspiring speech on her own journey in
psychology. She talked about the difficulties she had while completing an
internship and the COVID-19 pandemic's then-impending effects. Nuñez stressed
the value of perseverance, faith, and the pin that every single psychology
student wears with pride.

In her powerful speech, respected board member of the Psychological
Association of the Philippines Dr. Pricila B. Marzan urged the graduating
class to maintain their professional growth, stay involved in associations for
psychologists, and accept the difficulties that come with practicing
psychology.

"May each of us develop a
strong sense of self-worth and grow into better versions of ourselves, who
will soon lead your chosen field," Dr. Romero read.

Prominent professionals graced the event, including Rachel Faye Torio Nuñez,
an alumna of batch 2022 who gave an inspiring speech on her own journey in
psychology. She talked about the difficulties she had while completing an
internship and the COVID-19 pandemic's then-impending effects. Nuñez stressed
the value of perseverance, faith, and the pin that every single psychology
student wears with pride.

In her powerful speech, respected board member of the Psychological
Association of the Philippines Dr. Pricila B. Marzan urged the graduating
class to maintain their professional growth, stay involved in associations for
psychologists, and accept the difficulties that come with practicing
psychology.

“I want you to remind yourselves to enhance or impact yourself on the lives of
other people. Your knowledge and skills have the power to heal, to inspire,
and to transform each interaction that you have with a client or patient, or a
research participant [which] is an opportunity for all of you to make a
difference and also to provide support and to promote positive change.”

Following a successful first pinning ceremony, the psychology department
shared its aspirations for the future. They expressed their desire for this
ceremony to become tradition at the PLM Department of Psychology, affirming
its significance in promoting the field of psychology.

In spite of difficulties, the occasion honored academic triumphs and displayed
the determination along with dedication of psychology students in pursuing
their studies. In the future, the organizers hoped to make the ceremony
accessible to friends and families by involving the larger community.

PsySoc Treasurer, Bea Rodelas, stressed the importance of upholding
transparency and prudent financial management for the subsequent pinning
ceremonies: "Siguro as part ng preparation sa interest check pa lang,
i-release kung ano yung result, then i-heads up agad yung students na mga
ganitong amount yung magagastos natin. Also, i-consider din talaga yung
contingency fund.”

"What we have learned lang naman is kapag sa next batch, need nila talagang
[i]-consider lahat ng factors like 10 step ahead kayo kasi may mga
circumstances yung hindi mo ma-expect," said PsySoc Senior Officer Chelsea
Queen Cabalquinto, who also offered advice for the upcoming batches on how to
overcome criticisms and unforeseen circumstances.

The cooperation and dedication of PsySoc, students, and faculty members of
PLM's Department of Psychology was vital in making the pinning ceremony a
success. This historic event not only established a new chapter in the history
of PLM's psychology department, but it also provided a model for upcoming
generations of psychology students to follow. The guidance, insights, and
words of wisdom that were provided at this occasion will surely serve as a
beacon of hope for these fourth year students as they set out on their
careers.
