# SSC Acting President steps down; CN rep appointed as new Council head

Written by Rylan Gabriel B. Bernardo • Board by by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 29 February 24

PLM Supreme Student Council (SSC) Acting President John Coby A. Cabuhat
officially resigned from the University’s highest student governing body,
effective Wednesday, Feb. 28 at 5:00 PM.

Ending his two-month tenure, Cabuhat cited personal matters and asked for the
community to respect his privacy amid his resignation.

“I hope that in my brief term as a member of the council, I have started a
little step that requires a journey… a journey to continuing, reformed, and
better student governance that has high regards to transparency,
accountability, and rule of law,” Cabuhat writes in his resignation letter
last Feb. 23.

The SSC called for an Emergency Council General Meeting the following day,
informing student officers of his resignation along with providing updates on
the ongoing initiatives and turnover of plans for the rest of the academic
year.

Following Cabuhat’s resignation, the SSC Core Committee held another Council
Emergency Session on Wednesday morning, Feb 28 to formally vote and address
the vacancy within the council, where College of Nursing (CN) Representative
Edwin Joseph C. Espinas was elected as the new Acting President of the
Council.

The meeting was in conformity with the SSC’s by-laws, as stipulated in Section
2, Article XII of the Supreme Student Council: “In case of vacancy in the PLM
SSC by reason of death, resignation, disqualification, permanent incapacity,
or separation from the University of any officer, an acting officer elected by
majority vote of SSC officers shall serve for the unexpired term, or the
election, as the case may be.”

Cabuhat formally communicated his resignation to University President Atty.
Domingo “Sir Sonny” Y. Reyes, Jr. and Vice President for Research, Academic,
and Extension Services Dr. Dan Michael Cortez last Feb. 27. His resignation
was also announced during his closing remarks at the Office of Student
Development and Services (OSDS) General Assembly held on the same day.

Last Monday, the Council Advisers, Student Organization and Activities (SOA)
Head Prof. Jasmin B. Jocson, OSDS Director Lynnette G. Cleto, representatives
from the Student Commission on Elections, and Student Commission on Audit, and
College Student Council Presidents were also made aware of Cabuhat’s
resignation.

Cabuhat’s two-month term saw his efforts in leading the SSC to its Strategic
Planning Conference, the establishment of resolutions on its Internal Rules
and Procedures, the reorganization of the student governing body, the
introduction of a Code of Conduct, and the formation of programs and ad hoc
committees to address student concerns.

The SSC remains committed to ensuring “continuity of governance.”

# EKSTENSYONG SOLUSYON: Makabagong paraan ng pag-oorganisa

Written by Vince Villanueva • Board by Angelle Valbuena | 17 September 23

Paulit-ulit na paggawa ng sariling _class schedule_ , palagiang pagtingin sa
listahan ng mga klase at karaniwang pagkalimot sa mga oras nito dala ng samu’t
saring gawain — ito ang mga madalas na hamong dinaranas ng mga Haribon bunsod
ng hindi epektibong paraan ng pag-oorganisa ng mga pang-akademikong gawain.

Tinatangkilik ngayon ang solusyong binuo ni Adrian Angelo Abelarde, mula sa
_Computer Science (CS)_ , ang _PLM CRS Class Schedule Google Calendar
extension_ na kung saan ang _class schedule_ na makikita sa Pamantasan ng
Lungsod ng Maynila _Computerized Registration System (PLM CRS)_ ay madidirekta
sa _Google Calendar_ sa pamamagitan ng isang _extension_. Sa tulong ng
ekstensyong ito, nagkakaroon ng _notification_ o abiso ang mga estudyante bago
magsimula ang isang klase, depende sa kung anong araw at oras nakalaan ang
asignatura.

Ang nasabing _extension_ ang kauna-unahang _web extension_ na nabuo ni
Abelarde. Sa katunayan, umani ng mahigit 13 libong _views_ at tatlong daang
_shares_ ang kaniyang kasalakuyang _Facebook post_ patungkol dito _._ Si
Abelarde rin ang kasalukuyang _web development lead_ ng _Google Developer
Student Clubs (GDSC)_ ng PLM.

**Ideya noon, solusyon ngayon**

****

Ilan sa mga rason ng pagkakabuo ng ekstensyon ay ang sangkaterbang
responsibilidad, mga sunod-sunod na takdang-aralin, at iba’t ibang
_extracurricular activities_ na naranasan mismo ni Abelarde noong unang taon
niya sa Pamantasan na sumubok sa kaniyang kakayahang mag-organisa ng oras para
sa mga gawain bilang estudyante.

Sa katunayan, umani ng mahigit 13 libong _views_ at tatlong daang
_shares_ ang kaniyang kasalakuyang _Facebook post_ patungkol dito _._ Si
Abelarde rin ang kasalukuyang _web development lead_ ng _Google Developer
Student Clubs (GDSC)_ ng PLM.

**Ideya noon, solusyon ngayon**

****

Ilan sa mga rason ng pagkakabuo ng ekstensyon ay ang sangkaterbang
responsibilidad, mga sunod-sunod na takdang-aralin, at iba’t ibang
_extracurricular activities_ na naranasan mismo ni Abelarde noong unang taon
niya sa Pamantasan na sumubok sa kaniyang kakayahang mag-organisa ng oras para
sa mga gawain bilang estudyante. Nanatiling ideya lamang niya ito noon at
ginamit bilang motibasyon ang mga pagsubok upang mas pagtibayin niya ang
kaniyang kasanayan sa pagbuo ng mga komplikadong _programs_ at _websites._

Idagdag pa ang kawalan ng maayos at nakalilitong _class schedule:_ Kung
titingnan sa kasalukuyang ayos sa _PLM CRS_ , ang mga asignatura ay nakalista
lamang na may kalakip na araw, oras, silid at kung ito man ay isasagawa
_online_ o _face-to-face._ Tiyak na paglalaanan ng oras at pag-aanalisa bago
mabuo’t maisaayos ang mga ito sa mas maiintindihang porma. Kung kaya’t
malaking kagaanan para sa maraming Haribon ang bagong buong proyektong ito ni
Abelarde sapagkat bukod sa direkta na ito mailalagay sa _Google Calendar_ ,
ito na rin mismo ang magsasaayos ng asignatura depende sa oras at araw.

**Hamon ang impormasyon**

****

Malaking hamon para maisakatuparan ang mga teknikal na aspeto sa pagbuo nito.
Nariyan ang pagkuha ng mga impormasyon at datos upang gawin itong _.csv file,_
gayundin ang pagkakaroon at paglalagay ng _start at end dates_ upang itugma
ang mga asignatura at araw na may pasok sa wasto’t klarong paraan. Ang
pagmamanipula sa mga datos mula sa _CRS class schedule_ ay mas naging posible
sa paggamit ng _Artificial Intelligence (AI)_ tulad ng _Large Language Models
(LLMs)_ na nag-udyok upang mabuo itong ideya.

Sa kabila ng hamon ng pagkuha ng mga impormasyon, ang ekstensyong sinimulang
buuin noong ika-4 ng Setyembre ay naisakatuparan matapos ang isang buong araw.
Natutuhan din niya ang iba pang bagay tulad ng paggawa ng _open-source
project_ sa _GitHub_ na nagpabukas ng mas maraming oportunidad.__ Bagama’t
isang araw lamang ang ginugol, tiyak na hinasa ng panahon, at binigyan ng
oras, pagsasanay, pagpupursige’t dedikasyon upang maisagawa ito.

**Plano para sa ekspansyon**

****

Bukas din sa samu’t saring suhestyon ang _developer_ upang mas mapalawak ang
kaniyang nabuong solusyon. Ilan sa kaniyang mga plano ay ang paglalagay ng
_subject set-up details_ tulad ng _LecSyncOnline_ o _face-to-face_ sa mismong
pamagat na makikita sa _Google Calendar_ , pagsasaayos ng _user interface_
upang mas kaaya-ayang tingnan ang _extension_ , at pagpapalawak at pagkakaroon
ng _Firefox at Firefox Add-ons._

__

Gayundin ang posibleng pag-export ng _class schedule_ bilang imahe o
_timetable format_ katulad ng _ClassUp_ at pagreresolba ng mga isyu o _bugs_
sa _Delete All Events_ na itinatampok nito.

Ilan sa kaniyang mga plano ay ang paglalagay ng
_subject set-up details_ tulad ng _LecSyncOnline_ o _face-to-face_ sa mismong
pamagat na makikita sa _Google Calendar_ , pagsasaayos ng _user interface_
upang mas kaaya-ayang tingnan ang _extension_ , at pagpapalawak at pagkakaroon
ng _Firefox at Firefox Add-ons._

__

Gayundin ang posibleng pag-export ng _class schedule_ bilang imahe o
_timetable format_ katulad ng _ClassUp_ at pagreresolba ng mga isyu o _bugs_
sa _Delete All Events_ na itinatampok nito. Dahil sa patuloy na pagtangkilik
ng mga Haribon, maraming ideya’t suhestyon ang natatangap ni Abelarde na
naging malaking tulong upang higit na mapaganda’t madagdagan ang mga maaaring
ihandog ng ekstensyong ito.

_“Embrace the opportunity to delve into diverse branches within the expansive
technology realm, including but not limited to web development, mobile app
development, data analytics, cybersecurity, and much more. The technological
landscape offers a wide array of exciting pathways for exploration and
growth,”_ wika ni Abelarde.

Ang mga maliliit na ideya ay posibleng magsiklab ng malaking solusyon.
Pinatunayan lamang ng pagkabuo ng _PLM CRS Class Schedule Google Calendar
extension_ na malawak ang oportunidad kung gagamitin natin ang teknolohiya sa
responsableng pamamaraan. Malaki ang ginagampanan ng mga makabagong
teknolohiya sa pagpapagaan at pagpapaunlad ng akademikong kasanayan at husay
ng mga Haribon kung kaya’t maging inspirasyon ang mga ganitong bagong buong
proyekto na hindi imposibleng maging reyalidad ang isang simpleng ideya.

# Teaching Minds, Touching Hearts, Transforming Lives: PLM inaugurates Atty.
Reyes as its 11th President

Written by Calvin Agustin • Photos by Roland Justin Molato | 20 February 24

Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) conducted the Investiture Rites for its
11th University President, Atty. Domingo “Sir Sonny” Y. Reyes, Jr., at the
Justo Albert Auditorium, Feb. 15.

Dr. Ma. Flordeliza Anastacio, former professor of Pres. Reyes and the Vice
President of Centro Escolar University - Malolos; CV Zalamea, Ice Clemente,
Raven Quan, former students of Pres. Reyes; and Ms. Myra Reyes-Barrera, Pres.
Reyes’ sister, gave their salutations and shared their memories with their
beloved Sir Sonny as a student, a teacher and a father figure, and a brother.

“Your journey to this presidency has been marked by hard work, perseverance,
and passion for making a positive impact on the lives of kids, students, and
the people around you. I have witnessed your dedication, principles of
integrity, inclusivity, and academic excellence in education. I am confident
that with your leadership, PLM will flourish and continue to be a beacon of
inspiration for students, faculty, and the entire community,” Ms. Reyes-
Barrera said.

Senator Christopher Lawrence “Bong” Go and Manila City Mayor Ma. Shielah
“Honey” Lacuna-Pangan also sent their regards to the new PLM President with
his installation to the post.

Atty. Carlo Florendo Castro, the University Board Secretary, read the citation
of Board of Regents (BOR) Resolution No. 5163, ratifying the appointment of
Sir Sonny Reyes as a BOR member and his election as the University President
last October 2023.

Afterwards, former President and incumbent 2nd District of Pampanga
Representative Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo (GMA), City Vice Mayor Yul Servo-Nieto,
Manila 3rd District Rep. Joel Chua, and BOR members Dr. Joseph Berlin Guanzon
and Atty. Castro led the bestowal of the University symbols such as the hood,
the PLM Academic Collar, the University Charter and Mace upon the new PLM
President.

Also present in the ceremony were government leaders, presidents and heads of
various local universities and colleges, family and friends of Pres. Reyes,
college deans, officials, and members of the Executive Committee, as well as
representatives from the PLM Supreme Student Council, and Ang Pamantasan.

After the bestowal of the University symbols, Pres. Reyes took centerstage and
delivered his inaugural address. He shared his discernment on leaving his
career as a lawyer and pursuing the mission of higher education.

Joel Chua, and BOR members Dr. Joseph Berlin Guanzon
and Atty. Castro led the bestowal of the University symbols such as the hood,
the PLM Academic Collar, the University Charter and Mace upon the new PLM
President.

Also present in the ceremony were government leaders, presidents and heads of
various local universities and colleges, family and friends of Pres. Reyes,
college deans, officials, and members of the Executive Committee, as well as
representatives from the PLM Supreme Student Council, and Ang Pamantasan.

After the bestowal of the University symbols, Pres. Reyes took centerstage and
delivered his inaugural address. He shared his discernment on leaving his
career as a lawyer and pursuing the mission of higher education.

“Tinalikuran ko ang maginhawa at maperang karera ng aking propesyon na
pagiging abogado, at tuluyan ko nang niyakap ang misyon ng edukasyon nang
mahigpit, buong-buo, at walang pag-aalinlangan o pagsisisi man… Sa Pamantasan
ng Lungsod ng Maynila nagtuloy ang misyon ng **_teaching minds, touching
hearts, and transforming lives to the last, the least, and the lost_** _,_ ”
the PLM President stated.

Pres. Reyes then emphasized that during his term, he will be focused on
achieving two aspirations: continuity and improvement of PLM’s quality
education, and strengthening of the efficient service provided to the PLM
community and its stakeholders. Furthermore, Pres. Reyes shared that for the
next three to four years of his term, he will be committed to excellence in
higher education by allocating budget for learning laboratories, extensive
review of PLM’s programs and its curriculum, accreditation of the roster of
programs that PLM continues to offer, involvement in research and
internalization, strengthening institutional partnerships, integration of
technology in service of PLM and its stakeholders, and the implementation of
PLM’s performance matrix.

The new PLM President closed his inaugural address by expressing his
admiration towards teaching personnel and students of the Pamantasan, that
despite the challenges in the academe, their perseverance continues to be
evident.

“Lahat tayo ay maituturing na guro or teachers in our own rights, not
necessarily in schools but in other areas of our chosen endeavors, I hope you
could say the same to your future mentees. For in the end, it is the love for
what you do and the love for the people that you encounter because love will
always make the difference,” Pres. Reyes stated.

After the Investiture Rites, the PLM community and distinguished guests
gathered at the PLM Open Field for the wreath laying ceremony in front of the
statues of Dr. Jose Rizal and former City Mayor Ramon Bagatsing.

Students from the PLM Chorale together with members of the Magwayen Creative
Scholars’ Guild performed “Ngayon ang Simula at Ako, Ikaw, Tayong Lahat ang
Pagbabago”, a commemorative song for this momentous event, composed by Pres.
Reyes himself and music accompaniment by Prof. Harold Perfecto Galang. Vice
Chair for Arts and Culture of the Presidential Committee on Arts, Culture, and
Sports.

Before the Investiture Ceremony, the PLM community and distinguished guests
had a eucharistic celebration presided by Rev. Msgr. Ernesto Mandanas.

# BOR Chair resigns

Written by John Coby Cabuhat • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 28 September 23

Effective yesterday, Sept. 28, the Board of Regents (BOR) Chairperson Atty.
Jose Ngaw resigned from his post.

Atty. Ngaw expressed his decision to Manila Mayor Maria Sheilah ‘Honey’
Lacuna-Pangan last Sept. 12.

“I thanked the City of Manila for giving me the opportunity to serve PLM for
the past four (4) years, a period which I will fondly look back [on] as my
attempt in paying back the City where I was born,” Ngaw said in his message to
the PLM community on Sept. 29.

Ngaw served as a member of the BOR since 2019 and was then named as its
Chairperson last Mar. 28 following the resignation of the late Dr. Francisco
Roman Jr.

As a regent, Ngaw initiated discussions for cross-border collaboration on
education and research with international education institutions. This
resulted in a visit from the National Cheng Kung University of Taiwan (NCKU)
officials in PLM last October 2022.

The outgoing Chairperson has years of work experience in the government,
corporate sector, and non-government organizations.

Prior to his appointment, he once served as legal counsel of the Philippine
Health Insurance Corporation and held key positions in listed companies.

He was also a trustee at the University of the East and its Ramon Magsaysay
Memorial Medical Center.

Also, under his leadership was the time when the Commission on Higher
Education revoked the exemption of the University to the minimum requirements
of institutional recognition, a condition for the Free Higher Education (FHE)
Program.

This resulted in the possible recommendation of the commission to delist the
University from the FHE program if it will not be complied with.

In addition, the Manila City Government also advised him and the BOR not to
take any action or approve such from University President Emmanuel Leyco until
a new appointee is named in his stead. This is in light of the revocation of
the City Council’s concurrence to Leyco’s appointment.

As earlier reported by Ang Pamantasan, there is an absence of expressed
provisions for the removal of a BOR member through a resolution withdrawing
consent that was given already.

# 'It Won’t Be My Last': Villegas takes Bronze in her Olympic debut, hopes
intact

Written by Cedrick Paynor • Board by Angelle Valbuena | 7 August 24

 _Aira 's pursuit of gold may have ended in the semifinals, but the bronze in
her Olympic debut signals a future with greater triumphs._

Aira Villegas wrapped up her Olympic debut with a bronze medal as she endured
a unanimous decision loss to Turkey’s Buse Naz Cakiroglu in the Paris Olympics
women’s 50-kg boxing semifinals at the Roland Garros Stadium, Aug. 7.

Though she fell short in reaching the final, the 28-year-old pride of Tacloban
showed no signs of disappointment and hopes Filipinos will celebrate her
bronze finish with pride.

“Hindi naman po ako super disappointed, kasi ginawa ko yung best ko. Sa lahat
ng Pilipino na napuyat, sorry. Nakapag-uwi po ako ng medal, sana proud pa rin
kayo sa’kin,” Villegas shared in an interview with One Sports.

Villegas also admitted that despite her best efforts, her opponent was simply
exceptional in the sport.

A former World Champion and Tokyo Olympics silver medalist, Turkey's Cakiroglu
was simply too dominant for Villegas, winning convincingly with scores of
30-26, 30-26, 30-27, 30-27, and 30-27.

Before reaching the semifinals, Villegas took down Morocco’s Yasmine Mouttaki
and Algeria’s Roumaysa Boualam with unanimous decisions, and clinched a split
decision win over France’s Wassila Lkhadiri.

Her stint in the semifinals boosted the Philippines’ medal count at the 2024
Olympics, adding a bronze to the two elusive golds snagged by the decorated
gymnast Carlos Yulo.

Villegas will not go home empty-handed despite missing out on the title as she
will receive a P2 million cash incentive from the government under Republic
Act No. 10699, along with additional perks from government officials and other
sponsors, similar to those given to Filipino boxer Eumir Marcial for his Tokyo
bronze.

Reflecting on her inaugural Olympic campaign, Villegas took pride in both her
past self, who worked hard to reach Paris, and her future self, who will
continue striving for success.

“Sa younger self ko I know that you are already proud of me,” Villegas said.
“To my future self, mas lalo ka pa magiging proud. Gagawin ko [ang lahat para
sa] pangarap ko na bago man lang mag-retire sa boxing, patutugtugan ako ng
national anthem ng bansa natin sa Olympics.”

Villegas hoped her first Olympic appearance would not be her last, believing
that her hard-earned bronze and dedication would open the door to more
opportunities and future successes.

# SO NEAR YET SO FAR: Obiena improves previous Olympics rank, slips podium
finish

Written by Raniel Paquingan • Board by John Ivan Pasion | 6 August 24

By a whisker.

From 11th place in Japan, EJ Obiena soared to 4th place in the 2024 Paris
Olympics men’s pole vault, one leap away from jumping for joy of bringing home
the elusive medal, Aug. 6.

Despite a shaky start during the qualifications, Obiena’s flight towards the
podium started smoothly, as he successfully cleared 5.50 m and 5.70 m in a
single attempt without any trouble. But, it was a heart-stopping moment anew
for the Filipinos as the country’s pole vaulter dislodged the bar in his first
attempt at 5.80 m, where he later skipped to save his jumps for higher
heights.

Obiena managed to bounce back at 5.85 m and 5.90 m but struggled to make it
past 5.95 m.

With only four participants remaining, World Rank no. 2 laid out all his
cards, risked it all, and took a leap of faith—but to no avail as he slipped
the 5.95 m bar in all three attempts.

In his post, Obiena expressed his gratitude towards Filipino fans and promised
to come back stronger.

“Thank you again for your support and standing by me. I love you all, and we
all share a common love and pride for the Philippines... I have been knocked
down. But I will get back up,” the pole vaulter quipped.

Obiena’s showing in Paris is still an improvement, as this is his best
performance in the Olympics by far.

# ‘Mataas ang aking kumpiyansa’: PBBM concludes his third SONA

Written by Calvin Agustin & Rinoa Angeline Dela Torre • Board by John Ivan Pasion | 22 July 24

President Ferdinand “Bong-bong” Marcos, Jr. (PBBM) finished his third State of
the Nation Address (SONA), confident with the administration’s endeavors and
future plans, at the Batasang Pambansa, July 22.

The President highlighted the administration’s achievements, notably on
economic growth, job creation, and infrastructure development. He then
highlighted the administration’s priorities for the upcoming year.

“Mga kababayan, sa lahat ng mga ginagawa nating ito at mga gagawin pa, mataas
ang aking kumpiyansa na malalampasan din natin ang hamon ng ating
pinagdadaanan dahil ito ang pangunahing hinaing ng taumbayan. Hindi tayo
titigil sa paglaban sa kahirapan, at sa paghahanap ng lunas upang maibalik sa
normal ang presyo ng bilihin, lalo na ang bigas. At ngayon po, naririnig po
namin ang malakas na sigaw ng taumbayan laban sa mga POGO,” Marcos Jr. stated.

Despite the Philippines being praised as one of the best-performing economies
in Asia, Pres. Marcos admitted that these numbers mean little to Filipinos
struggling with high prices, especially for rice. In response, he vowed to
tackle rising food costs and make Kadiwa stalls permanent across the country.

Marcos Jr. highlighted the need to keep working on reducing food prices,
noting that rice inflation was 22.5% in June, slightly down from 23% in May.
He promised to expand the Kadiwa program in partnership with local
governments, ensuring that affordable food remains accessible to all
Filipinos.

In response to Beijing’s authoritative claims over the South China Sea, PBBM
emphasized that the territory indisputably belongs to the Philippines and must
stay under its sovereignty.

"Ang West Philippine Sea ay hindi kathang-isip natin lamang. Ito ay atin. At
ito ay mananatiling atin, hangga’t nag-aalab ang diwa ng ating minamahal na
bansang Pilipinas," he said.

Just before the end of his speech, the chief of state stated that all
Philippine Offshore Gaming Operators (POGO) shall be banned, effectively
immediately. The President also urged the Philippine Amusement and Gaming
Corporation to seize the operations of POGOs by the end of the year. He stated
that the Department of Labor and Employment shall plan to provide new job
opportunities for Filipino workers who will be displaced once POGO operations
come to halt.

PBBM emphasized that all officials, law enforcers, government workers, and the
people shall remain vigilant and principled, thinking of the nation’s health,
in order to solve the problems faced by the country.

# PLM commences annual VAWC campaign

Written by Angel Crismar Joy Udtohan • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 30 November 23

In accordance with Proclamation 1172 s. 2006, the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng
Maynila (PLM) held its campaign to end Violence Against Women and their
Children (VAWC) on Nov. 28 until Dec. 12.

With the VAWC Banner hanging at the PLM facade and lobby, the kick-off
activity led by Prof. April Bonoan at the Tanghalang Bayan, saw performances
from various student organizations.

Throughout the campaign, various seminars and check-ups will be conducted over
the course of 14 days for the student and faculty populace about health
awareness, Commission on Higher Education guidelines, and the VAWC law.

On Dec. 6, “Magtanong kay Attorney” will be held at Justo Alberto Auditorium
in the morning to be followed by “Her Story: a Day Forward” in the afternoon.
Thereafter, another seminar will be conducted on Dec. 7, “Empowering Women’s
Health: a Guide to Sexual Wellness and Pelvic Floor Therapy”, while a final
seminar that focuses on how to handle sexual harassment will be held on Dec.
12.

“This will provide an opportunity for the participants to increase awareness
and accuracy in recognizing sexual harassment and educate them on the
organization‘s process for handling complaints for them to be protected,
understand the law and exercise their right”, College of Education (CED) Dean
Dr. Jimmy Romero said during the opening ceremony.

“Harana para kay Juan” will also be conducted at the Tanghalang Bayan and led
by the College of Music and the Admissions Office on Dec. 4, Dr. Romero added.

The School of Social Work and the School of Government then led the Orange
Exhibit during the opening day at the Gusaling Emilio Aguinaldo lobby and PLM
facade.

# IN PHOTOS | Bonifacio Day

Caption by Roland Justin Molato • Photos by Charlotte Mei Quintana, Jonas Shane Duque | 29 November 23

Kaugnay sa celebrasyon ng ika-160th na anibersaryo ng kapanganakan ni Gat.
Andres Bonifacio. Nag sama-sama ang iba’t ibang sektor ng lipunan upang
ibahagi ang kani-kanilang hinaing patungkol sa isyu ng paggawa. Nagsimula ang
kilos protesta sa kahabaan ng Kalaw Avenue at nag tapos sa Malacañang sa
Mendiola, Nobyembre 30.

# Malacañang declares April 10 as Eid’l Fitr Holiday

Written by Rinoa Angeline Dela Torre • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 8 April 24

In order to bring religious and cultural significance of the Eid’l Fitr to the
fore of national consciousness, Malacañang declared April 10 as a regular
holiday throughout the country under the Proclamation No. 514 s. 2024, Apr 4.

Based on the recommendation from the National Commission on Muslim Filipinos
(NCMF), this proclamation aims to honor the Islamic holiday for Eid'l Fitr to
promote unity and understanding among all FIlipinos.

Eid’l Fitr, also known as the Feast of Ramadan, is a celebration that marks
the end of Ramadan, a month-long period of fasting, prayer and reflection for
Muslims.

# PLM CHASS snatches Binibini at Ginoong Pamantasan 2024 crowns

Written by Rinoa Angeline Dela Torre • Board by Angelle Valbuena | 23 June 24

 _Lakas ng Pamantasan, buhay na buhay!_

Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) College of Humanities, Arts and Social
Sciences (CHASS) representatives were crowned as the first Binibini at Ginoong
Pamantasan 2024 at the Justo Albert Auditorium, June 20.

With a score of 91.58%, Jar-el Beatrice Garcia won as the Binibining
Pamantasan, while July Andrei Alfonso, with a score of 89.25%, was crowned as
the Ginoong Pamantasan, both representing CHASS.

In her winning answer, Binibining Pamantasan Jar-el Beatrice Garcia was asked
about her stance on mandatory ROTC.

“My stand on the mandatory ROTC is that I am completely against it. Why?
Because I believe that we should give or we should consider first the welfare
of our students. We have to consider that not everyone is capable of going
through the ROTC method. Although it might be effective for some, [but] we
must put into consideration na hindi para po sa lahat ang ROTC. As a premier
people’s university, that is something that we should uphold the most. Dapat
ang mga tao, dapat ang constituents natin ang ating pina-priority,” she
responded.

On the other hand, Ginoong Pamantasan July Andrei Alfonso was asked how he
would promote a safe space at the university once crowned.

“I believe that being Mr. Pamantasan is not just inside the school but can
also a reflect outside of the school. Once I win Mr. Pamantasan, I know that I
will be able to uphold a safety environment to everyone by being an example to
them. By showing them that Pamantasan is really a premier school, na lahat
tayo rito, lahat ng pinag-aaralan natin ay talagang magagamit natin even
outside the school. Since alam naman natin na yung mga pumipila para sa PLM at
maraming tumitingala para sa Pamantasan and I will make sure that every core
value that we have is mapapakita natin yan sa mga estudyante natin dito sa
Pamantasan,” he stated.

Binibini runners-up were Altheyya Nicole Lopez from the College of Business
Administration (CBA) coming in first with a score of 85.98%, while College of
Public Administration (CPA) Salvie Delfin Mazo achieved a score of 82.05%,
placing in second.

In addition, Ginoo runners-up were College of Nursing (CN) candidate Abriane
Raf A. Serrana achieved a score of 88.98% securing first, while Prince Cedie
Decino in second with a score of 77.8%, representing CPA.

Since alam naman natin na yung mga pumipila para sa PLM at
maraming tumitingala para sa Pamantasan and I will make sure that every core
value that we have is mapapakita natin yan sa mga estudyante natin dito sa
Pamantasan,” he stated.

Binibini runners-up were Altheyya Nicole Lopez from the College of Business
Administration (CBA) coming in first with a score of 85.98%, while College of
Public Administration (CPA) Salvie Delfin Mazo achieved a score of 82.05%,
placing in second.

In addition, Ginoo runners-up were College of Nursing (CN) candidate Abriane
Raf A. Serrana achieved a score of 88.98% securing first, while Prince Cedie
Decino in second with a score of 77.8%, representing CPA.

Aside from Bb. Pamantasan 2024, Garcia also bagged the Best Evening Gown and
Best Advocacy Video, together with Ginoong Pamantasan 2024 Alfonso, who also
achieved the Best Casual Wear.

For the Binibini special awards, first runner up Lopez from CBA won as the
Best Talent, while second runner up Mazo from CPA was awarded as the Best
Casual Wear and Best Sportswear.

On the other hand, in the Ginoo category, first runner up Serrana from CN won
Best Suit and Best Talent, while Decino from CPA was awarded Best Sportswear.

The event featured an esteemed panel of judges, including Dr. Lynnette Cleto,
Acting Director of the Office of Student Development and Services; Dr. Dan
Michael Cortez, Vice President for Academic Research and Extension Services;
Dr. Ronaldo Tan, Vice President for Administration; Atty. Relson Moral, PLM
Chief Executive Staff; and University President, Atty. Domingo "Sir Sonny"
Reyes, Jr. along with a special guest Miss Manila Diana Dayao.

The winners of Binibining and Ginoong Pamantasan 2024 will advance to compete
in the intercollegiate competition.

# PLM CNSC PRO debunks plagiarism claims

Written by Rinoa Angeline Dela Torre • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 18 November 23

In a Facebook post, College of Nursing Student Council Public Relations
Officer (CNSC PRO) Carl Win Cruz clarified the plagiarism allegations between
a Manila-based university, Nov. 15.

Last Nov. 14, the College of Nursing Student Council President of a university
shared a post on using personal Facebook account captioned “Pahingi lang daw
ng idea” and “Parang familiar ‘yung pubmat and caption” expressing familiarity
with regards to their college “branding,” publication materials as well as
their captions used, notably “resembling” those of PLM CNSC.

As a response, the council spokesperson made clear that the publication
materials were already made before the said university college council
Facebook page posted their said “branding.”

“You can see there that I’ve sent our design to our group chat to ask for
thoughts on October 1 and 2. The first publications about CCLC they posted on
their FB account was on October 16. With that in mind, there is literally 0
chance of us “copying” their publication just based on that fact,” he said.

Addressing the allegations about how the CNSC already saw their post but “made
no changes,” Cruz emphasized that they had no intention of copying and that
they claim has never occurred.

“I have also told the [university] that this never really occurred to us since
we never really looked at their pubs for their “branding” as they claim. We
were only notified of this problem when the president of the [university]
herself commented on our DP Blast and made bold statements online to discredit
the work of my team,” he also added.

As of this writing, there has been no official statement from the said
university regarding these clarifications.

# Classes open on Aug. 29; registration starts on Aug. 7.

Written by John Coby Cabuhat • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 6 August 23

Classes for the Academic Year 2023 - 2024 will start on Aug. 29, Tuesday.

The registration period for the regular 4th and 5th-year students is from Aug.
7 to 13; regular 2nd and 3rd-year on Aug. 14 to 20; and irregulars on Aug. 21
to 27.

Meanwhile, the deadline for student requests to the Office of University
Registrar on readmission, shifting, and petition to open among others is on
Aug. 11.

The late registration and add-drop period will run from Aug. 29 to Sept. 1.

The Academic Calendar is yet to be released by the University.

# Nakauwi Na

Written by Rommel Lacambra • Board by Arjay Samson | 21 January 24

Lahat ng tao sa dyip, pagod at bagot

Hinahanda ang sarili sa pag-uwi at higa

Siyang nakikiusap sa hangganan ng layo

Siyang nakikisama sa pagliko at biglaang hinto

Saka tutunghay sa labas ang mga matang namimitig sa pagtitiyaga

Nang malamang hindi pa tapos ang paglibot

Pinilit ang dumadausdos na posisyong isiniksik

 _" Dalawa pa!"_ at maghihimutok ang masang sakay

Inipit ang musmos na binayaran ng tatay

Lahat ay nasa kalagpasan na ng pasensya

Pinag-iiba ng pagninilay, binubuod ng mga walang imik

Na presensyang nakikisama sa katal-katal na makina

Iba't ibang hikahos ang kahalo sa samyo ng mga pabalik at papunta

Kamao sa kambyo, pihit ang benteng ipit sa daliring ginaspang ng karanasan

Sa ugong ng rosaryo, humampas ang sampaguitang kuwintas

Sinirko ng hari ang manibelang may mga kamay na binakasan

Ng pawis at oras na ibinuwis sa paghihintay

Akong nasa tapat ang pinakalantay sa dekadang hapis ng paglululan

Tinitipa ang mga segundong alay sa pagkayamot

Pinula ng lumalagos na init ng araw,

Huminog sa isang oras na pagbabaybay

Tantos ang bilang ng upuang pupunan,

Punuan ang kaliwa at kanan, bawat kanto at pagitan

Himagsikan sa mga hiningang humahangad ng pwestong prentehan

Pumipinto ang pagal sa katawan

At sumasara na ang bintana ng paningin

Humahapo ang lahat, ngunit nakapapayapang isipin

Na sa kabunsuran ng sumasaid na enerhiya at gasolina

Sa buklod na barya at ganid ng mga busina

Hinahango kami nito sa iisang tugma: _hindi ako pagod mag-isa_

# Simbang Gabi: Ang Panggigising ng mga Kampana

Written by Jamilla Marie Matias • Board by John Ivan Pasion | 23 December 23

Hudyat ang pagtungtong ng ika-16 ng Disyembre sa pagsisimula ng Simbang Gabi o
ang serye ng siyam na gabi ng pangingilin na naging bahagi na ng pagdiriwang
ng kapaskuhan ng mga kristiyanong Pilipino. Tinatawag din itong Misa de Gallo
na impluwensya ng mga kastilang mananakop. Orihinal itong ginawa upang
padaluhin sa misa ang mga magsasaka bago tumungo sa sakahan.

Sa kasalukuyan, ang pagdaraos ng simbang gabi ay isa na sa mga tradisyong
patuloy na humuhubog sa kultura ng mga Pinoy. Taglay nito ang kariktan ng
pananampalataya sa pagsibol ng pag-asa, katuparan sa mga kahilingan, at ang
pagpapasalamat sa Maykapal sa mga biyayang natanggap. Tulay rin ito upang
pagbigkisin ang pamilya sa pamamagitan ng sama-samang pananampalataya.

Karaniwan itong ginaganap tuwing alas-kwatro hanggang alas-singko ng madaling
araw ngunit may ilan din namang mga simbahang nagdaraos nito sa hatinggabi.
Natatapos ang simbang gabi sa ika-24 ng Disyembre o sa bisperas ng pasko kung
saan kadalasang isinasagawa rin ang panunuluyan o ang pagsasadula nang
pagsilang kay Kristo.

Ang paniniwalang matutupad ang kahilingan kung makumpleto ang siyam na gabi ng
pagdalo sa misa ay isa sa mga dahilan kung bakit sa kabila ng kagipitan sa
oras ay naglalaan pa rin ng pagkakataon ang mga Pilipino upang makapag simba.

Para naman sa iilan, higit pa sa personal na kahilingan ang simbang gabi.
Kagaya na lamang ni Angelita Pallorina mula sa College of Humanities Arts and
Social Sciences (CHASS) na itinuturing na tradisyon at hakbangin papalapit sa
Diyos ang bawat pagsa bangon sa umaga’t pagtungo sa simbahan. “In a way
sacrifice siya eh kasi bukod sa tradisyon na siya ng family mas naiignite mo
yung faith mo kay God”, paglalahad niya.

Bahagi rin ng simbang gabi ang mga pagkaing binebenta sa labas ng simbahan
matapos ang isang oras na pangingilin.

Para naman sa iilan, higit pa sa personal na kahilingan ang simbang gabi.
Kagaya na lamang ni Angelita Pallorina mula sa College of Humanities Arts and
Social Sciences (CHASS) na itinuturing na tradisyon at hakbangin papalapit sa
Diyos ang bawat pagsa bangon sa umaga’t pagtungo sa simbahan. “In a way
sacrifice siya eh kasi bukod sa tradisyon na siya ng family mas naiignite mo
yung faith mo kay God”, paglalahad niya.

Bahagi rin ng simbang gabi ang mga pagkaing binebenta sa labas ng simbahan
matapos ang isang oras na pangingilin. Ilan sa mga ito ay ang puto bumbong at
bibingka na marahil ay sumisimbolo sa pagkakaisa at pagkakabuklod-buklod ng
mga indibidwal na may iisang tunguhin – ipagdiwang ang pagsilang kay Kristong
manunubos.

Ang mayabong na kultura’t tradisyong ito ng mga Pilipino ay indikasyon din ng
pagkakaroon ng malalim na pananampalataya. Hatid nito ang diwa ng pagmamahalan
at pagbibigayan karugtong ang mga aral na hatid sa ispiritwal na kalooban ng
isang tao. Ang pagtunog ng mga kampana ng simbahan ay paanyaya na manalangin
upang makamtan ang mga bendisyon mula sa itaas at upang salubungin ang
paparating na pag-asa.

# SIX DECADES IN THE MAKING: Gilas tops Jordan to capture elusive Asiad gold

Written by Raniel Paquingan • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 12 October 23

After 61 years, the Philippines finally rules Asian basketball!

Despite last-minute adjustments and lineup issues before entering the
tournament, Gilas Pilipinas defied all odds to claim the gold medal in the
19th Asian Games men's basketball finals at the Hangzhou Olympic Sports Center
in China, Oct. 6.

Heroics from naturalized players Justin Brownlee and Ange Kouame, who both
finished with a double-double performance, and backup support from locals
Scottie Thompson and Chris Newsome, stunned the out-of-rhythm Jordan, with a
score of 70-60.

Brownlee proved how reliable he is for the Gilas squad, as he finished with 20
points, 10 rebounds, and 5 assists.

Meanwhile, the former Ateneo standout Kouame showed up at the right place and
at the right time, contributing 14 points, a team-high 11 rebounds, and a
game-high 5 steals.

Kouame made sure each of his minutes inside the court were felt and valuable,
as back-to-back baskets from the 6'11 center, followed by a crafty Thompson
putback, extended the lead for the Filipinos anew to double digits with 4:53
remaining in the final frame.

The Rondae Hollis-Jefferson-led Jordan squad never faltered until the closing
minutes of the game, but another tip from a Newsome miss by Kouame spoiled the
Jordanians’ attempt to get close, pushing the gap back to nine, 64-55, with
1:45 on the clock.

No matter how they tried, it was too late for Jordan, as a horrendous and off-
shooting night cost them their first and untimely loss of the tournament,
settling with a silver against Gilas, who they had once dominated in the group
stages, with an 87-62 standing.

Jefferson, also called “Lefty Kobe” because of his similarities with the great
Kobe Bryant, tallied 24 points and 12 rebounds, while Freddy Ibrahim added 13
points and 5 assists.

Team captain Newsome and Ginebra star Thompson provided necessary support for
the national squad, who finished with 13 and 11 points, respectively.

But aside from these numbers, Newsome provided a vital contribution outside of
the stat sheet.

The Meralco guard, who was cut for the last FIBA World Cup lineup, showcased
his dedication to play for the motherland after embracing the role of
Jefferson's primary defender. Newsome's tremendous defense turned Jordan’s
naturalized player’s basket into a needle hole, forcing him to shoot 27% from
the field (8/29 FG).

“We know this means so much [to Filipino fans]. We are passionate about
basketball. And for us to be able to do that for our countrymen was such a
huge thing.

Team captain Newsome and Ginebra star Thompson provided necessary support for
the national squad, who finished with 13 and 11 points, respectively.

But aside from these numbers, Newsome provided a vital contribution outside of
the stat sheet.

The Meralco guard, who was cut for the last FIBA World Cup lineup, showcased
his dedication to play for the motherland after embracing the role of
Jefferson's primary defender. Newsome's tremendous defense turned Jordan’s
naturalized player’s basket into a needle hole, forcing him to shoot 27% from
the field (8/29 FG).

“We know this means so much [to Filipino fans]. We are passionate about
basketball. And for us to be able to do that for our countrymen was such a
huge thing. We can’t wait to get home and share it with them when we get
back,” said Gilas head coach Tim Cone, who finally settled his unfinished
business after falling short and settling for a bronze in the 13th Asian Games
in Bangkok, Thailand.

This is the Philippines’ first gold medal for basketball since 1962, when the
team defeated Japan in the 4th Asian Games in Jakarta, Indonesia.

After the successful run, players from Gilas 1.0 in 2009, Japeth Aguilar and
Marcio Lassiter, also announced that the Asiad triumph will be their last time
wearing blue, red, yellow, and white in international tournaments.

Before entering the finals, the national squad came from behind to shock and
dethrone the host country China in front of their home crowd, 77-76. China
made sure they would cap off the tourney with a podium finish, overpowering
Chinese Taipei, 101-73, taking home the bronze.

# Leksyon sa Eleksyon

Written by Jamilla Marie Matias • Board by Arjay Samson | 20 May 24

May isang taon na mula nang umasa ako sa pagbabago sa sistema ng kataas-
taasang kongreso sa Pamantasan. Tanda ko pa kung paano ko pinili ang mga
lider-estudyante na sa paningin ko’y may angkop na plataporma para sa aming
mag-aaral. Ngunit, taliwas sa pangakong gagawing makulay, inklusibo, at
progresibo ang paaralan, tila ba naging tampulan ng pangamba at duda ang
konsehong aking inaasahan.

Di ko sukat akalain na ang mga pinagkatiwalaang ihalal sa upuan ay magiging
dahilan ng kaguluhan. Pinako ang mga pangakong naglantad ng katotohanan,
marahil ay kinutya rin at pinagtawanan ang mga hinaing ng kapwa iskolar ng
bayan. Siyang nagdulot ng markang kailan ma’y di mabubura at malilimutan.

Kaya naman, tangan-tangan ko ang mga leksyong natutunan ko sa nakaraang
eleksyon—na ang pagkilala sa kandidato ay hindi lamang dapat sa matatamis na
salita kundi pati na rin sa prinsipyong taglay na panghahawakan gaano man
kataas ang daluyong na sasalubong sa terminong daratnan. ‘Yun bang titindig sa
bawat hamon, hindi katahimikan ang magiging tugon, mas lalong hindi sa pagong
hihingi ng solusyon. May pananagutan sa kanilang sinumpaang tipan, magiging
boses ng mga mag-aaral ng eskwelahan. Hindi mang-iiwan at hindi isasantabi ang
kritisismo ng nasasakupan.

Nalalapit nanaman ang pag-usbong ng bagong kabanata. Tanda ito ng pagsasara ng
gula-gulanit na dulong pahina. Subalit hindi pa rin dito natatapos ang laban
dahil ika nga’y ang namulat ay hindi na muling pipikit. Kaya’t pilit man
ipalipad sa eroplanong papel ang mga nagdaang suliranin, patuloy pa rin
lalaban upang katarungan ay makamtan. At lagi’t laging isasaisip at
ipaglalaban ang aking karapatan.

Nawa’y ang pagsilang ng makabagong simula ay ang panunumbalik ng tiwala’t
integridad na kay tagal nawala. Kung kaya, bagamat maraming alinlangan,
datapwat maraming tumatakbong katanungan sa isipan. Sisiguraduhin at titiyakin
pa rin na gagamitin ang ipinagkaloob sa aking kapangyarihan.

lalaban upang katarungan ay makamtan. At lagi’t laging isasaisip at
ipaglalaban ang aking karapatan.

Nawa’y ang pagsilang ng makabagong simula ay ang panunumbalik ng tiwala’t
integridad na kay tagal nawala. Kung kaya, bagamat maraming alinlangan,
datapwat maraming tumatakbong katanungan sa isipan. Sisiguraduhin at titiyakin
pa rin na gagamitin ang ipinagkaloob sa aking kapangyarihan. Mariing
mangingilatis ng mga nararapat at iluluklok sa pwesto ay tapat. Sapagkat
nakasalalay sa aking boto ang kahihinatnan at darating na kinabukasan sa
sinisinta kong Pamantasan.

# Last Day of Filing of Certificate of Candidacy

Caption and Photos by Jeanette Tropa | 1 May 24

Aspiring candidates for the 2024 Supreme Student Council and College Student
Council Elections submitted their Certificate of Candidacy (COC) at the drop
box outside PLM Commission on Elections (PLM COMELEC) Office at Gusaling
Villegas, near Room 206, April 30.

The PLM COMELEC has announced the unofficial list of candidates for the 2024
Supreme Student Council and College Student Council Elections yesterday, May
1.

# Lagusnilad Underpass reopens after six-month rehab

Written by Rylan Gabriel Bernardo • Board by Arjay Samson | 26 November 23

Lagusnilad Underpass will be reopened to the public starting 8:30 AM on
Tuesday, Nov. 28, the Manila Public Information Office (MPIO) announced on
Monday.

The underpass, which is located in front of the Manila City Hall, started its
six-month rehabilitation last May 2 and has since remained closed for
motorists’ use.

MPIO initially announced the completion of Lagusnilad repair last September,
but delays in the construction of chambers by the Department of Public Works
and Highways extended its initial four-month repair.

During the closure of Lagusnilad to the public, drivers heading towards Taft
Avenue were redirected to utilize Padre Burgos Avenue and Roxas Boulevard to
reach their destinations.

# If CHED pays its debt to PLM, Leyco will resign - SSC updates

Written by John Coby Cabuhat • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 31 August 23

"Hindi ako kapit-tuko sa posisyon."

President Emmanuel Leyco asserts that his position is not the main issue and
mentioned resignation if debts to the Pamantasan will be paid based on an
update posted by the Supreme Student Council (SSC), Aug. 31.

In a meeting earlier today, the SSC and University officials discussed the
plans and actions ‘once again’ on the issue of the Pamantasan with the
Commission on Higher Education (CHED) in relation to the Free Tertiary
Education under the Unified Student Financial Assistance System for Tertiary
Education (UniFAST) and other student concerns.

“Parang anlaki ng kasalanan ko sa Pamantasan. Naningil ba tayo ng tuition?
Kung ang UP, sunod-sunod, walang Doctorate, [at] ‘di hiningi ng batas? Anong
pinagkaiba nun’ sa PLM? Parehong batas ang nagtayo sa atin,” Leyco said based
on the updates of the council.

According to the SSC, Leyco insisted that his position is not the main issue
of concern with CHED. “He added that if CHED pays their debts to PLM, he will
resign as PLM President,” the council reported while pertaining to Leyco.

In an interview with The Big Story on One News PH on Aug. 31, the University
President said that the commission still owes the Pamantasan in the amount of
Php 134 million last academic year. He added that the University will be
submitting “something like” __ Php 340 million for reimbursement this academic
year.

Last January, the University submitted a new tuition fee schedule of Php 1,200
per unit “to make PLM feasible.”

“So instead of addressing that issue, here comes a memo saying that PLM is not
compliant. We don’t believe that,” Leyco said in the interview.

Ang Pamantasan was not invited to the said meeting.

This is a developing story.

# OSDS holds Freshmen Orientation for AY 2023-2024

Written by Alessandra Frianela • Photo by Dean Joseph Palapar • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 30 August 23

As part of the university’s welcome to new students for the opening of the new
academic year, the Office of Student Development and Services (OSDS) initiated
the freshmen orientation at the Justo Alberto Auditorium, Aug. 29.

![Orye IL
\(4\)](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2FQVnBLKzKKsuGzrBy7tXI0%2Fe86f3e69fc4b2ac79c940a25575cd1c1%2FOrye_IL__4_.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

The event kicked off with the PLM Business School for its morning session.
Thereafter, the afternoon session catered to the freshmen students of College
of Engineering.

![Orye IL
\(2\)](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F2ft6tjQEqpNQhZ3xpHJ2LL%2Fbb8a440367f3172aa1be2a5d3423ccad%2FOrye_IL__2_.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

This is intended to give the students briefing and introduction of PLM
officials, facilities, and student services inside the university. Discussions
during the orientation proper were headed by the officials from OSDS, College
of Education, National Service Training Program (NSTP), University Health
Services (UHS), University Library (UL), Office of Guidance and Testing
Services (OGTS), Information and Communications Technology Office (ICTO),
University Security Office (USO), and Presidential Committee on Arts, Culture
and Sports (PCACS).

![Orye
\(5\)](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F326lzXCRtlBSpr1FNE9K3T%2Fdfc4b882d109a0dde303fba65a0da7c3%2FOrye__5_.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

The said orientation will be a week-long event. The College of Education will
have its turn on August 30. The students from College of Humanities, Arts, and
Social Sciences, School of Social Work, College of Architecture and Urban
Planning, and School of Government are scheduled on August 31. Finally, for
the last leg of this event, the orientation for the College of Science,
College of Nursing, College of Medicine, College of Physical Therapy, and
College of Law will be held on September 1.

# 59th Founding Anniversary Battle of The Bands

Caption and Photo by Janelle Ugot | 20 June 24

Haribons unleashed their talents in music as they competed for this year's
Battle of the Bands at PLM Tanghalang Bayan on June 21, 2024.

BLNKTS topped the other seven bands in competition, claiming the BOTB 2024
Champion spot, Fifty Per Hour in 1st place, and Romantico in 2nd place.

# MGA LARAWAN | PUV Modernization Program Protest

Written and Photos by Charlotte Mei Quintana | 29 December 23

Nagkasa ng kilos-protesta ang mga transport groups para sa huling araw ng
tigil-pasada sa University Avenue, UP Diliman upang tutulan ang pagpapatupad
ng PUV Modernization Program na makakaapekto sa mahigit 140,000 na mga tsuper
at 60,000 na operator, Disyembre 29.

# Petecio punches bronze to become first two-time Olympic medalist in boxing

Written by Raniel Paquingan • Board by John Ivan Pasion | 8 August 24

Despite her co-Olympic medalists Carlo Paalam and Eumir Marcial getting
knocked down early in the 2024 Paris edition, Nesthy Petecio made sure to rise
until another podium finish. Petecio finished with bronze after succumbing to
younger and more agile Julia Atena Szeremeta of Poland via split decision,
4-1, in the semifinals of women’s 54 kg, cementing her name in the prestigious
list of multiple Olympic winners, Aug. 8. The Filipina boxer started her route
towards a finals return strong and asserted dominance over the less-
experienced Polish, connecting combinations one after another in the first
round, which was given to her by the judges. Szeremeta did not falter and
remained in her open stance during the second round, showing no fear against
the Tokyo 2020 silver medalist. The Polish fighter also managed to get
close—literally and figuratively—landing punches in close-range encounters to
get the second round, leaving no opportunities for a one-sided bout. During
the final round, Petecio continued targeting her opponent’s body, while
Szeremeta stuck with close hits, which seemed to successfully get her momentum
as she even tried to hype up the crowd at one point in the decisive round.
With the decision siding in favor of the Polish boxer, spoiling her return
trip to a gold medal attempt, Petecio was puzzled with the judges’ call.
“Sobrang labo. Sobrang labo talaga pero ‘yun nakikita nila so wala na tayo
magagawa po. Siguro hindi ko alam ‘yung nakikitang side nila, so sila na ‘yun
and nirerespeto ko ‘yun,” Petecio said. “Akala ko akin na ‘to this time,”
Petecio added. The Davao del Sur-raised fighter will join the likes of swimmer
Teofilo Yldefonso, weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz, and gymnast Carlos Yulo in the
elite roster of athletes who have won more than one medal in the Olympic
games.

# Academe and Esports ignites as one on first ever SummEET

Written by Kyla Camilla Martinez • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 18 March 24

Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) led by the university president, deans,
and Haribon Esports attended Estudyante Esports' 1st SummEET as an accredited
school partner together with different school representatives and students
across the Philippines at Rizal Memorial Coliseum, March 2.

After the recent accreditation of Haribon Esports as a non-academic
organization, the university took another step forward toward esports
recognition inside PLM.

"[Esports] it's here, and we the academe would have to embrace it, we have to
find ways to embed technology in all aspects of our curriculum," said PLM
President Sonny Reyes when asked why he said yes to Estudyante Esports.

Dark League Studios, through their program Estudyante Esports, aims to unite
education and Esports as they bring them together on a summit that empowers
and acknowledges the significance of Esports on the academe.

"The school administrators have acknowledged the potential of esports… it has
opened up new career opportunities to pursue as alternatives to traditional
jobs," said Bobby Rosales, Chairman and Co-Founder of Dark League Studios.

The summit promotes responsible gaming, mental well being, and career
opportunities for students who aspire to be a professional player with a
degree in one.

"Esports is important since the principles of it are aligned to sports'
discipline such as proper communication, responsibility, teamwork... if we
want to promote responsible gaming, it should involve and start in the
academe," said AC Valdenor, CEO of Dark League Studios.

Aside from a biannual summit, Estudyante Esports under Dark League Studios
will conduct their esports caravan, exhibits, tournaments, seminars, gamer
fests, and career talks for students who want to pursue a career in the
industry.

In an ongoing partnership with College of St. Benilde School of Professionals
and Continuing Education, a certificate course on esports and digital gaming
fundamentals is being developed as one of the program's goals on expansion of
certificate courses and electives centered on the esports industry.

# Pres. Leyco, distinguished guests look back on PLM’s 56 years of providing
quality education, service for public interest

Written by Calvin Agustin • Board by Angelle Valbuena | 2 July 23

With its 56th year in providing high quality tertiary education, the
Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) commemorated its remarkable journey,
and celebrated its transformation and growth as a public university at the
Justo Alberto Auditorium, June 19.

PLM President Emmanuel Leyco spearheaded the transformation program with his
welcoming remarks, looking back to the educational crisis brought about by the
pandemic and how the university dealt with the setbacks it caused. Pres. Leyco
shared the university’s journey in responding to such a crisis, from adapting
the Alternative Grading System, shifting to online virtual learning, doubling
the acceptance of freshmen to accommodate more applicants, to the recruitment
of additional faculty members and regularization of staff employees.

Moreover, the University President shared his worry of grade inflation when
the first physical commencement exercises after the pandemic recorded an
unprecedented numbers of graduates with latin honors. However, he then
exclaimed with pride that with the results of the various board exams, PLM
students garnering high passing rates and landing the top spots reassured them
the quality education that PLM continues to offer.

“PLM has completed 56 years of dedicated service to provide excellence in
higher education. It is more than ready now to take on additional challenges
of our times and continue to do so with even more vigor and commitment for
quality education that serves the public interest,” Pres. Leyco said.

PLM Board of Regents (BOR) Chairperson Atty. Jose Ngaw also expressed his
aspirations for PLM after his recent appointment in the highest decision-
making body in the Pamantasan. He recognized the diligence of the students as
the key to the university’s performance in licensure examinations, as well as
their coworkers’ dedication over the years.

“PLM is now embarking in the process of transformation. We will be actively
engaging with our alumni, with business and industry leaders to study and
improve our curriculum content to be attuned to the practical needs of the
society and the economy,” Atty. Ngaw said.

Lastly, former PLM Acting University President and College of Law Dean, and
now Commission on Elections (COMELEC) Chairperson Atty. George Erwin Garcia
reminisced his times working before in PLM, sharing his journey as a public
servant and how he brought the university with his service.

“Darating ang tamang panahon, lalong lalo na sa mga giliw nating mga mag-
aaral, na kayo ga-graduate dito sa Pamantasan.

“PLM is now embarking in the process of transformation. We will be actively
engaging with our alumni, with business and industry leaders to study and
improve our curriculum content to be attuned to the practical needs of the
society and the economy,” Atty. Ngaw said.

Lastly, former PLM Acting University President and College of Law Dean, and
now Commission on Elections (COMELEC) Chairperson Atty. George Erwin Garcia
reminisced his times working before in PLM, sharing his journey as a public
servant and how he brought the university with his service.

“Darating ang tamang panahon, lalong lalo na sa mga giliw nating mga mag-
aaral, na kayo ga-graduate dito sa Pamantasan. Sana lagi’t laging niyong
babalikan ang mga alaala na kayo ay nasa Pamantasan at kinakailangan, sa
pagpupursigi niyo sa buhay, maging parte kayo ng hindi lamang 56 na taon ng
pagsisilbi sa sambayanan kundi maging parte kayo ng isang unibersidad ng
masang Pilipino,” Atty. Garcia said.

Present in the Transformation Program are Senator Aquilino “Koko'' Pimentel as
the keynote speaker, Finance Secretary Benjamin Diokno, (COMELEC) Commissioner
Nelson Celis, Intramuros Administrator Joan Padilla, Insurance Commission
Commissioner Dennis Funa, National Commission for Culture and the Arts -
Public Affairs and Information Head Rene Napeñas, Bureau of Internal Revenue -
Manila Regional Director Renato Molina, CEO and Publisher of Manila Bulletin
Sonny Coloma, Land Bank of the Philippines (LBP) Vice President Francisco
Burgos, LBP-Department of Labor and Employment Branch Manager Maria Suyin
Cabrera, Healthway Philippines President Jaime Ysmael, The Manila Times
President and CEO Dante Ang, Philippine Red Cross - Manila Chapter
Administrator Crisanta Cayetano, SM Foundation Consultant Juris Soliman, SM
Foundation Project Assistant Cyear De Lara, BOR member Relson Moral, and son
of former Mayor Villegas Antonio Villegas Jr.

Moreover, PLM administrative staff, faculty members, students, together with
the Board of Regents and representatives from the City Government of Manila
were also present.

The PLM Chorale, led by Prof. Harold Galang and selected students from the
College of Education performed at the event. The Transformation Program
concluded the first day of the week-long foundation anniversary celebration of
Manila’s premier university.

# PLM kicks off Day 2 of its 59th founding anniversary with games,
thanksgiving mass, a guest band visit

Written by Zarena Hermogeno • Board by John Ivan Pasion | 23 June 24

On its second day of the five-day celebration, Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng
Maynila (PLM) commenced a series of games, a thanksgiving mass, an employee
service awards rites, and a special guesting of the Wish 107.5 bus with its
guest Filipino alternative rock band, Mayonnaise, June 19.

As early as 9AM, the PLM Supreme Student Council (SSC) opened Day 2 of the
celebration with a series of Carnival Games such as Strongman Tug, Dodgeball,
and Trip to Jerusalem, where all students of the university were encouraged to
participate.

The activity narrowed down to five (5) participating colleges namely: College
of Accountancy, College of Business Administration, College of Education,
College of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences; and College of Engineering
competed for the top three awards: Overall Champion and 1st and 2nd Runners-
Up.

According to Edwin Espinas, head of the Founding Anniversary’s Student
Activities, this celebration marks another year of fulfilling “manifestations
and excellence” to be met in the succeeding years from its students and every
individual in the university.

“Sana through this founding anniversary natin is we are able to have everyone
be included and feel na this event is for them and that they are being part of
the entirety of this celebration,” he added.

While the students were enjoying a fun under the sun at the Tanghalang Bayan,
several staff and faculty members observed a moment of spiritual soliloquy at
the university chapel for the Thanksgiving Mass headed by Rev. Fr. Christian
“Toots” Buenafe, OCarm.

In his homily, Rev. Fr. Buenafe, OCarm., said “Kung ano ang atin ngayon, ng
present generation, dahil ‘yon sa pagsisikap ng mga nauna sa atin”

He also emphasized that there is a higher calling for the institution to not
only train students professionally but also produce persons with integrity and
honesty among others.

After the mass, all employees of PLM feasted on lunch at the University
Activity Center (UAC) followed by the Program on Recognition of Awards and
Incentives for Service Excellence (PRAISE) Awards at the Justo Albert
Auditorium for employees and faculty members for their service tenure.

The highlight of the celebration arrived around three in the afternoon as the
Wish 107.5 bus parked near the UAC with guest band, Mayonnaise. Students
surrounded the bus to catch the performance of the 2004 Red Horse Muziklaban
grand winner.

Among the setlist was the iconic “Jopay” which was adored by Haribons.

After the mass, all employees of PLM feasted on lunch at the University
Activity Center (UAC) followed by the Program on Recognition of Awards and
Incentives for Service Excellence (PRAISE) Awards at the Justo Albert
Auditorium for employees and faculty members for their service tenure.

The highlight of the celebration arrived around three in the afternoon as the
Wish 107.5 bus parked near the UAC with guest band, Mayonnaise. Students
surrounded the bus to catch the performance of the 2004 Red Horse Muziklaban
grand winner.

Among the setlist was the iconic “Jopay” which was adored by Haribons.

Aside from the Day 2 celebration, the same day marks the signing of Republic
Act 4196 or the “An Act Authorizing the City of Manila to Establish and
Operate the University of the City of Manila and for Other Purposes”,
otherwise known as the “PLM Charter” in which President Diosdado Macapagal
signed 59 years ago.

# FILMayer 2024 grants best production, performance awards for film festival
entries

Written by Rinoa Angeline Dela Torre • Photos by Roland Justin Molato and Janelle Ugot | 12 June 24

Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) College of Humanities, Arts, and Social
Sciences (CHASS), together with the FILMayer 2024 Organizing Committee
presented best production and performance awards for the festival awards day
at the Justo Albert Auditorium, June 8.

The festival featured productions by fourth-year Communication students,
including AbanTake Productions, Dalayday Productions, Dorothy Productions,
Four Walls Motion Picture, Inari Productions, Kusine Films, Sangandaan
Productions, Serafilm Production, Route 5 Productions, and Pawid Productions.

Out of ten short film entries, "Tara, G!" by Route 5 Productions was awarded
as the Best Picture. On the other hand, "Alamat ng Isdang Kulay Bahaghari" by
Dalayday Productions secured second place, followed by "Para Po!" by
Sangandaan Productions in third, and "Evangeline" by Serafilm Productions in
fourth.

In the Production Category, Dalayday Productions secured five awards,
including Best Cinematography by Dean Joseph Palapar, and Best Musical Score
with Charlotte Mei Quintana. The Production also won Best Visual Effects by
Avin Dela Cruz, Best Location with Aldrid Arenas and Cathy Abendanio, and Best
Costume Design by Sophia Mendoza and Sherina Agoncillo.

Following closely, Sangandaan Productions also bagged five awards with Jaed
Ababao winning Best Director and Best Editing; Chloe Ysabel Mangabat, Erick
Cabuang, Kenneth Manikan and Mariah Ang who secured the Best Screenplay;
Coleen Alvarez and Czyrene Ysabele Ay-ay who won Best Sound Design; and
achieved Best Theme Song “Hipnotismo,” which was performed by Alyanna Ambrosio
and Rosh Pascual.

Kusine Films was awarded Best Production Design by Aira Janella Manabat and
Best Makeup by Eliza Ann Masa and Justine Mercader.

On the other hand, AbanTake Productions was awarded as Best Poster by
Katherine Palang.

In the Performance Category, AJ Benoza from "Tara, G!" by Route 5 Productions
won Best Actor, while Chase Salazar from "Overnight Stay" by Four Walls Motion
Picture was awarded Best Actress. In addition, Adrian Labior from "Para Po!"
by Sangandaan Productions received Best Supporting Actor, and Trisha Mae Baul
from "Absolusyon" by AbanTake Productions won Best Supporting Actress. Lastly,
Lucas Martin from "Alamat ng Isdang Kulay Bahaghari" by Dalayday Productions
was recognized as the Best Child Performer.

As a special award, Ken Joshua De Paula and Rosewiel Gien Rubin were honored
as the Male and Female Stars of the Day.

Department Chairperson Prof. Maychell Jastia concluded the event by
congratulating and applauding all productions for their efforts.

“This event may be short but it has a lifelong effect on all of you, sweet. To
all those who won today, it is a sweet reward for all of your hard work.

In addition, Adrian Labior from "Para Po!"
by Sangandaan Productions received Best Supporting Actor, and Trisha Mae Baul
from "Absolusyon" by AbanTake Productions won Best Supporting Actress. Lastly,
Lucas Martin from "Alamat ng Isdang Kulay Bahaghari" by Dalayday Productions
was recognized as the Best Child Performer.

As a special award, Ken Joshua De Paula and Rosewiel Gien Rubin were honored
as the Male and Female Stars of the Day.

Department Chairperson Prof. Maychell Jastia concluded the event by
congratulating and applauding all productions for their efforts.

“This event may be short but it has a lifelong effect on all of you, sweet. To
all those who won today, it is a sweet reward for all of your hard work.
Therefore, I will now officially pronounce FILMayer: PLM festival of films
officially closed,” she said.

These short film entries were under the supervision of Film Writing and
Production instructors, Prof. Ayen Bayani and Prof. David Ramos Jr.

# Inventory concerns urge SCOA to render SSC with qualified opinion

Written by Calvin Agustin • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 24 July 23

The PLM Student Commission on Audit (SCOA) gave the financial statement of the
PLM Supreme Student Council (SSC) a qualified opinion after the commission was
uncertain of the council’s Cash in Bank and Inventories account’s completeness
and accuracy, June 10.

In the audit report, SSC’s Cash in Bank and Inventories account was deemed
questionable because the council utilized the treasurer’s personal GCash
account which was used for both personal and council transactions. It was also
identified that the SSC have not established proper tracking and management of
their inventory, earning them a qualified opinion.

It was discovered in the audit that carried-over inventory was not properly
turned over to the current term which reflected the lack of inventory
management and control of the council. SCOA suggested that the SSC shall
conduct a formal inventory and reconciliation process to ensure that all
inventory items are accounted for and handed over to the incoming officers
appropriately.

Additionally, SCOA has observed the SSC’s lack of a systematic approach to
inventory tracking, and lack of clear procedures on defective merchandise
which may result in mismanagement and potential loss. With this, the
commission recommended that the council should establish clear procedures for
regular inventory to ensure its accurate tracking and monitoring. The SSC
should also develop processes for handling defective merchandise items to
avoid financial losses.

The use of a personal GCash account for council transactions and the lack of a
cash box for its cash on hand were also some of the concerns of the
commission. The SSC was directed to create an account solely for the council
in order to separate personal and organization funds. Moreover, the SSC should
procure a safe container as their cash box which should be accessed only by
the authorized personnel.

# AP scribes shine bronze in FilipiKNOWS 2024 tilt

Written by Calvin Agustin • Board by Angelle Valbuena | 18 March 24

Campus journalists from Ang Pamantasan (AP), the official student publication
of the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila, took spots in the FilipiKNOWS 2024
journalism symposium at the De La Salle Araneta University (DLSAU), March 16.

Twinning in third place are first year students from BS Psychology, Marian
Sophia Carreon for Feature Writing, and from BA Communication, Ma. Janelle
Ugot for Photojournalism. They both bested contestants from other schools
within the National Capital Region.

FilipiKNOWS 2024 is an annual symposium spearheaded by TINIG, the official
student publication of DLSAU, which aims to explore the vital role of
journalism in addressing various social issues evident in the Filipino society
with the theme “Psychology of Journalism: Ethics, Decision-making, and Point-
of-view.”

# PLM secures four topnotchers in Psychometrician Licensure Examination

Written by Calvin Agustin • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 9 August 23

Four graduates from the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) were among the
successful examinees included in the topnotchers during the August 2023
Psychometrician Licensure Examination, Aug. 9.

Rachel Faye Nuñez landed in the 4th place with an 88.40% grade, followed by
Audrey Jorge Angeles who garnered an 88.20% score, claiming the 5th place.
Landing the 8th place was Jenicca Denise Livara with a score of 87.60%, while
Wilyane Eunice Isaiah Go clinched the 9th place with an 87.40% grade.

Out of 97 examinees from the University, 96 have passed the examination. This
performance made PLM the 2nd highest performing school with 50 or more
examinees, with an overall passing rate of 98.97%.

# “pintuan”

Written by Jhea Buela • Board by Junnine Tupaz | 11 December 23

kumatok ako

sa ating pinto,

inaabangan

na muli mo ‘kong tatawagan

para sabayan ka sa hapunan.

gutom ay nalipasan

sa katahimikan.

traydor ang kahoy

sa bawat simoy

ng aking panaghoy.

hindi ako mahimasmasan.

hindi ko pa kayang buksan

ang ating pintuan.

umupo ako

sa iyong bangkito,

nagsisisi na sana

kwinentuhan pa kita

tungkol sa nagkainitan sa kalsada

o sa isang beses na nadapa ako

sa may eskinita,

kahit alam kong

bihira kang tumawa.

hindi ako mapatahan.

hindi ko pa kayang buksan

ang ating pintuan.

naka-ilang balik ka na sa hintayan

ngunit nakapirmi pa rin ako

sa nakaraan.

mailalangoy ko ba

ang dagos ng hinagpis

mabuksan lang ang pintuan

na bakas ang iyong paglisan?

hindi ko malalaman.

tila nawala na ako

sa aking pupuntahan.

ngunit sa aking gunita,

ang ngiti mo ay payapa,

at sana,

makita mo rin

ang sa akin

sa susunod na buksan ko

ang ating pintuan.

# distance.sky

Written by Gabriel Ciego • Board by John Ivan Pasion | 6 December 23

the window frames the bigger picture:

a number of buildings

in the distance: the city hall

clock looming over: white

porcelain structures lining up:

sun

wind

casting shadows

against the grit of concrete below.

you reach out your hand

to be found wanting.

like the day, retreating

to kill its softest

shadow.

soil beneath soles

into dust, natural

powders.

a lone maya perches above the field, far

from an arm's length.

it sings.

only if i listen

at a distance.

# PLM community gathers together as PLM Intramurals 2023 commences

Written by Calvin Agustin • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 11 July 23

Officials, faculty, staff, and students of Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila
(PLM) gathered and celebrated the opening of the much-awaited PLM Intramurals
2023 at the Tanghalang Bayan and PLM Open Field, July 11.

PLM was once again able to kick off a university sportsfest after more than
two years of online distance learning because of the pandemic. In his welcome
message, PLM President Emmanuel Leyco commended the organizers of the
sportsfest, emphasizing the importance of such activity to showcase the
strength and excellence of the students.

“Ang Intramurals is an opportunity for all of us to come together, to get
together. This is also an opportunity for us to show what we can do to show
our talents, our skills. And inevitably, a team will win, a team will lose.
Pero ‘yun nga, ang sabi nila – ‘manalo, matalo, panalo pa rin tayong lahat.’
Mananalo tayo sa teamwork, mananalo tayo sa pagtutulungan,” Pres. Leyco said.

The President also shared to the students that the Intramurals will not be the
last parade inside the University as they are to put together another
celebration to welcome the incoming freshmen.

Southeast Asian Games 2023 gold medalist and PLM alumnus Jay-ar De Castro and
World Championship 2022 silver medalist Jenina Ernestine Coloyan were present
in the ceremony as they spearheaded the torch lighting, together with PLM
Supreme Student Council President Vince Edrick De Guzman. Afterwards, Jude
Michael Tapang, from the College of Architecture and Urban Planning, led the
Oath of Sportsmanship alongside the student athletes who will be participating
in different sporting events.

College students and athletes paraded around the PLM Grounds, represented by
their muses in their various sports attire. Thereafter, the ladies showcased
their glamor and wit during the presentation and question and answer portion
of the Ms. PLM Intramurals 2023.

The ceremony concluded as Pres. Leyco formally opened the PLM Intramurals 2023
which was followed by the men and women’s volleyball games at the Rajah
Sulayman Gymnasium.

# PLM awards top-performing students, faculty in university recognition

Written by Zarena Hermogeno • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 12 October 23

Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) merited its top performing students,
academic organizations, alumni, and faculty in the University Recognition held
at the Justo Albert Auditorium with the theme "PLM Transformation: Quality
Education for the Public Interest," Sept. 26.

Manila's premier university awarded the University Academic Excellence Award
to its undergraduate students who have obtained the highest overall general
weighted average (OGWA) across the university in their respective year level.
Among the awardees were Michelle N. Tolentino (1st Year) from the College of
Engineering (CEng); Catherine Jules C. Juvida (2nd Year) from the College of
Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences (CHASS); Yuanah Marie S. Cruz (3rd Year)
from CEng; Eduardo D. Yungca (4th Year) from the College of Education (CED);
and Aliah Jane P. Garcia (5th Year) from the College of Architecture and Urban
Planning (CAUP).

College Academic Excellence awards were also given to students who earned the
highest OGWA for the whole academic year per course and year level in each
college. Whereas the Most Outstanding College Student Award and Student
Achiever Award were granted to students per college who have excelled in the
aspects of academics and extracurricular endeavors.

Rean Christine T. Estimo from CHASS and Ahnnie Mayleen A. Solidum of CEng were
recognized as PLM's most outstanding college students. Estimo was also
commended as the Most Outstanding University Student. Meanwhile, Jilmar John
M. Contreras earned the Student Achiever award from his recent 3rd placing
during the 6th National Civil Engineering (CE) Wizard Quiz: Clash of CE.
Moreover, PLM also honored Lance Emmanuel J. Ladrazo from the PLM Business
School (PLMBS) with a Posthumous Recognition.

Despite the abundance of student-led organizations inside the Pamantasan, the
Mass Communication Students' League from CHASS emerged as the Most Outstanding
Academic Student Organization while the Magwayen Creative Scholars' Guild
stood out as the Most Outstanding Non-Academic Student Organization.

Furthermore, the College of Architecture and Urban Planning Student Council
(CAUP SC) outshined as the Most Outstanding Student Council Award.

PLM also took pride in its alumni by bestowing the Board Topnotcher Award to
those who were included in the top 10 in their respective professional
licensure examinations.

Among the recipients of the honorable recognition in CEng were Jolison Kenneth
G. Arita, Nieve Rain S. Ugto, Jayson Patrick B. Bantog, and Reindel N.
Mallari.

Despite the abundance of student-led organizations inside the Pamantasan, the
Mass Communication Students' League from CHASS emerged as the Most Outstanding
Academic Student Organization while the Magwayen Creative Scholars' Guild
stood out as the Most Outstanding Non-Academic Student Organization.

Furthermore, the College of Architecture and Urban Planning Student Council
(CAUP SC) outshined as the Most Outstanding Student Council Award.

PLM also took pride in its alumni by bestowing the Board Topnotcher Award to
those who were included in the top 10 in their respective professional
licensure examinations.

Among the recipients of the honorable recognition in CEng were Jolison Kenneth
G. Arita, Nieve Rain S. Ugto, Jayson Patrick B. Bantog, and Reindel N.
Mallari.

Ninna G. Hapita, Jesse Ian F. Cambaliza, Shiela Mae T. Legaspi, and Bryan D.
Pablo from the College of Physical Therapy (CPT) were also given the said
award as they placed 4th, 5th, 7th, and 8th respectively in the December 2022
Physical Therapy Board Examination while College of Medicine (CM) alumni
Philip Patrick P. Lee and Karla Joyce S. Badong were also recognized for the
same award for their 2nd and 3rd respective finish during the March and
October 2023 Physician Licensure Examination.

With this, CEng, CM, and CPT were merited with the Performing Colleges in
Licensure Exam Award.

The recognition of the advisers of all student councils and accredited
organizations were also observed towards the end of the program as Ar. Maria
Monica E. Pujalte, adviser of the CAUP SC, was hailed as the Model Campus
Adviser.
