# ‘Hindi po tayo maniningil ng tuition mula sa mga estudyante’ - Pres. Leyco

Written by Calvin Agustin • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz • Photo by Roland Justin Molato | 27 August 23

Students of Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) were reassured that they
will not be paying any tuition fee as per PLM President Emmanuel Leyco during
his online briefing via Zoom, Aug. 27.

As stipulated in Republic Act No. 10931 namely the "Universal Access to
Quality Tertiary Education Act," Filipino students have the absolute right to
quality education, therefore, the State must ensure that education shall be
accessible for all.

On Aug. 15, PLM Board of Regents Chairperson Atty. Jose Ngaw received a letter
from the Commission on Higher Education (CHED) which stated that the
university’s exemption from compliance with institutional recognition was
revoked. With the effectivity of CMO No. 18, s. 2022, PLM was directed to
comply with the Enhanced Policies, Standards, and Guidelines on the Grant of
Institutional Recognition as a Higher Educational Institution to Local
University and College (LUC) within 15 days from the date of the letter’s
issuance.

Attached in the letter was the Commission En Banc (CEB) Resolution No.
285-2023 which encompassed its meeting that discussed the said revocation of
PLM’s exemption. The university was now directed to comply with CHED’s
determination of higher educational institutions (HEI) which shall benefit
from RA 10931. With CMO No. 11, s. 2018, LUCs under the reimbursement program
shall comply with the requirements for institutional recognition wherein one
of them is that the president of an LUC must have earned a doctorate degree.

Based on CHED-NCR records, the PLM President does not possess a doctorate
degree which is a requirement for an LUC to be granted with institutional
recognition. With the enhanced standards for qualification, the CEB has
decided to retract PLM’s exemption to the compliance and directed the
university to comply with CMO No. 18, s. 2022. Failure to adhere, the
Commission shall recommend to the Unified Financial Assistance System
(UniFAST) governing board to delist PLM from its list of beneficiaries.

During Leyco’s public briefing, he disclosed that the university had already
responded to the letter from CHED. However, in case that CHED stands firm on
their decision and the CEB Resolution No. 285-2023 is still in effect, PLM is
prepared to appeal to the UniFAST governing board.

“Hindi po negotiable, and hindi tayo mag-cocompromise when it comes to the
plight of the welfare of our students and employees,” Leyco said.

The main concern at hand is the status of PLM’s classification as a
university. The Republic Act No.

18, s. 2022. Failure to adhere, the
Commission shall recommend to the Unified Financial Assistance System
(UniFAST) governing board to delist PLM from its list of beneficiaries.

During Leyco’s public briefing, he disclosed that the university had already
responded to the letter from CHED. However, in case that CHED stands firm on
their decision and the CEB Resolution No. 285-2023 is still in effect, PLM is
prepared to appeal to the UniFAST governing board.

“Hindi po negotiable, and hindi tayo mag-cocompromise when it comes to the
plight of the welfare of our students and employees,” Leyco said.

The main concern at hand is the status of PLM’s classification as a
university. The Republic Act No. 4196, “An Act Authorizing the City of Manila
to Establish and Operate the University of City of Manila” was the very law
that established PLM as a chartered university. However, State Universities
and Colleges (SUC), and LUC were the only classifications of CHED for UniFAST
qualification, both of which the university does not exactly fall under but
identifies in both classifications in some aspects. Part of PLM being
identified as SUC is that it is established by the national government while
its identification as LUC comes from it being financially supported by the
local government unit (LGU). The confusion regarding PLM’s classification was
rooted from the aforementioned circumstances.

In the event that PLM will be delisted from the UniFAST reimbursement program,
the university will fully rely on the funding from Manila LGU. However, Manila
LGU will not be financially capable of covering the tuition fee of the entire
student population of PLM and its other operating expenses. In addition, PLM
will no longer be operating as an independent and autonomous university.

The university is willing to challenge this to the court, specially the
classification of PLM. Leyco noted that the university has a network of
constituents in the education sector that may be asked for assistance with
regards to this matter.

“Hindi po tayo magsasara, hindi po tayo maniningil ng tuition mula sa mga
estudyante na dapat ay mabayaran mula sa UniFAST,” Leyco said.

The PLM administration and its executive committee have been conducting
constant consultations and they assured that all possible avenues will be
exhausted regarding this matter.

# ESSCandalo ng Konseho

Written by Alessandra Frianela • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 16 November 23

Magdadalawang buwan na ang nakalilipas mula ng pumutok ang isyung gumimbal sa
bawat mag-aaral sa pamantasan.

Ang nakaaalarmang isyu na ito ay umusbong noong lumutang ang isang _thread_ sa
_social media platform_ na X at isang post sa isang Facebook group noong
ika-24 ng Setyembre. Buhat nito ang mga _screenshot_ mula sa isang _group
chat_ na may pangalang "MGA BACKSTABBERS,” na naglalaman ng malinaw na
indikasyon sa mangilan-ngilang pagkakataong naging biktima ang ilang lider
mag-aaral sa pag-uuyam at masasamang komento mula mismo sa kanilang kapwa
lider mag-aaral sa kinabibilangang konseho.

Ang naganap ay tumataliwas sa kanilang sinumpaang salaysay na nangangakong
ipaglalaban at itataguyod ang karapatan at kapakanan ng bawat mag-aaral. Ito
rin ay nagpapakita ng kanilang malinaw na paglapastangan sa prinsipyong
inaasahan mula sa kanila bilang mga lider.

Sa kabila ng tahasang pag kondena ng mga partido, alyansa, organisasyon, mga
konseho mula sa iba’t ibang kolehiyo, at patuloy na paguusig at paghingi ng
kasagutan ng mga mag-aaral sa pamantasan hinggil sa naturang insidente ng
_bullying_ na naganap mula sa mga lider ng kataas-taasang konseho, makikinita
ang pananahimik ng bawat opisyales na sangkot.

Sa katunayan, ang huling kaganapang naisapubliko ukol sa isyung ito ay ang
pagpupulong na naganap sa pagitan ng mga sangkot noong ika-25 ng Setyembre.
Nabanggit sa naging _post_ ng konseho sa kanilang Facebook page ang naturang
detalye.

Nabanggit rin sa _post_ ang mga konsultasyong naganap kasama ang iba’t-ibang
konseho, di umano, upang talakayin ang mga nararapat na kaparusahang ipapataw
sa mga _College Representatives_ na sangkot.

Dagdag pa nito ay ang paglalahad na ang pangunahing prayoridad ng konseho ay
ang maibalik ang tiwala ng mga mag-aaral maging ang kanilang kredibilidad.

Nabanggit sa naging _post_ ng konseho sa kanilang Facebook page ang naturang
detalye.

Nabanggit rin sa _post_ ang mga konsultasyong naganap kasama ang iba’t-ibang
konseho, di umano, upang talakayin ang mga nararapat na kaparusahang ipapataw
sa mga _College Representatives_ na sangkot.

Dagdag pa nito ay ang paglalahad na ang pangunahing prayoridad ng konseho ay
ang maibalik ang tiwala ng mga mag-aaral maging ang kanilang kredibilidad.

Sa kabila ng pangangako na ipapabatid sa mga mag-aaral ang lahat ng detalye sa
imbestigasyon, kapansin-pansin ang naging kakulangan sa nailapag na
impormasyon ukol sa mga partikular na hakbangin at pangyayaring may kaugnayan
sa isyung ito. Kung kaya’t prominente ang naging pagkalampag ng mga mag-aaral
sa konseho - upang makakuha ng mga kasagutan sa mga katanungang tila kanilang
iniiwasan.

Ano ba ang mga naging kaganapan sa _internal meeting_? Hindi dapat
nananatiling pribado ang mga ganitong uri ng detalye. Wala bang karapatan ang
mga mag-aaral na alamin ang mga kaganapang ito?

Ang insidente ng _bullying_ ay hindi na bago sa nakararami, ngunit sa paglipas
ng panahon ay nagiba-iba na ang mukha at maging ang epekto nito. Higit sa mga
tradisyunal na anyo ng pisikal na pang-iintimidasyon, ang pag-usbong ng
_cyberbullying_ ay nadagdag bilang bagong aspeto sa problemang ito. Ito rin ay
maituturing na paninirang puri. Ang naturang pangyayari sa konseho ay isang
hayagang kaso nito.

Ang _bullying_ ay maituturing na isang nakalalasong gawain, lalo na kung ito
ay magmumula pa mismo sa mga taong nasa mataas na posisyon. Ang pinsala nito
ay hindi lamang para sa mga naturang biktima, ngunit maging sa kabuuang
aspetong moral at pagkakabuklod-buklod ng mga mag-aaral sa pamantasan.

Ang konsepto ng _bullying_ ay lubos na tumataliwas sa dapat ng ipinaglalaban
at pinapahalagahan ng isang lider mag-aaral.

Isa sa kanilang sinumpaan ang pagiging isang magandang ehemplo sa bawat mag
aaral sa institusyon.

Ang konseho rin ang dapat na nagtatanggol sa bawat mag aaral laban sa pang-
aapi at opresyon.

Kapag mismong mga lider ang nasangkot sa ganitong gawain, maaaring mawala ang
tiwala at respeto na mahalaga para sa isang progresibong pamamahala.

Mahalaga na ang bawat mag-aaral ay humingi ng pananagutan mula sa mga taong
sangkot. Ang mga taong ito ay hindi higit sa mga alituntuning ipinangako
nilang itaguyod; dapat silang magsilbing mga tanglaw ng inspirasyon at hindi
ng intimidasyon. Sa halip na takot at intimidasyon ang mamutawi, pagtutulungan
ang dapat na manaig.

Ating tandaan na ang konseho ang nagsisilbing kinatawan ng bawat mag-aaral.
Sila ang nagsisilbing boses at sila ang may malaking responsibilidad na
tumugon at ipahayag ang pangangailangan ng lahat.

Kayo ay naihalal dahil sa binigay na tiwala. TIwala sa kakayahan, hangarin, at
maging sa mga nailatag na plataporma. Sa pangyayaring ito, mga mag-aaral na
naniwala ang pinakaapektado.

Sa halip na takot at intimidasyon ang mamutawi, pagtutulungan
ang dapat na manaig.

Ating tandaan na ang konseho ang nagsisilbing kinatawan ng bawat mag-aaral.
Sila ang nagsisilbing boses at sila ang may malaking responsibilidad na
tumugon at ipahayag ang pangangailangan ng lahat.

Kayo ay naihalal dahil sa binigay na tiwala. TIwala sa kakayahan, hangarin, at
maging sa mga nailatag na plataporma. Sa pangyayaring ito, mga mag-aaral na
naniwala ang pinakaapektado.

Paano sila sasangguni at lalapit kung nabahiran na ng hindi magandang anyo o
imahe ang konseho?

Isa itong buhay na patunay na bago dapat mangako at maglapag ng iba’t-ibang
plataporma, alalahanin ang mga kaakibat na bigat ng iyong bagay na papasukin.

Mahalagang sama-samang nagtutulungan para sa inklusibong pamantasan na
isinusulong. Itigil ang _bullying_ at maging daan dapat ito sa isang konsehong
mapagpalaya, tapat, at naglilingkod para sa ikabubuti ng lahat.

Bilang mga mag-aaral, tayo ay mayroong karapatang magnais ng isang pamumuno na
nagpapakita ng etikal na asal at integridad.

Higit kailanman, napakahalagang magpakatao tayo sa lahat ng oras. Makinig sa
bawat boses ng mga taong nasa paligid, tayo man ay mayroong posisyon o hindi.

Ang tenga ay mas mataas ang posisyon sa ating bibig dahil sa isang natatanging
dahilan, at ‘yon ay para tayo’y makinig muna bago magbitiw ng salita.
Makiramdam at lubusang pag-isipan ang mga salitang ating bibitawan.

# PLM COMELEC Chair addresses election issues, concerns on HARAPAN 2024

Written by Calvin Agustin • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 19 May 24

PLM Student Commission on Elections (COMELEC) Chairperson Zion Malibunas
brought attention to the surfacing issues and concerns on the conduct of
HARAPAN 2024 at the Justo Albert Auditorium, May 20.

Unknown to many, student voters have raised concerns in an online group on the
allegations that the questions were leaked and the candidates have already
prepared their answers prior to the HARAPAN 2024.

During his closing remarks, the Commission Chairperson stated that he will not
condone any speculation regarding the questions curated for the election
activity.

“Let us give respect to the organizers that curated these questions,”
Malibunas stated.

He further emphasized that the candidates for this year’s Supreme Student
Council and College Student Council Elections are aware of how strict are the
implementing rules and regulations of the HARAPAN 2024 to ensure its
integrity.

Meanwhile, PLM COMELEC encourages students to cast their votes on May 21, from
8:00 AM to 5:00 PM via Microsoft Forms.

# PLM alumnus ranks 10th in teachers' licensure examination

Written by Rommel Lacambra | 30 May 23

A graduate from Pamantasan Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) emerged as topnotcher in
March 2023 Licensure Examination for Secondary Level Teachers, May 19.

Ricardo Mallari Cordova, a College of Engineering and Technology alumnus,
ranked 10th with a rate of 91%. He is a degree-holder from Bachelor of Science
major in Chemical Engineering in 1998.

40 other passers from PLM completed the slate with 75.47% overall performance.
They are among the 48, 005 passers out of 102, 272 takers in secondary level.

For the elementary level, the University also mustered 13 successful takers
with 92.86% total grade.

These overall ratings from both levels are superior to the national passing
rate: 40.76% for elementary level and 46.94% for secondary level,
respectively.Issuance of identification cards will start from June 13 until
August 17. In-person and online oath-taking schedules are yet to be announced
by the Professional Regulation Commission Board.

# New Man and Culture: The Bold Cultural Shift Led by President Sonny

Written by Charyll Joan T. Pascua • Pubmat by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 19 February 24

Akin to a poet to her verses, a scientist to his experiments, and philosophers
to their existential decisions, culture intricately weaves itself into the
very fabric of our identity. It extends from the individual level, defining
who we are singularly, to the broader scope of institutions. President Sonny,
the newly appointed president of Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM),
astutely recognizes this pivotal significance of culture, evident in his
explicit remarks during discussions related to such matter. As he embarks on
his term as the new figure leading PLM, he endeavors to introduce specific
cultural aspects into our beloved _Pamantasan_.

**Leadership Redefined: The President of Students**

President Sonny dares to challenge the conventional notion of leadership by
emphasizing that he is the boss of the learners, not the employees. Across his
odyssey in the realm of education, which commenced at the tender age of 19,
his self-perception as a public servant remains unaltered—he is a laborer in
the education sector paid by the government to serve the students. He furthers
that upon his appointment as the new leader of PLM, he intentionally chose not
to bring in any external individual to work with him. In this deliberate move,
he underscores that this decision serves as a symbolic testament to his
unwavering commitment to a leadership with an exclusive focus on the students’
well-being.

**Teachers as Nurturers**

In a compelling call for a transformative shift in the traditional teacher-
student dynamic, Sir Sonny passionately advocates for an approach rooted in
his profound belief that each student is a child of God. Propelling an
inspiring goal, he champions educators who perceive the divine within every
student, nurturing genuine care and fostering meaningful relationships.

In a candid account of his experiences, the president shares that the students
who were once under his guidance hold a special place in his heart. From
navigating unexpected pregnancies to grappling with financial constraints for
school fees, and even dealing with drug-related challenges, he asserts his
commitment to withholding judgment and going beyond the prescribed roles of
his profession to offer assistance.

In his current term, President Sonny has taken proactive steps to forge
meaningful relationships within the school community. A notable initiative
involves personally greeting students at the campus entrance. This intentional
act goes beyond mere formality, serving as a powerful reminder that greetings
are not just rituals but integral actions towards meaningful rapports. Through
this approach, the president aims to construct bridges that lead to genuine
and authentic connections, promoting an environment where students feel seen,
heard, and supported.

**Institutionalizing Premier Status for PLM**

In line with the enduring vision established by PLM’s forefathers, President
Sonny is deeply committed to upholding a culture of academic excellence within
the institution. Recognizing the significant strides already made in this
direction, particularly evidenced by PLM’s commendable achievements in various
licensure examinations, he is resolute in not only upholding but also
advancing this culture to greater heights.

The new president aims to elevate PLM to a level of prominence that rivals
even the most esteemed private institutions in the country.

This intentional
act goes beyond mere formality, serving as a powerful reminder that greetings
are not just rituals but integral actions towards meaningful rapports. Through
this approach, the president aims to construct bridges that lead to genuine
and authentic connections, promoting an environment where students feel seen,
heard, and supported.

**Institutionalizing Premier Status for PLM**

In line with the enduring vision established by PLM’s forefathers, President
Sonny is deeply committed to upholding a culture of academic excellence within
the institution. Recognizing the significant strides already made in this
direction, particularly evidenced by PLM’s commendable achievements in various
licensure examinations, he is resolute in not only upholding but also
advancing this culture to greater heights.

The new president aims to elevate PLM to a level of prominence that rivals
even the most esteemed private institutions in the country. To achieve this
ambitious plan, he is committed to implementing transformative initiatives,
promoting academic innovation, enhancing research endeavors, and cultivating a
supportive environment conducive to scholarly excellence.

Guided by the established 3 K’s of PLM—that is _Karunungan_ , _Kaunlaran_ ,
and _Kadakilaan_ —President Sonny’s aspirations extend beyond being at par
with the private counterparts of the institution in the Philippines as he is
determined to behold a future where PLM stands as a beacon of academic
excellence on the global stage. He envisions a reality where PLM garners
widespread recognition and attains high-ranking positions in prestigious
global university rankings, solidifying its status as a world-class
educational institution.

**Academic Excellence with Efficiency**

While President Sonny acknowledges PLM’s consistent top ratings in various
professional licensure exams, he emphasizes that maintaining excellence is
just one facet of his broader goals for the institution. Alongside academic
achievement, he prioritizes the optimization of service delivery to enhance
the overall student experience. Recognizing the challenges posed by
inefficient document processing, particularly in the issuance of Transcripts
of Records (TOR), he is committed to implementing reforms aimed at
streamlining administrative procedures. By addressing bottlenecks and
exploring more efficient systems, he aims to create an environment where
administrative tasks are completed promptly and seamlessly. This proactive
approach not only improves operational efficiency but also contributes to
fostering a culture of excellence that extends beyond academic pursuits,
ensuring that every aspect of the student journey at PLM is characterized by
efficiency, effectiveness, and excellence.

**Student-Centric Focus**

For his term, President Sonny makes a steadfast commitment towards a PLM which
prioritizes the welfare and advancement of students across colleges of the
university. Central to his vision is a strategic redirection of institutional
resources towards initiatives that directly benefit students. With a clear
focus on creating a conducive and innovative atmosphere for academic growth
and development, President Sonny pledges to allocate substantial portions of
the institution’s budget towards the modernization and improvement of school
equipment and facilities.

Related to such matter, President Sonny advocates for the empowerment of
student leaders by ensuring the University Student Council’s financial
autonomy, believing that this enables student leaders to effectively manage
and lead initiatives that directly impact their peers. Drawing from his own
experiences as a former student leader, the president understands the
importance of nurturing leadership skills among students, fostering a
generation of capable and empowered individuals ready to drive positive change
in their communities and beyond.

Akin to a poet crafting her verses, a scientist conducting his experiments,
and philosophers navigating their existential decisions, integrating new
cultures into existing societies or institutions poses formidable
challenges—but the new president seems to be committed to overcoming these
challenges. And despite his initial surprise at being chosen as PLM’s
president, Sir Sonny reassures students of his preparedness, drawing from
extensive experience in the fields of both corporate and educational. With
strong resolve, he affirms his readiness to embark on this transformative
journey, envisioning our _Pamantasan_ as a metamorphosed community, bound
together by a collective dedication to excellence, efficacy, and sincere
concern for each individual.

The cultural transformation the 11th PLM President advocates for represents a
tangible pathway toward a renaissance of enlightened education at PLM. While
these cultural shifts are still to materialize, the institution benefits from
their manifestations, and so we, as Haribons, can only hope that it transcends
into more than a conceptual ideal.

# PIDI conquers Dance Supremacy tilt; Kings bag third, Queens place fifth

Written by Calvin Agustin • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 29 January 24

 _PIDI Kings placed third and Queens placed fifth in intercollegiate dance
competition._

The Kings of PLM Iskolar Dance Incorporated (PIDI) was hailed third place
during the Dance Supremacy: Kings and Queens - College Division at the Theater
Solaire, Jan. 20.

PIDI competed against 12 colleges for the Kings’ category and 18 colleges for
the Queens’ category. The PIDI Kings garnered a score of 82.33 while the
Queens landed at the fifth place with a score of 78.85.

The boys of PIDI showcased the different kinds of love in their romantic “Love
Express” performance while the girls of PIDI graced the Theater Solaire stage
with their magical performance portraying the famous Disney princesses.

“We thank everyone who supported us, from our friends, family and of course
our dearest alumni for the support you gave for our team! Your screams and
cheers motivated us to give it our all,” PIDI stated in their Facebook post.

PIDI President, Kent Joaquin Pades, shared the dance crew’s experiences prior
to their victory with Ang Pamantasan, from the extensive training and
rehearsals to the mental and physical conditioning of the Iskolar dancers,
under the guidance of their coaches Dhztine Bernardino and Renelee Raye
Bernardino.

However, PIDI also faced challenges in the process of their preparations such
as scheduling conflicts among its members; finding suitable venues for their
training and rehearsals; as well as financial constraints with emphasis on
their search for sponsors to assist them with their expenses.

Pades then expressed his thoughts on winning the intercollegiate competition
as they represented PLM.

“It's gratifying to witness the dedication and outstanding efforts of all PIDI
members as they showcased their best to uphold the honor of our university.
Winning in such a prestigious competition is a testament to the hard work and
commitment of the entire PIDI team in bringing glory to PLM. It clearly shows
that PLMayers not only excel in academic aspect but also in exhibiting our
talents,” the PIDI President stated.

# YGOAL-VOICE empowers youth in Yakap Pakay Social Conversations Caravan

Written by Rinoa Angeline B. Dela Torre • Photos by Ma. Janelle Ugot | 21 February 24

“Only through stories that we are able to build legacies.”

This was the key message delivered by the CEO of YGOAL Inc. Mr. Ireneo
Demecais, Jr., “Kuya JR” as he preferred to be called, to the students at the
recent Yakap Pakay Social Conversations Caravan, spearheaded by the PLM
College of Humanities, Arts and Social Sciences - Student Council (CHASS-SC)
at Bukod Tanging Bulwagan, Feb. 14.

In his opening remarks, Kuya JR recounted the organization's inception and
provided insights into their work and purpose. He expressed gratitude to the
university and CHASS-SC for providing a platform to share stories from
vulnerable groups.

Thereafter, CHASS-SC Adviser and Department of Social Sciences Chairperson
Prof. Bernadette Dela Rosa emphasized the importance of storytelling,
particularly for vulnerable groups, in achieving an inclusive society during
her welcome remarks.

“Mapagpalaya talaga ang pagkukwento. It’s the start of reform. Sisimulan natin
yung pagbabago sa pakikinig sa mga kwento at hinaing ng ating mga kapwa
Pilipino,” Prof. Dela Rosa said.

This was followed by Mr. Yani Alonto, YGOAL Program Manager, who reiterated
the purpose of the Yakap Pakay Caravan, emphasizing the exhibition's role in
amplifying the voices of vulnerable groups for societal inclusivity.

“It’s not just a plenary session, and then makikinig lang kayo. It’s an
engagement, ito yung pagsasama, pagpapalitan ng ideya, o kaya pagbibigay
clarity sa mga questions na mayroon tayong mga kabataan patungkol sa mga issue
at advocacy ng institution,” he said.

Mr. Vince Davidson Pacañot, YGOAL - VOICE L&L Community Manager and Grantee
Coordinator, moderated the discussion proper through featuring representatives
from Rights Holder Groups (RHGs) and Voice grantees, including Mr. Rafae El-
Hawi, President of Philippine Arab Cooperation Council Inc. (PACCI); Atty.
Mack Hale Bunagan, Program Manager for Economic Rights of IDEALS, Inc.; and
Ms. Zarah Navarro, Deputy Executive Director for Programs of the Center for
Youth Advocacy and Networking (CYAN).

Representatives from different non-government organizations (NGOs) shared
their own causes, highlighting how important volunteerism is, and discussed
their volunteer work inside their own.

Mr. El-Hawi, shed light on the challenges faced by refugees in the
Philippines. He emphasized the importance of empowering refugee women and
youth towards self-reliance and socio-economic integration in the country. He
also lamented the financial constraints that often hinder NGOs from providing
adequate support to those in need.

Afterwards, Atty. Bunagan, a Human Rights Lawyer from IDEALS, Inc., shared his
personal journey towards advocating for human rights.

Ms. Zarah Navarro, Deputy Executive Director for Programs of the Center for

Representatives from different non-government organizations (NGOs) shared
their own causes, highlighting how important volunteerism is, and discussed

Mr. El-Hawi, shed light on the challenges faced by refugees in the
Philippines. He emphasized the importance of empowering refugee women and
youth towards self-reliance and socio-economic integration in the country. He
also lamented the financial constraints that often hinder NGOs from providing

Afterwards, Atty. Bunagan, a Human Rights Lawyer from IDEALS, Inc., shared his

experiences, he highlighted the discrimination faced by LGBTQIA+ individuals

Lastly, Ms. Navarro, Deputy Executive Director for Programs at CYAN, discussed
her passion for advocating for the rights of young farmers. She emphasized the
importance of supporting vulnerable groups in society and outlined the
programs implemented by CYAN to empower youth and promote good governance.

The Yakap Pakay Caravan serves as a platform for RHGs and grantees to share
their narratives through art exhibits and interactive dialogues. This exhibit
features artworks capturing the untold stories of marginalized communities,
aiming to amplify their voices. Additionally, the launch of the INCLUCIETY
card game aims to spark conversations on inclusion, which were located in the
lobby of Gusaling Ejercito Estrada from Feb. 13 to 16.

Voice, managed by Hivos and Oxfam Novib, supports marginalized groups in their
pursuit of access to resources, social services, and political participation.
YGOAL facilitates Voice initiatives in the Philippines, focusing on grassroots
organizations representing diverse communities.

# PLM sets 55th Commencement Exercises on Sept. 7, 8, 28

Written by John Coby Cabuhat • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 6 August 23

Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila’s 55th Commencement Exercises will be held on
September 7, 8, and 28 at the Philippine International Convention Center.

In the morning session of Sept. 7, from 7:00 AM to 12:00 PM, the ceremonies
will be for the graduates of PLM Business School and School of Government.

Meanwhile, the afternoon session, starting at 12:00 PM to 5:00 PM, is for the
School of Social Work; College of Humanities, Arts and Social Sciences;
College of Nursing; College of Education; College of Physical Therapy; College
of Architecture and Urban Planning.

The graduation rites for the College of Engineering and College of Science
will be on Sept. 8 from 7:00 AM to 12:00 PM.

The schedule of ceremonies for the College of Law, College of Medicine,
Graduate School of Law, and all graduate programs across all colleges will be
on Sept. 28, Thursday, from 7:00 AM to 12:00 PM.

The Office of University Registrar issued Memorandum OUR 2023-0803-01 last
Aug. 3 informing all the college deans of the schedule distribution.

# OP signs order to lift in-campus health protocols

Written by Calvin Agustin | 23 July 23

The Office of the PLM President (OP) Emmanuel Leyco signed the Pamantasan
Administrative Order No. 19, s. 2023, updating the health and safety
guidelines inside the university premises effective today, July 24.

With this, wearing of face masks in both indoor and outdoor settings will no
longer be required. The online health declaration form will not be required
upon entry into the PLM campus as well. However, students and employees are
required to report to the University Health Services (UHS) in case they are
sick in order to obtain clearance upon entering the campus.

Moreover, college-based COVID-19 monitoring is also no longer required but
faculty members are still encouraged to do their monitoring for the UHS’
information and evaluation.

All those who enter the Pamantasan are encouraged to maintain good hygiene and
health etiquette. This implementation was made after Proclamation No. 297 was
issued by the Office of the President of the Philippines, which lifted the
state of public health emergency due to COVID-19.

# PCACS closes PLM Intramurals 2023 with awarding ceremony; Pres. Reyes shares
plans on sports development in PLM

Written by Calvin Agustin • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 9 March 24

The Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) - Presidential Committee on Arts,
Culture, and Sports (PCACS) concluded the PLM Intramurals 2023, which began on
July 2023, with an awarding ceremony at the Rajah Sulayman Gymnasium, March 5.

Teams of student-athletes from various colleges gathered to celebrate
camaraderie and triumph they have showcased during the different sports
competitions last year.

PLM President Atty. Domingo Y. Reyes, Jr. opened the awarding ceremony with
gratitude towards PCACS and its Head, Prof. April May Bonoan, for inviting him
to the ceremony and awarding of the PLM student-athletes even though he was
not yet president during the conduct of the said sports event in the
University. He also thanked the students for making time to attend the
awarding despite their busy schedules.

Pres. Reyes also shared his plans for PCACS during his term, specifically for
the year 2024, that the administration together with the committee will
enhance the sports program in PLM.

“We are now in talks with other schools. We will have an intercollegiate
sports [event], mayroon na kaming mga school partners… Magkakaroon tayo ng
tryouts for basketball, for volleyball, and other sports, and I hope you will
all take interest in this. So aside from our intramurals, we will also have
interschool activities,” the University President stated in his opening
remarks.

Thereafter, Pres. Reyes, assisted by Ms. Intramurals 2023 Bethany De Guzman
from the College of Nursing, spearheaded the awarding of medals to the winners
of the various sports events– from Badminton, Chess, Table Tennis, Volleyball,
Basketball, and Cheerdance.

Prof. Bonoan then officially closed the PLM Intramurals 2023 with her speech,
thanking all those who participated in the university sports event. She also
announced that the PLM Intramurals 2024 will be held this coming June.

# Anonymous post exposes alleged bullying within PLM-SSC

Written by Calvin Agustin • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 2 October 23

 _TRIGGER WARNING: BULLYING_

Last Sept. 24, a thread (now deleted) from an anonymous account (also deleted)
posted on X (Twitter) circulated online which exposed the alleged bullying of
some members of the PLM Supreme Student Council (SSC) Executive and Core
Committee towards their co-officers in the council.

The thread compiled screenshots of a group conversation named “Mga
backstabbers,” showing the exchange of poorly-worded remarks from SSC
President Vince Edrick De Guzman, Vice President Jam Iris Paglicawan,
Treasurer Sophia Rhyzel Pitero, Junior Officer Archer Pasardosa, College
Representatives Jhon Christian Rebortera (CED), Rey Lagoc (PLMBS), Jastine De
Guzman (COE), Deo Benavidez (PLMBS), Krystle Cabagay (CAUP), Jomarie Soriano
(CED), and Redrick Kyle Gregorio (COE).

PLMBS College Representative Jancel Louise Natividad, SSC Acting Auditor
Jannel Letrero, and COESC President Joaqi Pangindian were some of the names
mentioned, attacked through harsh comments, and victimized by the horrendous
behavior from the members of the said group chat.

Thereafter, various college student councils and organizations inside the
Pamantasan expressed their major disappointment on the issue, condemning the
grave misconduct exhibited by the aforementioned individuals.

AP reached out to the victims last Sept. 27 to ask for their statement on the
incident. However, as of this writing, some of them have not yet responded
while others are not yet ready to give their statement as the issue just
recently came to light.

On the same day, AP, through its Editor-in-Chief Alessandra Frianela, sent a
message in a group chat composed of the SSC Executive Committee and Key
Editors of the student publication to ask for their statement on the incident.
Thereafter, Vince De Guzman and Paglicawan reached out to Frianela privately,
stating that they cannot give any statement as of the moment as the issue is
still under deliberation within the council.

Last Sept. 29, PLM SSC released its official statement regarding the issue at
hand, stating that the council is diligently working to address such with
emphasis to due process in its conflict resolution approach.

“Rest assured, however, that the council's officers are diligently working to
address the issue, upholding their sworn oath of office, and taking the
necessary steps to rectify any instances of misconduct and unethical
behavior,” the PLM SSC said in its statement.

Subsequently, the council expressed its condemnation of such malbehavior
exhibited by the members involved. While resolving the issue internally, the
council will take on actions in compliance with Article 15 (Accountability) of
the PLM SSC Constitution.

Moving forward, PLM SSC expressed that its priorities as of the time being is
to restore the trust of the studentry to the council, as well as rebuilding
the council’s credibility.

Last Sept. 29, PLM SSC released its official statement regarding the issue at
hand, stating that the council is diligently working to address such with
emphasis to due process in its conflict resolution approach.

“Rest assured, however, that the council's officers are diligently working to
address the issue, upholding their sworn oath of office, and taking the
necessary steps to rectify any instances of misconduct and unethical
behavior,” the PLM SSC said in its statement.

Subsequently, the council expressed its condemnation of such malbehavior
exhibited by the members involved. While resolving the issue internally, the
council will take on actions in compliance with Article 15 (Accountability) of
the PLM SSC Constitution.

Moving forward, PLM SSC expressed that its priorities as of the time being is
to restore the trust of the studentry to the council, as well as rebuilding
the council’s credibility.

Meanwhile, AP also reached out to selected SSC officers who were not involved
in the issue namely Janine Ysabelle Nacuna, SSC Secretary; and Edwin Joseph
Espinas, College of Nursing Representative to ask for their thoughts and
sentiments on the issue.

Nacuna shared that after the incident came to light, she personally did not
have security in terms of her relationship with the council members. The
secretary also asked the involved officers through the SSC Core Committee on
their plans to address the issue, however, she did not receive any response.

“Definitely, it will impact the behavior of the officers, as well as the
attitudes of the student towards us. It is undeniable that this turmoil will
greatly affect our connection with the students, sadly. And we cannot just
proceed without having the entire council accountable. As elected officials,
we bear the weightiest duty to prove that the council is still worthy of being
regarded as the highest duly-constituted governing body of the students,”
Nacuna said.

On the other hand, Espinas expressed that such behavior was unacceptable for
him, emphasizing that one’s thoughts and opinions can never be used as an
excuse to speak ill of someone like that. He also said that he hopes justice
for the victims of the incident, and that he is with them in whatever decision
they make.

“As an individual, student, and leader, I am someone who strongly condemns
such acts and behavior, for I consider it unbecoming for a student leader. The
impact it has caused on the image that holds the trust of the students to the
PLM SSC affected not only the involved individuals but even those who are not
even part of it,” Espinas said.

The student publication, true to its mandate of keeping the students informed
and socially conscious, is still waiting for the involved parties to give
their narratives and responses in order to publish a full story on the
bullying incident.

This is a developing story.

# Paalala sa Mahimbing na Pahinga

Written by Jan Rennie Abat • Board by Elyse Abadilla | 18 March 24

Pansin mo rin ba ang pag-igsi ng gabi?

Sa pagsibol ng kapanahunan ay tila oras ng buwan ay nababawasan. Ang walong
oras ay naging pito, ang pito’y bumagsak sa lima, at ang lima ay nauwi na
lamang sa tatlong oras na pagitan mula pagpikit ng mata hanggang sa pagsikat
ng bagong umaga.

Kapag humarap na sa patong-patong na takdang-aralin at pagsusulit, pahinga at
tulog ang madalas na isinasakripisyo ng mga mag-aaral. Ngunit sa paggunita ng
nagdaang linggo ng kamalayan ng hipig, ating kikilalanin ang halaga ng
nakagawiang minsan nang binalewala– ng pagtulog na unti-unting ninanakawan ng
panahon.

**Linggo ng Pagpapahinga**

Sinimulan noong 1998, mahigit dalawang dekada na nang ipinagdiwang ng National
Sleep Foundation (NSF) ang Sleep Awareness Week bilang pagkilala sa
kahalagahan ng pagtulog sa kagalingan ng bawat isa. Kaakibat nito ay ang
pagkilala ng mundo sa World Sleep Day noong ika-15 ng Marso. Sa pamamagitan ng
pagkilatis ng mga bagong pananaliksik, nabibigyang liwanag ng taunang
selebrasyon ang malungkot na realidad ng kakulangan sa kalidad na tulog ng
karamihan, higit pa ang masamang epekto na dulot nito sa pisikal at mental na
kalusugan.

Isa na rito ang ebidensya na nagsasabing ang kakulangan sa tulog ay nagdudulot
ng pagpalo ng panganib ng problema sa kalusugan kabilang ang sakit sa puso,
alta-presyon, at ang maya’t-mayang pagkatok ng kalungkutan ng depression.
Kaya’t kung ikaw ay isa sa libo-libong pinipiling labanan ang pagpikit ng mga
mata ay marahil kailangan mo na ring marinig ang masikot na proseso ng
pagtulog at ang pagyari ng isang kalidad na pahinga.

**Salubong sa Mainit na Araw**

Kasalungat sa paniniwala ng karamihan, ang pagsipa ng maayos na tulog ay hindi
sa paghiga sa kama tuwing gabi bagkus ay sa pagmulat ng mga mata sa umaga.

Kaya’t kung ikaw ay isa sa libo-libong pinipiling labanan ang pagpikit ng mga
mata ay marahil kailangan mo na ring marinig ang masikot na proseso ng
pagtulog at ang pagyari ng isang kalidad na pahinga.

**Salubong sa Mainit na Araw**

Kasalungat sa paniniwala ng karamihan, ang pagsipa ng maayos na tulog ay hindi
sa paghiga sa kama tuwing gabi bagkus ay sa pagmulat ng mga mata sa umaga.
Bukod sa pagiging hudyat ng pagbangon ng katawan, ang matingkad na liwanag na
hatid ng sikat ng araw ang siyang nagsasaayos ng ating _body clock–_ ang
natural na oras ng paggising at pagtulog ng katawan. Bunsod nito ay ang
pagkaalisto sa pag-angat ng araw at ang kadalian ng pagdating ng antok sa pag
kislap ng buwan.

Matapos ang masaganang pagbangon at pagharap sa bagong umaga ay nariyan ang
pagiging aktibo at pagkain nang tama na magpapanatili ng maayos na takbo ng
oras ng katawan. Kaya’t sa pagbungad pa lang ng araw ay maiging makapag-
ehersisyo kahit na 30 minutong paglalakad lang. Higit pa ay ang kahalagahan na
makakain ng tatlong beses sa isang araw, ng tama sa oras, at ng mga putaheng
may dalang sustansya. Ang mga simpleng bagay na ito– bagama’t parte ng normal
na buhay ay sila ring napapasawalang-bahala– ay nagbubunga sa kalidad na
tulog, ayon sa 2022 na pag-aaral ng NSF.

**Patungo sa Panaginip na Himbing**

Sa paglubog ng araw, anumang tukso ang lumapit ay mainam nang iwasan ang pag-
inom ng kape sa dapithapon at ang pagtulog nang maaga sa gabi upang gumising
ng madaling araw. Sapagka’t ang dalawang gawain na ito ay nagiging dahilan ng
pagkawarak ng balanse ng ating _body clock;_ ang pagkawarak ng tulog na
kumpleto’t tama sa oras.

At sa pagsapit ng kampana ng paghiga sa kama ay isang mairerekomendang gawain
ang makinig sa mga musikang nagpapakalma sa isipan matapos ang nakapapagod na
araw. Isang paalala rin ng mga eksperto na huwag kalimutang gawing malinis,
madilim, at tahimik ang pagtutulugan. Anumang _gadget_ ay siya nang itatabi,
ang mga mata’y siya nang ipipikit, at ang katawan at isipan ay
pagpapahingahin.

Datapwa’t ang iba sa kaalamang nilathala’y hindi na bago sa isipan, hindi
mapagkakailang karamihan ay pinagpapaliban na lamang ang pahinga; ang pagtulog
ng kinagabihan at paggising sa liwayway matapos lumipas ang walong oras.
Kaya’t alintana ng layunin ng nagdaang National Sleep Week at World Sleep Day,
ay nararapat na muli’t muling idiin ang pangangailangan ng mahimbing at
kalidad na tulog higit pa sa mga mag-aaral. At sa pagbaon ng mumunting paalala
ukol sa pagtulog ngayong linggo ay haharap sa bagong umaga, babangon nang
hindi pagod, at handang sasalubungin ang mga hamon hanggang sa pagpatak ng
gabi ng paghipig. Ito ang hakbang tungo sa mas malusog na kinabukasan.

# Walang Batas sa Sugat - No Rules for Wounds

Written by Gabriel Ciego • Board by Arjay Samson | 4 July 24

Ito ang nalalabing hawig ng katwiran, ang ulan.

_This is the remaining semblance of reason, the rain._

Darating para mamurga.

_It visits to cleanse._

__

__

Tinatatakan kami ng panahon bilang preso,

_The weather brands us like prisoners,_

Sinusugatan sa diin ng hiblang tubig—

_Scarring with the threads of water flowing_

Tumatapon mula sa nakataas na kamay.

_From surrendering arms._

Sinisinok, sinisinok. Sinusulsi ng oras.

_Stuttering, stuttering_. _Mended by time._

Tagpi-tagpi. Tagpo-tagpo.

_Patchwork. Rendezvous._

Nawawala. Nabubuo.

_Into mist. Into more._

Sa kalagpasan ng mga alon.

_Astray by the oceans._

Hinabi kami sa hinawing hamog ng kalsada,

_We are weaved in fading street fog,_

Umuuwi sa sariling pahintulot.

_Holding our own hands on the way home._

Giniginaw, giniginaw. Kinukumutan ng mga gabi.

_Shivering, shivering. Embraced by many moons._

__ Madilim na ang ilalim ng naghihingalong posteng kahoy.

_It has become dark under the rotting wooden lamp post._

Putol na ang linya ng kuryente kong salita.

_The electricity of my words has died out._

__ Mahina na ang pagkalat ng liwanag.

_The light grows dimmer._

Naghihintay ang Conchang nakapayong.

_Concha waits under umbrella._

Kasihan nawa ako ng Diyos.

_So help me God._

Amen.

_Amen._

# PLM commences 59th Founding Anniversary

Written by Angel Crismar Joy Udtohan • Board by Angelle Valbuena | 18 June 24

Manila’s premiere university, Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) commenced
59th Founding Anniversary: the road to 60 and beyond with the theme “Pagbabago
sa Pamantasan tungo sa Kaunlaran” during the Flag Raising and Wreath-Laying
Ceremony at the Tanghalang Bayan and Dr. Jose Rizal Monument, June 18.

University President Atty. Domingo Y. Reyes Jr. led the opening ceremony along
with Manila City Mayor Dra. Maria Sheilah “Honey” Lacuna-Pangan, and Prof.
Antonio Villegas, son of the late city mayor.

In her speech, Mayor Lacuna congratulated PLM on their founding day and
thanked the late Mayor Villegas for his legacy. She also emphasized the city’s
continuous support for the university in producing students who excel in
various fields.

Meanwhile, Pres. Reyes also lauded the several students who excelled in
different fields such as Joyce Ramos, Joniel Bolocon, Georgeson Yssrael Guray,
and Mushi Araf Jihad D. Yahya. Moreover, he also congratulated PLM alumni Dr.
Gina F. Padilla and College of Law faculty Hon. Anne Perpetua S. Rivera-Sia
for being recognized at the Gawad Manileño.

Furthermore, the University President announced the memorandum of
understanding between PLM and Xiamen Effie Overseas Education, the agency who
previously partnered with Rizal Technological University (RTU) and Central
Philippine University (CPU), Iloilo City, bringing over 200 international
students to attend the universities.

“Para po sa pagtanggap natin sa graduate school ng mga foreigners. Again,
inuulit ko walang madidisplace na estudyante na Pilipino. Ito po ay online.
Ito po ay malugod nating sinisimulan dahil kailangan po natin ng
internationalization. Kasi nga po, nabanggit ko noong isang linggo,
magpapadala naman ang PLM, hopefully, ng apat na na mag-aaral sa Taiwan para
sa kanilang Master’s Degree Program,” Pres. Reyes said.

PLM’s week-long anniversary celebration comprises several activities and
competitions such as Binibini at Ginoong Pamantasan 2024, Employees Service
Awards Rites (PRAISE), Singing and Dance Competition, Intramurals, as well as
the arrival of Wish 107.5 Bus, and the JENGA Challenge which will award Php
40,000.00 to the champion. The festivities will culminate on June 22,
Saturday, with the Alumni Homecoming.

# PLM CISTM students develop award-winning Arduino-Driven Flea Repellent
Device

Written by Jeanette Tropa • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 8 March 24

A group of Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) students from the College of
Information Systems and Technology Management (CISTM) received international
recognition for their groundbreaking project, "Serenivice: An Arduino-Driven
Automated Flea Repellent Device with Computer Vision Integration for Cat Flea
Management." The device aims to develop cat flea control using innovative
technology.

The group, composed of Fritz Jannus V. Aniciete, Cyreene Lyn A. Genova, Ariz
Ann C. Salazar, and Darren Jay P. Salgado, received the Best Presentation
Paper Award at the 6th International Conference on Advanced Science,
Education, Social Science, Technology, and Management (ICASETM) held in Bali,
Indonesia, Dec. 30, 2023.

In an exclusive interview with Ang Pamantasan, Salazar shared, "Sobrang
thankful namin na yung hard work namin is may napala." This sentiment reflects
the group’s dedication and sacrifice in pursuing their research.

The group’s project, Serenivice, integrates Arduino technology with computer
vision for a comprehensive solution to cat flea management. The automated flea
repellent device can serve as a prototype, and the group believes that further
innovation and improvements are possible.

Reflecting on their memorable experiences during the competition, Aniciete
stated, “Nagulat kami, kasi, di naman namin in-expect talaga. Number one goal
lang namin, is makapag-present and publish. Experience siya, syempre. Then,
yung network."

The group’s achievement not only brings honor to PLM but also serves as an
inspiration for students to push their limits and explore the possibilities of
technology in addressing real-world challenges.

The group’s adviser, Prof. Criselle J. Centeno, encouraged students to strive
for excellence even in the face of challenges. She also shared her vision for
her students’ success, leveraging their skills and talents and believing in
the fact that all things are possible.

Dr. Khatalyn Mata, CISTM Acting Dean, highlighted the resilience and patience
required in the field. "So, yung training namin sa kanila, is papunta na doon
sa industry training. So, kailangan nilang maging patient and resilient. Kasi,
they need to work under pressure,” she emphasized.

As they continue their journey in the field of technology and innovation, the
Serenivice group, through Genova, emphasized the importance of resourcefulness
and determination, considering the limited funds and resources they had
throughout the competition, "Strive for excellence. Kahit na wala tayong
resources, as long as meron tayong skills and meron tayong talent.”

# PLM-CM ranks first runner-up in IMSPQ 2024

Written by Angel Crismar Joy T. Udtohan • Board by John Ivan Pasion | 2 August 24

The Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila’s (PLM) College of Medicine (CM) ranked
first runner-up during the Inter-Medical School Physiology Quiz (IMSPQ) at the
Cebu Doctors’ University, Mandaue City, Cebu, July 26-27.

Glann Leo O. Santiago, Joseph Oliver R. Mayor, and Jerson A. Recio secured the
silver medal in the competition under the guidance of their faculty coach Dr.
Fernando P. Solidum.

60 teams from different medical schools in Southeast Asia participated in the
annual competition, including representatives from Japan, Australia, Vietnam,
Thailand, Indonesia, Cambodia, Malaysia, and Taiwan.

Chulalongkorn University from Thailand was hailed as champion, with the PLM-CM
following behind by a few points. Mahidol University from Thailand and Cebu
Institute of Medicine from the Philippines ranked second and third runner-ups,
respectively.

# DFA to roll out ‘Passport on Wheels’ to PLM on June 21

Written by Rylan Gabriel Bernardo • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 3 June 24

The Department of Foreign Affairs (DFA), in partnership with the Pamantasan ng
Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM), is set to bring its Passport on Wheels (POWs)
service to the University Campus on Friday, June 21.

All students, faculty members, and administrative personnel are qualified to
apply for “NEW” and “RENEWAL” applications of the Philippine passport. The
POWs in PLM will accommodate a total of 500 applicants on a “first come, first
serve” basis.

Necessary documentary requirements are advised to be prepared prior to
securing the slots. The documents needed will vary depending on the type of
passport application. For the full list of requirements, applicants may view
the POWs email sent on their respective PLM email addresses or visit
[_https://dfa-oca.ph/passport/passport-requirements_](https://dfa-
oca.ph/passport/passport-requirements).

Interested passport applicants (either “NEW” or “RENEWAL”) may signify their
interest through filling out this form
[_https://forms.office.com/r/hLmDEdqf1U_](https://forms.office.com/r/hLmDEdqf1U).
Afterwards, the applicants will receive an acknowledgement and they will be
informed to accomplish the Passport Application Form and POWs Waiver Form
along with the required documents.

Applicants will then be asked to proceed to the Pre-Registration Site in the
campus to complete the process in the DFA portal, where they will receive
their schedule and Payment Reference Number. A processing fee of P1,200.00 is
required to be paid through DFA-accredited payment merchants. After the
payment, another email will be sent to the applicants informing them of their
successful appointment.

Two copies of the e-Receipt with Passport Application Form as sent by the DFA
after completing the aforementioned steps will be needed on June 21. These
shall be attached to the original and photocopied documentary requirements
plus the POWs Waiver.

After successful validation by the DFA processor, applicants will proceed to
the biometrics capturing, where they will also be asked to pay the passport
delivery fee. Applicants’ new or renewed Philippine passports will then be
delivered to their addresses.

Applicants with other inquiries are encouraged to coordinate with the PLM POWs
Coordinator Mr. Ryan Jay SM. Cruz (rjsmcruz@plm.edu.ph), or through the PLM
designated POWs encoder/validator Ms. Leisyl M. Mahusay (lmocampo@plm.edu.ph).

POWs, as launched last 2018, is an initiative by the DFA to accommodate
passport seekers through mobile stations that visit schools, municipalities,
and government offices.

# PLM hails as 2nd best performing school, graduate ranks 7th in chemical
engineering licensure exams

Written by Rommel Lacambra • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 29 May 23

Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) excelled as the second top performing
school in chemical engineering board exams, securing 90.48% overall passing
rate, May 22.

Reindel Nolasco Mallari also leads as the 7th topnotcher, along with 18
passers. Mallari gained an average of 85.80% in the said examination.These
newly produced engineers were all successful first-time takers.

PLM's school performance was far-above compared to the national passing rate
of 52.93%.

The schedule of oath-taking will be announced at a later date. Passers were
advised to register for their issuance of Professional ID starting July 17
until July 20.

# ‘Org Culture’ sa Pamantasan

Written by Dean Joseph Palapar • Board by Angelle Valbuena | 21 November 23

Kalakip na sa isang unibersidad o kolehiyo ang pagkakaroon ng mga
organisasyon. Bukod sa masidhing pagsusunog ng kilay at pagharap sa alon ng
mga gawain sa klase, ay ang kagalakan ng mga mag-aaral na lumahok sa mga
samahang magsisilbing kanilang palihan ng angking kahusayan.

Nito lamang nakaraang buwan, opisyal na binigyang pagkilala ng Pamantasan ang
36 academic at 13 non-academic na mga organisasyon para sa kasalukuyang pang
akademikong taon. At sa kabila ng kapanapanabik na mga aktibidad na kanilang
handang ihain sa mga Haribon,**** ay ang pagsilip ng kuryosidad na****
alamin**ano nga ba ang kalagayan ng ‘org culture’ sa Pamantasan? Na kung
susuriin, ay may malaking implikasyon sa kultura ng mga mag-aaral ng PLM.**

** _Panday ng Kahusayan_**

** __**

Tanda ang pagsali sa mga organisasyon bilang likas na kagustuhan ng mag-aaral
na palawigin ang kaalaman at gamitin ang mga matututuhan sa labas ng apat na
sulok ng silid-aralan. Para kay James Clarence Albano, miyembro ng higit sa
isang organisasyon sa Pamantasan, ang mga ito ay nagsisilbing alternatibong
pinagmumulan ng makabagong kabatiran ng anumang larangan. Higit din sa
paglinang na pinapangako ng mga organisasyon ay ang kolektibong paghubog sa
mga miyembro na siyang nagpapatibay ng kahusayan.

_“It’s meaningful kasi, you will meet people. People na will mold your
perspective. [Palagi] tayong may matututunan on different people,”_ saad ni
Albano.

Ito’y nagsisilbing patunay na ang kahusayan ng bawat Haribon ay hindi lamang
nasusukat sa mga metrong akma sa edukasyong pang-akademiko. Malawak ang
potensyal ng mga orgs sa pagpukaw ng interes at hangarin ng isa o grupo ng mga
mag-aaral na makatulong, makibahagi at makapag-ambag sa komunidad nang naaayon
sa kanilang makakaya. Katatagpuan ng mag-aaral ang komunidad sa mga orgs
bilang mga paunang lipunang maaari niyang pagsilbihan.

_“Sa mga organizations, nagkakaroon ka ng responsibility.

[Palagi] tayong may matututunan on different people,”_ saad ni
Albano.

Ito’y nagsisilbing patunay na ang kahusayan ng bawat Haribon ay hindi lamang
nasusukat sa mga metrong akma sa edukasyong pang-akademiko. Malawak ang
potensyal ng mga orgs sa pagpukaw ng interes at hangarin ng isa o grupo ng mga
mag-aaral na makatulong, makibahagi at makapag-ambag sa komunidad nang naaayon
sa kanilang makakaya. Katatagpuan ng mag-aaral ang komunidad sa mga orgs
bilang mga paunang lipunang maaari niyang pagsilbihan.

_“Sa mga organizations, nagkakaroon ka ng responsibility. Na-ho-hone doon
‘yung pagkakaroon mo ng initiative na to help to and to serve—to have a sense
of awareness din sa kapaligiran nila, hindi lang sa loob ng Pamantasan kundi
maging sa labas; sa panlipunan natin in general.”_ saad ni Ea Nazal, Executive
President ng PLM Children’s Rights Advocates League (CRAdLe).

**_Paglinang ng Kabuuang Pamantasan_**

** __**

Maaaring maituring na isang makulay na hibla ang komunidad ng mga organisasyon
sa Pamantasan. Mula sa mga samahan ng mag-aaral na tumatalakay sa kalaliman ng
kanilang kurso; sa mga katuwang ng mga lider-estudyante; hanggang sa mga
nagsusulong ng kolektibong interes at adbokasiya ng masang estudyante.

Hindi lamang nalilimita sa kung saan ang mga ito nakatuon. Higit pa sa mismong
pagpapabilang sa mga organisasyon ay ang pagkilala ng bawat miyembro sa
kanilang kolektibong kapangyarihan at kapasidad na umalpas at makapagdulot ng
makabuluhang pagbabagong nakaayon sa isyung pangkampus at pambansa.

Matatandaang umani ng puri ang PLM noong nakaraang taon mula sa pag-implementa
ng Pamantasan Administrative Order No. 21-ACA s. 2022 o ang Uniform and Dress
Code Policy kung saan nagkaroon ng pagkilala ng karapatan ng bawat Haribon sa
kasuotang naaayon sa kanilang pagkakakilanlan ng kanilang kasarian sa loob ng
Pamantasan. Bagay na naisakatuparan sa pamamagitan ng pagdulog ng kolektibong
panawagan ng PLM Propaganda, ng nakaraang konseho, at ng mga kasaping
organisasyon.

_“Finally na-recognize ni PLM yung gender expression and identity ng LGBTQIA+
community sa Pamantasan. After 55 years, another breakthrough ito sa history
of PLM, and since nabalita ito, even non-haribons were inspired sa ganitong
klase ng inclusivity and progressiveness which made the Pamantasan an even
more progressive and inclusive environment.”_ saad ni Gella Aboratigue, Vice
President for Internal Affairs ng Santelmo Arts.

Ilan lang din sa mga patunay nitong kapasidad ay ang mga simpleng paglalabas
ng official statements upang magbigay suporta o paninindigan, at pagbubuo ng
mga bagong organisasyon sa gitna ng pandemya. Manipestasyon ito ng kakayahang
magtaguyod ng pagkakaisang pananaw, at makapagbigay ng pangkalahatang
representasyon sa kapwa mag-aaral.

**_Mga Hamon na Kinahaharap_**

** __**

Bagaman maraming organisasyon sa Pamantasan, hindi maitatanggi ang mga hadlang
at suliraning kinahaharap sa aspekto ng proseso sa operasyon, sa pagtawid sa
mga miyembro, at maging sa pagpapatuloy ng pagsulong ng adbokasiya.

Manipestasyon ito ng kakayahang
magtaguyod ng pagkakaisang pananaw, at makapagbigay ng pangkalahatang
representasyon sa kapwa mag-aaral.

**_Mga Hamon na Kinahaharap_**

** __**

Bagaman maraming organisasyon sa Pamantasan, hindi maitatanggi ang mga hadlang
at suliraning kinahaharap sa aspekto ng proseso sa operasyon, sa pagtawid sa
mga miyembro, at maging sa pagpapatuloy ng pagsulong ng adbokasiya. Higit pa
ang hamon na makamit ang tunay na kasaganahan ng ‘org culture’ ng Pamantasan
na siyang nakasalalay sa kung paano nga ba ganap na naipamamalas ang layuning
makapagsilbi ng organisasyon at kung lubos itong nararamdaman ng mga mag-
aaral.

Para kay Madie Retiro, Supremo ng PLM Propaganda, mainam na mapalawig pa ang
malalim na implikasyon ng mga organisasyon at mga aktibidad nito sa lipunan.
Ang pangkalahatang organisasyon ay may kapasidad na magtaguyod ng karapatan at
kapakanan ng bawat mag-aaral sa pamamagitan ng pagtuon sa pagkakaisang diwa ng
bawat maka-estudyanteng adbokasiya datapwa’t anyo’y magkakaiba.

_“Dapat we always ask yung capacity or yung outcome ng mga nangyayari du’n sa
mga events na iniispearhead natin. It is very important na ibahin din natin
yung organization culture kasi it starts with us eh. It’s very important na if
it starts with us, dapat yung ginagawa natin ay [makatutulong] sa welfare at
sa buong studentry natin.”_

Mahalagang maipamalas ang prinsipyo ng organisasyon at ang malaking gampanin
sa pagpapatuloy nito, mula sa mga kawani at mga programang inilalahad, upang
mapunan ang siwang sa mga miyembro at makamit ang laganap na pakikilahok sa
komunidad.

 _“It revolves around [the] activities nga na binibigay mo sa students, na
dapat relevant siya na hindi lang basta-basta. Dapat na-aabsorb ng students
yung benefits and ‘yung essence or “yung importance. Important ‘yun, na
iniinstill mo rin sa students [kung] gaano kalaki yung importance nila, as a
member,”_ ayon naman kay Shane Cuevas, Executive President ng PLM
Psychological Society _._

_“Kung ano man ‘yung prinsipyo ng organizations, kailangan ito ‘yung patuloy
na maipamuhay namin, and it helps din kasi na ma-encourage yung mga members to
join. Kasi paano nga naman mag-jojoin ang mga members kung mismong officers
nakikita nila na hindi naman nag rereflect sa kanila ‘yung org?”_ saad naman
ni Nazal.

Sa kabilang dako, mahalagang salik din ang pagkakaroon ng mas matibay na
pagkilala at suporta mula sa administrasyon ng Pamantasan. Mainam na higit
pang mabigyang-pansin ang mga panawagan ng mga estudyante at miyembrong
nasasakupan ng organisasyon, mapabilis ang proseso sa paglunsad ng proyekto at
mga adbokasiya, at makapagbigay-halaga sa papel ng mga organisasyon sa mga
napapanahong usaping sangkot ang mag-aaral at kabuuang Pamantasan.

_“[Makatutulong] ang University natin or ibang universities sa kanilang mga
organization by being open to what their students really want to push. Kumbaga
hindi lang naman kasi gumagawa ng events ang mga organization just because
they want something na maipakita. Lahat ‘yun may katuturan sa likod.

Mainam na higit
pang mabigyang-pansin ang mga panawagan ng mga estudyante at miyembrong
nasasakupan ng organisasyon, mapabilis ang proseso sa paglunsad ng proyekto at
mga adbokasiya, at makapagbigay-halaga sa papel ng mga organisasyon sa mga
napapanahong usaping sangkot ang mag-aaral at kabuuang Pamantasan.

_“[Makatutulong] ang University natin or ibang universities sa kanilang mga
organization by being open to what their students really want to push. Kumbaga
hindi lang naman kasi gumagawa ng events ang mga organization just because
they want something na maipakita. Lahat ‘yun may katuturan sa likod. So I
guess, sana makita; sana mas maging bukas pa”_ , saad ni Albano.

Para kay Aboratigue, malaking tulong din ang pagkakaroon ng karagdagang
espasyo para sa mga mag-aaral upang makapagpulong, at mga aktibidad na
magpapalaganap pa ng kanilang presensya sa mga estudyante sa Pamantasan.

_“The only way to make the rich org culture maintain its richness is
[ma]pakinggan tayo sa mga concerns ng organizations. Also since napakaraming
orgs sa PLM, I think it’s better if magkakaroon tayo ng ‘organization week’ na
hindi lang puro selling yung mangyayari,”_ saad ni Aboratigue.

Ang pagtamasa sa mayabong na ‘org culture’ sa Pamantasan ay larawan ng
pagkakaroon ng mayamang kultura ng kaisipan at ganap na pagkilala sa
akademikong kalayaan ng mga mag-aaral. Bagay na siyang magpapawari sa kanila
ng kakayahang magsilbi bilang mga pangunahing instrumentong magdadala sa
Pamantasan sa hinaharap.

Ang mga naisulong na maka-estudyanteng hakbang ng mga organisasyon ay siyang
patunay ng kanilang taglay na malawak na kakayahan—kapangyarihang magtaguyod
ng kapakanan ng mga estudyante ng Pamantasan.

Ang kultura sa mga organisasyon ay salamin sa kultura ng kabuuang sistema ng
paaralan. Kinakailangan na patuloy sikapin at ipaglaban na maabot ng bawat
Haribon at organisasyon ang ganap nilang pagkakakilanlan, para sa patuloy na
pagpapabuti ng buong komunidad, mula at para sa bawat mag-aaral ng Pamantasan.

# Ang Paglitaw ng Matingkad na Bahaghari

Written by Jamilla Marie Matias • Board by Angelle Valbuena | 19 June 24

Lumaki ako sa isang silid na may samu’t saring kulay. Tila ba isa akong
bahagharing mahiyain, nakatago sa mga ulap sa himpapawid. Bagamat tago, masaya
pa rin naman akong namamalagi rito. Ngunit, may katanungang patuloy na umiinog
sa aking isipan — makulay pa rin kayang mamuhay sa labas ng mga kaulapan kung
maraming tumutuligsa sa sarili kong pamantayan?

Paslit pa lamang ako, batid ko nang may kakaiba sa akin. Sapagkat hindi
katulad ng pasubali ng iba, may kagustuhan akong taliwas sa kanilang
paniniwala. Minsan kong sinubok ihayag ang pagsalungat sa kanilang kinagisnan
ngunit panghuhusga at panunuya lamang ang aking nakuha. Nakakatakot—tila ba
isa akong salot. Parang may kapansanang hindi madadala ng kahit anong gamot.
Kung kaya’t naisipan ko na lamang lumagi sa isang sulok.

Sa pananalagi ko sa loob ng tila aparador na silid, dinig ko ang mga panaghoy
at pagtangis. Nasaksihan ko ang iba’t ibang karahasan, biktima ang ‘sang
kabaklaan. Puno ng diskriminasyon, wala raw kaming mapupuntahang destinasyon.
Walang lugar sa tahanan ng lumikha ng langit at lupa, maging sa lipunang
patuloy kaming kinukutsa. Dahil sa pakiwari na malaking kasalanan ang hindi
tumalima sa nakasanayang alituntunin ng mala-santong madla. Isang pagkakamali
na dapat tuwidin. Gawi ng mga baliko’y hindi dapat tangkilikin.

Subalit, itanggi man nang paulit-ulit; ikubli man nang maraming beses, ang
bahagharing gaya ko’y lilitaw rin. Sa dami ng pag-ulang naranasan, may araw
ring darating. Kung saan ang mga ulap ay magiging pakpak, lilipad ako sa
alapaap bitbit ang giting at tapang. May kumpiyansa sa sarili, ihahayag ang
pagkatao kong may matayog na pangarap. Haharapin kung ano mang bagyo ang
dumating. Sapagkat, aanhin ko nga ba ang papuri ng iba kung bulag ako sa
sarili kong katauhan?

Gawi ng mga baliko’y hindi dapat tangkilikin.

Subalit, itanggi man nang paulit-ulit; ikubli man nang maraming beses, ang
bahagharing gaya ko’y lilitaw rin. Sa dami ng pag-ulang naranasan, may araw
ring darating. Kung saan ang mga ulap ay magiging pakpak, lilipad ako sa
alapaap bitbit ang giting at tapang. May kumpiyansa sa sarili, ihahayag ang
pagkatao kong may matayog na pangarap. Haharapin kung ano mang bagyo ang
dumating. Sapagkat, aanhin ko nga ba ang papuri ng iba kung bulag ako sa
sarili kong katauhan? Kung magiging sunod-sunuran lamang ako sa kung ano man
ang idikta ng mapanghusgang lipunan?

Ang pagladlad ko’y katapusan ng katahimikan. Pagwawakas na maituturing kong
bagong simula. Ito’y kalayaan na kay tagal kong nang hinihintay. Marahil isang
tagumpay mula sa aming hanay. Sawa na ‘kong magbalat kayo! Ayoko na magtago sa
kaanyuan ng hindi ko naman ginusto. Mula sa araw na ito, yayakapin na nang
buong-buo; pipiliin na ang sarili; panghuhusga ng iba ay aking isasantabi.
‘Pagkat ano’t sino man ako, lagi naman silang may hindi magandang nasasabi.
Kung kaya’y hindi na mahihiya, isisiwalat na kung sino ako sa madla. Dahil ang
paglitaw ko ay simbolo ng matingkad na bahaghari — namumukadkad ang kulay at
may pag-asang taglay.

Masarap din pa lang mabuhay ng ganito. Walang iniisip na pagkukunwari. Malaya
ang puso at isip. Hindi pigil ang emosyon. Hindi na nakakulong sa kung saan
lamang sang-ayon ang lipunan buhat ng limitasyong sa ami’y kinahon. Subalit
batid kong malayo pa ang lalakbayin ng aming hanay. Kaya’t hiling ng puso’y
pumanig na sa amin ang ihip ng panahon — isakatuparan na marahil ang batas na
sa amin ay nararapat. Dahil bahagi man ng bahaghari, kami’y tao rin.
Makasalanan man kung ituring, ang pagwawalang-hiya sa mga bading ay karahasan
din.

At sa mga kapwa ko bading, ating ibandera ang matingkad na kulay sapagka’t
tayo’y natatangi — pinamamayanihan ng katapangan sa lipunang puno ng
pangkakahon; ng mga matang mapanghusga’t lipos sa diskriminasyon. Ipaglaban
ang sa ati’y ipinagkakait at isigaw ang ating karapatan; ang kagandahan ng
ating bahaghari.

Isang pagbati ng maligayang buwan ng pride, aking kapwa mandirigma!

Binantayan at ngayon ay hinalal!

Here are your newly elected student leaders for the Supreme Student Council
(SSC) and College Student Councils (CSC) of A.Y. 2023 - 2024.

today at 9:30 AM in the Justo Alberto Auditorium.

# Mensahe ng Pagkakaisa

Written by John Coby Cabuhat • Board by Angelle Valbuena | 20 September 22

Pagbabalik Tanaw: Mensahe ng Pagkakaisa ng dating Punong Patnugot at Senior
News Correspondent ng Ang Pamantasan sa ika-50 anibersaryo ng 1972 Martial Law
noong Setyembre 21, 2022, Maynila.

Sa mga miyembro ng pamunuan ng pamantasan, mga kapwa ko lider-kabataan, at sa
lahat ng kasama nating umaalala ngayon, isang mapagpalayang araw.

Sa ika-50 annibersaryo ng isa sa pinakamalagim na yugto sa kasaysayan ng
Pilipinas, ang 1972 Martial Law [na] idiniklera ng diktador [na si] Ferdinand
Marcos Sr., inaalala natin ang sakripisyo at laban ng mga biktima at namatay,
higit sa lahat ang mga martir mula sa ating pamantasan.

Isa sa pinakamalapit, lalo na sa ating pahayagan, ay si Liliosa Hilao, dating
pangalawang patnugot ng Hasik at isa sa pinaka-unang biktimang kabataan [at]
mag-aaral ng batas militar. Dinakip, pinahirapan o sumailalaim sa torture, at
pinaslang.

Bilang kabataang mamamahayag, siya ay kritikal na tumindig laban sa banta ng
demokrasya at kalayaan. _“Kamatayan ng Demokrasya ng Pilipinas sa Ilalim ng
Martial Law”_ \- kaisipan, isang katotohanan na kaniyang pinanindigan sa
pamamagitan ng sanaysay.

Hindi man makasama noon sa pagkilos dahil sa kaniyang kalusugan, pluma at
papel ang kaniyang sandata upang maipaglaban ang kaniyang kapwa Pilipino.

Higit kailanman, huwag sana maging pangalang inaalala lamang si Liliosa Hilao.
Kung hindi, siya ay maging inspirasyon at motibasyon ng mga mamamahayag, mag-
aaral, at ng pamantasan na tumindig sa mga hindi maka-demokratikong gawi at sa
kasinungalingan. Ito ay upang hindi muli dakipin, pahirapan, at paslangin ang
katotohanan at kalayaan.

Na hindi nila tayo madadaan sa mga Youtube vlogs (video blogs) o interviews
(panayam) para baluktutin ang kasaysayan o bigyang katwiran ang rehimeng
responsable sa pagdanak ng dugo ng daan-daaang Pilipino.

Si Liliosa Hilao ay hindi lang mamamahayag, siya ay isang kabataan bago
aktibista.

Kung hindi, siya ay maging inspirasyon at motibasyon ng mga mamamahayag, mag-
aaral, at ng pamantasan na tumindig sa mga hindi maka-demokratikong gawi at sa
kasinungalingan. Ito ay upang hindi muli dakipin, pahirapan, at paslangin ang
katotohanan at kalayaan.

Na hindi nila tayo madadaan sa mga Youtube vlogs (video blogs) o interviews
(panayam) para baluktutin ang kasaysayan o bigyang katwiran ang rehimeng
responsable sa pagdanak ng dugo ng daan-daaang Pilipino.

Si Liliosa Hilao ay hindi lang mamamahayag, siya ay isang kabataan bago
aktibista. Kung kaya’t sa mga kapwa nating mag-aaral sa pamantasan, manunulat
ka man, lider, volunteer, aktibista; o miyembro ng civil society
organizations, progresibong grupo; at higit sa lahat ay isang kabataan, huwag
tayong magbulag-bulagan sa mga kamalian, kapalpakan, at kasinungalingan.
Tayo’y tumindig. Tumindig para sa ating kapwa Pilipino. Tumindig para sa ating
bayan.

# Kwento mo sa Pagong

Isinulat ni John Coby Cabuhat • Pubmat ni Mary Joy Cerniaz | 30 November 23

Sa bagal, halos maihahalintulad na sa pagong ang paghingi ng pananagutan mula
sa kataastaasang konseho ng mga mag-aaral sa pamantasan.

Dalawa sa mga prinsipyo ng mabuting pamamahala ay ang may pananagutan
(accountability) at walang kinukubli (transparency). Sa pagsulong nito, huwag
naman kumilos na parang isang pagong.

Nagsisilbing patunay sa kabulukan ng konseho ang pagbibitiw at paghingi nang
pananagutan ng Auditor at Public Relations Officer ng Supreme Student Council.
Ilan man ang sangkot, ito ay pasanin ng Pangulo. Pasanin niya ang mga bawat
gawi at asal ng mga kapwa niya tagapaglingkod.

Sa pagpapanagot sa Pangulo, parang nakikipag-usap ang mga mag-aaral, na
humihingi ng pananagutan, sa isang pagong.

Tinatanong nang karamihan kung kumusta na ba at ano na ang nangyari sa mga
proseso. Parang isang pagong, binigyan lang tayo ng tugon na ito ay umuusad pa
rin. Paano ito umuusad? Sino-sino ang namamahala?

Bilang isang organisasyon na may ‘autonomy,’ o kakayahang pamunuan ang sarili,
isang panloob (internal) na proseso ang impeachment. Kung hindi man magbitiw,
ito ang maaaring magpanagot sa pamamagitan ng mayorya (majority) ng mga
opisyal sa konseho. Maaaring gabayan pero dapat igalang ng mga tagapayo ng
konseho at administrasyon ng pamantasan ang proseso at botohan ng mga mag-
aaral.

May iilan nang mga kinatawan sa loob mismo ng konseho ang nagtatanong
patungkol sa proseso pero tahimik ang mga nasa taas. Samantala, ano naman ang
ginawa ng iba pang nasa konseho? Clout lang ba talaga ang pagtakbo ninyo?

Bumuo kayo ng mayorya at kung nilabag ang konstitusyon ng konseho at wala na
kayong tiwala sa pangulo, maaari kayong bumuto na siya ay patalsikin. Tumindig
ang mga Kolehiyo at pakilusin ang mga kinatawan sa konseho. Pagusapan na lang
sa susunod ang gagawin sa iba kung hindi pa sila mahiya at magbitiw.

Hindi kinakailangan ng pormal na kaso na dadaan pa sa buhol-buhol na proseso
at sa sistema na hindi man lang alam ng karamihan ng mga mag-aaral. Nabanggit
ko na ito noon.

Clout lang ba talaga ang pagtakbo ninyo?

Bumuo kayo ng mayorya at kung nilabag ang konstitusyon ng konseho at wala na
kayong tiwala sa pangulo, maaari kayong bumuto na siya ay patalsikin. Tumindig
ang mga Kolehiyo at pakilusin ang mga kinatawan sa konseho. Pagusapan na lang
sa susunod ang gagawin sa iba kung hindi pa sila mahiya at magbitiw.

Hindi kinakailangan ng pormal na kaso na dadaan pa sa buhol-buhol na proseso
at sa sistema na hindi man lang alam ng karamihan ng mga mag-aaral. Nabanggit
ko na ito noon. Babangitin ko muli ngayon.

Isang kahihiyan sa pamantasan na may konsehong hindi mapanagot, hindi ang
paglalantad ng mga isyung ito sa lahat. Napilay na ang konseho sa pagkakataong
nawawalan na ng tiwala ang mga mag-aaral. Hindi ito magbabago kahit manatili
ang inaasahan sanang mga tagapaglingkod.

Maaaring ito na rin ang huling kolum na maisusulat ng inyong lingkod mamahayag
patungkol dito, kung kaya at isang paanyaya na mabalikan ang iba pang punto sa
isyung ito:

BASAHIN: Student Governance is Student Trust

[ _https://www.angpamantasan.org/opinion/student-governance-is-student-
trust_](https://www.angpamantasan.org/opinion/student-governance-is-student-
trust)

Muli, hindi komplikado ang magpanagot kung hindi nangangailangan lamang ng
pagtindig. Hindi dapat parang pagong (mabagal) sa pagkilos, kung hindi dapat
iisa ang yapak.

# PLM alumni hails its first topnotcher in real estate appraiser exam

Written by Rinoa Angeline Dela Torre | 12 September 23

Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) placed one topnotcher and achieved an
85.71% passing rate during the Real Estate Appraiser licensure exams, Sept.
12.

Among the 596 takers, PLM Business School (PLMBS) graduate Arianne Millene
Lorenzo Villa snagged the 10th place with a grade of 85.50%.

PLMBS graduate Patricia Mae Masanga, the first taker and passer of Real Estate
Appraiser licensure exam, and Villa, were among the first batch of graduates
from PLM’s Real Estate Management program.

According to the PRC's official results, the Pamantasan have reached above the
national passing rate which stood at 70.20%.

Manila’s premier university started offering the Bachelor of Science in Real
Estate Management program back in 2018.
