# Mayor Lacuna vows to grant incentives to PLM, UDM grads

Written by Angel Crismar Joy Udtohan • Board by Rinoa Angeline Dela Torre | 9 August 24

Graduates of Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) and Universidad de Manila
(UDM) will soon receive “incentives” after Manila Mayor Maria Sheilah “Honey”
Lacuna-Pangan has announced that she would ask the City Council to draft an
ordinance, Aug.7.

“Ipapakiusap natin sa konseho na gumawa sila ng isang ordinansa na bigyan ng
incentive ang mga bawat isang matatapos ang kanilang kurso sa ating dalawang
unibersidad,” the mayor said.

The announcement was made during the commencement exercises of UDM, stating
that it will be a “graduation gift” for all graduates and an inspiration to
what she called “Mga Iskolar ng Maynila” to finish their studies.

“Hangad ko na magamit ninyo ang lahat ng inyong karunungan at kaalaman upang
lalong palaguin ang inyong sarili at matulungan ang inyong pamilya, pamayanan,
at bayan,” she added.

Other cities have already started giving incentives to their graduates, such
as Valenzuela City, which grants P1,500–P2,500 to their scholars, and Pasig
City, with a generous amount of P20,000–P30,000.

# AP Bren snatches M5 victory, cements PH dominance with four straight MLBB
world titles

Written by Kyla Camilla Martinez • Board by Arjay Samson | 27 December 23

The champs are back!

AP Bren from the Philippines secured its second world title against the
championship-hungry Indonesia's Onic Esports, 4-3 in their final showdown
match held at the Rizal Memorial Coliseum, Dec. 17.

The country’s best made history in Mobile Legends: Bang Bang (MLBB) after they
came back to their throne as the first team with two world titles following
their successful M2 run last 2021.

The roaring home crowd now has four world titles, with Blacklist International
and Echo Philippines reigning the M3 and M4, respectively.

Bren clinched victory by aggressively attacking the exposed midlane and
finally ending the best of seven series grand finals against the resilient
Onic.

David "FlapTzy" Canon earned the MVP award for his notable performance as one
of the best EXP laners in MLBB worldwide.

"Mga teammates ko 'yung nagpanalo...actually, nagpatalo pa nga ako nung nag
Arlott ako...[tapos] 'di ko aakalain, parang ano...surreal," FlapTzy said in
an interview by ONE ESports on MLBB's awarding ceremony when asked why he is
surprised by his MVP award.

With the said victory, AP Bren bagged the M5 world championship and their
share from a prize pool of USD 900,000.

# Love Always Comes Home: Unpacking the Balikbayan Box

Written by Marian Sophia Carreon • Board by Angelle Valbuena | 1 January 24

“Atin na kaya ‘yan?” Echoes of excitement fill the house as family members
peer through windows to catch a glimpse of the LBC truck in the neighborhood.
As if the long-awaited promise has taken form, Balikbayan boxes are delivered
on doorsteps, believed to be carrying not only souvenirs from a foreign land
but also the heartfelt sentiments of a family member working abroad. This
long-standing tradition takes place in Christmas and for the much-eager
Filipinos, gifts pour in as early as September.

Having begun in the 1980’s during the Marcos regime, the term, “balik-bayan,”
is a combination of two words: balik meaning “return” and bayan meaning
“place”- sometimes translated as “home.” It was coined to inspire nationalism
and reinforce connection between families despite a distance spanning seas
apart due to its tax-free incentives back then. Ranging from cans of Vienna
sausage and Spam to Victoria Secret perfumes and branded clothing, a
Balikbayan box contains desired products that are cheaper when bought in other
countries or believed to have better quality than local ones.

And with how the number of OFWs have been fluctuating over the years, it seems
plausible that more boxes are on the way. As per the 2022 survey of the Social
Weather Stations, 1 out of 5 Filipinos aspire to live abroad while there are
currently 1.96 million OFWs. It is not a stretch to say that foreign horizons
have always been a great standard of success for Filipinos where a better life
is promised– a product of colonialist ideals where Western commodities reign
superior over local ones.

These adapted values of quality have shone a light upon American products as
symbols of modernity and luxury in Philippine society, fueling the social
prestige that can only be afforded by an OFW’s family. Being a prominent mark
of diaspora, Balikbayan boxes bridge the emotional divide between Filipinos
overseas and their loved ones back home while narrating a story of migration,
hope, and resilience.

**_All for the Family_**

In the Filipino culture, no words can ever sufficiently describe the bond of a
family as it is held in the highest regard, an absolute in the life of every
Filipino. Family has always been the foremost priority, driving many to work
abroad in hopes of affording life’s comfort and luxuries in a poverty-filled
country. With Balikbayan boxes, OFWs send out a message that they are still
with the family; however, along with that loving reminder, it is a box stamped
with a strong message of sacrifice. Fueling the Filipinos’ theme of
sacrificial love, Balikbayan boxes perpetuate a cycle of resilience for the
OFW and _utang na loob_ for the receiver, which is most often their children.
Consequently, this debt of gratitude lingers among the children as they learn
to pay it through questionless obedience and devotion for their family.

Family has always been the foremost priority, driving many to work
abroad in hopes of affording life’s comfort and luxuries in a poverty-filled
country. With Balikbayan boxes, OFWs send out a message that they are still
with the family; however, along with that loving reminder, it is a box stamped
with a strong message of sacrifice. Fueling the Filipinos’ theme of
sacrificial love, Balikbayan boxes perpetuate a cycle of resilience for the
OFW and _utang na loob_ for the receiver, which is most often their children.
Consequently, this debt of gratitude lingers among the children as they learn
to pay it through questionless obedience and devotion for their family.

_Sa susunod ay ako naman ang tutulong._

There has always been a social cost in exchange for this dream, and with the
growing number of Filipino emigrants, this ideology is being passed down
generations because we never learn or, better yet, have a choice to stay and
find success in our own country. Working overseas was once seen as a means of
escaping poverty, and now, poverty has become such a commodity that the path
of becoming an OFW has turned into a custom, even expectation. Balikbayan
boxes embody the social obligation existing between the OFW and receiver,
ingraining a sense of duty and commitment out of this sacrifice. With this,
the social cost extends towards a need for reciprocity, a constant yearning
from both sides to receive any indication of “I remember you.”

**_A House is Different from a Home_**

Moving abroad was their golden ticket out of poverty and through it, Filipinos
earn wages they could never have dreamt of in the Philippines. But despite
this, OFWs suffer a spiritual and cultural dislocation in a country that is
not their own. The glorified backdrop of an OFW would always have a shadow of
sacrifice and homesickness, molded into regrets of what they have missed at
home. Challenges of liminality arise where they are stuck between here and
there, having to adjust to an entirely new place that some never do. Since no
matter its issues, there is still no place like home.

Initially used to describe a Filipino returning home, what now remains is a
special symbolic box that, in a way, serves as a proxy of a person that should
have been there in the important season of Christmas. More than a love letter,
it can also be a gift of guilt, meant to replace the presence of the OFW
themself- an absence bubble-wrapped by precious luxuries and souvenirs to deem
it unnoticeable.

The Balikbayan box is an iconic representation of the resilience and
adaptability in the unwavering Filipino spirit upon the harsh landscape of
diaspora. Rather than its contents, perhaps what matters most is the
preparation and thoughtfulness weaved into the creation of the box. A
cardboard box that was born out of a necessity to deliver items has become a
tradition of sacrifice, togetherness, and family within the global community
of Filipinos; all of which can ultimately be traced down to what stays through
trials of time and distance– love.

# The Healing Harmony: A PLM-based Christmas Tale

Written by Charyll Joan Pascua and Erick James Cabuang • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz • Photos from The Brotherhood of Medical Scholars | 31 December 23

In the many things that we do not know of in this life, what we do know is how
meaningful Christmas is to any child. For them it unfolds as a season of pure
joy, echoing the melodious carols that resonate through their neighborhoods.
To them, each moment is filled with excitement as they unwrap their holiday
gifts. In their world, it is a delightful time to indulge in merry feasts
shared with their beloved families. The words that could ever live up to
capture the essence of not experiencing these gifts of youth— remain words
many are yet to know.

But then, one of the things we realize in life is that it is not always fair.
Because while some children revel in the vibrant lights of the streets, in the
pediatric wards of Ospital ng Maynila Medical Center (OM), a different scene
unfolds. Sick children lie confined to their beds, separated from the warmth
of the season, bravely enduring every pang of pain. Their closest taste of
Christmas is in the guise of medicine, disguised in fruit-flavored syrups, a
feeble attempt to resemble candy. Alongside their caregivers, they strive to
find comfort, consoling one another amid fears of bad news, diverting their
minds from the unanswerable question “What could a child possibly have done to
deserve being in the hospital—especially on Christmas?”

This is a scene that the medical students of Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila
(PLM) are all too familiar with. As they attend to the pediatric ward of OM,
witnessing their little patients feeling excluded from the festivities beyond
the hospital’s white walls tugged at their hearts. Despite their dedicated
efforts to offer the best care to the patients, they couldn’t help but feel
that their best fell short—especially with evident supply challenges in the
ward, with some doctors using personal funds to address the lacking hospital
supplies for the children. Their hearts went out to the patients in the
pediatric ward and the OM itself, and they knew they needed to do something.
For Neil Gabriel Pascual and many of the other medical students, they share
the same sentiment “...to be a ray of light amidst the unfortunate
circumstances of these children.”

And so, as a fruit of this compassion and burden, “Pasko na Pedia ko” came
into existence.

“Pasko na Pedia ko” is a heartfelt initiative that takes place every December,
dedicated to providing essential support to the pediatric ward of Ospital ng
Maynila. Spearheaded by the Brotherhood of Medical Scholars, an organization
comprising PLM medical students, this project seeks donations in the form of
monetary contributions, toys, and hospital supplies. Originating in the late
1990s with the vision of then-student Dr. Jonathan-Morley Ramirez, “Pasko na
Pedia ko” has evolved into a cherished annual tradition, sustained through the
close collaboration of the Brothers of Medical Scholars with the university
community.

“‘Yung mga bata kasi parang ‘di nila kasalanang [nasa] ospital sila.

“Pasko na Pedia ko” is a heartfelt initiative that takes place every December,
dedicated to providing essential support to the pediatric ward of Ospital ng
Maynila. Spearheaded by the Brotherhood of Medical Scholars, an organization
comprising PLM medical students, this project seeks donations in the form of
monetary contributions, toys, and hospital supplies. Originating in the late
1990s with the vision of then-student Dr. Jonathan-Morley Ramirez, “Pasko na
Pedia ko” has evolved into a cherished annual tradition, sustained through the
close collaboration of the Brothers of Medical Scholars with the university
community.

“‘Yung mga bata kasi parang ‘di nila kasalanang [nasa] ospital sila. ‘Di ba
‘pag matanda ka parang [to] some extent kasalanan mo na nasa ospital kasi
siguro dahil sa lifestyle mo or what. Pero ‘pag bata ka hindi mo kasalanang
nasa ospital ka,” said Mar Klain Aggabao, a member of the said organization.

(It feels like the kids don’t deserve to be in the hospital. When you look at
adults, to some extent you may think that their lifestyle could have
contributed to why they’re in the hospital. But for kids, you can’t fault them
for being in a hospital.)

Embarking on this year’s “Pasko na Pedia ko” came with its own set of
challenges, particularly as the annual project faced a pause in 2020 when the
pandemic struck. The organizers found themselves grappling with uncertainties,
placing a significant focus on societal shifts that necessitated thoughtful
consideration for this year’s endeavors. Questions weighed heavily on their
minds: “How can hospital supplies be enhanced to address potential new patient
needs?” and “Will we garner sufficient support to ensure these supplies are
delivered in time for Christmas?” Undeterred by lingering questions, the
organizers, driven by their dedication to bringing Christmas joy to patients
facing health challenges, took the first steps in the donation drive.

In the early stages of organizing the initiative, as the school opened its
doors in the first few months, the organizers diligently compiled the
schedules of the organization’s members. This meticulous planning allowed them
to seamlessly chart out schedules for the drive and other community services.
Over the subsequent months, they proactively inquired about the essential
supplies the hospital’s pediatric ward required. Approaching the kick-off of
the donation drive, they initiated discussions regarding the platforms for
promoting the drive on social media and explored effective methods to
encourage people to contribute generously, successfully concluding the initial
phases of the project.

On December 5, the donation drive commenced and brought forth a surge of
unknowns for the organizers. Despite their excitement, they couldn’t help but
feel apprehensive about the possible changes in our society. Concerns about
rising inflation added to their worries, as it could impact the support they
might receive from the PLM community. The unpredictable state of unity was
also a cause for concern, especially noteworthy as classes had shifted to
online platforms for the past two years, a stark departure from the
conventional campus setting.

Embodying the phrase “Working in harmony, we create a beautiful symphony of
change,” the support of the PLM community provided radiant and heart-warming
answers to these uncertainties. In spite of the challenges of rising commodity
prices, students grappling with financial constraints consistently returned to
the booth and contributed to the drive. This dedication expanded beyond
students; PLM alumni, spanning from nearby and distant locations, made the
journey to the campus to deliver their contributions. The faculty members
showcased equal support, as highlighted by the generosity of both the Dean of
the College of Medicine and the University’s president, who not only
heightened the visibility of the drive but also set a positive example.

Exceeding their commitment, the members of the Brotherhood of Medical Scholars
dedicated hours to studying in the donation booth, foregoing more comfortable
review spaces. Sacrificing sleep and personal indulgence, they diligently
managed the donation booth and provided timely updates on the project.
Motivated by their aspiration to provide gifts to the children in the
hospital, they took their online quizzes at the booth, attended classes on
campus only to promptly return to the stall after class, and organized shifts
to continuously man it. Their unwavering solidarity, combined with the
generosity of all PLM students, faculty, and alumni, resulted in abundant
donations.

And so, come December 19, the prescription of pediatric delight was
administered to these children, casting a magical glow over the ward.

Exceeding their commitment, the members of the Brotherhood of Medical Scholars
dedicated hours to studying in the donation booth, foregoing more comfortable
review spaces. Sacrificing sleep and personal indulgence, they diligently
managed the donation booth and provided timely updates on the project.
Motivated by their aspiration to provide gifts to the children in the
hospital, they took their online quizzes at the booth, attended classes on
campus only to promptly return to the stall after class, and organized shifts
to continuously man it. Their unwavering solidarity, combined with the
generosity of all PLM students, faculty, and alumni, resulted in abundant
donations.

And so, come December 19, the prescription of pediatric delight was
administered to these children, casting a magical glow over the ward. As the
gifts were bestowed upon the eager children, their faces transformed into
radiant expressions of pure joy and heartfelt gratitude, the culmination of a
project that had become a beacon of hope. The medical staff of OM, touched by
the profound impact, conveyed their deep appreciation to the tireless
organizers and the expansive embrace of the PLM community for this
transformative initiative. In a crescendo of emotion, through the resounding
symphony of giving by Medical Students and the unwavering spirit of the PLM
Community, “Pasko na Pedia ko 2023” reached its triumphant and heartwarming
conclusion, leaving an indelible mark on the hearts of all involved.

For Kymtoby Andres and the Brotherhood of Medical Scholars, the Gift of giving
does not wish to end here. “Nagstart ang ‘Pasko na Pedia ko’ sa PLM, [pero]
hindi nating inaasahang mag-eend lang siya sa PLM. Inaasahan naming
magkakaroon pa kami soon ng mas marami pang partners sa project na ito [sa]
other universities or outside organizations.” said Andres, one of the
organizers.

(“Pasko na Pedia ko” started here at PLM, but we don’t expect it to only end
here. We hope to expand soon and get more partners for this project in other
universities or outside organizations.)

And while we all know that the festive spirit of Christmas and the opportunity
to be a blessing to others don’t come to an end here, the narrative of 'Pasko
na Pedia ko' concludes for now, leaving every PLMayer the message of enduring
generosity, compassion, and the potential for stories like this to echo far
beyond the walls of our beloved _Pamantasan_.

# Mahiya naman kayo!

Written by John Coby Cabuhat • Board by John Ivan Pasion | 12 November 23

Bawal ang magbigay ng pera, pabor o anuman kapalit ang boto. Bawal mangampanya
labas sa nominasyon ng halalan ng Pederasyon ng Sangguniang Kabataan (SK).

Mahiya naman tayo bilang mga kabataan na sa bawat pandidiri sa maduming
politika, pangunguna bilang isang modelo sa komunidad, at pagsulong ng
pagbabago at pag-unlad, ay magiging alipin lang din ba tayo ng mga korap na
gawain.

Sa pagkakahalal ng mga miyembro ng SK ng daan-daang barangay sa Maynila,
gaganapin naman ang halalan para sa Panglungsod na Pederasyon ng SK sa Martes,
Nobyembre 14.

Ipinagbabawal ang pagkakaloob ng anuman kapalit tulad ng pera o pabor para o
laban sa SK Chairperson o miyembro ng Panglungsod na Pederasyon. Hindi rin
pinahihintulutan ang pagbibigay ng transportasyon, pagkain o inumin.

Dagdag pa rito, hindi rin maaari ang pangangampanya sa labas ng nominasyon
higit na ng mga opisyal ng pamahalaan, SK Chairperson, at kamag-anak. Bawal
magpamigay o maglathala kahit sa social media ng anumang patungkol sa pagboto
ng miyembro para sa pederasyon.

Habang tanging sa nominasyon ng mga miyembro lamang maaaring magpakilala ang
mga SK Chairperson na gustong kumandidato. Ito ay sa pamamagitan ng pagbibigay
ng talumpati na hindi lalagpas sa limang minuto.

Lahat ng ito ay ipinagbabawal sa loob ng limang araw bago at matapos ang
halalan ng pederasyon ayon sa Joint Memorandum Circular No. 2017-01 Section
21, na inulit sa Memorandum Circular No. 2023-168 mula sa Department of the
Interior and Local Government, Commission on Elections, at National Youth
Commission.

Sa pagkakataon na naniniwala tayo sa kakahayan ng kabataan na baguhin paunti-
unti ang sistema ng politika, nakakapanghinayang na nariyan pa rin ang
pagkakataong magpakaalipin sa korapsyon.

Paano ipagkakatiwala ang Pederasyon, lalo na ang pagkapangulo nito, na siyang
kakatawan sa kabataang Manilenyo sa Sangguniang Panglungsod kung bago pa
lamang maihalal ay korap na?

Paano maniniwala ang mga kabataang Manilenyo sa mga polisiya na maaaring
maisulat at maimungkahi sa konseho kung walang kakayang sumunod sa batas?

Sa pagkakataon na naniniwala tayo sa kakahayan ng kabataan na baguhin paunti-
unti ang sistema ng politika, nakakapanghinayang na nariyan pa rin ang
pagkakataong magpakaalipin sa korapsyon.

Paano ipagkakatiwala ang Pederasyon, lalo na ang pagkapangulo nito, na siyang
kakatawan sa kabataang Manilenyo sa Sangguniang Panglungsod kung bago pa
lamang maihalal ay korap na?

Paano maniniwala ang mga kabataang Manilenyo sa mga polisiya na maaaring
maisulat at maimungkahi sa konseho kung walang kakayang sumunod sa batas?

Kung maaaring kultura na ito sa politka, kailangang baguhin ng kabataan. Kung
may sapat namang kakayahan, mabuting kagustuhan, mahahalagang karanasan, at
magandang ‘credentials,’ hindi na kailangang kumapit sa pamamahagi ng pera o
maging sa kahit na ano mang pabor para maihalal ng kapwa SK Chairperson.

Sa mga SK Chairperson na naihalal, mahiya naman at itaas ang antas ng
pamamahala sa kabisera ng bansa. Bilang mga kabataan ng Lungsod ng Maynila,
mamamalagi ba sa ganitong tradisyunal na politika? Tradisyon na patuloy na
lumalason sa pag-asang may pagbabago sa pamamahala sa mga SK ng lungsod.

Tandaan na malaki ang mandato ng pederasyon. Ang tagapangulo nila ang
mangangasiwa ng pagbuo ng Local Youth Development Plan na lalamanin ang mga
programa, proyekto at aktibidad para sa mga kabataan ng Maynila. Katuwang nito
ang Local Youth Development Council na binubuo ng ilang mga organisasyon ng at
para sa kabataan.

Nakasalalay dito ang mga programang maaaring magbigay solusyon sa krisis sa
edukasyon, pagpasok sa pag-aaral at kolehiyo, suporta para sa mga working
students o kabataang manggagawa, kasangkutan sa krimen, paggamit ng droga,
teenage pregnancy, diskriminasyon at iba na hamon para sa mga kabataang
Manilenyo.

Katulad ng isang Konsehal, mauupo ang Pangulo ng Pederasyon sa sangguniang na
tatanggap ng parehong sahod at benepisyo. Maaari pa itong magkaroon ng budget
para sa opisina nito sa kanyang gampanin bilang miyembro ng sanggunian.

Kaya bago tumanggap ng limang daan, isang libo, dalawa, o tatlo, isipin ang
nakasalalay. Kawawa ang mga SK sa Maynila. Kawawa ang mga kabataang Manilenyo.
Sapagkat sila ay pamumunuan ng korap na kapwa nila kabataan. Ang hamon sa
paparating na halalan ng pederasyon, sa lahat ng SK Chairperson, ay itaguyod
ang prinsipyo ng katapatan at pananaig ng batas. Tandaan na may bumibili ng
boto dahil may tumatanggap.

Higit kailanman, inaasahan na mas may alam ang kabataan sa ideyalismo ng
mabuting pamamahala at politika sa bansa. Puno ang kabataan ng kanilang
kasigasigan buhat nang mas batang edad, interes na mapayabong pa ang isipan
bilang isang mag-aaral, at kaalaman sa reyalidad ng kabulukan at pag-asa sa
sistema.

Katuwang ang mga ito, bitbit ang ideyalismo, malaki ang mandato na
makapaghatid ng pag-unlad sa kultura, mga gawi, at kaisipan ng politika ang
mga kabataang Manilenyo sa lungsod at sa Pilipinas.

# SSC Core Comm elects acting officers due to vacancies

Written by Calvin Agustin • Board by Joseph Andrei Torres | 27 December 23

The PLM Supreme Student Council (SSC) called its Core Committee for an
emergency meeting after the resignations of select executive officers and
college representatives via Microsoft Teams, Dec. 22.

The emergency meeting was called after SSC President Vince Edrick De Guzman,
Treasurer Sophia Ryzel Pitero, College Representatives Jastine De Guzman
(COE); Jomarie Soriano (CED); and Rey Lagoc (PLMBS) have informed the Core
Committee that they have sent their resignation letters to the respective
channels last Dec. 21.

Through PLM SSC Resolution Nos. 20, 21, the council has ratified the
resignation of the aforementioned individuals and declared them clear of any
deliverables. For Vince De Guzman and Pitero’s case, their resignation shall
be in effect Dec. 23 and their positions shall be declared vacant on the same
date.

Afterwards, the council moved towards the second agenda for the emergency
meeting; to elect acting officers for the vacant positions in the council.

As result of the election, 18 out of 30 members of the Core Committee voted
for Acting Public Relations Officer John Coby Cabuhat as the Acting President
of the highest student governing body while 15 votes were recorded for COE
College Representative Steve Cophernicus Galve as the Acting Auditor. However,
the Treasurer position shall remain vacant due to the insufficient number of
votes rendered upon the nominees.

Meanwhile, the election for the position of Public Relations Officers shall be
conducted in a following meeting since Cabuhat needs to assume position as the
Acting President while the position of Treasurer will still be discussed
whether it will be subjected for an election or it will be opened for student
application.

Before the meeting was adjourned, Cabuhat expressed his gratitude to the
college student council presidents for their presence and observance in the
said meeting, as well as their support to the future plans of the council.

“We will be releasing a solidarity statement to reassure the students that
with this development, the SSC will continue to govern, will continue to help
them, will continue to serve, and that we will be committed in regaining [the]
trust of the students,” Cabuhat said.

The PLM Student Commission on Elections and Ang Pamantasan were invited in the
said meeting as observers.

# IN PHOTOS | VAWC

Caption by Janelle Ugot • Photos by Janelle Ugot and Shane Duque | 28 November 23

Various sectors from the City of Manila joined the unity walk to kickstart the
city's 18-day campaign for a VAW-free Manila on Tuesday, November 28 at
Kartilya ng Katipunan.

The said unity walk was held in accordance with Proclamation 1172, s. 2006,
declaring that November 25 to December 12 will annually be devoted to an
18-day campaign to end violence against women and will be actively supported
and participated by "[a]ll departments and agencies of the national
government, including state colleges and universities, Local Government Units
(LGUs) and all the other sectors of society."

# Ang Pamantasan announces its new key editors on its transition and turnover
conference

Written by Calvin Agustin • Board by John Ivan Pasion | 20 July 24

Ang Pamantasan, the official student publication of Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng
Maynila, presented its newly-appointed key editors for A.Y. 2024-2025 during
its Transition and Turnover Conference 2024 at the Justo Albert Auditorium,
July 20.

From the 11 qualified applicants who took the Editorial Examination (EdEx)
last July 6-7, Calvin Kristan R. Agustin was appointed as the Editor-in-Chief,
Zarena C. Hermogeno as the Associate Editor, and Jeanette B. Tropa as the
Managing Editor.

Together, they shall appoint the members of the Editorial Board, the highest
governing body of the student publication, and may create additional
designations if deemed necessary.

The EdEx is the competitive journalistic examination and interview given to
qualified staff members of the student publication to determine its key
editors for the next academic year.

# The PLM Student Commission on Elections finally wraps up the Harapan 2023

Photos by Bill Ariega • Caption by Roland Justin Molato | 25 May 23

IN PHOTOS | The PLM Student Commission on Elections finally wraps up the Harapan 2023 for the College Student Councils, College Representatives, and Supreme Student Council at University Activity Center and Justo Albert Auditorium, May 24 and 25.

![Pic 2 | The PLM Student Commission on Elections finally wraps up the Harapan 2023](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F62ip4At5mMyh0B6n8iWQhe%2Feab565e8ff29262f476b1a96bcd02208%2FCopy_of_2.jpg&w=3840&q=100)![Pic 3 | The PLM Student Commission on Elections finally wraps up the Harapan 2023](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F7pAZWCYhSLIZOcFTWjy1Rv%2Ff3097d47f94b24b6ab881811231c3923%2FCopy_of_5.jpg&w=3840&q=100)![Pic 4 | The PLM Student Commission on Elections finally wraps up the Harapan 2023](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F1vBq929527KAZdrjtGzSP5%2F817caca011ca71b191ce91020a227eed%2FCopy_of_1.jpg&w=3840&q=100)![The PLM Student Commission on Elections finally wraps up the Harapan 2023 Picture 5](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F7f8pb5UvY0jbLhwlHVGsC8%2Fda90a35b26496df7855e3fe237a41636%2FIMG_9793__2_.jpg&w=3840&q=100)![The PLM Student Commission on Elections finally wraps up the Harapan 2023 Picture 6](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F1w7sFFBDp1uoTsHXduVWAB%2F92a2d6c0116353ea2061ed9604ac6dcc%2FIMG_9794__1_.jpg&w=3840&q=100)!

# PLMayers dominate 2024 Elite Smashers Anniversary Badminton Tournament men's
doubles

Written by Kyla Camilla Martinez • Board by Arjay Samson | 20 February 24

Kurt Ashley Asistores and Kevin Enzo Lim of Bachelor of Physical Education 2-1
strategically disposed their final opponents on the recently concluded 2024
Elite Smashers Anniversary Badminton Tournament for Beginner’s Level men's
doubles, 31-24 at Powerplay Bocobo Court, Manila, Feb. 9.

Before entering the championship, Lim and Asistores had the chance to watch
their final rival’s play style, and that's when they knew how to beat them
using their own tactics.

The badminton duo smashed four consecutive wins from different opponents all
throughout the tourney, 31-12, 31-21, 31-29, and 31-24.

With a tenacious show, Lim and Asistores unleashed the Haribon’s might and
strength as they managed to pin down the more aggressive players of
Polytechnic University of the Philippines (PUP) in the semi-finals, 31–29.

"Semis po kasi mas nahirapan po kami sa play style nila, mas aggressive po
sila, hindi po nila kami binibigyan ng chance maka-attack kaya naka defense
mode po kami buong game," Asistores said.

By avoiding shot errors, consistency, and a champion hungry heart, the Haribon
tandem stood their ground for their tournament win.

"The moment na panalo na kami sa game na ‘yon, ‘di pa talaga nag sink in
agad…noong nagpahinga lang kami sa benches tsaka lang naging grabe yung happy
feeling…I finally achieved what I was dreaming of ever since I was [in] high
school, which was to receive a medal from playing my favorite sport badminton,
tapos ngayon ‘di lang medal nakuha ko kundi trophy pa so I was really
overjoyed,” said Lim.

With the victory, Asistores and Lim bagged a trophy and a cash prize in their
first tournament together.

# Off the Beaten Path for Valentine’s in the Walled City

Written By Erick James Cabuang • Photos by Dean Palapar and Charyll Pascua | 14 February 24

Intramuros has no shortage of tourists and lovers going in and out of the
city. An amalgamation of modern society and Spanish colonial architecture,
Intramuros provides a quaint backdrop to many great Valentine’s ideas.

If you've ever wondered if Intramuros holds more than its familiar
attractions, we've got you covered. We've explored some of the less obvious
options, at least from our perspective, for you to consider this love month.

![1 - Balai
Maria](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F6LVHrEb5mYKL40mcOkhGSB%2F05a37bd99b8bc75b3d2995fadd86cb15%2F1_-_Balai_Maria.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

**Balai Maria**

Found along Beaterio Street, Balai Maria is an unassuming gallery restaurant
hiding in plain sight. The inside features a rustic interior adorned with
paintings from local artists available for sale. Reopened in 2022, the
restaurant serves traditional Filipino food as well as pasta dishes for the
more foreign taste buds. If you are looking for a new place to dine, Balai
Maria is a refreshing place that serves a tad more elevated local cuisine and
even better local artistry.

![2 - Balai
Maria](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F1OkqGYMKKLX1PohSwoCH99%2Ff3b84467ecbd68a4db45847fd1809d65%2F2_-_Balai_Maria.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

 __

__

__

![3 - Balai
Maria](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F4K5aN7izohtSvQ4URdfmE4%2F9e9007ee1254ffca465ec01b38fd6801%2F3_-_Balai_Maria.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

![4 - Balai
Maria](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F4iek6T1paEvFvjDNZTzzHn%2Fa28b921276f523b6ce3f78c3f791fcc7%2F4_-_Balai_Maria.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

Some of their best-sellers are the Sizzling Tofu Madness (P250) which is good
for 2-3 persons and their Bagnet Laing (P220). They are open seven days a week
from 10 a.m.-9 p.m. and regularly features exhibits in their gallery. This
National Arts Month, they’re giving homage to Filipino talent and culture
through their exhibit called Atip running from Feb 3-29.

!

[4 - Balai
Maria](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F4iek6T1paEvFvjDNZTzzHn%2Fa28b921276f523b6ce3f78c3f791fcc7%2F4_-_Balai_Maria.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

Some of their best-sellers are the Sizzling Tofu Madness (P250) which is good
for 2-3 persons and their Bagnet Laing (P220). They are open seven days a week
from 10 a.m.-9 p.m. and regularly features exhibits in their gallery. This
National Arts Month, they’re giving homage to Filipino talent and culture
through their exhibit called Atip running from Feb 3-29.

![7 - Balai
Maria](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F3zY2Uh5tezHPA1h3eeefxX%2Fb6bb0d70ee152ce41d90b625b6b59a6c%2F7_-_Balai_Maria.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

_Balai Maria is located at Knights of Columbus bldg. Council 1000, 1002
Beaterio St. For more information, you may check_[ __Balai
Maria’s__](https://www.facebook.com/balaimaria19) _Facebook page._

__

**Knights of Columbus Manila Council No. 1000**

Once you’ve had your fill, in the same building of Balai Maria is a dingy and
often overlooked hall of the Knights of Columbus Council No. 1000 where you
can try your hands at pool, table tennis, darts, and duckpin bowling. Apart
from a few locals and students, we were the only ones there during our visit
in the afternoon. According to one of its caretakers, what once was a thriving
and busy hall of the building began to wane down as people grew less and less
aware of the recreations they offered.

![1 -
KOC](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F6flGOcdV7BDusxoKKyFbBM%2Fbc44ed7e53947589397132a0de71bb79%2F1_-_KOC.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

![2 -
KOC](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F7DfL0TgoKhEAS9tu6yLH9p%2F181c210b26326c9ad6571d7bbd7cb1e5%2F2_-_KOC.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

If you’re looking for something fun and novel, we suggest you take advantage
as the place offers a decent amount of activities couples and groups can do
for very affordable rates. The pool table costs P100 to rent per hour and
their ping-pong table costs P80 per hour. Meanwhile, duckpin bowling only
costs P40 per game.

![1 -
SkyDeck](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F1hbFTnKREZlkWkGeHE3EuP%2F2ecf3ff5c11e661079e9dbbba9c65170%2F1_-_SkyDeck.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

****

****

**Skydeck Viewbar**

Their menu is relatively on the pricier side which is why it made the list.
But for those craving a touch of luxury, the view at the Skydeck Viewbar of
Bayleaf Hotel is an experience by itself.

![2 -
SkyDeck](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F1bjCt3LvtUkMOg3Ssnm5yZ%2Fc15b6ec2e215f03f94b88bf27129bc7f%2F2_-_SkyDeck.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

!

But for those craving a touch of luxury, the view at the Skydeck Viewbar of
Bayleaf Hotel is an experience by itself.

![2 -
SkyDeck](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F1bjCt3LvtUkMOg3Ssnm5yZ%2Fc15b6ec2e215f03f94b88bf27129bc7f%2F2_-_SkyDeck.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

![3 -
SkyDeck](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F6JL9CN3H7MwKL5NfBZWgvv%2F67ea46748ec848f2cb9be24697d87edb%2F3_-_SkyDeck.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

Wining and dining several feet above the ground, the alluring interior and
cozy music seamlessly complement the cool breeze and charming panorama that
greets you upon entry. If you can shell out a few extra bucks on the most
romantic month of the year, we think it’s worth giving a shot just for the
experience and scenery. Their first seating starts at 4 p.m. and runs until 7
p.m. while their second seating is from 7-11 p.m. Their starters and meals
range from P200 to P950, all exclusive of value-added tax and their service
charge of 10%.

![4 -
SkyDeck](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F4wp3k00SZfPNzSONoqHcLp%2Fb1b3d63633e8fc0e5b453f76e0834d15%2F4_-_SkyDeck.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

_Skydeck Viewbar is located at Muralla Corner Victoria Street Intramuros 1002
Manila, Philippines. For more information, you may check_[ __The Bayleaf
Intramuros
'__](https://www.facebook.com/groups/593716174327258/user/100067912009767/)_Facebook
page._

![1 - San
Agustin](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F57fyUJWwpjtZjGfFTAiuz1%2F964b0ff72323e098da1aacffb729da3c%2F1_-_San_Agustin.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

**San Agustin Museum + Cafe**

Right beside the San Agustin church sits what used to be the monastery for
Augustinian priests. Now a museum, the storied building of adobe stones houses
many religious artifacts celebrating the long history of the Augustinian order
and Catholicism in the Philippines. First conceived in 1965, San Agustin
Museum’s tranquil halls and scenic garden are perfect for people looking to
veer away from the usual flock of tourists and escape into a secluded and
quiet place at the heart of the walled city.

![2 - San
Agustin](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F5mFfJ05OcKSvdqZLkYPduG%2F04c49f64dbc189adc08843332e33c544%2F2_-_San_Agustin.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

![3 - San
Agustin](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F7gqH0YSHLk0iy1Mdm32HK3%2F11cec5c2cbf48ff883f7cec395810efc%2F3_-_San_Agustin.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

!

![2 - San
Agustin](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F5mFfJ05OcKSvdqZLkYPduG%2F04c49f64dbc189adc08843332e33c544%2F2_-_San_Agustin.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

![3 - San
Agustin](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F7gqH0YSHLk0iy1Mdm32HK3%2F11cec5c2cbf48ff883f7cec395810efc%2F3_-_San_Agustin.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

![5 - San
Agustin](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F6pWPQb8Lz5usgS1D2Ud2Lm%2F54a3e5fd4ef9025c153b3b1f0937ef3f%2F5_-_San_Agustin.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

If relics and paintings aren’t your cup of tea, then maybe a cup of coffee is.
A small cafe inside offers a selection of beverages priced from P110 to P180.
Specializing in “Napoleones,” these pastries are baked by Father Alvin, the
Augustinian priest responsible for all of the cafe’s baked goods.

![6 - San
Agustin](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F5tck6IRVfMdoCvjIuNwFv%2F351afde8cf3d9b5acb2514f812f317ea%2F6_-_San_Agustin.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

![7 - San
Agustin](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F51lK35SBCxiXVr6AlmMaJ2%2Fda964d05e24a6ddf4a73e65bb3814ede%2F7_-_San_Agustin.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

![8 - San
Agustin](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F1SDTGFqQCTFTZwGKIk20hc%2Fcad2755a13bbbc1437a1bbf931905d49%2F8_-_San_Agustin.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

Embracing the motto “Every Coffee is a Mission,” Fr. Alvin shares that a
significant portion of their sales contributes to funding for the church's
seminarians. Providing a variety of pastries and beverages, the integration of
the cafe with the museum provides for one of the most relaxing and serene
museum experiences one can have.

![1 -
Destileria](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F4NOiIh56xAkcNKdPfLJabl%2Fa18285e32c5c3fcf651aad1131df6dd3%2F1_-_Destileria.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

**Destileria Limtuaco Museum**

For P50 in Destileria Limtuaco Museum, you get a guided tour into the storied
past of the distillery responsible for the iconic White Castle Whisky and
Sioktong herbal wine. The tour takes you through the evolution of the
company’s processes in creating its liquor, as well as some of the personal
collections and items from the distillery’s history and founding. While one of
the lesser-known museums in Intramuros, a visit to the place gave us one of
the more interesting glimpses into the country’s oldest–and arguably one of
the most iconic–distilleries.

!

The tour takes you through the evolution of the
company’s processes in creating its liquor, as well as some of the personal
collections and items from the distillery’s history and founding. While one of
the lesser-known museums in Intramuros, a visit to the place gave us one of
the more interesting glimpses into the country’s oldest–and arguably one of
the most iconic–distilleries.

![3 -
Destilerias](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F65efLGjX4HLvwEoNyv1o1u%2Fd8809a8d62c4e056a8e239f863576632%2F3_-_Destilerias.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

![4 -
Destileria](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F6e6rhYLqfduwioWpWknV6D%2F787f87ea39536a305f917f4b123e8c38%2F4_-_Destileria.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

![5 -
Destileria](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F3oVNhJGwPFCmsJQ5EfefQm%2Fc73d3fb0d68458996ad094a5b9fc88e2%2F5_-_Destileria.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

Regular guests pay P100 and can choose to upgrade their tickets to premium for
P200 which will come with a liquor tasting after the tour. Fair warning, the
museum does not allow students hailing from any Intramuros schools to avail of
the premium tickets. The museum is open from 9 a.m.-6 p.m., Tuesdays-Sundays.

![6 -
Destileria](/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.ctfassets.net%2Fkt65ribdjnvr%2F5fCAbBKsYSTZsiljva8VBI%2F3d64b05f5c0e035084ff4203a631e96f%2F6_-_Destileria.jpg&w=3840&q=100)

_Destileria Limtuaco Museum is located at 482 San Juan de Letran St. For more
information, you may visit the_[ __Destileria Limtuaco
Museum__](https://www.facebook.com/DLCIMuseum) _Facebook page._

# IN PHOTOS | EdEx 2023

Caption and photos by Roland Justin Molato | 26 June 23

The Ang Pamantasan Editorial Examination (EdEx) has finally concluded last
June 27. The Oath Taking and Turnover Ceremony for the new set of
publication’s Key Editors, composed of the Editor-in-Chief, Associate Editor,
and Managing Editor, for the Academic Year 2023-2024 will be held on June 30.

![EdEx 2023

2023

# PLM College of Law opens its applications for AY 2024-2025

Written by Zarena Hermogeno • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 11 March 24

Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) - College of Law (CL) is now accepting
applications for Academic Year 2024-2025, Feb. 5

To be eligible for admission, applicants must have a general weighted average
of at least 2.00 in their bachelor’s degree and have earned 12 units of
English subjects.

Partial scholarship may be offered to Manila residents with supporting
documents such as Voter’s ID or Barangay Certification. Conversely, Non-Manila
residents may apply as “full-paying” students.

Other requirements include:

  * Transcript of Records (TOR) 

  * Letter of Recommendation from the Dean/Head of former school

  * Any government-issued ID 

  * Income Tax Return (ITR) of applicant or the applicant’s parent from the year prior to the date of application

  * Two (2) recent passport size, identical colored photos 

Applicants may submit their requirements to the College for Committee on
Admission and undergo a preliminary interview based on the criteria on
admission.

Moreover, acceptance to the college will be based on the compliance of
admission requirements; passing of the College of Law Admission Test (CLAT),
and the personal interview and evaluation by the Committee on Admissions.

PLM is remembered to have clinched a 100% passing rate in the 2020-2021 Bar
examinations and a 67.50% passing rate in the 2023 Bar Examinations.

# About Us

Ang Pamantasan (AP) is the Official Student Publication of Pamantasan ng
Lungsod ng Maynila. It is a non-partisan organization whose duties and
responsibilities are to serve as the conscience of the PLM community.

In 1968, PLM’s school organ, Sunburst, was changed to Ang Hasik to make it
sound more nationalistic. Even before the declaration of Martial Law, by then
President Ferdinand Marcos, the publication was already critical and
progressive. It was deemed to be the voice of PLM.

One notable figure in the history of this publication is Liliosa “Lili” Hilao.
She was one of the editors of this publication during her time and she was the
first victim of the government’s viciousness during the Martial Law. She was
reported to be the first case of a political prisoner’s death and her fate to
the outcry for reforms in the country.

After years of being shut down. PLM brought back its official student
publication under the name Ang Pamantasan in 1978. Up to the present, Ang
Pamantasan, still continues to serve the students with utmost honesty and
professionalism in delivering quality news that would open their eyes to the
issues, challenges, triumphs, and success of the people especially the beloved
PLM students. Adhering to the Campus Journalism Act of 1991 (RA 7079), we at
Ang Pamantasan strives to uphold and promote press freedom.

# Ang Pamantasan conducts APGA 2024

Written by Alessandra Frianela • Photos by Jonas Shane Duque | 16 May 24

The University’s official student publication conducted the Ang Pamantasan
General Assembly (APGA) and Team Building Activity 2024 with the theme “TATAK:
TAlino, TApang at Katapatan Tungo sa Mabisang Pamamahayag” held at the Bukod
Tanging Bulwagan, May 12.

APGA aims to foster connections among its staff members through a variety of
interactive activities and enlightening learning opportunities. The outcomes
of this event will enhance the publication’s networks through effective
journalism, solidify its knowledge base with industry exposure, and shape its
members into conscientious citizens beyond the academic domain. .

Mon Gualvez, an award-winning broadcast journalist known for his incisive
reporting and dedication to uncovering the truth, was invited as a resource
speaker who focused on the vital role of intelligence, courage, and honesty in
ethical journalism. The student journalists were given a chance to ask
questions after the speech was delivered. Meanwhile, the former Editor-in-
Chief and student leader, John Coby Cabuhat, delivered his discussion about
the importance of being critical as a student journalist.

In addition to the formal agenda, the afternoon session of the event included
various team building activities where the AP staffers participated in. These
activities were aimed at strengthening the camaraderie among the staff members
of the publication.

The major highlight of the event was the unveiling and ratification of the
newly-revised Editorial Policy of the publication which was presented by the
Editorial Policy Reform Committee. The Editorial Policy, which provides clear
guidelines and standards for the content, ethics, and operations of the
publication, must be revised every 5 years.

The Ang Pamantasan General Assembly is one among the annual events of the
publication.

# IN PHOTOS | COMELEC celebrates National Voters’ Day with voter registration kick-off

Written by Calvin Agustin • Photos by Roland Justin Molato | 13 February 24

The Commission on Elections (COMELEC) conducted its kick-off event for the
resumption of voter registration in line with the National Voters’ Day at the
Palacio del Gobernador, Intramuros, Feb. 12.

Nationwide voter registration will be open until Sept. 30 at the COMELEC
Office, Palacio del Gobernador, satellite and mall registration sites, as well
as sites under their Register Anywhere Program (RAP) from Monday to Saturday,
8:00 AM to 5:00 PM. However, RAP will only be open until Aug. 31.

These registration sites shall cater applications for new registration,
transfer, change or correction, reactivation, and inclusion of voter’s
records.

In an interview, COMELEC Commissioner Aimee Ferolino reminds the people to
register as early as possible to avoid the rush on the last days of
registration and to be assisted with specific registration concerns.

Moreover, the Commissioner shared there is no initial estimated number of
registrations during the kick-off event yet, but a target number by the end of
the nationwide voter registration is expected.

“Pagclose natin ng registration on September 30, we hope na makarehistro tayo
ng hindi bababa sa 2.5 million - 2.6 million. ‘Yun kasi ang target natin na
irehistro for the 2025 Elections,” Commissioner Ferolino stated.

# PLM suspends both in-person and online classes

Written by John Coby Cabuhat • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 21 September 23

Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila suspends onsite work and classes, and online
classes starting at 1:00 PM, today, Sept. 22.

This is in light of the class and work suspension from the Local Government of
Manila, according to the copy of an office order obtained by Ang Pamantasan.

The city government suspended afternoon face-to-face classes at all levels
“due to the volcanic sulfuric dioxide emission from Taal Volcano,” its Public
Information Office announced.

READ: [Manila suspends afternoon in-person
classes](https://www.facebook.com/ManilaPIO/posts/pfbid0Q695JYKrKN6SV2GsGYUyfPKiYMnchvoGfqZKVNDyaqvSbuKcXvdXhvyYmXxrz6Rvl)

In a news update from ABS-CBN, the Philippine Institute of Volcanology and
Seismology (PHIVOLCS) said that the smog over Metro Manila is “not related to
activity from Taal Volcano.”

Earlier, the Manila Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Office (MDRRMO)
reported that the haze or smog observed last night was due to meteorological
factors and not directly because of the sulfur dioxide emission from Taal
Volcano.

The city’s disaster management office added that smog or the combination of
smoke (air pollutants) and fog appears if the air pollutants are not being
dispersed properly during rainy days with weaker wind flow.

“Nangyayari ito kapag nagkaroon ng mga pag-ulan at mahinang hangin, dahil dito
ay hindi nakakadisperse ng maayos ang mga air pollutants na nagreresulta sa
mababang kalidad ng hangin at mababang bisibilidad (visibility),” the office
explained in its advisory.

MDRRMO observed a moderate level of air quality in the nation’s capital in its
advisory. The office recorded “a measurement of 30 in the Air Quality Index of
Manila” which constitutes a moderate level.

Still, in light of this, citizens were still advised to wear masks and limit
outdoor activities.

READ: [Manila DRRM Air Quality Advisory No.
2](https://www.facebook.com/sagipmanila/posts/pfbid03tCvRiGKz4VBpZq5rg2AeFDeGec6oF5U7ytWU8oLcB1n1qqEF5UgoSBPZ59G1wB6l )

RELATED: [Manila Public Information Office’s Air Quality
Advisory](https://www.facebook.com/ManilaPIO/posts/pfbid02keH1xskcojFEo7AhqXxRJtufbHyCx2GBVLcGJynXoEKtNcdbjUd87tVkbzTmv3cMl )

PHIVOLCS recorded a flux of 4569 tonnes of sulfur dioxide at the Taal Volcano
on Thursday, and on low-level unrest or Alert Level 1.

2](https://www.facebook.com/sagipmanila/posts/pfbid03tCvRiGKz4VBpZq5rg2AeFDeGec6oF5U7ytWU8oLcB1n1qqEF5UgoSBPZ59G1wB6l )

RELATED: [Manila Public Information Office’s Air Quality
Advisory](https://www.facebook.com/ManilaPIO/posts/pfbid02keH1xskcojFEo7AhqXxRJtufbHyCx2GBVLcGJynXoEKtNcdbjUd87tVkbzTmv3cMl )

PHIVOLCS recorded a flux of 4569 tonnes of sulfur dioxide at the Taal Volcano
on Thursday, and on low-level unrest or Alert Level 1.

READ: [Taal Volcano Summary of 24Hr Observation (22 September 2023 at 5:00
AM)](https://phivolcs.dost.gov.ph/volcano-hazard/volcano-bulletin2/taal-
volcano/20011-taal-volcano-summary-of-24hr-
observation-22-september-2023-5-00-am?fbclid=IwAR3-yRWgwtstWhHQ8pWOZTORSEerGUHJXnjOKeJTTZRLB2v66XnCoWtlT6A )

MDRRMO also cautioned that exposure to sulfur dioxide may cause irritation to
the eyes, throat, and respiratory tract that may worsen depending on the
concentration and duration.

In addition, citizens were advised to close windows and doors, drink more
water, and immediately seek clinical consultation if experiencing difficulties
in breathing and other effects of smog.

# 59th Founding Anniversary College Booths

Caption and Photos by Dean Joseph Palapar | 17 June 24

As part of the university's founding celebration, students from various
colleges alongside PLM Alumni present their creative and interactive booths at
the PLM Lobby, June 18, Tuesday. The booths feature achievements, games,
studies, and documentations of each college through the years, and will be
available for public viewing until Friday, June 21.

# Pamantasan sets stage for 59th Founding Anniversary, unveils week-long
festivities

Written by Rylan Gabriel Bernardo • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 9 June 24

In celebration of its 59th Founding Anniversary, the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng
Maynila (PLM) has announced its five-day schedule of activities, starting June
18 until June 22.

With the theme “Pagbabago sa Pamantasan Tungo sa Kaunlaran,” PLM is inviting
its faculty, students, staff, and alumni to join in the week-long festivities.
The celebration will commence with the commemoration of Dr. Jose P. Rizal's
birthday and parade in Intramuros.

Among the notable slate of activities prepared for the celebration are the
Binibini at Ginoong Pamantasan pageant, an invitation to the Wish 107.5 Bus,
the Passport on Wheels service, a music festival, and the PLM Alumni
Homecoming Night to be held on June 22.

# Paskuhan sa Pamantasan: Pagbibigayan sa Gitna ng Pagmahal ng Kabayaran

Written by Jan Rennie Abat • Board by Mary Joy Cerniaz | 31 December 23

Sa pagdaan ng halos isang linggo matapos ang Pasko ay huni pa rin ng _All I
want for Christmas_ ang madirinig sa tuwing papasok sa mga bilihan. Hindi lang
mga naggagandahang _Christmas tree_ , handaan, at regalo ang laman ng
_newsfeed_ dahil pati ang mga _memes_ ni Jose Mari Chan ay nariyan pa rin.
Gayunpaman, sa kabila ng nakatutuwang mga larawan ay tila idinaos ng
karamihang ordinaryong Pilipino ang Kapaskuhan nang may sakit sa bulsa buhat
ng mataas na presiyuhan sa bansa.

Sinalubong ng pagpalo ng _inflation rate_ sa 6.1 porsento mula 5.3 ang unang
buwan ng _ber months_ batay sa ulat ng Philippine Statistics Authority. Buhat
nito’y nanatiling hamon para sa mga karamihan ang maipagdiwang ang Kapaskuhan
sa huling buwan ng taon. Bukod sa salo-salo sa Noche Buena pagpatak ng ika-25
ng Disyembre ay nariyan rin ang mga kinagawiang paghahandog sa nangangaroling,
_reunion_ kasama ang mga kamag-anak, at pagkakaloob ng mga regalo. Ang
kaliwa’t-kanang gastusin kung tutuusin ay hindi maipagkakailang isang
pagsubok, higit pa sa kasalukuyang panahong isang libo’y tila hindi sapat.

Ngunit katulad lamang ng mga nagdaang taon, hindi ito hadlang upang ibahagi
rin sa iba ang saya ng Kapaskuhan. Kalahok sa pakikibahaging ito ang
iba’t-ibang organisasyon sa Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) na nagbigay
ng donasyon at nagsulong ng mga programang nakaiinit ng damdamin sa malamig na
simoy ng hangin.

**PARA SA MGA BATA**

Makikita ang mga _smiley face_ , bituin, at puso sa makulay na pulseras na
yari ng PLM Children’s Rights Advocates League (CRAdLe). Nagawa nilang
magbigay ngiti sa mga labi at ipadama sa mga bata na sila ang _star_ ng pasko
sa pamamagitan ng mga donasyon at _beaded bracelet_ na na kanilang hinulma ng
may puso.

Kalahok sa pakikibahaging ito ang
iba’t-ibang organisasyon sa Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) na nagbigay
ng donasyon at nagsulong ng mga programang nakaiinit ng damdamin sa malamig na
simoy ng hangin.

**PARA SA MGA BATA**

Makikita ang mga _smiley face_ , bituin, at puso sa makulay na pulseras na
yari ng PLM Children’s Rights Advocates League (CRAdLe). Nagawa nilang
magbigay ngiti sa mga labi at ipadama sa mga bata na sila ang _star_ ng pasko
sa pamamagitan ng mga donasyon at _beaded bracelet_ na na kanilang hinulma ng
may puso.

Ayon sa Vice-President for Internals Affairs ng PLM CRAdLe at _project head_
na si Arianna Ramos, “It was very heartwarming that we were able to celebrate
this season in such a meaningful way… In every event naman, whenever we spend
time with the children, we always go home with happy and fulfilled hearts.”

Sa tulong ng kanilang _3-day donation drive_ na “Pamaskong Handog: Pasko ng
mga Bata”, pagbebenta ng mga natirang beaded bracelets, at ang “Adopt-a-child”
na programa ng Holy Trinity Academy ay naabot nila ang humigit-kumulang 600 na
bata sa Sampaloc, Manila noong ika-16 araw ng Disyembre. Hindi lang dito
natatapos ang pagtulong, dahil kung mayroong regalo para sa mga bata at ay
mayroon din handog para sa ating mga manggagawa.

**MULA SA KABATAAN**

Dala-dala ang prinsipyong makatulong at ibsan ang paghihirap ng iba, nabuo ang
“Lovingly Youth” ng Manila Red Cross Youth (RCY). Katuwang din ang PLM RCY sa
pag-aayos ng mga donasyon, at sa ika-14 taon ng programang ito ay nakapagbigay
sila ng Noche Buena _package_ sa halos 120 _cancer patients_ ng Bahay Aruga at
_blue-collared workers_ ng Maynila.

Isa sa mga sandaling hindi malilimutan ni Zhaira Blanco, Public Relations
Officer ng Manila Chapter Youth Council at _project head_ ng Lovingly Youth,
ay ang pagtulong sa isang kaminerong may edad na at hirap pa sa pagdinig.
Dali-dali ang pagbuhos ng luha ni Nanay nang abutan siya ng mumunting regalo
para sa Pasko– at isang taos-pusong “Salamat!” ang naging paalala sa halaga ng
patuloy na pagbibigay ng serbisyong boluntaryo.

“Honestly, as the project head, I wish we could've accommodated more
volunteers to help distribute the donations so more people, particularly the
youth, would have a deeper sense of empathy and compassion for others. Kaso
since humanitarian organization ang Red Cross and we don't really have a set
budget, very very limited lang talaga ang resources…”, ani Blanco.

Tunay ngang kay hirap panatiliin ang nakagawiang selebrasyon ng Pasko sa gitna
ng pagtaas ng mga presyo. Gayunpama’y tanyag pa rin sa karamihan ang paghahari
ng diwa ng Pasko— nagsasalo-salo kasama ang mga kapamilya at bitbit ang ngiti
at mga iniwang regalong handog ng iba’t-ibang organisasyon na walang sawa sa
pagbibigay serbisyo’t liwanag tuwing Kapaskuhan.

At sa pagwawakas ng kapanahunan ng Kapaskuhan ay nananatili pa rin ang makulay
na pag-indak ng mga ilaw sa gabi– hindi pa rin lipas ang diwa ng pagmamahalan
at pagbibigayan na siya ring itinatanghal sa Pamantasan.

# ‘PLM deserves more because PLM can do more’ — Sen. Koko Pimentel

Written by Calvin Agustin • Board by John Ivan Pasion | 2 July 23

In line with PLM’s 56th founding anniversary, Senator Aquilino “Koko” Pimentel
celebrated with the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM) in its
Transformation Program at the Justo Alberto Auditorium, June 19.

Sen. Koko Pimentel, the keynote speaker of the program, highlighted PLM's
commitment in delivering quality education especially during the pandemic in
which the university opened its doors to more than 9,000 freshmen, doubling
the number of its student population. He also recognized PLM’s contributions
to the urgent needs of healthcare workers, admitting around 400 new nursing
students and 100 physical therapy students, and establishing the School of
Public Health. Also, he praised PLM and its students for their groundbreaking
performances in licensure examinations.

“Your success exemplifies the resilience, dedication, and unyielding spirit
that is nurtured within the halls of PLM… In the midst of every crisis lies
great opportunities, PLM has just proven this… Your accomplishments bear
witness to the exceptional quality of education that PLM provides,” Sen.
Pimentel said.

Moreover, Sen. Pimentel mentioned that the adequate resources provided by the
national government is still and has always been a major concern. Even the
UNIFAST tuition reimbursement program is not enough to sufficiently support
PLM’s operations. He himself has seen that some infrastructures need
rehabilitation, and libraries, laboratories, classrooms, and learning spaces
need to be modernized. Sen. Pimentel added that if PLM needs to make
amendments to its Charter, he would gladly help the university in its process.

“Allow me, with the help of Atty. George Garcia, allow us to study further
your situation because the more I understand your situation, the more I will
be in the position to help. In the next budget process, let us collaborate on
how we can help PLM with the national budget through CHED. So together, let us
find a way to pressure UNIFAST to cover at least 100% of your operating
expenses. So I therefore call for meaningful and sufficient support from the
government and the private sectors for PLM. PLM deserves more because PLM can
do more,” Sen. Pimentel said.

The senator also expressed his admiration to the university officials, that no
matter what is thrown at them, no matter what situation they find themselves
in, they have always exerted their best efforts to survive and succeed.

# It’s a Match!: Navigating the Online Dating Scene

Written by Calvin Agustin • Board by John Ivan Pasion | 13 February 24

Ever since technology gave birth to applications like _Bumble_ and _Tinder_ ,
online dating has become a hit among Millenials and Gen Zs. These applications
changed the dating game by making its user interface sort of a “jowa for hire”
application where seekers set up their personal dating profiles in hope of
capturing the interest of other seekers. Who knew that your “the one” could be
one swipe away, right?

Dating has also become more inclusive with the help of these applications by
including features such as same-gender dating for the LGBTQIA+ community, and
filters to make your search for “the one” a lot easier.

However, before ending up with a match, seekers go through the process of
matchmaking to see if there will be a spark that will ignite between them and
other seekers. To make the most out of your matchmaking journey, here are some
online dating tips you might want to take note of.

**_You as a partner_**

Before stepping into the online dating scene, you need to know who you are as
a partner. For instance, it is helpful if you know what forms of love
languages you’d want to give or receive, whether it’s quality time, physical
touch, words of affirmation, gift-giving, or acts of service. Knowing this
sets the type of person that you are looking for. You might also want to know
your desirable and undesirable traits, more known as your _green flags and red
flags_ , as this shows your potential partner how good your self-awareness is,
and that’s a green flag.

**_Your profile matters_**

Bestie, you need to dress to impress! When setting up your dating profile,
make sure to showcase your best and instagrammable photos as these will be the
first thing that fellow dating app users see on your profile before they
continue to scroll. You need to attract, not chase with these photos so you
can’t look like a raggedy doll.

Your profile should also include some of your details that you want your
potential match to know such as zodiac sign (for compatibility purposes), what
kind of connection are you looking for like a relationship or something
casual. Make sure to make your profile as ideal as possible but don’t stray
from reality, okay?

**_Know your ideal “potential match”_**

Now that you’re all set and ready to swipe, you need to know your ideal
partner like do you want a tall moreno guy or a chinita shawty girl? Are you
looking for a nonchalant boyfie or a social butterfly girlie? In dating
applications with a vast catalog of users, this will make your search easier
by setting standards. Take note that these standards are not all met and you
may need to compromise but your standards will help you in deciding whether
you’ll swipe left or swipe right._(PS. Never ever lower your standards at this
stage, or at all!)_

After the seemingly endless swiping, patiently wait and you will finally see
the “It’s a Match!” prompt on your screen and when this happens, you’re on for
a good start.

**_Learn more about your match_**

Obviously, you’re single and ready to mingle and here comes the exciting part
– mingling!

Are you
looking for a nonchalant boyfie or a social butterfly girlie? In dating
applications with a vast catalog of users, this will make your search easier
by setting standards. Take note that these standards are not all met and you
may need to compromise but your standards will help you in deciding whether
you’ll swipe left or swipe right._(PS. Never ever lower your standards at this
stage, or at all!)_

After the seemingly endless swiping, patiently wait and you will finally see
the “It’s a Match!” prompt on your screen and when this happens, you’re on for
a good start.

**_Learn more about your match_**

Obviously, you’re single and ready to mingle and here comes the exciting part
– mingling! Get to know more about your match by asking about their interests,
hobbies, lifestyle, as well as their principles and perspective in life.
Knowing these will help you think whether these discoveries sit well with you
or not. Sometimes, it would make you even more curious about them.

Since you’ve already seen their profile, you may also want to ask more about
the details they have posted in their profile such as their favorite
activities, and music taste to see the ones you have in common. This will be
useful in maneuvering your conversations as you get to know each other. Also,
try to ask some things that are not posted on their profile, who knows, you
might be surprised…

**_Smash or pass?_**

After getting to know your match, sit still and keep contact with them for a
consistency check. Observe whether their energy towards you is consistent or
changing as the days go by because this will determine how your dynamic will
go on a daily basis. Simultaneously, try to assess if their personality is a
match with what you’re looking for, if they depict the “ideal partner” you
have pictured before having met them. If yes, then smash, if no, then pass and
keep swiping.

**_Create your idea of a relationship_**

You’re almost at the end of the line (hopefully)! This is where things get
more serious and deeper as you need to communicate your idea of a relationship
to one another. Remember that a relationship is not a one size fits all, it
would still depend on your dynamic as a potential couple.

Talk about things such as roles in the relationship (Who does what?),
communication practices, boundaries, and most importantly, label. This is the
most difficult thing to ask from a partner but this plays a vital role in your
relationship. Just remember to not ask too early nor too late, find the
perfect timing. Always check the label!!

Can you imagine? From the traditional “pag-akyat ng ligaw” and “harana”, we
are now in a time where dating is just at the tip of our fingers. However,
dating being this easy does not always mean it’s effective. What works for you
might not work for others or vice versa. Hence, it’s still up to you on how
you can make online dating work for you.

Anyways, these are just some _landi-tips_ to make your online dating journey
more exciting and purposeful. It would be much better if you have a unique
approach to it to make you more remarkable. Nonetheless, just enjoy but not
too much because you only love once right, or no?

# Parade for Filipino Olympians 2024

Students, faculty, and employees of the Pamantasan gather along Padre Burgos
Avenue to welcome the nation’s athletes after their journey at the Paris 2024
Olympics.

The parade will come from the Aliw Theater, passing through Roxas Boulevard,
Padre Burgos Avenue, Finance Road, and Taft Avenue, heading to Rizal Coliseum.

# IMAHEstranghero: Nang minsang nagtagpo ang pagngiti at pagpitik

Written by Vince Villanueva • Board by Roland Justin Molato | 28 May 23

Siksik sa samu’t saring emosyon, may mga natatanging kwento at karamihan ay
estranghero. Ilan lamang iyan sa mga larawang kuha sa saglit na pagtatagpo ng
ngiti at pitik. Walang pinipiling paksa ang One Pics; magbabarkada,
magkasintahan o kahit mag-isa ka man, lahat ng iyan ay maaaring makuhanan ng
larawan at makabuo ng alaala.

Patok ngayon sa Pamantasan ang maniniyot na si Joreian A. Requitillo, 22 taong
gulang, o mas kilala sa tawag na “One Pics.” Inaabangan ng karamihan sa labas
ng Pamantasan hindi lang dahil sa palagi nitong pagkuha ng mga larawan bagkus
sa kakaibang sayang nadudulot nito sa mga mag-aaral.

Ang estilo ng pagkuha ng larawan ng One Pics ay tinatawag na “random
photography” at “street photography,” isang nauusong estilo kung saan samu’t
saring estranghero, mapa-estudyante man o tipikal na Pilipino na nakikita sa
kalye ang nagiging sentro at paksa sa isang imahe.

Ang unang pagpitik

Nagsimula ang pagiging maniniyot ni Requitillo noong nakaraang taon sa
kaniyang probinsyang kinalakhan, ang Bacolod. Matapos ang kursong kinuha niya
sa kolehiyo, pinagpatuloy naman niya ang kaniyang pangarap sa Maynila at mag-
asikaso ng mga papeles para makahanap ng trabaho. Ginamit naman niya ang mga
libreng oras niya dito sa Maynila upang ipagpatuloy ang hilig sa pagkuha ng
mga litrato. Malaking bahagi para sa unang pagpitik ng “One Pics” ay ang
pagmamahal niya sa kaniyang larangan at sa mga magagandang komentong
natatangap niya sa mga estranghero’t estudyante katulad na lamang ng mga
Haribon.

Pinatutunayan lamang ni Requitillo na ang pagiging malikhain at pagmamahal sa
napiling larangan, bagama’t mahirap at tiyak na malaking pagsubok, ay higit na
mas kasiya-siya at nagreresulta sa isang matamis na bunga.

Ginamit naman niya ang mga
libreng oras niya dito sa Maynila upang ipagpatuloy ang hilig sa pagkuha ng
mga litrato. Malaking bahagi para sa unang pagpitik ng “One Pics” ay ang
pagmamahal niya sa kaniyang larangan at sa mga magagandang komentong
natatangap niya sa mga estranghero’t estudyante katulad na lamang ng mga
Haribon.

Pinatutunayan lamang ni Requitillo na ang pagiging malikhain at pagmamahal sa
napiling larangan, bagama’t mahirap at tiyak na malaking pagsubok, ay higit na
mas kasiya-siya at nagreresulta sa isang matamis na bunga.

Natatanging ngiti

Sa katunayan, kasalukuyang mayroong mahigit 23 libong followers ang facebook
page ng One Pics kung saan marami na ring mga paaralan at lugar ang mga naging
pangunahin nitong mga naging modelo at nakuhanan ng litrato. Maliban sa
Pamantasan, ilan pa sa mga paaralang napitikan na rin niya ay ang Domingo
Lacson National High School, at St. Benilde at maging ang mga lugar ng
Maynila, Bago City, at Bacolod.

Higit na namumukod-tangi para kay One Pics ang mga ngiti ng mga Haribon dahil
sa mainit nilang pagtanggap sa simpleng libangan lamang niya dati. Marami rin
kasi ‘di umano sa mga Haribon ang masayang pumapayag magpakuha ng litrato,
dahilan kaya’t naging mas madalas at maging paborito silang kuhanan ng mga
litrato. Isinasaalang-alang din ng nasabing litratista ang pagrespeto sa
karapatan ng mga nagiging bahagi ng kaniyang facebook page. Hinihingan ng
permiso ang mga Haribon patungkol sa social media posting ng kanilang litrato
at bukas din sa pagtatanggal ng larawan bilang pagrespeto ng kanilang
karapatan at pagkapribado.

Iisang layunin: ang magpasaya

Iisa lamang ang layunin ng One Pics, iyon na marahil ay ang magpasaya. Sa
kabila ng pagsubok sa loob ng Pamantasan, mapa-akademiko man o kaniya-kaniyang
problemang pinagdaraanan, iisa lang ang tinuturo ng karanasang ito–iyon ay sa
tuwing lalabas tayo ng ating paaralan, huwag nating kalimutang ngumiti kahit
saglit. Isang panibagong araw ang natapos at isang panibagong bukas na naman
ang magbibigay ng oportunidad upang magkaroon ng pag-asa.

“Sa mga Haribon, maraming salamat po sa pag-welcome at pagtanggap kay One pics
bilang isa sa mga maniniyot ninyo. Isa pong karangalan na maranasan ang
ganitong mga bagay. Salamat din sa pagpayag sa akin na gawin ang gusto kong
gawin. Hangga’t kaya po ni One Pics [na] maghandog ng serbisyo ay gagawin ko.
Asahan din po ninyo na I will be forever grateful dahil isa kayo sa unang
tumanggap sa akin dito sa Manila” saad ni One Pics.

Nang minsang nagtagpo ang pitik at ngiti bunga ng kaniyang pagmamahal sa
ginagawa, natutuhan din ng mga Haribon ang huminto’t huminga sa kabila ng mga
sari-sariling pagsubok. Piliin palagi natin na mahalin at maging masaya sa
larangang ating tatahakin. Sa mga litratong kuha niya na may magkakahalong
emosyon at may iba’t ibang k’wentong nakukubli, nariyan ang mga panibagong
ala-alang dadalhin ng mga Haribon.

Asahan din po ninyo na I will be forever grateful dahil isa kayo sa unang
tumanggap sa akin dito sa Manila” saad ni One Pics.

Nang minsang nagtagpo ang pitik at ngiti bunga ng kaniyang pagmamahal sa
ginagawa, natutuhan din ng mga Haribon ang huminto’t huminga sa kabila ng mga
sari-sariling pagsubok. Piliin palagi natin na mahalin at maging masaya sa
larangang ating tatahakin. Sa mga litratong kuha niya na may magkakahalong
emosyon at may iba’t ibang k’wentong nakukubli, nariyan ang mga panibagong
ala-alang dadalhin ng mga Haribon. Estranghero man ang karamihang paksa, hindi
naman iba ang sayang dulot nito sa bawat isa.

# Sa Likod ng Entablado ni Taylor Sheesh

Written by Jan Rennie Abat • Board by Angelle Valbuena | 2 August 23

Kaliwa't kanang palakpakan at pagsuporta ang sumasalubong kay Taylor Sheesh sa
tuwing siya ay sasabak na sa entablado para sa kaniyang Eras Tour. Bawat hataw
sa kanta ay sinasalubong ng hiyaw. Bawat tinig ng musika ay sinasabayan ng
madla. At sa pagtapos ng pagtatanghal ay oras na para bumalik sa mundo ni Mac
Coronel– ang tao sa likod ng paboritong Taylor Swift impersonator ng bansa.

Si Mac, 28, ay panganay sa tatlong magkakapatid ng kanilang pamilya sa
Antipolo. Nagtapos ng Computer Technology at ngayon ay isang call center agent
na sumasideline ng drag performances sa mga mall bilang Taylor Sheesh. Lingid
sa kaniyang kaalaman na ang pang araw-araw na pagtatanghal ay magviviral at
makikila mula sa iba't ibang bahagi ng daigdig.

****

**Kwentong Mac**

“Actually hindi pa ako nag-come out ever [sa family ko].”

Takot ang unang naramdaman ni Mac nang makita ng kaniyang bunsong kapatid ang
drag performance niya mula sa IG stories ng tanyag na photographer na si BJ
Pascual.

Bagamat nagagawang magsuot ng wig sa kanilang tahanan, walang pormal na usapan
patungkol sa kaniyang kasarian ang naganap kasama ang mga magulang niya.
“Hindi ako nag-o-open talaga. If they ask me about it, then go. Pero yung mga
kapatid ko, pinsan ko, accepted nila,” aniya.

Nag-umpisa naman ang paghanga ni Mac sa sikat na si Taylor Swift nang siya ay
15 pa lang, habang nakikinig ng kantang “Fifteen” na todo relate naman nang
panahong iyon buhat ng kaniyang highschool crush. Lalo lang lumaki ang
pagtingala niya sa mahusay na mang-aawit noong 2010 sa awiting “Speak Now."

**MAC-kulay na simula sa drag**

Nagsimula ang kaniyang makulay na kwentong drag noong 2017 matapos biglaang
sumali sa isang lip sync battle sa Nectar Nightclub’s Poison Wednesdays Drag
Cartel. Dala ng karisma at galing ni Mac ay nakuha niya ang tawa at suporta ng
madla at dineklarang kampeon ng kompetisyon.

Ang kaniyang unang pagwawagi ang naging daan upang maging regular artist sa
Nectar nang imbitahin na mag-audition. Sa kaniyang panibagong trabaho ay nabuo
ang mundo ni Taylor Sheesh.

Lalo lang lumaki ang
pagtingala niya sa mahusay na mang-aawit noong 2010 sa awiting “Speak Now."

**MAC-kulay na simula sa drag**

Nagsimula ang kaniyang makulay na kwentong drag noong 2017 matapos biglaang
sumali sa isang lip sync battle sa Nectar Nightclub’s Poison Wednesdays Drag
Cartel. Dala ng karisma at galing ni Mac ay nakuha niya ang tawa at suporta ng
madla at dineklarang kampeon ng kompetisyon.

Ang kaniyang unang pagwawagi ang naging daan upang maging regular artist sa
Nectar nang imbitahin na mag-audition. Sa kaniyang panibagong trabaho ay nabuo
ang mundo ni Taylor Sheesh.

Datapwat nahinto, muling bumalik ang buhay ni Mac sa drag matapos ang
pandemya– isang malaking comeback kung maituturing ang drag performances ni
Taylor Sheesh. Dumating ang buwan ng Mayo ngayong taon at naging abala si
Sheesh sa kaniyang Eras Tour na ginaganap sa mga mall. “Until now marami pa
ring nag-i-inquire. Padagdag nang padagdag,” sambit ni Mac sa isang interview
sa ABS-CBN news.

****

**ERAS TOUR: MAC-kasaysayang drag ni Taylor Sheesh**

“Yes, I did the Eras Tour. I performed for almost one hour and 24 mins. I’m
that Swiftie."

Iyan ang sabi ni Mac Coronel sa kaniyang Twitter matapos magviral muli ng
kaniyang matagumpay na Eras Tour sa TriNoma. Gayunpaman, maliban sa pagsisikap
na aralin ang performances ni Taylor Swift at pagbabayad ng gastusin sa
costumes ay maraming pang paghihirap ang kaniyang hinarap.

Hindi nakatakas mula sa pangungutya ng ibang tao si Mac nang siya ay magsuot
ng swimsuit costume at ipinost sa social media. Isa ito sa mga pinakamahirap
na pagsubok na kaniyang hinarap– tila winawasak ang tiwala sa sarili at
humahantong sa pag-atake ng anxiety.

Sa kabila ng paggapang ng maraming pagdududa ay hindi basta-basta magpapatalo
si Mac kapag kailangan nang tumapak sa entablado at humarap sa madla. Sulit
kung kaniyang itinuturing ang pagod sa pagbigay aliw buhat ng kalugod-lugod na
reaksyong kaniyang natatanaw at naririnig; ng pagkilala ng daigdig sa Filipino
Swifties at ang pag-asa na mapansin ng idolong si Taylor Swift.

“Pag hindi ako si Taylor, nagkakaroon ako ng inner saboteur sa life. Palaging
may self-doubt, unlike pag naka-drag ako, parang tumataas ang confidence level
ko. Lalo na pag maraming crowd, parang may ibang energy na sumasanib sa akin,”
aniya.

Si Taylor Sheesh ang nagbibigay saya at kumpiyansa sa sarili ni Mac. Ano man
ang daanang paghihirap at magkaiba man ang mundong hinaharap– sa likod ng
entablado ay ang mga pagsisikap ni Mac Coronel at sa pagtungtong nito ang
tagumpay ni Taylor Sheesh.

# Ang Pamantasan's Newly Appointed Key Editors

Caption by Stefanie Santilla | 30 June 23

THE NEXT KEY EDITORS | Last June 27, the Editorial Examination took place where eight examinees underwent a series of evaluations to determine the new Key Editors of Ang Pamantasan. 

Today, the publication presents you the newly appointed Key Editors for A.Y.
2023-2024: Alessandra Frianela for the position of Editor-in-Chief, Ken Joshua
De Paula for the position of Associate Editor, and Stefanie Ann Santilla for
the position of Managing Editor.

The results for the recently concluded EdEx were announced in the Oath Taking
and Turnover Ceremony held at the Justo Alberto Auditorium yesterday, June 30.

Together, they shall appoint members of the Editorial Board, the highest
governing body of the publication, and may create additional designations if
deemed necessary.
